questions.text:
A patient presented with multiple itchy lesions, as shown in the image below. KOH stain revealed the presence of predominant macroconidia and scanty microconidia. The hair shaft showed ectothrix, but the nails were spared. Which of the following is likely to be the cause of this condition?

KOH - Potassium hydroxide
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario with the involvement of the hair and skin but not the nails along with the microscopic examination findings point toward a diagnosis of Microsporum infection.

The given image shows annular lesions with central clearing, which is seen in dermatophytosis. Dermatophytes involve only the superficial cornified layer of skin, sparing the dermis. It should be differentiated from dermatomycosis which is the cutaneous involvement of systemic fungi.

Dermatophytes are of three types:

  • Trichophyton: Infection involves the skin, hair, and nails. The species include Trichophyton rubrum, Trichophyton mentagrophytes, Trichophyton tonsurans, Trichophyton schoenleinii, and Trichophyton violaceu. Microconidia > Macroconidia
  • Microsporum: Infection involves skin and hair. The species include Microsporum gypseum, Microsporum canis, and Microsporum nanum. Macroconidia> Microconidia.
  • Epidermophyton: Infection involves skin and nails. Only Macroconidia. Epidermophyton floccosum is the only species in this genus.

Clinical features of infection by Microsporum:

  • Skin lesions in the skin tend to be circular, dry, erythematous, scaly, and itchy.
  • Hair lesions include kerion, scarring, and alopecia.

Diagnosis is established by clinical features, use of Wood's lamp, and laboratory investigations such as microscopic examination and culture characteristics.

Microscopic examination of material teased out from the fungal colony (culture mount) or material taken on cellophane tape (cellophane tape mount) is observed for identification of the species. It is observed for the presence and type of hyphae and conidia. Conidia (asexual spores) are of two types: small unicellular microconidia and larger septate macroconidia.

Endothrix refers to dermatophyte infections of the hair that invade the hair shaft and internalize into the hair cell. As the name suggests, endothrix causes infection inside the hair shaft and ectothrix causes infection outside the shaft.

  • T. tonsurans, T. violaceum, T. schoenleinii, Trichophyton yaoundei, and Trichophyton soudanense cause endothrix type of tinea capitis.
    • Remember: TV is always kept inside the house (ENDO) — so T. tonsurans and T. violaceum cause endothrix.
  • Microsporum audouinii, M.canis, Microsporum equinum, and Microsporum ferrugineum cause ectothrix infection.

Sporothrix does not cause superficial mycoses.

Related Pearl: Wood's lamp examination

Wood's lamp examination is a diagnostic test wherein the skin or hair is examined under exposure to the black light emitted by the Wood lamp.

Blacklight is invisible to the naked eye because it is in the ultraviolet spectrum, with a wavelength just shorter than the color violet. The lamp glows violet in a dark environment because it also emits some light in the violet part of the electromagnetic spectrum.

A traditional Wood lamp is a low-output mercury arc covered by a Wood filter (barium silicate and 9% nickel oxide) and emits light at wavelength 320–450 nm (peak 365 nm).

questions.text: Falsely low values of BNP can be seen in which of the following?
questions.solution:
Falsely low values of BNP can be seen in obese patients.

It is also falsely low in:

  • Flash pulmonary edema
  • Heart failure due to- mitral regurgitation, mitral stenosis, constrictive pericarditis, restrictive cardiomyopathy

It falsely increases in:

  • Advanced age
  • Renal impairment
  • Female patients

questions.text: A 1.5 kg male baby was delivered following an emergency caesarean section at 30 weeks of gestation. His  SpO2 was 92% and he developed dyspnoea and cyanosis a few hours after birth and required CPAP immediately. His chest radiograph is shown below. A deficiency of which of the following in the lungs is the most likely cause for this condition?
questions.solution:
Respiratory distress syndrome/Hyaline membrane disease occurs primarily in premature infants (as the baby in this case) due to surfactant deficiency in the alveoli. It is primarily caused by a deficiency of lung surfactant Dipalmitoylphosphatidylcholine (DPPC) or (dipalmitoyl lecithin) which is a Phospholipid.

Neonatal respiratory distress occurs due to insufficient surfactant. It presents as breathlessness with air bronchograms or bilateral ground-glass opacity on X-Ray. Cesarean delivery is a risk factor for neonatal respiratory distress. Antenatal corticosteroids are given to increase the production of surfactant and prevent neonatal respiratory distress.

The chest x-ray findings in respiratory distress syndrome (RDS) are:

  • Fine reticulogranular pattern
  • Air bronchogram
  • Bilateral diffuse ground-glass opacities
  • White-out lung (severe disease)

Dipalmitoyl lecithin is a major component of lung surfactant which comprises mainly of phospholipids. In DPPC, positions 1 & 2 on the glycerol are occupied by palmitate. 

The most important components are

  • Phospholipid - dipalmitoylphosphatidylcholine (DPPC) also known as Dipalmitoyl Lecithin. Lecithin is the most abundant lipid in surfactant.
  • Phosphatidylglycerol- minor component
  • Surfactant apoproteins
  • Calcium ions.
  • 4 unique apoproteins of surfactant: surfactant protein (SP)-A, SP-B, SP-C, and SP-D.

Phospholipid consists of Diglyceride + phosphate + choline or ethanolamine. A phospholipid is any lipid consisting of a diglyceride combined with a phosphate group and a simple organic molecule such as choline or ethanolamine, such as lecithin or cephalin.

Surfactant is secreted by the type 2 pneumocytes in the alveoli. It reduces surface tension at the air-liquid interface of the alveolus.

Clinical correlate :

  • Respiratory distress syndrome (RDS) in preterm neonates is due to insufficient surfactant production.
  • Lung maturity of the fetus can be assessed by determining the ratio of lecithin to sphingomyelin (L:S ratio) in the amniotic fluid. A ratio of >2 indicates maturity.
  • Shake test/Bubble test/Clement test: Formation of stable foam in the presence of surfactant.
  • Phosphatidylglycerol levels in Amniotic fluid.

Phosphatidylethanolamine, also called cephalin, is found in the cell membranes of nervous tissue, particularly in the brain.

Diphosphatidyl glycerol, also called cardiolipin, is found in the inner membrane of mitochondria and plays a key role in apoptosis.

Phosphatidylinositol present in the cell membrane acts as precursors of hormone secondary messengers and platelet-activating factor.

Compound lipids are subclassified based on extra groups as:

  1. Phospholipids (containing phosphoric acid) - Ex: plasmalogens, dipalmitoyl lecithin, cardiolipin, sphingomyelin etc
  2. Non-phosphorylated lipids - Ex: cerebrosides, globosides, gangliosides, sulpholipids etc

Note:

-Autosomal dominant familial interstitial lung disease has absent surfactant protein SP-C.

-Pulmonary alveolar proteinosis - Autoantibody against GM-CSF which is involved in clearance of surfactant.

questions.text: You arrive as part of the disaster response medical team to an area struck by a massive earthquake. During triaging of casualties from a building collapse, a patient has been tagged with the colour code as shown below. You will prioritize this patient for treatment as ______.
questions.solution:
This patient is classified under red code, according to triage color-coding. In triage, red signifies high priority who are in need of immediate resuscitation or surgery in the next 6 hours or transfer.

Triage consists of rapidly classifying the injured on the basis of the severity of their injuries and the likelihood of their survival with prompt medical intervention.

Triage is the only approach that can provide maximum benefit to the greatest number of injured in a major disaster situation.

Note:

  • Reverse triage is a situation where the less injured are treated earlier than the ones that are injured more.
  • This is used in wars and military settings where soldiers may need to return to the field of battle soon after treatment.
  • It is also done when there is scarcity of medical resources after a disaster.

Related Pearl: Triage Colour Coding

 Triage system consists of four colour codes:

May survive if timely medical intervention can be given
  • Tension pneumothorax
  • Airway obstruction
  • Hemothorax
  • Cardiac tamponade
  • Acute circulatory arrest
  • Major intra-abdominal bleed etc.
Yellow (Medium priority)

Possible resuscitation or surgery in the next 24 hours.

Likely to survive if prompt treatment is given.
  • Compound fractures
  • Degloving injuries
  • Pelvic fracture
  • Spinal injuries
  • Moderate head injury
Green (Low priority)

Ambulatory patients or minor illnesses.

Likely to survive if treatment is slightly delayed.
  • Simple fractures
  • Minor lacerations etc.
Black (Least priority)

Dead or moribund patients.
  • Severe brain injury
  • Major damage / disruption to chest wall and abdominal structures

questions.text: As part of your research project, you are conducting a study to assess the utility of a new Bariatric surgical procedure in helping morbidly obese people lose weight. For this, you compare the pre-operative weight of the patient with their respective postoperative weight 6 months after undergoing the said procedure. Assuming that the procedure was successfully carried out in all of the study subjects, and that nobody is lost to follow-up, which of the following is the most appropriate test you would like to use for testing the statistical significance in this scenario?
questions.solution:
Since the results of weight-reduction surgery are checked on the same individuals, before and after the surgery, therefore the test used is paired t-test.

Paired t-test.

  • paired test is mainly used in comparison of a before and after scenario 
  • Also known as correlated t test, dependent samples t test.
  • It is mainly used on dependent samples For example, the cholesterol level of a person before and after using a specific drug.
  • It can also be used when you put the same condition under test using different items or things. For example, same crash safety tests for different cars.

Related Pearl: Tests of Significance

How to choose which test to use?

  • See the variable. Are the variables quantitative or qualitative?
    • If the variables are qualitative (nominal), then Chi square test is used.
    • If the variables are quantitative, then see whether 2 groups or more than 2 groups .
      • If 2 groups are being tested, then T tests are used. In that, if the same group is tested before and after, paired T test is used. Otherwise, unpaired T test is used.
      • If more than 2 groups are being tested, then use ANOVA.

1. T Tests

  • Unpaired t tests
    • Also known as the student’s t test, independent t test, two-samples t test.
    • It's the most commonly used t test and it tests the difference between two groups (the means of 2 groups) independent of each other and indicates how significant the differences are.
  • Paired t tests
    • "Pairs before marriage are not the same after!"
    • So remember the paired test is mainly used in the comparison of a before and after scenario 
    • Also known as correlated t test, dependent samples t test.
    • It is mainly used on dependent samples. For example, the cholesterol level of a person before and after using a specific drug.
    • It can also be used when you put the same condition under test using different items or things. For example, same crash safety tests for different cars.
  • T scores 
    • The t score is referred to as the ratio of the difference between two groups and the difference within the groups.
    • The smaller the t score, the more similarity there is between two groups and vice versa.

 

2. Analysis of Variance (ANOVA)

  • The analysis of variance test (ANOVA) is used to test the difference between two or usually more than two groups (means) and here the inferences are made by analyzing the variances.

 

3. Chi-Square Test

  • The Chi-Square test (χ2) is a non-parametric(non-numeric) test and it is used to test hypotheses in relation to nominal scale data or categorical data.
  • It is a test of proportions and associations.
  • A Chi-square distribution is usually positively skewed but it approaches a normal distribution as its degrees of freedom increases.
  • If the frequency of any of the cells of the categorical table is <5, then Fisher’s exact test is used.

questions.text: A biochemist is studying the effect of RNA interference in gene expression. He is neutralizing targeted mRNAs using microRNAs (miRNA). In the RNA induced silencing complex (RISC) complex, these miRNAs can modulate mRNA function by all these mechanisms except _____

choices.text: Inhibition of translation by targeting the 5′-methyl cap-binding translation factor
Trimming small double-stranded RNAs into molecules that can block translation

questions.solution:
DICER trims small double-stranded RNA and generates short, double-stranded (ds) miRNA molecules that can block translation. In the RISC complex, miRNAs can modulate mRNA function by any of the three mechanisms:

  • Promoting mRNA degradation directly
  • Stimulating CCR4/NOT complex-mediated poly(A) tail degradation
  • Inhibition of translation by targeting the 5′-methyl cap-binding translation factor.

Micro-RNA (miRNA) is an endogenous non-coding RNA. The primary function of miRNA is to modulate the translation of target mRNAs into their corresponding proteins. After the target RNA is transcribed from its gene (post-transcriptional), the miRNA may either induce mRNA cleavage or repress its translation. This is referred to as gene silencing.

RNA interference(RNAi) is a biological process in which miRNA/siRNA molecules inhibit gene expression by neutralizing targeted mRNAs.The microRNA (miRNA) belongs to a group of non-coding genes. The miRNA genes are transcribed but not translated into proteins. They play a role in the regulation of the expression of the target gene by post-transcriptional silencing.

Mechanism:

  • The miRNA gene present in the nucleus is transcribed to primary miRNA, which is further converted to pre-miRNA by an enzyme DROSHA intranuclearly and exported to the cytoplasm by an export protein.
  • The pre-miRNA undergoes trimming, by an enzyme called DICER, into mature single-stranded miRNA.
  • The mature miRNA is associated with a multiprotein aggregate called RNA-induced silencing complex (RISC).
  • The target mRNAs contain seed sequences in their 3′ untranslated region (UTR) that determines the specificity of miRNA binding and gene silencing.

Depending on the base pairing between the miRNA strand and its target mRNA, the RISC causes gene silencing either by mRNA cleavage or by repressing its translation.

siRNA is similar in function to miRNA and is used in RNA interference.

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman with a history of pleomorphic adenoma in the left parotid gland comes to the clinic for follow-up three weeks after a parotidectomy. She complains of flushing, sweating, and burning sensation on the left side of her face every time she sits down to have a meal. The area is also pruritic. The postganglionic parasympathetic nerve fibres of which of the following nerves is the likely culprit for this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
The symptom complex in this patient, coupled with a history of recent parotid surgery, is indicative of Frey's syndrome in which the Auriculotemporal nerve marked as "D" is involved.

Frey’s syndrome/Gustatory sweating (auriculotemporal syndrome)

  • Commonly develops after parotid surgery or other trauma that results in the opening of the parotid capsule.
  • It results from damage to the autonomic innervation of the salivary gland. There is a regeneration of the parasympathetic nerve fibres that stimulate the sweat glands of the overlying skin in response to salivary stimulation or mastication. 
  • It is thought to reflect abnormal innervation of sweat glands on the face by regrowing parasympathetic secretomotor axons that would previously have innervated the parotid gland
  • Clinical features:
    • Sweating, warmth, and erythema over the region of surgical excision of the parotid gland. This is due to the autonomic stimulation of salivation by the smell/taste of food.
  • Diagnosis:
    • The starch iodine will aid in diagnosis. The affected area painted with iodine will turn blue on exposure to sweat.
  • Management:
    • Prevention: Sternomastoid muscle flap, temporalis fascial flap, and insertion of an artificial membrane between the skin and the parotid bed will minimise the inappropriate regeneration of the autonomic nerve fibres. 
  • Treatment:
      • Antiperspirants with aluminium chloride
      • Subcutaneous infiltration of purified botulinum toxin into the affected area
    • Denervation by a tympanic neurectomy or auriculotemporal nerve avulsion has been advocated but is often not curative

questions.text: If a drug follows first-order kinetics, how much drug will remain at the end of 6 hours when a patient is given 300 mg drug of which 120 mg is excreted in 90 min?
questions.solution:
The amount of drug remaining in the body after 6 hours following an initial administration of 300mg of the drug is 38mg.

In first-order kinetics, a constant fraction of the drug is excreted in a given time. 

120 mg of 300 mg is excreted in 90 minutes ---> 120/300 = 0.40 is eliminated 

After 90 minutes; 300 mg-120 mg = 180 mg remains 

The next 90 minutes (after 180 minutes) = 180 * 0.4 = 72 mg is eliminated and 180-72 = 108 mg remains 

The next 90 minutes (after 270 minutes) = 108 * 0.4 = 43.2 mg is eliminated and 108-43.2 = 64.8 remains 

The next 90 minutes (after 360 minutes) = 64.8 * 0.4 = 25.92 mg is eliminated and 64.80-25.92 = 38.88 mg remains after 6 hours. 

A simpler way to calculate 

  • 2/5 fraction is excreted in 90 minutes → 3/5 remains after 90 minutes.
  • 6 hours (360 min) is 4 times of 90 minutes.
  • So 300 * (3/5)(3/5)(3/5)(3/5) = 38.88 mg remains after 360 minutes 

Related Pearl: Zero order vs First order kinetics of drugs

Zero order

First order

Constant amount of drug is eliminated per unit time

 Constant fraction of drug is eliminated per unit time

Rate of elimination is independent of plasma concentration

 Rate of elimination is proportional to the plasma concentration

Clearance is more at low concentration and less at high concentration

 Clearance remains constant 

Half-life is less at low concentration and more at high concentration

 Half-life remains constant

Very few drugs follow zero-order kinetics, e.g.(WATT Power)

  • Warfarin
  • Alcohol, Aspirin
  • Tolbutamide
  • Theophylline 
  • Phenytoin

 

 Most of the drugs follow first order kinetics

questions.text:
A 4-year-old girl is brought to the pediatrician for evaluation. The mother remarks that her daughter appears yellow and that she has been scratching her arms and legs profusely. On examination, the child appears jaundiced. She has deep-set eyes, triangular facies, and a broad nasal bridge. On auscultation, there is a fixed splitting of the second heart sound. The girl's height is less than the 3rd percentile for age. Laboratory findings are as below.
Liver Function Test Values
Bilirubin (mg/dL) 7
Aspartate aminotransferase (U/L) 75
Alanine aminotransferase (U/L) 90
Alkaline phosphatase (U/L) 250
Gamma-glutamyl transpeptidase (U/L) 160
Albumin (mg/dL) 3
Prothrombin time (s) 11

 

A provisional diagnosis of Alagille syndrome is made. Which of the following would help confirm it?

choices.text: Paucity of interlobular bile ducts in liver biopsy
Demonstrating collagen abnormality by gene sequencing
Presence of butterfly vertebrae confirmed by an X Ray

questions.solution:
The clinical vignette describes a patient with Alagille syndrome. The laboratory findings indicate cholestasis. The associated finding in this patient would help confirm the diagnosis is a paucity of interlobular bile ducts in the liver biopsy.

Alagille syndrome

  • Autosomal dominant disorder with mutations in the JAG1 gene in 90% of the patients and the NOTCH2 gene in the remainder of the patients
  • The abnormality of this syndrome is arterio-hepatic dysplasia, it is the most common syndrome with intrahepatic bile duct paucity
  • Clinical manifestations
    • Short stature
    • Failure to thrive
    • Hepatic: Chronic cholestasis, jaundice, cirrhosis, pruritus, and xanthomas
    • Cardiac: Peripheral pulmonic stenosis, tetralogy of Fallot, ductus arteriosus, septal defects, coarctation of the aorta
    • Butterfly vertebrae (Though it is an associated feature, it will not help confirm the diagnosis as it can be seen in other conditions also)
    • Eye: Posterior embryotoxon
    • Facies: Dysmorphic facies with a broad nasal bridge, triangular face, and deep-set eyes
    • Renal: Renal dysplasia, glomerular mesangiolipidosis or renal tubular acidosis

Diagnosis:

  • Cholestasis on liver function tests with conjugated bilirubinemia, elevated serum aminotransferase, gamma-glutamyl transpeptidase
  • Reduced number of interlobular bile ducts on liver biopsy
  • Genetic testing for JAG1 or NOTCH2 mutations

Treatment

  • Ursodeoxycholic acid or bile acid sequestrants for pruritis
  • Conservative management for malnutrition
  • Transplantation for patients with severely compromised hepatic function

questions.text: A 35-year-old female patient who underwent radiotherapy for Hodgkin's lymphoma 5 years ago presents with a slow-growing thyroid swelling for 6 months. Physical examination reveals 2 by 2cm swelling over the thyroid gland. Laboratory investigations show a normal TSH, T3, and T4. Which of the following is false regarding the underlying disease?

choices.text: The most common type of  thyroid tumor

questions.solution:
This patient with thyroid swelling, who was treated for Hodgkin’s lymphoma by radiotherapy, is likely to have papillary thyroid cancer. Papillary thyroid cancer spreads through the lymphatic system.

Radiation is the established risk factor for the development of differentiated thyroid carcinoma (papillary and follicular). This association is stronger for papillary than for follicular carcinomas.

Papillary thyroid carcinomas are the most common forms of thyroid carcinoma and present in younger individuals. They commonly spread by the lymphatic system but have an excellent 10-year survival rate of 95%.

The risk of developing papillary thyroid cancer is high among individuals who:

  • Received external irradiation to the thyroid as children (< 5 years of age)
  • Received radiation for soft tissue malignancies, such as Hodgkin’s lymphoma
  • Have a history of acute environmental exposure
  • Familial syndromes (Cowden syndrome, Werner syndrome, Carney syndrome, etc)

Clinical features -

  • thyroid swelling
  • lateral aberrant thyroid -cervical node invasion my metastasis)
  • dysphagia
  • horseness

Diagnosis -

  • Thyroid function studies
  • Thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) suppression test
  • Thyroid ultrasound
  • Fine-needle aspiration biopsy (FNAB)(to confirm the diagnosis)

Histopathology -

  • Complex, branching, randomly oriented papillae with fibrovascular cores associated with follicles.
  • Usually dense fibrosis.
  • Papillae lined by cuboidal cells.
  • Nuclei are overlapping with finely dispersed optically clear chromatin (also called ground-glass), which gives a clear or empty appearance, therefore, the name is ground glass or Orphan Annie eye nuclei.
  • Macronucleoli, eosinophilic intranuclear inclusions (represent cytoplasmic invaginations) and nuclear longitudinal grooves (represent folding of the redundant nuclear membrane, but nonspecific).
  • Stromal elastosis - often lymphatic invasion.
  • Psammoma bodies.

Staging - 

  • AGES scoring system- Age, histologic Grade, Extrathyroidal invasion, and metastases and tumor Size. Predict the risk of dying from papillary cancer.
  • MACIS scale - Postoperative modification of the AGES scale. Includes Metastases, Age at presentation (<40 or >40 years old), Completeness of original surgical resection, extrathyroidal Invasion, and Size of original lesion
  • AMES system - classifies differentiated thyroid tumors. Includes Age (men <40 years old, women <50 years old), Metastases, Extrathyroidal spread, and Size of tumors (< or >5 cm). 

 

The image below shows papillary thyroid carcinoma with characteristic orphan Annie eye nuclei:

 

The image below shows psammoma bodies in papillary thyroid cancer.

Related Pearl: Papillary thyroid carcinoma

Papillary carcinoma is the most common thyroid carcinoma. It is most common in iodine sufficient areas, children and in those exposed to ionizing radiation. 

The mean age of presentation is 3rd-4th decade and is more common in women than men (2:1). Dysphagia, dysphonia and dyspnea are associated with local invasion.

It usually presents as a cold nodule on the scan. Histological findings include:

  • Branching papillae 
  • Follicles with the fibrovascular stalk
  • Psammoma bodies
  • Nuclear changes- 
    • Optically clear - Ground glass or Orphan Annie eye nuclei
    • Pseudo-inclusions
    • Nuclear grooves.

Lymph node metastasis is common. Lateral aberrant thyroid denotes a cervical lymph node invaded by papillary carcinoma. The most common sites of metastasis : lung > liver > bone > brain.

It has an excellent prognosis, with a 10-year survival rate in excess of 95%.

questions.text: A primigravida at 39 weeks of gestation presents with watery discharge per vagina and regular contractions. Physical examination reveals an adequately dilated and effaced cervix with rupture of membranes. Presentation is vertex, but labor stops progressing after the head has appeared in the vulva.  Which of the following maneuvers can be used to assist in the delivery of the head?
questions.solution:
Ritgen maneuver can be used to assist with the delivery of the head in normal labor.

When the head distends the vulva and perineum enough to open the vaginal introitus to a diameter of >5 cm, a gloved hand may be used for supporting the perineum in order to avoid expulsive delivery and to avoid perineal lacerations.

If the expulsive efforts are inadequate, the Ritgen maneuver is employed for assisted delivery of the head. This is accomplished by pushing the chin upward with the fingers of the right hand (positioned over the anococcygeal region), while the left hand exerts pressure on the occiput. Hence, the head is delivered by extension. 

The image below demonstrates the Ritgen maneuver:

 

Other options-

Option (A): Pinard maneuver is used for the delivery of extended legs in case of frank breech delivery.

Frank breech delivery (Pinard’s maneuver)—is done by intrauterine manipulation to convert a frank breech to a footing breech. Pinard maneuver is usually performed when the membranes have ruptured recently.

Technique:

  • The middle and index fingers are carried up to the popliteal fossa.
  • Then press and abduct the popliteal fossa so as to flex the fetal leg
  • Catch hold of the ankle
  • Pull down along with abduction and breech extraction is accomplished.

 

Option (B): Lovset maneuver used for the delivery of extended arms in case of a breech presentation.

Technique:

  • Hold the sacrum with the thumb and the hips and pelvis with other fingers.
  • Turn infant 90 degrees to bring shoulder under pubic symphysis and deliver the anterior shoulder.
  • Then counter-rotate 180 degrees to engage and deliver the posterior shoulder.

This technique is demonstrated in the images below-

 

Option (C): Modified Prague’s maneuver(shown below) is used in breech presentations to deliver the aftercoming head when the back of the fetus fails to rotate to the symphysis.

Technique:

  • Grasp the shoulders of the baby from below with two fingers of one hand.
  • Draw the feet up and over the maternal abdomen with the other hand.

Related Pearl: Maneuvers for breech delivery

Pinard’s manoeuvre 

It is used for the delivery of extended legs in case of breech delivery.

Technique:

  • Flex and abduct the popliteal fossa
  • Catch hold of the ankle
  • Pull down along with abduction

 

Lovset’s manoeuvre

It is used for the delivery of extended arms in case of a breech presentation.

Technique:

  • Hold the sacrum with the thumb, and the hips and pelvis with other fingers.
  • Turn the infant 90 degrees to bring the shoulder under pubic symphysis and deliver the anterior shoulder.
  • Then counter-rotate 180 degrees to engage and deliver the posterior shoulder. 

 

Modified Prague’s manoeuvre

It is used in breech presentations to deliver the aftercoming head when the back of the fetus fails to rotate to the symphysis.

Technique:

  • Grasp the shoulders of the baby from below with two fingers of one hand.
  • Draw the feet up and over the maternal abdomen with the other hand.

 

Burns-Marshall method

It is used for delivery of aftercoming head in case of breech presentation.

Technique:

  • Allow the baby to hang by its own weight.
  • When the nape of the neck is visible under the pubic arch, grasp the baby by the ankles with a finger in between the two.
  • Swing the baby in an arc in an upward and forward direction.

 

Mauriceau-Smellie-Veit technique

It is another method that can be used in the delivery of aftercoming head in case of breech presentation. It is also called malar flexion and shoulder traction.

Technique:

  • Place the baby on the supinated left arm with limbs hanging on either side.
  • Place the index and middle fingers of the left hand on either side over the malar bones.
  • Place the ring and the little finger of the pronated right hand on the child’s right shoulder, index finger on the left shoulder and middle finger over the suboccipital region.
  • Traction is given in the downward and backward direction till the nape of the neck is visible.
  • Thereafter, the baby is carried in an upward and forward direction towards the mother’s abdomen.

 

Mnemonic:

  • Extend the arm to express Love(Lovset's)
  • Put the fingers in popliteal fossa for Pinard's(P for P)

questions.text: A 23-year-old football player is brought unresponsive to the emergency room, following trauma to the head. His teammates recall that he was alert and responsive for a brief period in the locker room before he became unconscious. Physical examination now shows a GCS of 6 with anisocoria. Pulse rate is 53 beats/minute, blood pressure is 170/100 mmHg, and respiratory rate is 10 breaths/minute. Head CT images are shown below. What is the definitive management for his condition?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario along with the image showing lens-shaped hemorrhage is consistent with acute epidural hematoma. Craniotomy with emergency evacuation of the hematoma is the definitive management of this condition.

Extradural hematoma (EDH) is also known as an epidural hematoma. It is a collection of blood between the outer layer of the dura and the inner surface of the skull, which is called the periosteal layer. The bleeding is most commonly due to torn middle meningeal artery.

EDH is commonly associated with a history of trauma and associated skull fracture. It is associated with an underlying fracture of the squamous part of the temporal bone.

Epidural hematoma may present with a transient loss of consciousness immediately after the trauma, followed by a lucid interval, where consciousness is recovered. The neurological status of the patient subsequently worsens due to continued bleeding from the site, as seen in this patient. This can cause a mass effect, with herniation.

EDH is diagnosed with CT and MRI. CT image shows the typical bi-convex hyperdense lesion that does not cross the cranial sutures but can cross venous sinuses.

The definitive management for any patient with GCS <9 and pupillary abnormalities such as anisocoria is craniotomy, with emergency evacuation of the hematoma. Surgery is also recommended for patients with worsening neurological status and hematoma volume of >30 mL, regardless of neurological status.

The image given below shows a CT scan depicting EDH. Note the biconvex or lens-shaped hematoma.

Other options:

Option A: Hyperventilation lowers the pCO2 and lowers the intracranial pressure (ICP) because of vasoconstriction. But this may also worsen the perfusion in the brain and must be done with caution.

Option B: Intravenous mannitol may be used to lower ICP, but it is not a definitive management option in this patient in a coma.

Option D: Intravenous fluids are not indicated in this condition. It may be used as an adjunct in therapy.

Related Pearl: Types of Intracranial Hemorrhage

1. Extradural hemorrhage/epidural hematoma (EDH)

  • Source: Arterial - middle meningeal artery (m/c)
  • Cause: Trauma - fracture of the squamous part of the temporal bone
  • Lens or lentiform shaped opacity
  • Presence of a characteristic lucid interval
  • Treatment: Surgical evacuation of large/rapidly evolving EDH

 

2. Acute subdural hemorrhage (SDH)

  • Source: Venous - bridging veins
  • Cause: Trauma
  • Common in old age, alcoholics, patients on anticoagulants, shaken baby syndrome (a form of child abuse seen in infants and toddlers)
  • Clinical features: Acute SDH may be associated with a lucid interval; chronic SDH is associated with drowsiness, headache
  • CT findings: Crescent opacity
  • Treatment: May resolve spontaneously or require surgical drainage

 

3. Acute on chronic SDH

  • Source: Venous - bridging veins
  • Cause: Usually, trivial trauma in old age or patients on anticoagulants
  • Crescent clots
  • Presence of a history of headache, confusion, and being prone to falls

 

4. Subarachnoid hemorrhage

  • Source: Arterial
  • Causes: Trauma (most common), berry aneurysm (2nd most common)
  • M/c sites: Terminal ICA, MCA bifurcation, top of basilar artery
  • Clinical features: Characteristic thunderclap headache
  • CSF: Xanthochromia
  • Hyperdensity in the subarachnoid space
  • Treatment:  Triple H therapy (hypertension, hypervolemia, and hemodilution) to prevent vasospasm, Clipping/coiling of berry aneurysm

 

5. Intra-parenchymal hemorrhage

  • Most common type of intracranial hemorrhage
  • Cause: Hypertension (most common cause)
  • Hyperdensity within the brain parenchyma
  • Site: Putamen of the basal ganglia (most common)
  • Treatment: Correction of any identified coagulopathy by infusing prothrombin complex concentrates, FFP, or fresh platelets as required; surgical evacuation for cerebellar hematoma >3 cm in size

  • GCS, in particular, the motor score, is the best predictor of neurological outcome.
  • If an area cannot be assessed, no numerical score is given for that region, and it is considered “non-testable." (NT)
  • In case of endotracheal intubation or tracheostomy, the verbal component of the score is denoted as NT.

  • Half-hourly for 2 hours,
  • Then 1-hourly for 4 hours,
  • 2-hourly thereafter.

Should the patient with GCS equal to 15 deteriorate at any time after the initial 2-hour period, observations should revert to half-hourly and follow the original frequency schedule.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man presents with shortness of breath. He has a history of heart failure treated with furosemide. he has been non-compliant with his medications since the past week as he could not afford it. Vital signs show a BP of 160/95 mm of Hg, PR - 100bpm, and tachypnea. Physical examination shows jugular venous distention, diffuse crackles, and an S3. He is noted to have the breathing pattern seen in the image below. Which among the following options may also have a similar breathing pattern?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette describes a case of acute decompensated heart failure. The pattern of breathing seen in the image is Cheyne–Stokes breathing. It is also seen during uremia.

In this case, the person breathes deeply for a short interval and then breathes slightly or not at all for an additional interval. Every minute this pattern repeats itself. Relative hyperventilation is present in such individuals due to increased sensitivity to CO2 and thus lowering the arterial Pco2. Following this there is apnoea and the arterial Pco2 rises again to normal. The respiratory mechanisms again over-responds to CO2. This causes breathing to stop, and then the cycle repeats itself.

It is the most common type of periodic breathing seen most commonly in patients with heart failure and uremia, also seen in patients with brain disease and during sleep in normal individuals.

Other options:

 

Note:
  • Uremia can be associated with both Cheyne stoke breathing and Kussmaul's Breathing
  • Damage to the pons due to stroke, trauma, or uncal herniation is typically associated with Biot's Breathing, also known as ataxic breathing. It is characterized by regular deep respirations interspersed with periods of apnea.

questions.text: A 63-year-old female patient is brought to the emergency room with sudden onset dizziness. She was working in the kitchen when she suddenly felt the room spinning and had to sit down. She also complains of nausea and blurred vision. On examination, the pulse is 100/min, blood pressure is 170/ 110 mm Hg. Nystagmus is present. Sensory examination show loss of pain and temperature sensations on the right side of the face, diminished gag reflex, and taste sensation on the right. She has dysarthric speech and aspirates a sip of water that she drinks. Which of the following arteries are likely to be involved in this patient?
questions.solution:
Thrombosis of the vertebral artery (marked as B) is most commonly implicated in Wallenberg syndrome.

Wallenberg syndrome, also called lateral medullary syndrome, is due to occlusion of the ipsilateral vertebral artery (V4 segment) in most cases. In the remainder, posterior inferior cerebellar artery occlusion is responsible.

Wallenberg/Lateral Medullary Syndrome:

  • Descending tract and nucleus of cranial nerve V: Ipsilateral impaired sensation over half of the face
  • IX and X cranial nerves: Ipsilateral paralysis of palate, vocal cord, diminished gag reflex
  • Nucleus of Tractus solitarius: Ipsilateral loss of taste
  • Vestibular nucleus: Nystagmus, diplopia, vertigo, nausea
  • Spinocerebellar tract: Ipsilateral ataxia
  • Descending sympathetic tract: Ipsilateral Horner’s syndrome
  • Lateral spinothalamic tract: Contralateral impaired pain and thermal sensation over half of body

 

"A" is the middle cerebral artery

"C" is the anterior cerebral artery

"D" is the basilar artery

questions.text: A 4-day-old neonate is being evaluated in the nursery for a bluish discoloration of the skin. This child was born to a mother who is 41 years old and has a long-standing history of diabetes mellitus. On examination, the child is cyanotic at rest and there is no change with crying or feeding. Cyanosis does not improve with supplemental oxygen. Pulse rate is 120/min and respiratory rate is 70/min. There is a pansystolic murmur heard at the lower left sternal border on auscultation. Chest X-ray findings are significant for an egg-on-side appearance, as shown in the image below. What is the next step in management for this patient?

choices.text: PGE2 infusion to keep the ductus arteriosus open
PGE1 infusion to keep the VSD open
PGE2 infusion to keep the VSD open
PGE1 infusion to keep the ductus arteriousus open

questions.solution:
The classic "Egg on side appearance " appearance on this chest X-ray image is seen in the transposition of great arteries (TGA). Prostaglandin E1 is administered for initial stabilization.

TGA is characterized by the aorta arising from the right ventricle and pulmonary artery from the left ventricle. Since systemic and pulmonary circulations are separate, survival depends on the mixing of oxygenated pulmonary blood and deoxygenated systemic blood which can occur:

  • At atrial level: Through atrial septal defect (ASD)
  • At ventricle level: Through ventricular septal defect (VSD)
  • At great vessel level: Through patent ductus arteriosus

Clinical features:

  • Most infants present with cyanosis that is not affected by exertion or supplemental oxygen
  • Tachypnea with a respiratory rate > 60 breaths/min
  • Murmurs depending on the presence of a VSD or a left-ventricular outflow tract obstruction
  • Some patients with coarctation of the aorta may have diminished pulses in the lower extremities

Imaging:

  • ECG may demonstrate right axis deviation
  • Chest X-ray image shows cardiomegaly, a narrow superior mediastinum (the classic “egg on a string heart”), and normal to increased pulmonary blood flow. The narrow pedicle of the heart is because of the malposition of the great vessels
  • Echocardiography with Doppler will show a great artery branching into the left and right pulmonary arteries arising from the posterior left ventricle. The aorta arises anteriorly from the right ventricle

Treatment:

Here, prostaglandin E1 administration and septostomy help initial stabilization by creating a communication between the right and left atria, thereby facilitating the mixing of systemic and pulmonary circulation

Congenital heart disease and time of presentation of cyanosis:

  • At birth - TGA, Tricuspid atresia, pulmonary atresia, truncus arteriosus, Obstructed TAPVR 

 

Related Pearl: Radiological findings in some congenital heart defects

Boot shaped heart - Tetralogy of Fallot (TOF)

 

Egg on string appearance - Transposition of Great Arteries (TGA)

 

Snowman's heart appearance or figure of 8 appearance - Supracardiac TAPVC

 

Box Shaped Heart - Ebstein's Anomaly

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman is complaining of a nagging headache after undergoing a Caesarian section under spinal anesthesia. The headache is occipital in nature, worsens on standing, and is relieved by lying flat. What is the definitive management in this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario points to the diagnosis of post-dural puncture headache (PDPH). The definitive treatment for post-dural puncture headache is an epidural blood patch. 

PDPH can occur after spinal or epidural anesthesia due to loss of CSF through the dura which causes traction on the pain-sensitive intracranial structures. It may also occur due to compensatory, painful intracranial vasodilation to offset the reduction in intracranial pressure. The headache is typically frontal or occipital in distribution and is associated with nausea, neck stiffness, and lower back pain. Most of the headaches resolve spontaneously within 7 days. 

An epidural blood patch is the definitive management. It is ideally performed 24 hours after dural puncture and the development of classic symptoms. 15-20 mL of autologous blood is injected into the epidural space at the same or one interspace below the level of the dural puncture. It acts by stopping the CSF leak by either mass effect or coagulation. Most patients will respond to a single blood patch, and 90% of initial nonresponders will obtain relief from a second injection (1 to 2 days after the first). A prophylactic epidural patch is not recommended.

Related Pearl: PDPH- Post-Dural Puncture Headache

  • May follow lumbar puncture, spinal anesthesia, wet epidural tap (in which epidural needle pierced dura).
  • Onset 12-72hrs and last for 1-2 weeks.
  • Aggravated by sitting and relieved by lying down.
  • Incidence increases with the larger needle, cutting point (in comparison to pencil point) needle, young age, females, pregnancy.
  • Prevention by thinner needle

Management:

  • Supine position
  • IV fluids
  • Caffeine and analgesia
  • Epidural blood patch

Related Pearl: Factors That Can Increase the Incidence of Headache After Spinal Puncture

  • Age: Younger, more frequent
  • Sex: Females > males
  • Needle size: Larger > smaller
  • Needle bevel: Less when the needle bevel is placed in the long axis of the neuraxis Orienting a needle bevel parallel with the axis of the spine, such that the longitudinal fibers of the dura would more likely be separated than cut, results in a lower incidence of postspinal puncture headache
  • Pregnancy: More when pregnant
  • Dural punctures: More with multiple punctures

Factors That Do Not Increase the Incidence of Headache After Spinal Puncture

  • Insertion and use of catheters for continuous spinal anesthesia
  • Timing of ambulation

questions.text: A patient presents with fever,  vomiting, and watery diarrhea. He gives a history of having consumed shellfish and raw seafood a day before, at a party. The causative agent showed hemolysis on Wagatsuma agar. Which of the following organisms is responsible for his presenting features?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario, along with culture findings of hemolysis on Wagatsuma agar, is suggestive of infection with Vibrio parahaemolyticus.

V. parahaemolyticus causes food poisoning due to the consumption of contaminated seafood, after an incubation period of 12–24 hours. The common sources of infection are raw seafood like molluscs and crustaceans.

Clinically, patients present with nausea, vomiting, abdominal cramps, fever, and watery or bloody diarrhea. Fecal leukocytes are often seen in stool samples.

Enteritis subsides spontaneously in 1–3 days with no specific treatment. Adequate hydration and electrolyte balance should be restored.

V. parahaemolyticus is a capsulated bacterium. It shows bipolar staining and has a tendency to pleomorphism. It is characterized by peritrichous flagella on solid media and monotrichous on liquid media and gives a positive string test.

V. parahaemolyticus grows well on blood agar, where it is identified by its oxidase-positive growth. On thiosulfate-citrate-bile salts-sucrose (TCBS) agar, it produces green colonies, as shown in the image below.

Pathogenic strains of V. parahemolyticus are hemolytic on Wagatsuma agar, while non-pathogenic strains are non-hemolytic. This is called the Kanagawa phenomenon and is due to a heat-stable hemolysin.

questions.text: A 15-year-old girl comes to the clinic for evaluation for progressively worsening vision and floating black opacities in front of her eyes. On examination, her eyeballs are prominent, the cornea is large and the anterior chamber is deep. Pupils react sluggishly to light and her visual acuity is 6/60 in both eyes. The optics of her vision are shown below. Fundoscopic examination shows the presence of coin hemorrhages and Fuchs spots. Which of the following is unlikely to occur in this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette describes a case of pathological myopia. Malignant transformation is not a complication of pathological myopia. 

Myopia or short-sightedness is a refractive error in which parallel rays of light are focussed in front of the retina instead of at the retina. In pathological myopia, there is progressively diminishing vision that results in high myopia of > -6D in early adult life. This may also be associated with degenerative changes of the eyeball.

The pathophysiological features of pathological myopia are:

  • Increased axial length
  • Degeneration of the choroid
  • Degeneration of the retina
  • Degeneration of the vitreous

Clinical features:

  • Defective vision
  • Muscae volitantes which are seen as floating black opacities in front of the vision
  • Diminished night vision
  • Prominent eyeballs
  • Large cornea
  • Deep anterior chamber
  • Sluggishly reactive pupils

Complications of pathological myopia include the following:

  • Macular degeneration
  • Macular hole
  • Rhegmatogenous retinal detachment
  • Posterior subcapsular cataract
  • Complicated cataract
  • Vitreous hemorrhage
  • Choroidal hemorrhage
  • Strabismus fixus convergence
  • Primary open-angle glaucoma, which is not a complication, but reported to occur in association with pathological myopia.

Fundus features that are seen in pathological myopia:

  • Lacquer cracks - They are ruptures in the RPE-Bruch membrane-choriocapillaris complex and appear as fine irregular yellow line crisscrossing at the posterior pole. They can lead to choroidal neovascularization.
  • Coin hemorrhages - They develop from lacquer cracks
  • Fuchs spot - It is a raised, circular, pigmented lesion developed at the macula after a subretinal hemorrhage has been absorbed
  • The pale tessellated appearance of the fundus
  • Myopic crescent - in the temporal retina
  • Supertraction or oblique optic disc

questions.text: A 23-year-old G2P1 lady with a previous history of cesarean section was found to have placenta accreta on ultrasonography. Imperfect development of which layer leads to this condition?
questions.solution:
Imperfect development of the Nitabuch layer, which is marked as 1 in the given image, leads to placenta accreta.

The other structures marked in the image are: 2 and 4 are cytotrophoblast and 3 is inner syncytiotrophoblast. 

Placenta accreta is a condition in which the placenta is directly attached to the myometrium either partially or completely without any intervening decidua. This abnormal attachment to myometrium is due to the partial or total absence of the decidua basalis and imperfect development of the Nitabuch layer.

The definitive placenta consists of the chorionic plate on the fetal aspect and a basal plate on the maternal aspect with the intervillous space between them. The structures in each of these parts are as follows: 

Morbidly adherent placenta (MAP) occurs when the placenta fails to detach from the uterine wall and these include: 

  • Placenta accreta - villi are attached to the myometrium
  • Placenta increta - villi invade the myometrium
  • Placenta percreta - villi penetrate through the myometrium and to or through the serosa

The image given below shows different types of morbidly adherent placenta.

Risk factors for MAP include prior cesarean delivery, placenta previa, prior uterine surgeries like hysterotomy, prior curettage, and endometrial ablation.

Ultrasound imaging, color doppler, and MRI have all been helpful in the diagnosis of MAP during pregnancy.

Management:

  • Partial placenta accreta - placental tissue is removed and bleeding areas are oversewed.
  • Total placenta accreta - 
    • Parous women - hysterectomy is done 
    • If the patient desires to have a child - the umbilical cord is cut close to its base so that the placenta left behind gets autolyzed
  • If MAP invades the bladder, hysterectomy and partial cystectomy are required.

questions.text: A 44-year-old woman comes to the clinic with a history of ulcers on her fingertips for the last one year. She says that her fingertips change color when exposed to cold . Examination findings are shown below. Auscultation reveals a loud second (P2)heart sound. Laboratory investigations reveal normal renal function. Which of the following antibodies is likely to be positive in this patient?
questions.solution:
The clinical image shows calcinosis cutis, a feature commonly seen in patients with longstanding limited systemic sclerosis or CREST syndrome. The anticentromere antibody is positive in these patients.

CREST stands for calcinosis cutis, Raynaud’s phenomenon (color change in fingers on exposure to cold), esophageal dysmotility, sclerodactyly, and telangiectasias. The condition can be associated with ulcers on the fingertips and isolated pulmonary hypertension (loud P2), which can be asymptomatic or present with reduced exercise capacity.

Calcinosis cutis is dystrophic calcification in the skin, subcutaneous tissues, and soft tissues. The serum calcium and phosphate levels are generally normal. 

Systemic sclerosis (SSc)  is a complex heterogeneous disorder that can potentially involve every organ system. There is significant variability in the patterns of skin involvement, organ complications, and rates of disease progression that gives rise to two major subtypes of the disease - diffuse cutaneous SSc and limited cutaneous SSc.

The antibodies tested in systemic sclerosis include:

  • Antinuclear antibody (ANA) - positive in most cases of systemic sclerosis. The absence of this antibody suggests considering an alternate diagnosis.
  • Anticentromere antibody (ACA) - usually positive in limited cutaneous systemic sclerosis or CREST
  • Antitopoisomerase I (anti-Scl-70) antibody - usually positive with diffuse cutaneous systemic sclerosis (option A)
  • Anti-RNA polymerase III antibody - usually positive with diffuse cutaneous systemic sclerosis.

Other options:

Option C: Anti-Ro antibodies are used to diagnose Sjogren’s syndrome, which is an autoimmune disorder characterized by the involvement of the exocrine glands which results in impairment of salivary and lacrimal gland function. Although patients with Sjogren’s syndrome may have arthralgias, Raynaud’s phenomenon and cough, calcinosis cutis is not a feature of this disease.

Option D: Anti Mi-2 antibodies are highly specific for dermatomyositis which may have cutaneous manifestations such as Gottron's papules on the dorsum of the hands. This disease is characterized by proximal muscle weakness and is usually associated with an underlying malignancy.

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman comes to the clinic with a history of swelling over the anterior neck, fatigue and weight loss for two months. Further evaluation reveals an anterior thyroid nodule, which moves with deglutition. FNA shows the histopathological features shown below. Laboratory testing reveals highly elevated serum calcium, PTH, and calcitonin. She also gives a history of her mother undergoing surgery for a lump in the neck many years previously. What other test should be performed in this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette describes the features of MEN 2A syndrome (medullary thyroid carcinoma, parathyroid adenoma and pheochromocytoma). This patient needs to be screened for the presence of a pheochromocytoma using plasma fractionated metanephrines as the next step in evaluation. If this test is positive, adrenal imaging with CT or MRI is the next step.

This patient with a history of thyroid swelling, fatigue, and weight loss, shows features of medullary thyroid carcinoma on histopathology - characteristic round, polygonal or spindle-shaped neoplastic cells with eosinophilic cytoplasm. The most characteristic feature is stromal amyloid deposition. This along with the elevated serum calcitonin confirms the diagnosis of MTC. Elevated serum calcium and parathyroid hormone are seen in hyperparathyroidism which may be caused by a parathyroid adenoma.

The diagnosis is based on classical clinical features, family history, and genetic testing. In an index patient with one or two classical clinical features, either genetic testing for RET mutations or the identification of features in a first-degree relative is required to make the diagnosis.

Serum gastrin levels (Option 2) and IGF-1 levels (Option 3) may be elevated in a patient with MEN 1 syndrome. Urine for ketone bodies (Option 4) will be positive in patients who are fasting or have diabetic ketoacidosis. 

 

Related Pearl: MEN 2 Syndrome Features

MEN 2A

  • Known as Sipple’s syndrome
  • Chromosome 10 / RET gene
  • Associated conditions are:
    • Medullary Thyroid Carcinoma (90%)
    • Pheochromocytoma (>50%)
    • Parathyroid adenoma (10–25%)

MEN 2B

  • Known commonly as MEN 3
  • Chromosome 10/ RET gene
  • Associated conditions are:
    • Medullary Thyroid Carcinoma (>90%)
    • Pheochromocytoma (>50%)
    • Other associated abnormalities include: (40–50%)
      • Mucosal neuromas
      • Marfanoid habitus
      • Medullated corneal nerve fibers
      • Megacolon

Related Pearl: MEN 1 Syndrome Features

Chromosome 11q13 / MEN1 gene

Also known as Wermer’s syndrome

Characteristic tumors seen in:

  • Parathyroid adenoma – 90 % - Most common overall
  • Entero pancreatic tumors - Most common functioning tumor is gastrinoma (most common site is duodenum)
  • Pituitary adenoma – Most common is prolactinoma
  • Mnemonic – Par Pan Pit – in decreasing order of frequency

Associated tumors are:

  • Angiofibroma
  • Collagenomas
  • Adrenal cortical tumors
  • Lipoma
  • Neuroendocrine tumors - gastric, thymic, lungs
  • Meningioma
  • Pheochromocytoma
  • Carcinoid tumors, usually of the foregut

Related Pearl: Pheochromocytoma

Features:

  • When pheochromocytoma is associated with the MEN syndrome it is rarely malignant.
  • Phaeochromocytomas are greyish-pink on the cut surface and are usually highly vascularised.
  • Zellbalen cells and nuclei with salt and pepper chromatin are seen.

Factors indicating more chances of malignancy:

  • An increased PASS (phaeochromocytoma of the adrenal gland scale score)
  • High number of Ki-67-positive cells
  • Vascular invasion or a breached capsule

Diagnosis:

  • Measurement of the plasma metanephrines is the most sensitive screening test.
  • MRI is the IOC.
  • Biopsy and CT Contrast scans are contraindicated in order to avoid a hypertensive crisis.

Treatment:

  • Adrenalectomy is preferred TOC.
  • Size<5 cm -  Laparoscopic adrenalectomy
  • Preop Alpha blockers should be given
  • Mitotane should be started as adjuvant or palliative treatment

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman comes to the hospital for a procedure. She has a long-standing history of diabetes with multiple complications. She has frequently visited the ophthalmology clinic with decreased vision, photophobia, pain in the eye, and vomiting. Examination findings were conjunctival redness, mid-dilated pupil, and a shallow anterior chamber. She has been treated using both medical and surgical methods for her condition and she is recommended implantation of the device shown below. Which of the following is false about this device?

choices.text: It is the first line management for glaucoma
It is sutured to the sclera

questions.solution:
The clinical vignette describes a patient with recurrent angle-closure glaucoma in the setting of long-standing diabetes mellitus. This patient may be suffering from neovascular glaucoma which is refractory to treatment and requires the placement of a drainage device. The given image shows Baerveldt Implant which is a glaucoma drainage device (GDD)/aqueous shunt. It is not the first-line treatment for glaucoma.

The term "angle-closure" refers to the occlusion of the trabecular meshwork by the peripheral iris (iridotrabecular contact [ITC]), obstructing aqueous outflow. Angle-closure can be primary when it occurs in an anatomically predisposed eye or secondary to another ocular or systemic factor.

Baerveldt Implant

  • It is a device used for complex refractory glaucoma with one or more prior failed trabeculectomies or considered high risk for failure
  • It consists of a scleral plate that is sutured to the sclera and a tube connecting it into the anterior chamber.
  • The aqueous humor drains into a bleb behind the eyelid and is then absorbed
  • It is valveless, and hence, it carries the risk of postoperative hypotony and choroidal effusions due to excessive aqueous drainage

Glaucoma drainage devices: They are devices that allow aqueous outflow by establishing a communication between the anterior chamber and sub-Tennon's space/sub-conjunctival space. The glaucoma valve implant is also known as a seton.

 

The term "angle-closure" refers to the occlusion of the trabecular meshwork by the peripheral iris (iridotrabecular contact [ITC]), obstructing aqueous outflow.

Angle-closure can be primary when it occurs in an anatomically predisposed eye or secondary to another ocular or systemic factor.

questions.text: A single mother is taking care of her twin infants(one male, one female). She generally artificially feeds them. Which among the following points, in this case, is not a criterion for identifying as 'at-risk' infants?
questions.solution:
A female child is not mentioned as a criterion for identifying 'at-risk' infants.

The following are considered as criteria to identify 'at-risk' infants:

  • Birth weight less than 2.5 kgs
  • Twins 
  • Birth order of 5 or more
  • Artificial feeding
  • Weight below 70% of the expected weight
  • Failure to gain weight during 3 successive months
  • Children with protein-energy malnutrition, diarrhea
  • Working mother or single parent

The 'at-risk' infants contribute largely to perinatal, neonatal, and infant mortality. Hence, a special intensive care, is usually suggested for these infants.

questions.text: A 60-year-old diabetic woman presents with an ulcerative vulval lesion that bleeds. Biopsy confirms a diagnosis of vulvar carcinoma. The gynecologist is concerned about the involvement of lymph nodes. Which nodes are usually the first to be involved in such cases?
questions.solution:
The superficial inguinal lymph nodes are usually the first to be involved in vulvar carcinoma.

Vulval cancer is generally seen in elderly women and they present with vulvar pruritus, vulvar swelling, lump, or an ulcer. The lump is papular with a raised pigmented area. The ulcers have often everted margins with fissured, cracked, and indurated surrounding skin. They usually bleed and cause offensive vulval discharge. The lesions are most commonly seen over the labia major.  HPV or HIV infection, diabetes, hypertension, and obesity are associated with vulval cancers. 

The order of lymph node involvement in vulval cancer includes mainly the superficial inguinal lymph node, deep inguinal lymph node, and femoral group of lymph nodes. The external iliac, obturator, and common iliac nodes are also involved in the advanced stages.

Surgical morbidity in early vulval cancer can be reduced by restricting unnecessary lymph node dissection but it is necessary for the determination of the extent of primary lymph node (sentinel) involvement. Lymphatic mapping and sentinel node biopsy (frozen section) before or during surgery help to attain an adequate surgical procedure with a good prognosis.

Mapping is done by:

  • Intraoperative intradermal injection of blue dye around the tumor has reported a detection rate of 100%
  • Localization of radioactive tracer-labeled tissue with a hand-held detector
  • Lymphoscintigraphy also gives a 100% detection rate

For the treatment of vulval cancer in young women, conservative ablative surgery, as well as wide local excision, is adequate. A simple vulvectomy is performed in elderly women. Radical vulvectomy is recommended in patients with regional lymph node involvement.

The prognosis depends upon the lymph node status.

Related Pearl: Treatment Modality in Vulval Cancer

Stage Treatment
1A
  •  Radical wide local excision
     
1B
  • Partial vulvectomy + ipsilateral inguinofemoral lymph node dissection
II
  • Tumor 2-4cm – total vulvectomy + B/L groin lymph node dissection
  • Tumor >4cm or poorly differentiated – radical vulvectomy + B/L lymphadenectomy + pelvic lymph node dissection
 
III
  • Megavoltage radiotherapy
  • Local surgical excision - Radical vulvectomy + B/L lymphadenectomy + pelvic lymph node dissection
  • Local recurrence – chemotherapy
 
IV
  • Chemotherapy or radiotherapy
  • Local excision on residual tumor
  • ipsilateral inguinofemoral lymph node + ve – contralateral node removed
  • Femoral lymph node +ve – pelvic lymph node removed

questions.text: A newborn presents with respiratory distress, chest retractions, grunting, and cyanosis. The newborn was born via normal vaginal delivery and antenatal screening was not performed regularly.  Vital signs are remarkable for an elevated respiratory rate. The abdomen is scaphoid in shape and heart sounds are heard on the left side of the chest. Chest X-ray findings are shown in the image. Which of the following findings do you expect in this patient?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette describes a case of congenital diaphragmatic hernia. Pulmonary hypertension is seen in a congenital diaphragmatic hernia.

Pulmonary hypertension is a poor prognostic indicator in a congenital diaphragmatic hernia.

Chest X-ray commonly shows bowel(gas-filled lumen) in the thorax and commonly the heart is shifted to the right(unlike in this case where hernia occurred on the right side hence pushing heart to the left)

Confounder - 
note that heart sounds are on the left side of the chest. However, most CDH occurs on the left side and displaces heart sounds to the right.

Management - 
External tracheal clips or endotracheal balloons laparoscopically placed to occlude the fetal trachea. Post-natal management mainly involves stabilization of the cardiorespiratory status. Immediate endotracheal intubation is critical.  If infants have a stable pulmonary status, CDH repair can be safely performed on the second to the fourth day of life.

Other options-

Option B - Pulmonary hyperplasia is not seen in CDH. Pulmonary hypoplasia is seen instead due to compression of the developing lung.

Option C - Esophageal atresia is seen as a part of 

  • VACTERL (vertebral anomalies, anal atresia, cardiac malformations, tracheoesophageal fistula, esophageal atresia, renal anomalies, and radial aplasia, and limb anomalies)

 

  • CHARGE (coloboma, heart defects, atresia of the choanae, retardation of mental and/or physical development, genital hypoplasia, and ear abnormalities

Option D - renal agenesis leads to Potter's syndrome with flat fascies. 

 

Related Pearl: Congenital diaphragmatic hernias (CDH)

It is due to the failure of the closure of the pleuroperitoneal canal in the developing fetus (Normally the pleuroperitoneal cavities separate by 8-10 weeks of gestation). Left-sided hernias are more common(80%).

The two well-recognized congenital sites where abdominal viscera can herniate into the chest are:

  • The foramen of Morgagni: a hernia in the anteromedial part of the diaphragm with a defect between the sternal and costal attachments. The most commonly involved viscus is the transverse colon.
  • The foramen of Bochdalek: through the dome of the diaphragm posterolaterally

CDH causes pulmonary hypoplasia (bilateral) by compressing the developing lung. These lungs have smaller bronchi, with less bronchial branching and less alveolar surface area than lungs in normal infants. Pulmonary hypertension may also develop due to increased thickness of arteriolar smooth muscle and also by multiple local and systemic vasoactive factors.

Clinical features:

  • respiratory distress at birth
  • grunting respiration
  • chest retractions
  • dyspnea
  • cyanosis
  • scaphoid abdomen
  • decreased breath sounds along with bowel sound over the chest with CDH
  • shifting of heart sounds to the right (for left-sided CDH)

questions.text: A 60-year-old chronic smoker complains of cough, occasional chest pain and breathlessness, increased thirst, and increased urination for the past 6 months. The radiological investigations reveal a centrally located tumor with the histopathology showing a characteristic Azzopardi effect as shown in the image below. Which of the following statements is incorrect regarding this condition?

choices.text: Can cause ectopic release of adreno cortico trophic hormone
Salt and pepper pattern is seen on histopathological examination
Tumor originates from neuroendocrine progenitor cells

questions.solution:
This patient's clinical features and the histological image showing the basophilic staining of the vessel wall (Azzopardi effect) are suggestive of a small cell carcinoma of the lung. Chromogranin, synaptophysin, and CD56 are the markers for small cell lung carcinoma. Calretinin positivity is seen in mesothelioma, not here.

This tumor originates from neuroendocrine progenitor cells (Kulchitsky cells), which are present in the lining bronchial epithelium. Azzopardi effect is described as basophilic staining of vascular walls due to encrustation by DNA from necrotic tumor cells.

Histology of small cell lung carcinoma shows clusters of small cells with scant cytoplasm, ill-defined cell borders, finely granular nuclear chromatin (salt and pepper pattern), and absent or inconspicuous nucleoli. The cells are round, oval, or spindle-shaped, and nuclear molding is prominent.

Markers seen in small cell lung carcinoma include:

  • Chromogranin,
  • Synaptophysin,
  • CD56

Paraneoplastic syndromes associated with small cell carcinoma of the lung are Cushing Syndrome due to ACTH production and hyponatremia due to inappropriate ADH secretion. A majority of small-cell carcinomas (90%) show high levels of antiapoptotic BCL2 protein on Immunohistochemistry.

Small cell lung cancer-associated SIADH is due to the ectopic release of antidiuretic hormone. It is associated with increased thirst and hyponatremia. It resolves within a month of initiation of chemotherapy.

Immunohistochemistry in Lung cancers:

  • Primary lung adenocarcinoma (Napsin-A positive, Thyroid Transcription Factor (TTF-1) positive)
  • Primary lung squamous cell carcinoma (Napsin-A negative, TTF-1 negative)
  • Primary Small Cell Lung Cancers (Napsin-A negative, TTF-1 positive)
  • Nonsquamous NSCLC, SCLC, and mesothelioma may stain positive for CK7 and negative for CK20
  • Squamous cell lung cancer often will be both CK7 and CK20 negative
  • p63 is a useful marker for the detection of Non-Small Cell Lung Cancers with squamous differentiation when used in cytologic pulmonary samples
  • CK5/6, calretinin, and Wilms tumor gene-1 (WT-1), all of which show positivity in mesothelioma

questions.text: A young man complains of knee pain and a locking sensation in his knees for 3 days. He noticed this following a game of football a few days ago. He does not recall any acute event that precipitated the pain. The test shown in the image is done. What is the name of the test?
questions.solution:
The test done in the image is Apley's test. It is used to detect injuries to the menisci and it is done with the patient lying in the prone position.

A meniscal tear is a split or tear in the meniscus following a rotational or shearing force. The medial meniscus is affected more commonly than the lateral. Sometimes, it may be a vertical tear. If the separated fragment stays attached at the front and back, it is known as a bucket handle tear.

It presents as insidious or acute(in severe cases) onset pain, swelling, popping/catching/locking/giving out the sensation of the knee following a twisting injury to the knee. A plain X-ray appears normal, but MRI confirms the diagnosis.

Apley's test: This test is performed with a prone patient, the knee is flexed to 90  degrees and rotated while a compression force is applied, which is called the grinding test. Reproduction of symptoms indicates a torn meniscus. The distraction test involves repeated rotation while the leg is pulled upwards by the examiner, holding the thigh down. This produces increased pain only if there is ligament damage.

Other options:

Lachman test - done to detect anterior cruciate ligament injuries. Here the leg is in slight external rotation and the knee is in the position between flexion and extension. The femur is stabilized by one hand and the other hand applies the anterior force to the proximal tibia.

McMurray test: Done to detect menisci injuries. The patient's knee is completely flexed while he lies supine. One hand is used to stabilize and palpate the knee joint and the leg is internally and externally rotated with the other hand. The leg is then slowly extended. Meniscal injury presents as a palpable or audible click.

Thessaly test: With the affected knee flexed to 20 degrees and the foot placed flat on the ground, the patient takes his full weight on that leg while being supported by the examiner. The patient is then asked to twist his or her body to one side and then to the other three times. This test has shown a high diagnostic accuracy rate at the level of 95% in detecting meniscal tears.

questions.text: A 62-year-old man presented with a history of fatigability, weight loss, anorexia, and rubbery swellings in his neck and armpits for the past 3 months. On examination, cervical and axillary lymphadenopathy was detected along with hepatosplenomegaly. Investigations revealed mild anemia, normal platelet count, with a leukocytosis of 60,000/mm3 with 75% lymphocytes. Immunophenotyping reveals CD 19+,CD20+, CD21+,CD22+, CD 23+, CD5+ and CyclinD1 negative. The peripheral blood smear is shown in the image below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical features and peripheral smear are suggestive of chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL).

Chronic Lymphocytic Leukemia (CLL)/Small Lymphocytic Lymphoma (SLL)

The differentiating point between CLL and SLL is that in CLL: absolute lymphocyte count is >5000 per mm³ and in SLL:<5000 per mm³. It is the most common leukemia among adults in the western world.

Proliferation centers are pathognomonic for CLL/SLL.

  • The chromosomal defects:
    • Deletion of 13q (commonest and has a good prognosis)
    • Deletion of 11q
    • Trisomy 12q
    • Deletion of 17p (poor prognosis)

In CLL, B cells originate from naive B cell or Pre/Post Germinal Centre memory B cell. CLL arises in the lymph node.

The peripheral blood smear in cases of chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL) contains a large number of monotonous, uniform-looking, mature lymphocytes, which is often described as a "convent-girl" appearance. The small round lymphocytes (indicated by arrow) have condensed chromatin, and scant cytoplasm. Some of these cells may get disrupted while preparing the smears, producing so-called smudge cells (indicated by arrowhead).

Leukocyte count is highly variable; leukopenia in marrow involvement or leukocytosis. Hypogammaglobulinemia can be seen. 10% to 15% of patients develop hemolytic anemia or thrombocytopenia due to autoantibodies made by nonneoplastic B cells

Peripheral smear findings in CLL:

  • Numerous small round lymphocytes with scant cytoplasm
  • Smudge cells (artefacts due to disrupted tumor cells which lack vimentin)
  • Spherocytes (due to coexisting Autoimmune hemolytic anemia [AIHA])
  • Nucleated RBCs (due to premature release of progenitors in face of severe anemia, marrow infiltration tumor, or both)

The classical immunophenotypic feature of CLL is CD 19+,CD20+, CD21+,CD22+, CD 23+, CD5+ .The immunophenotype of CLL demonstrates coexpression of the B lymphocyte lineage marker CD 19 with the T lymphocyte marker CD5.

CLL most often affects elderly persons, many of whom are asymptomatic for many years. Generalized lymphadenopathy and hepatosplenomegaly, easy fatigability, weight loss, and anorexia are frequent findings. 

On lymph node biopsy:

Lymph node shows diffuse effacement composed of small lymphocytes admixed, with variable numbers of larger activated lymphocytes that often gather in loose aggregates referred to as proliferation centers, which contain mitotically active cells.

 

Expectant management is the treatment of choice for asymptomatic patients with chronic lymphocytic leukemia. Chemotherapy and monoclonal antibodies are used when there is

  • Progressive marrow failure- worsening anemia, thrombocytopenia
  • Progressive splenomegaly
  • Progressive lymphadenopathy
  • Presence of constitutional symptoms like weight loss, fever, night sweats, etc.

Important drugs used in the management of CLL are fludarabine, cyclophosphamide, bendamustine, and rituximab.

 

Other options:

Myeloid sarcoma (chloroma, extramedullary myeloid tumor, granulocytic sarcoma) is defined by the WHO as a tumor mass consisting of myeloid blasts, with or without maturation, occurring at extramedullary sites. It is called "chloroma" due to its peculiar green color, caused by myeloperoxidase, which fades in a few hours. Arbiskov cells are seen in chloroma.

Bones affected are orbit (most common), skull, paranasal sinuses, sternum, ribs, vertebrae, and pelvis.

 

Peripheral smear of CLL.

 

Mantle cell lymphoma :

The primary difference between immunophenotype of CLL/SLL and Mantle cell lymphoma is CD23

Mantle cell lymphoma (option 2): CD 19+, CD 20+, CD21+, CD22+,CD23 (-), CD 5+

Follicular lymphoma (option 3): CD 79b+, CD 19+, CD 10+, CD 20+, CD22+

Comparison between mantle-cell lymphoma and chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL) and small lymphocytic lymphoma (SLL)

  Mantle cell lymphoma CLL/SLL
CD5 Positive Positive
CD23 Negative Positive
CyclinD1 Positive Negative
FMC7 Positive Negative
CD10, BCL6 Negative Negative

 Mantle-cell lymphoma arises from the mantle-zone B cells as the IgH genes lack somatic hypermutation (naive B cells). They  have an (11;14) translocation involving the IgH locus on chromosome 14 and overexpression of cyclin D1. It is seen in fifth and sixth decades of life and has male predominance

Features:

  • Painless lymphadenopathy
  • Splenomegaly
  • Multifocal mucosal involvement of small bowel and colon – lymphomatoid polyposis

Histology :

  • Nodal tumor cells may surround reactive germinal centers to produce a nodular appearance at low power, or diffusely efface the node.
  • Typically, the proliferation consists of a homogeneous population of small lymphocytes with irregular to occasionally deeply clefted (cleaved) nuclear contours
  • Large cells resembling centroblasts and proliferation centers are absent, distinguishing mantle cell lymphoma from follicular lymphoma and CLL/SLL, respectively

Chronic myelogenous leukemia. 

CML is primarily a disease of adults but also occurs in children and adolescents. The peak incidence is in the fifth to sixth decades of life.

The presence of a chimeric BCR-ABL is created by a reciprocal (9;22)(q34;q11) translocation (the so-called Philadelphia chromosome [Ph]). This is detected by cytogenetics, FISH, or PCR.

Mild-to-moderate anemia and hypermetabolism, fatigability, weakness, weight loss, and anorexia. The spleen is often greatly enlarged as a result of extensive extramedullary hematopoiesis.  Dragging sensation in the abdomen caused by splenomegaly, or the acute onset of left upper quadrant pain due to splenic infarction. Extramedullary hematopoiesis can also produce mild hepatomegaly and lymphadenopathy.

Peripheral blood - Leukocytosis, often exceeding 100,000 cells/mm3 which consists predominantly of neutrophils, band forms, metamyelocytes, myelocytes, eosinophils, and basophils. Blasts usually make up less than 10% of the circulating cells. Platelets - usually increased

Marrow -The marrow is markedly hypercellular because of massively increased numbers of maturing granulocytic precursors, which usually include an elevated proportion of eosinophils and basophils.

Megakaryocytes are also increased and usually include small, dysplastic forms. Erythroid progenitors are present in normal or mildly decreased numbers. Increased deposition of reticulin is typical, but overt marrow fibrosis is rare early in the course. Low LAP score

Image shows peripheral smear finding of chronic myeloid leukemia (CML) with neutrophils, myelocyte, metamyelocyte, and band cells described as a "garden party" appearance.
