questions.text:
A 38-year-old female patient presents with a history of fever and cough for 10 days. On examination, the pulse is 96 bpm, BP is 118/70 mmHg, the temperature is 100.4 °F, RR is 15/min and SpO2 is 96%. Laboratory reports are awaited. Chest CT, as shown below, demonstrates ground-glass opacities close to the visceral pleural surfaces and visible intralobular lines. Which CO-RADS category does this patient fall under?

CO-RADS - COVID-19 Reporting and Data System
questions.solution:
The given clinical presentation is highly suspicious of COVID-19. The chest CT findings of ground-glass opacities near the visceral pleural line and crazy paving place this patient under CO-RADS 5 (COVID-19 Reporting and Data System).

CO-RADS 5 implies a very high level of suspicion for pulmonary involvement by COVID-19 based on typical CT findings. It requires the presence of at least one confirmatory pattern. 

Typical features for pulmonary involvement by COVID-19:

Obligatory features:

  • Ground-glass opacities, with or without consolidation, in regions close to the visceral pleural lines, including the fissures
  • Multifocal bilateral distribution

Confirmatory patterns:

  • Ground-glass regions
    • Unsharp, rounded shape
    • Sharp demarcation, outlining the shape of multiple adjacent pulmonary lobules
  • Crazy paving 
  • Patterns compatible with organizing pneumonia
  • Thickened vessels within parenchymal abnormalities 

CO-RADS uses a five-point scale to report suspicion for pulmonary involvement of COVID-19 on chest CT. The CO-RADS categories are as follows:

CO-RADS 0: Not interpretable, and technically insufficient to assign a score 

CO-RADS 1: Very low level of suspicion for pulmonary involvement by COVID-19. CT findings are normal or of unequivocal non-infectious etiology; e.g. mild or severe emphysema, perifissural nodules, lung tumors, or fibrosis

CO-RADS 2: Low level of suspicion for pulmonary involvement by COVID-19; includes infectious etiology that is not compatible with COVID-19 such as bronchitis, bronchiolitis, bronchopneumonia, lobar pneumonia, and abscess

CO-RADS 3: Equivocal findings for pulmonary involvement by COVID-19; findings overlap with other infectious etiologies; could include perihilar ground-glass, homogenous extensive ground-glass, with or without sparing of secondary pulmonary lobules

CO-RADS 4: High level of suspicion for pulmonary involvement by COVID-19; findings are similar to those of CO-RADS 5 but are not present in the typical locations; findings may also be superimposed on severe pre-existing pulmonary abnormalities 

CO-RADS 5: Very high level of suspicion for pulmonary involvement by COVID-19 based on typical CT findings mentioned above

CO-RADS 6: Proven COVID-19 by positive RT-PCR test.

questions.text:
You are an intern posted in a primary health center in a rural village for one month. As a part of a health screening program, you are assigned the task of diagnosing and treating children with malnutrition in the community. A 2-year-old boy is brought to you for assessment. His growth appears stunted and he is lethargic. Hair appears dry with patchy hair loss. His head appears relatively large compared to the body. There are redundant skin folds in multiple locations.

Vitals

  • Temperature: 96.5°F
  • Pulse Rate: 70/min
  • Blood Pressure: 80/40 mm Hg

Measurement with the WHO standard mid-upper-arm-circumference(MUAC) tape shows red. Which of the following is false?

choices.text: This child's MUAC correlates to a value of 12 cm
The tape can be used in children between 6 and 60 months
MUAC is measured between the acromion and the olecranon

questions.solution:
This child's presentation points towards the diagnosis of severe acute malnutrition (marasmus). Red colour on the new WHO standard mid-upper arm circumference of (MUAC) tape correlates to a MUAC of  <11.5 cm, not 12 cm.

Clinical features of Marasmus

  • Head that appears large relative to the body, with staring eyes
  • Emaciated and weak appearance
  • Irritable and fretful affect
  • Bradycardia, hypotension, and hypothermia
  • Thin, dry skin
  • Shrunken arms, thighs, and buttocks, with redundant skin folds caused by loss of subcutaneous fat
  • Thin, sparse hair that is easily plucked

Mid-upper arm circumference: 

  • Used in children between 6 to 60 months 
  • Measured between the acromion and olecranon process.
  • It is an age-independent parameter (between 6-60 months)

Severe acute malnutrition (SAM) in children of ages 6 to 59 months is defined by WHO as any of the following:

  • Weight-for-length (or height) below −3 SD of the WHO Child Growth Standards.
  • Presence of bipedal edema
  • Mid-upper arm circumference <11.5 cm

MUAC tape cut-offs:

Colour Measurements Indication
  Red   < 11.5 cm Severe Acute Malnutrition (SAM)
 Yellow   11.5 to 12.5 cm Under-nourished
  Green   > 12.5 cm Normal

Similar methods based on MUAC:

  • Bangle Test 
    • It has an internal diameter of 4 cms. 
    • Normally, it should not cross the elbow.
  • QUAC stick test
    • Mid-upper arm circumference/ Height of child
  • Skinfold thickness
    • Age-independent parameter.
    • Triceps skinfold thickness is measured with the help of Harpenden caliper.
      • Normal: 10 mm
      • Severe malnutrition: < 6 mm

WHO update:

A higher cut-off of 11.5 cm was recommended by the WHO. According to the new update, UNICEF started the supply of new MUAC tapes as described above.

questions.text: A patient diagnosed with onychomycosis was prescribed terbinafine. Which of the following correctly describes the mechanism of action of this drug?

choices.text: Inhibition of DNA and RNA synthesis
Inhibits epoxidation of squalene leading to impaired ergosterol synthesis
Chelation of trivalent metal ions causing inhibition of metal-dependent enzymes

questions.solution:
The mechanism of action of terbinafine is the inhibition of the enzyme squalene epoxidase and thus impairing ergosterol synthesis.

Squalene epoxidase is an enzyme that converts squalene to squalene epoxide. This is an early step in the synthesis of ergosterol, an important constituent of the fungal cell membrane. Terbinafine is an inhibitor of this enzyme. This results in the accumulation of squalene, which is toxic to the organism.

Flucytosine is converted inside the fungal cells to FdUMP and FUTP which inhibit DNA and RNA synthesis respectively (option A). Flucytosine shows synergy with amphotericin B and is used in the treatment of cryptococcal meningitis.

Griseofulvin disrupts the fungal cell division by inhibiting the microtubule function (option C). Griseofulvin is the drug of choice for tinea capitis in children.

Ciclopirox olamine is a broad-spectrum fungicidal agent that acts by chelating trivalent metal cations (option D) which leads to inhibition of the metal-dependent enzyme that degrades free radicals in the fungal cell. It is available as a nail lacquer formulation in the treatment of onychomycosis.

Related Pearl: Mechanism of action of Antifungal drugs

questions.text: A child with congenital thrombocytopenia presented with eczema and recurrent infections. On investigation, IgM levels in the serum were low, but levels of IgG were normal and mutation in the WASP gene was identified. The immunologist administered the 'Transfer factor' to this patient to improve his immunity. Which of the following statements is false regarding this transfer factor?

choices.text: It transfers both  cell mediated and humoral immunity
Can be transferred only to those antigens to which the donor is sensitive
The immunity offered by it is referred to as adoptive immunity

questions.solution:
Cell-mediated immunity (CMI) can be transferred in human beings by the injection of extracts from leucocytes. This extract is known as transfer factor(TF). It does not transfer humoral immunity.

The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Wiskott Aldrich syndrome. Here IgM levels in the serum are low, but levels of IgG are usually normal associated with increased levels of IgA and IgE.

Wiskott Aldrich syndrome: There is a mutation in the gene encoding Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome protein (WASP), which is located on Xp11.23.

  • The X-linked disease is characterized by thrombocytopenia, eczema, and a marked vulnerability to recurrent infection, resulting in early death.
  • Eczema begins in early infancy and may mimic atopic dermatitis.
  • Thrombocytopenia is associated with small-sized platelets.
  • The risk of lymphoreticular malignancies is increased.

The transferred cell-mediated immunity is not local at the injected site. It is systemic. The immunity transferred as a result of an injection of the Transfer factor is referred to as Adoptive immunity.

Transfer factor is composed of immunologically competent lymphocytes - T lymphocytes or tumor-infiltrating lymphocytes, NK cells, macrophages, or B cells. Transfer factor has the ability to passively transfer cell-mediated immunity against antigens to which the donor is sensitive. 

The Cell-Mediated Immunity can be transferred only to those antigens to which the donor is sensitive.

TF is a dialysable, low molecular weight substance.

Applications of Transfer factor:

  • To restore immune capacity in patients with T-cell deficiency (Wiskott – Aldrich syndrome)
  • Treatment of disseminated infections associated with deficient cell mediated immunity such as Lepromatous leprosy, Tuberculosis Mucocutaneous candidiasis
  • Treatment of Malignant melanoma
  • In treatment of autoimmune diseases such as Systemic lupus erythematosus, Rheumatoid arthritis.

questions.text: A male patient is brought into the emergency after a road traffic accident in which he has sustained injuries on the face. You note excessive mobility of the maxilla but no mobility of the nose. A CT scan reveals a fracture line passing through the lower part of the nasal septum, maxillary antrum, and pterygoid plates. Which among the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Le-Fort I fracture of the maxilla. 

Le Fort Type 1 fractures generally occur on the horizontal plane at the level of the nose base. It is caused due to downward directed force onto the lower part of the maxillary rim.

It involves the three walls of the maxillary sinus as well as the pterygoid processes, extending around the maxillary antrum, nasal septum, and pterygoid plate. This leads to the separation of the palate and face. There is no involvement of the glabella or zygoma in this case. 

Clinically, patients present with swollen upper lip, anterior open bite malocclusion, maxillary buccal vestibule, palate ecchymosis, and mobility of the maxilla.

Diagnosis is made with X-rays (Water's view, posteroanterior view, and lateral view) and CT scan. They help to understand the full extent of injuries. 

Treatment requires fixation of the maxillary fractures which can be achieved by interdental wiring, and intermaxillary wiring using arch bars. Open reduction and interosseous wiring may be required in zygomatic fractures.

Related Pearl: Le-Fort's classification of Maxillary Fracture

Le-Fort I is a transverse fracture of the maxilla
  • Fracture line passes through the lower part of nasal septum, maxillary antra and the pterygoid plates
  • It separates palate from the rest of the face leading to floating teeth or palate
  • Also called Guerin’s fracture. 
Le-Fort II is a pyramidal fracture
  • Fracture line passes through the root of the nose, lacrimal bone, floor of the orbit, upper part of the maxillary sinus and pterygoid plates
  • X-ray or CT appears like hanging maxilla
  • It is associated with CSF rhinorrhea.
Le-Fort III is craniofacial dysjunction i.e., facial skeleton completely disconnected from its cranial attachment
  • Fracture line passes through the root of the nose, ethmo-frontal junction, superior orbital fissure, lateral wall of the orbit, fronto-zygomatic and temporo-zygomatic sutures and the upper part of pterygoid plates
  • It is also associated with CSF rhinorrhea.

questions.text: A 6-year-old boy was brought to the OPD by his mother with complaints of weight loss, malaise, weakness, and passing loose, bulky stools for the past 3 months. Stools were initially profuse and watery and later became greasy and foul-smelling. This was often associated with pain in the abdomen. The pediatrician ordered a stool examination, which showed the following organisms with a "falling leaf" motility. Which of the following tests has the best sensitivity and specificity for diagnosing this condition?
questions.solution:
The child has loose stools and pain abdomen. The stool examination (with methylene blue staining) shows a pear-shaped trophozoite having two nuclei and a flagellum,  which is typical of Giardia lamblia. ELISA kits (ProSpecT/ Giardia kit) detect Giardia-specific antigen 65 (GSA 65) and have a sensitivity of 95% and specificity of 100%, compared to conventional microscopy.

Giardia lamblia:

Transmission: Infected drinking water

Clinical manifestations:

  • The symptoms include acute or chronic diarrhea, weight loss, malaise, abdominal cramps, distension, and weakness. The stools may be watery, greasy, bulky, or foul-smelling at various times during the course of the infection.
  • Stools initially may be profuse and watery and later become greasy and foul-smelling.
  • Stools do not contain blood, mucus, or fecal leukocytes.
  • Abnormal stool patterns may alternate with periods of constipation and normal bowel movements.
  • It is associated with iron deficiency and growth stunting

Diagnosis: ELISA kits (ProSpecT/ Giardia kit) detect Giardia-specific antigen 65 (GSA 65) and have a sensitivity of 95% and specificity of 100%, compared to conventional microscopy.

Enterotest (String Test) is used for obtaining duodenal specimen in the case of giardiasis. A coiled thread is placed inside a gelatin capsule which is swallowed by the patient. The capsule passes through the stomach to the duodenum. After 2 hours, the thread is withdrawn and placed in saline. It is shaken and the centrifuged deposit of the saline is examined for Giardia. But this test is very costly.

On microscopic examination, cysts and trophozoites of Giardia can be found in diarrheal stools by saline and iodine wet preparations.

Treatment: Tinidazole and nitazoxanide

The above image shows the trophozoite form of Giardia lamblia which is in the shape of tennis racket or “Heart-shaped” or “pyriform shaped”.

It is bilaterally symmetrical and possesses:

  • Nuclei - 1 Pair
  • Flagella - 4 Pairs
  • Blepharoplast/Basal bodies from which flagella arises - 4 Pairs
  • Axostyles running along the midline - 1 Pair
  • Parabasal or median bodies - 2

questions.text: A middle-aged woman with schizoaffective disorder was recently prescribed a different antipsychotic drug instead of the one she was usually taking. She is also on sertraline. She presented a month later, complaining of breast engorgement, galactorrhea, and amenorrhea. Investigations revealed highly elevated prolactin levels. The drug most likely prescribed was?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario is suggestive of hyperprolactinemia secondary to the use of risperidone, an atypical antipsychotic that can be used in schizoaffective disorder.

The clinical symptoms are indicative of hyperprolactinemia, most likely caused by the dopamine antagonist action of risperidone. Normally, prolactin secretion is inhibited by dopamine. Therefore, drugs that act as dopamine antagonists lead to loss of this inhibitory action and cause hyperprolactinemia. This results in symptoms like breast engorgement, galactorrhea, amenorrhea in women, and infertility in men. 

Risperidone is an atypical antipsychotic indicated in the management of schizophrenia, acute mania or mixed with bipolar disorder, aggressive episodes in autism spectrum disorder, etc. It is an antagonist of the serotonin 5-HT2A, dopamine D2, a1-adrenergic, a2-adrenergic, and histamine H1 receptors.

In schizoaffective disorder, symptoms of mania or depression develop concurrently with the major symptoms of schizophrenia. Thus, they are treated with mood stabilizers for manic episodes (like carbamazepine) or selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (like sertraline) for depressive episodes. Antipsychotics are prescribed for psychotic symptoms.

In this patient, sertraline was administered along with risperidone. The combined use of risperidone and selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (as in this patient) can result in a significant elevation of prolactin levels. This is due to the CYP2D6 enzyme inhibitory actions of SSRIs, thereby inhibiting the metabolism of other CYP2D6 substrates. 

This hyperprolactinemia can be rapidly reversed by discontinuing the drug or switching to other low potency/ prolactin sparing (eg. quetiapine) atypical antipsychotics. In case, risperidone needs to be continued, administering bromocriptine can alleviate the symptoms. 

Other options:

Brexpiprazole, clozapine, and aripiprazole are atypical antipsychotics. they do not have any effect on prolactin secretion.

questions.text: As a resident, you are explaining the clinical anatomy to the medical students on your team. The structure marked "A" forms which of the following boundaries of the anatomic snuffbox?
questions.solution:
The marked structure in the image is the extensor pollicis longus and forms the medial/ulnar boundary of the anatomical snuff box. It passes medial to the Lister tubercle on the radius. 

Boundaries of the anatomical snuffbox: 

  • Lateral wall:
    • Abductor pollicis longus (APL)
    • Extensor pollicis brevis (EPB)  
  • Medial wall:
    • Extensor pollicis longus (EPL)
  • Roof:
    • Cephalic vein
    • The superficial branch of the radial nerve
  • Floor:
    • Scaphoid and trapezium

Only content: Radial artery

The name "snuffbox" originates from the use of this surface for placing and then sniffing powdered tobacco, or "snuff."

questions.text: A primigravida woman with monochorionic twin pregnancy presents for an antenatal checkup in the third trimester.  The ultrasound reveal twin to twin transfusion syndrome. Subsequently, one of the twins is found to have hydrops fetalis. According to Quintero staging, you will classify this as:
questions.solution:
Quintero staging is used in the grading of twin to twin transfusion syndrome. Hydrops fetalis of either of the twins is classified as stage IV in Quintero staging.

The Quintero staging is as follows:  

  • Stage I—Amniotic fluid discordant + Urine visible in donor's bladder.
  • Stage II—Stage I +Urine not visible in donor's bladder.
  • Stage III— Stage II + abnormal Doppler studies of the umbilical artery, ductus venosus, or umbilical vein.
  • Stage IV— frank ascites or hydrops in either twin.
  • Stage V—the demise of either fetus.

Twin to twin transfusion syndrome is a condition that affects multifetal pregnancies where there are shared placentas. It occurs due to arteriovenous anastomoses occurring within the placenta. Unidirectional flow leads to shunting of blood away from one twin and towards the other. 

The donor twin may have anemia, growth restriction, oliguria, oligohydramnios, and pallor. The recipient twin may have polycythemia, heart failure, circulatory overload (hydrops), plethoric appearance, severe hypervolemia, hyperviscosity, severe hyperbilirubinemia, and kernicterus.

The image shows the lambda sign or twin peak sign seen in dichorionic diamniotic pregnancy. Lambda sign is seen in the image below: 

 

"T sign" is the sonographic image seen in a monochorionic twin pregnancy. It refers to the lack of chorion extending between the layers of the intertwin membrane.

Note:

The donor twin is also known as pump twin / stuck twin, and the manifestation is termed as polyhydramnios -oligohydramnios syndrome or poly-oli syndrome.

Related Pearl: Twinning

questions.text:
A 30-year-old woman presented with repeated episodes of headache, dizziness, and intense pruritis. Her lab investigations are given below. Bone marrow biopsy showed a hypercellular marrow with prominent erythroid, granulocytic, and megakaryocytic proliferation. She is also taking treatment for peptic ulcer disease. Which of the following genetic pathologies is strongly associated with this condition?

Lab investigations:

  • Hemoglobin- 17.0 g/dL
  • Hematocrit- 52%
  • Serum erythropoietin- low
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is highly suggestive of polycythemia vera which is strongly associated with activating point mutations in the tyrosine kinase JAK2.

A mutation in JAK2, a key member of the cytokine intracellular signaling pathway, can be found in 90–95% of patients with polycythemia vera.

It is characterized by:

  • Increased marrow production of red cells, granulocytes, and platelets (panmyelosis)
  • Low erythropoietin levels and elevated hematocrit
  • Blood viscosity and sludging lead to both thrombosis and bleeding
  • Headache, dizziness, hypertension, dizziness, venous thrombosis (Budd Chiari syndrome due to hepatic vein thrombosis), bowel infarction, and stroke
  • Intense pruritus, especially aquagenic pruritus 
  • Peptic ulceration, hyperuricemia
  • 15% to 20% of patients may develop myelofibrosis and extensive extramedullary hematopoiesis after few years
  • PCV transforms into AML in 2% of patients

Ruxolitinib is the Janus-associated kinase (JAK2) inhibitor used in the treatment of polycythemia vera.

Other options:

Chronic Myelogenous Leukemia or CML is the consequence of the balanced translocation between chromosomes 9 and 22 (t[9;22]).

Chronic Eosinophilic Leukemia CEL occurs with a deletion or balanced translocations involving the PDGFRa gene.

BTK mutation causes X-linked agammaglobulinemia.

Related Pearl: WHO Polycythemia Vera Criteria

Major criteria:

1. Hemoglobin >16.5 g/dL in men

     Hemoglobin >16.0 g/dL in women 

Or

     Hematocrit >49% in men

     Hematocrit >48% in women 

2. Bone marrow biopsy showing hypercellularity with trilineage hyperplasia (panmyelosis) and prominent erythroid, granulocytic, and megakaryocytic proliferation with pleomorphic mature megakaryocytes in the bone marrow, and 

3. Presence of JAK2 exon 12 mutation

Minor criterion:

Subnormal serum erythropoietin level

Diagnosis of polycythemia vera requires meeting either all 3 major criteria or the first 2 major criteria along with the minor criterion

questions.text: A postmenopausal lady presented with an itchy plaque over the vulva for the past 2 years, which persisted despite multiple topical treatments. Biopsy of the lesion revealed large vacuolated cells with mucin. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given scenario and presence of large vacuolated cells with mucin (Paget's cells) points to a diagnosis of extramammary Paget's disease. It is a form of intraepidermal adenocarcinoma.

Extramammary Paget's disease usually presents in the sixth to eighth decades of life. It may occur in the genital or perianal regions, or in cutaneous sites rich in apocrine glands such as the axilla. Approximately 25% of the cases are associated with an underlying in situ or invasive neoplasm. 

It most commonly presents with pruritus. The clinical appearance is similar to mammary Paget's Disease. Scattered areas of erosion and white scale can give rise to a “strawberries and cream” appearance. The invasion of the lymphatic system by the tumor gives rise to underpants-pattern erythema. 

Surgical excision forms the basis of treatment.

The given image shows large vacuolated cells with mucin (Paget's cells)

questions.text: A 30-year-old male patient comes to the clinic with pain, redness, and watering of the eyes. He reports that many of his friends and neighbours suffer from similar symptoms. Examination reveals oedema of the eyelids and subconjunctival haemorrhage. Pupillary reflexes are normal and vision is intact. An image of the examination findings is given below. Which of the following lymph nodes are likely to be enlarged in this patient?
questions.solution:
The clinical presentation seen in this patient resembles that of hemorrhagic conjunctivitis or "Apollo conjunctivitis". The lymph nodes likely to enlarged in this condition are the preauricular lymph nodes. 

Hemorrhagic conjunctivitis (a.k.a Apollo conjunctivitis):

  • It is due to picornaviruses, namely, Coxsackie A24 and Enterovirus 70. Worldwide pandemics caused by these viruses have occurred mostly in tropical coastal areas.
  • It presents as violent inflammatory conjunctivitis with lacrimation and photophobia. Subconjunctival hemorrhages and enlarged preauricular lymph nodes are common. The cornea is usually affected.
  • Transmission occurs via indirect routes involving eye discharge, fingers, and fomites with rapid spreading unsanitary conditions.
  • Symptoms peak in two to three days and the infection self resolve in 10 days usually without complications.
  • CNS manifestations may occur concurrently in hemorrhagic conjunctivitis caused by Enterovirus 70

Lymph from the conjunctiva drains directly into the submandibular and preauricular nodes.

Lymphatic supply of the conjunctiva

  • From the medial side, one-third of the superior and medial two-thirds of the inferior conjunctiva → Submandibular nodes
  • From the lateral side, two-thirds of the superior conjunctiva and lateral one-third of the inferior conjunctiva → Preauricular nodes

questions.text: A 50-year-old  obese female presents with pelvic discomfort which has been troubling her for the past 1 week. She also complains of some urinary incontinence for the past month. She has undergone a vaginal hysterectomy 6 months back. Physical examination shows the vaginal vault protruding through the introitus. What is the degree of vault prolapse which is seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario describes a second-degree vault prolapse, as the vaginal vault protrudes through the introitus.

Vault prolapse:

Vault prolapse is a delayed complication of both abdominal and vaginal hysterectomy when the supporting structures at the level I become weak and deficient. It also results from failure to identify and repair an enterocele during a hysterectomy.

Age, estrogen deficiency in a menopausal woman, parity, obesity, and chronic cough may contribute to its occurrence. Clinical features include pelvic pressure, urinary retention/incontinence, fecal urgency/incontinence, and sexual dysfunction. These women usually complain of coital difficulty and difficulty in walking. Backache, urinary and rectal symptoms may exist.

There are 3 degrees of vault prolapse:

  • First degree: The vaginal apex is visible at the introitus
  • Second degree: The vault protrudes through the introitus
  • Third degree: The entire vagina is outside the introitus

Management of Vault prolapse:

  • If the patient is fit for abdominal surgery: Transabdominal sacral colpopexy, i.e., suspending the vault to the sacral promontory extraperitoneally. It is best suited for younger women since coital difficulty following vaginal surgery is avoided
  • If the patient is not fit for abdominal surgery: Right Transvaginal sacrospinous colpopexy. It is usually preferred in obese and elderly women, who are not fit for abdominal surgery.
  • Colpocleisis is permissible if sexual activity is not desired

Related Pearl: Degrees of vault prolapse

  • First degree: The vaginal apex is visible at the introitus
  • Second degree: The vault protrudes through the introitus
  • Third degree: The entire vagina is outside the introitus

questions.text: The bone marrow density along with the gestational age is plotted from two different studies. Which of the following is true for the relation between bone marrow density and gestational age?

choices.text: Strength of correlation is same in A and B
Strength of the correlation is more in A than in B
Strength of the variation is more in B than A
Variation in variables is more with A than B

questions.solution:
The strength of the correlation is more in graph A than in graph B.
 
Graphs A and B show a positive correlation between bone marrow density and gestational age.
 
In graph A: The data points in the scattergram are closer to the line of best fit, indicating a strong correlation. 
 
In graph B: The data points are scattered farther away from the line of best fit, indicating a weak correlation.
 
Therefore, the strength of the correlation is more in graph A than B.

Related Pearl: Correlation

Correlation expresses the strength and direction of the relationship between two variables in terms of a correlation coefficient. It is represented by r.

  • Values of r vary from -1 (perfect negative correlation) to +1 (perfect positive correlation).
  • Value (size) of the coefficient: Indicates the strength of relationship
  • Sign of the coefficient: Indicates direction of relationship

Coefficients between ±0.5 and 1 are regarded as strong whereas those between ±0.5 and 0 are regarded as weak.

The data is plotted in a scattergram as shown in the examples given below

Examples:

Types of correlation coefficients

  1. Pearson coefficient
  2. Spearman coefficient

Coefficient of Determination (CD) =  r2

It is simply the percentage variability in one factor due to change in another variable.

questions.text: A 50-year-old female complains of lower backache. The radiographic image of her lumbosacral spine is given below. Her bone mineral density is measured and the T-score is found to be -2.6. The senior resident is apprehensive of a risk  of vertebral fracture and  started her on a recombinant preparation of parathyroid hormone. Which of the following statements is incorrect regarding this drug?

choices.text: Continuous administration of this drug promotes bone growth
It has to be administered subcutaneously
It  can increase the risk of osteosarcoma

questions.solution:
Teriparatide is a recombinant preparation of parathyroid hormone. Teriparatide increases bone formation especially when given in low doses and intermittently. Continuous administration of PTH or high-circulating PTH levels can cause bone demineralization and osteopenia.

The given clinical scenario with low backpain, a T-score of -2.6, and the above image depicting the ballooning of disc spaces leading to the biconcave shape of the vertebral body known as ‘Codfish appearance’, are suggestive of osteoporosis. Teriparatide can be used in this condition.

Pharmacokinetics and systemic actions of teriparatide on mineral metabolism are the same as for PTH.

Teriparatide increases bone formation especially when given in low doses and intermittently. The pharmacologic activity of teriparatide, which is similar to the physiologic activity of PTH, includes stimulating osteoblast function, increasing gastrointestinal calcium absorption, and increasing renal tubular reabsorption of calcium.

Although it may be more effective than bisphosphonates and estrogen, it has to be administered subcutaneously every day. Hence it is indicated mostly in severe osteoporosis.

Teriparatide can increase the risk of osteosarcoma and it is contraindicated in conditions that cause a high risk of osteosarcoma such as:

  • Paget disease
  • Prior h/o of radiotherapy
  • Young adults with open epiphysis
  • Unexplained elevated ALP
  • Hypercalcemia

Osteoporosis most commonly occurs in postmenopausal women and in old age.

The secondary causes of osteoporosis are:

  • Hypogonadal states: Turner's and Klinefelter's syndrome, Hyperprolactinemia
  • Endocrine disorders: Cushing's syndrome, hyperparathyroidism and hyperthyroidism, diabetes mellitus
  • Haematological disorders: Multiple myeloma, lymphoma and leukaemia, haemophilia, thalassemia
  • Nutritional and gastrointestinal disorders: Malnutrition, parenteral nutrition, malabsorption syndrome, gastrectomy, pernicious anaemia
  • Rheumatologic disorders: Rheumatoid arthritis and ankylosing spondylitis
  • Inherited disorders: 
    • Osteogenesis imperfecta
    • Marfan's syndrome
    • Ehler's Danlos syndrome
    • Hypophosphatasia
  • Prolonged immobilization
  • Pregnancy and lactation

Investigations:

The X-ray would depict ballooning of disc spaces leading to the biconcave shape of the vertebral body known as ‘Codfish appearance’, classically seen in osteoporosis. 

It is caused due to the reduction in the strength of the bone that leads to an increased risk of fractures. WHO defines osteoporosis as a T score of less than -2.5. It is the gold standard to assess bone mineral density.

Other radiological features of osteoporosis:

  • Loss of vertical height of vertebra due to collapse
  • Ground glass appearance of bones especially in the bones like the pelvis
  • Loss of cortical bone (picture frame vertebrae) and trabecular bone (ghost vertebrae)
  • Loss of trabeculae in proximal femur area.

The investigation of choice for the diagnosis of osteoporosis is DEXA - dual-energy X-ray absorptiometry. A T-score <–2.5 in the lumbar spine, femoral neck, or total hip has been defined as osteoporosis.

DEXA measures the bone mineral density of an individual. These measurements are made at the lumbar spine, femoral neck, or hip. In the DEXA technique, two x-ray energies are used to estimate the area of mineralized tissue, and the mineral content is divided by bone area, which partially corrects for body and bone size. But since the method is two dimensional, the correction is not adequate and the BMD(Bone Mineral Density) of small slim people tend to be lower than average BMD. Also, bone spurs, tend to falsely increase bone density especially of the spine and are a particular problem in measuring spine BMD in older individuals with osteoarthritis.

Chemical tests like serum calcium, phosphorus and alkaline phosphatase levels are usually normal. But, osteoblastic and osteoclastic markers in urine & blood can help in diagnosing and monitoring treatment.

Related Pearl: Z-score and T-score for osteoporosis:

Z-score:

It is the number of standard deviations a patient’s BMD(bone mass density) differs from the average BMD of their age, sex, and ethnicity.

A Z-score of -2 or below should trigger investigations for underlying disease.

T-score:

It is the BMD at the site when compared to the young normal reference mean. It is a comparison of a patient’s BMD to that of a healthy 30-year old.

  • Normal is a T-score of -1 or higher.
  • Osteopenia is defined as a T-score between -1.0 and -2.5.
  • Osteoporosis is defined as a T-score less than -2.5, that is a BMD which is two and a half standard deviations below the mean of a 30-year old man/woman.

questions.text: A 48-year-old non-diabetic obese man presented for routine follow-up. Laboratory tests showed dyslipidemia and a vitamin preparation was prescribed to him as a lipid-lowering agent. After two weeks, he developed flushing and pruritis, along with skin irritation. Which of the following statements is incorrect regarding the vitamin implicated in this scenario?

choices.text: Deficiency of this vitamin causes pellagra
It is an important constituent of coenzymes NAD and NADP
60 mg of this dietary vitamin  is equivalent to 1 mg of tryptophan
Involved in ADP-ribosylation of proteins and DNA repair mechanism

questions.solution:
The vitamin used as a lipid-lowering agent is nicotinic acid (niacin or vitamin B3). 1 mg of niacin is equivalent to 60 mg of tryptophan and not vice-versa (option C).

Niacin is a water-soluble B-complex vitamin. It is an important constituent of co-enzymes NAD and NADP which are active in ADP–ribose transfer reactions involved in DNA repair. The liver can synthesize niacin from the essential amino acid tryptophan, requiring 60 mg of tryptophan to make 1 mg of niacin.

Niacin reduces lipolysis by hormone-sensitive lipase (HSL) and reduces hepatic triglyceride synthesis. It causes a reduction in LDL, VLDL, and triglycerides along with an increase in HDL. It is the only lipid-lowering agent that lowers lipoprotein(a) levels significantly.

The toxic effects of niacin include:

  • Flushing, associated with skin dryness, pruritus, paresthesia, and headache. These effects may be seen with even a low dose of 30mg/day. Premedication with aspirin alleviates these symptoms (as these symptoms are mediated by prostaglandins).
  • Nausea, vomiting, and abdominal pain.
  • Hepatic toxicity, which presents as jaundice with elevated AST and ALT levels.
  • Fulminant hepatitis (requires liver transplantation).
  • Glucose intolerance (In patients with diabetes mellitus, niacin should be used cautiously because niacin-induced insulin resistance can cause severe hyperglycemia)
  • Hyperuricemia
  • Macular edema and macular cysts.

Niacin deficiency causes pellagra which presents with diarrhea, dermatitis, dementia, and if untreated, death. Hyperpigmentation and scaly plaques are seen in photo-exposed areas in dermatitis. Casal's necklace is a lesion seen around the neck. Excessive consumption of maize-based diets can also cause pellagra. Corn/Maize has low levels of niacin and tryptophan. 

The below image shows casal's paint necklace seen in niacin deficiency.

questions.text: A 35-year-old lady presented with epistaxis and severe menorrhagia. On clinical examination, there was no splenomegaly or organomegaly.  Her Hb= 5g/dL,  platelet count = 18,000/μL and white blood cell count is 2500/μL. She was advised a hematopoietic stem cell transplantation for this condition. Post transplantation, her family is apprehensive of COVID-19 infection which can pose a risk in her condition, and want her to receive the COVID-19 vaccine immediately. What will you advise the attendants regarding the COVID vaccination in this patient?

choices.text: Give COVID-19 vaccine next day after transplant and monitor complete blood counts
COVID-19 Vaccination is absolutely contraindicated in patients with cancer
Patient should receive COVID-19 vaccination at least 3 months after hematopoietic cell transplantation
Give patient COVID-19 vaccine along with vaccination against encapsulated micro-organisms

questions.solution:
The clinical, laboratory, and bone marrow findings are diagnostic of aplastic anemia. The best method of management is hematopoietic stem cell transplantation. The patient should receive COVID-19 Vaccination at least 3 months after Hematopoietic Cell Transplantation (HCT)/Cellular Therapy, according to the NCCN COVID-19 Vaccination Advisory Committee.

Vaccination should be delayed for at least 3 months following hematopoietic cell transplantation (HCT) or engineered cellular therapy (eg, chimeric antigen receptor [CAR] T cells) to maximize vaccine efficacy.

Graft-versus-host disease (GVHD) and immunosuppressive regimens used to treat GVHD (like systemic corticosteroids and targeted agents) can blunt the immune responses to vaccination.

Delay of vaccination until immunosuppressive therapy is reduced and/or based on immunophenotyping of T-cell and B-cell immunity can be considered.
Patients on maintenance therapies (on drugs like rituximab, Bruton tyrosine kinase inhibitors, Janus kinase inhibitors) may have decreased response to vaccination.

Prioritize patients with active cancer on treatment (including hematopoietic and cellular therapy), those planned to start treatment, and those immediately (<6 months) post-treatment, except those receiving only hormonal therapy. 

Consider additional risk factors for such patients and other factors linked to adverse COVID-19 complications including, but not limited to: 

  • Patients with advanced age (eg, ≥65 years of age) 
  • Patients with comorbidities (eg, chronic pulmonary, cardiovascular, or renal disease) 
  • Social and demographic factors

COVID-19 vaccines should be prioritized over other needed vaccines. Fourteen days are recommended between COVID-19 vaccines and other approved vaccines.

Aplastic anemia is pancytopenia with bone marrow hypocellularity. Patients will present with bleeding, anemia, and rarely infections. Bone marrow biopsy will appear hypocellular with fat occupying the majority of the bone marrow. Hematopoietic stem cell transplantation is the best method of management in young patients. Elderly patients and patients without an HLA matched donor are treated with antithymocyte globulin (ATG) in combination with cyclosporine.

questions.text:
A 60-year-old male patient on cardiopulmonary bypass in the operating room has the capnograph shown below. Physical examination findings are as below and there is noticeable rigidity over the masseter muscle. Which of the following is false about this condition?

Temperature - 101°F

Pulse Rate - 130/min

Blood Pressure - 146/98 mm Hg

Respiratory Rate - 25/min

choices.text: Dantrolene in saline is the treatment

questions.solution:
Capnograph shows a sudden and progressive increase in ETCO2 which is typical of malignant hyperthermia. 

Dantrolene sodium reconstituted in sterile distilled water is the mainstay of therapy for malignant hyperthermia but it is to be reconstituted with sterile distilled water. It is given at a dose of 2.5 mg/kg intravenously and can be repeated every 5-10 minutes (up to 10 mg/kg) till the attack subsides. It must not be reconstituted with saline as it results in reduced strength of the preparation as well as precipitation of insoluble particles in a heterogenous suspension. 

Correction of Electrolyte Imbalances:

  • Administer bicarbonate for metabolic acidosis.
  • Hyperkalemia should be treated with insulin
  • Furosemide may be used to induce diuresis and prevent acute kidney failure.

Other treatment options :

  • All anesthetic agents should be cut off.
  • Hyperventilation with 100% O2.
  • If the body temperature is high, it should be brought down using cold intravenous fluids, cooling body cavities with sterile iced fluids, surface cooling with ice packs, and cooling blankets.

Related Pearl: Various capnography waveforms:

A- Obstructive airway or bronchospasm
B- Expiratory valve malfunctioning
C- Inspiratory valve malfunction
D- Normal physiological variant seen in pregnant subjects under GA
E- Curare cleft
F- Rebreathing
G- Esophageal intubation
H- Spontaneous breathing
I-Dual capnogram in one lung transplantation patient. The first peak in phase III is from the transplanted normal lung, whereas the second peak is from the native disease lung. A variation of dual capnogram (steeple sign capnogram – dotted line) is seen if there is a leak around the sidestream sensor port at the monitor
J- Malignant hyperthermia
K- Classic ripple effect during the expiratory pause showing cardiogenic oscillations
L- Sudden rise of baseline and end-tidal PCO2 (PETCO2) due to contamination of the sensor with secretions or water vapor.
The gradual rise of baseline and PETCO2 occurs when soda lime is exhausted. 
M -Intermittent mechanical ventilation (IMV) breaths in the midst of spontaneously breathing patient.
N -Cardiopulmonary resuscitation: capnogram showing positive waveforms during each compression. 
O-Capnogram showing rebreathing during inspiration. This is normal in rebreathing circuits such as Mapleson D or Bain circuit.

Related Pearl: Malignant hyperthermia key features

Pathophysiology:

  • Prolonged opening of functionally altered ryanodine receptors, leading to uncontrolled release of calcium from the sarcoplasmic reticulum resulting in sustained muscle contraction.

Drugs known to trigger malignant hyperthermia:

  • Inhaled anesthetics: Halothane, Isoflurane, Sevoflurane, Desflurane, Ether, Methoxyflurane
  • Depolarising muscle relaxant: Succinylcholine

Clinical signs:

  • Increased metabolism: Increased EtCO2, decreased SpO2, metabolic acidosis
  • Increased sympathetic activity: Tachycardia, hypertension, arrythmia
  • Muscle damage: Masseter spasm, generalised rigidity, hyperkalemia, rhabdomyolysis, myoglobinuria
  • Hyperthermia: Fever, sweating

 Treatment: 

  • Discontinuation of all anesthetic agents
  • Hyperventilation with 100% O2
  • Dantrolene: 2.5 mg/kg intravenously every 5 min until the episode is terminated (upper limit - 10 mg/kg).
  • Correction of acid-base, electrolyte abnormality 
  • Cooling the patient

questions.text:
A 48-year-old female patient presents with dryness and irritation in eyes and difficulty swallowing solid food. Physical examination finds dental caries, and enlargement of her parotid glands along with marked dryness of her buccal mucosa. Schirmer's test was positive with <5mm in 5min without anesthesia. The histopathology shows focal lymphoplasmacytic infiltration in the minor salivary gland. The indirect immunofluorescence image is given below. Choose the true statements about this condition.

A. Glomerular lesions are frequently seen.

B. Primary biliary cholangitis is most commonly associated with this condition.

C. Patients are at high risk for development of B-cell lymphomas.

D. Laboratory examination finds the presence of both SS-A and SS-B antibodies.
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis considering the clinical history, parotid enlargement, positive Schirmer's test and the centromeric pattern on indirect immunofluorescence is suggestive of Sjogren's syndrome. Statements B, C and D are correct.

Sjögren syndrome:

Lacrimal and salivary glands are the major targets of the disease, respiratory and gastrointestinal tracts and the vagina may also be involved. The characteristic decrease in tears and saliva (sicca syndrome) is the result of lymphocytic infiltration and fibrosis of the lacrimal and salivary glands. Parotid gland enlargement is present in half the patients.

The infiltrate contains predominantly activated CD4+ helper T cells and some B cells, including plasma cells. About 75% of patients have the rheumatoid factor (an antibody reactive with self IgG) whether or not coexisting rheumatoid arthritis is present. ANAs are detected in 50% to 80% of patients by immunofluorescence assay. Antibodies are directed against two ribonucleoprotein antigens, SS-A (Ro) and SS-B (La). Patients with high titers of antibodies to SS-A are more likely to have early disease onset, longer disease duration, and extraglandular manifestations, such as cutaneous vasculitis and nephritis

Glomerular lesions are extremely rare in Sjögren syndrome. Defects of tubular function, however, including renal tubular acidosis, uricosuria, and phosphaturia, are often seen and are associated histologically with tubulointerstitial nephritis.

Patients are at high risk for the development of B-cell lymphomas. About 60% of patients have another accompanying autoimmune disorder, such as rheumatoid arthritis, and these patients also have the symptoms and signs of that disorder

Mikulicz syndrome - Lacrimal and salivary gland enlargement from any cause, including sarcoidosis, lymphoma, and other tumors

Biopsy of the lip (to examine minor salivary glands) is essential for the diagnosis of Sjögren syndrome.

International criteria for diagnosis of Primary Sjogren syndrome requires positivity of 4/6 criteria

  • Ocular symptoms: 1/3 at least (dry eyes, gritty sensation, or usage of teardrops)
  • Oral Symptoms: 1/3 at least (dry mouth, swollen salivary glands, or usage of liquids to aid swallowing)
  • Ocular signs: 1/2 positive at least (Schirmer 1 test - <5mm in 5min without anesthesia, or Rose bengal dye test)
  • Salivary gland involvement: objective evidence shown by one of the following ( total unstimulated salivary flow <1.5ml in 15min, salivary or parotid scintigraphy)
  • Histopathology: focal lymphocytic sialoadenitis in minor salivary glands
  • Anti Ro/La Antibodies in serum 

 

Primary biliary cholangitis (previously called primary biliary cirrhosis) is most commonly associated with sjogren syndrome. Other conditions associated are:

  • Thyroiditis (20%)
  • Scleroderma (5%)
  • Rheumatoid arthritis
  • Raynaud phenomenon
  • Celiac disease

Primary Biliary Cholangitis (PBC)

  • PBC is an autoimmune disease characterized by nonsuppurative, inflammatory destruction of small and medium-sized intrahepatic bile ducts.
  • Large intrahepatic ducts and the extrahepatic biliary tree are not involved.
  • Disease of middle-aged women, with a female predominance of 9:1.
  • Antimitochondrial antibodies are the most characteristic laboratory finding in PBC.

Histology:

  • Florid duct lesion: Lymphoplasmacytic infiltrate with or without granulomas centered around the bile duct (diagnostic)
  • Mallory–Denk bodies

 

Image: Primary biliary cholangitis

The test used for the detection of a specific type of ANA is called indirect immunofluorescence, in which the pattern of nuclear fluorescence suggests the type of antibody present in the patient’s serum.

Four basic patterns are recognized:

  • Homogeneous or diffuse staining of nuclei occurs when antibodies react with dsDNA, nucleosomes, and histones. This is seen in systemic lupus erythematosus.
  • A speckled pattern is seen in the presence of nuclear antigens like Sm and ribonucleoproteins.
  • The centromeric pattern is the characteristic staining of anti-centromere antibodies is seen in some cases of systemic sclerosis and Sjögren syndrome. 
  • The nucleolar pattern is typically seen in cases with antibodies against nucleolar proteins.

questions.text: A 32-year-old man is found to have right-sided colon cancer. His father had similar colon cancer and died at the age of 40. His paternal aunt suffers from endometrial cancer and his paternal uncle also suffers from urothelial cancer. There is no history of familial adenomatous polyposis. Abnormality in which of the following DNA repair mechanisms is responsible for this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Lynch syndrome or hereditary nonpolyposis colorectal cancer (HNPCC) and mismatch repair is the defective DNA repair mechanism here. 

HNPCC is an autosomal dominant genetic condition that is associated with a high risk of colon cancer as well as other cancers including endometrial cancer (second most common), cancers of the stomach, ovary, ureters, etc. It is the most common cause of the syndromic form of colon cancer. Colon cancers are seen at younger ages and usually on the right side.

DNA mismatch repair proteins function as spell checkers during DNA replication by correcting the incorrect pairing. In HNPCC, the proofreading function of the mismatch repair systems (majorly MLH1 and MSH2) is lost leading to the accumulation of errors throughout the genome. The genomes of these patients show microsatellite instability, which is characterized by changes in the length of short repeats.

Other options:

Option A: Defects in the nucleotide excision repair pathway are seen in patients with xeroderma pigmentosum.

Option B: Defects in non-homologous end-joining are seen in patients with subacute combined immunodeficiency syndrome (SCID).

Option C: Defects in DNA base excision repair are seen in patients with MUTYH-associated polyposis (MAP) syndromes. 

Related Pearl: Amsterdam Criteria II - Revised Criteria for HNPCC

The diagnostic criteria for HNPCC are referred to as the Amsterdam criteria or the 3-2-1-0 rule.

It includes the following:

  • Three or more relatives with HNPCC-associated cancer (colorectal cancer, endometrial cancer, cancer of the small bowel, ureter, or renal pelvis), one of whom is a first-degree relative of the other two
  • At least two successive generations affected
  • At least one case diagnosed before the age of 50 years
  • Familial adenomatous polyposis excluded.
  • Tumors verified by pathologic examination.

All of the above must be applicable for a presumptive diagnosis of HNPCC to be made in a family.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman comes to the primary health center to avail of a contraceptive provided under a new government program. She does not want to take daily pills. She was started on the contraceptive shown in the image below.  Which of the following drugs is used in this?
questions.solution:
Injectable contraceptive medroxyprogesterone acetate (MPA) is introduced under the Antara program.

The dosage is 150 mg I.M every 3 months. This injectable contraceptive is not to be refrigerated. It is to be stored always at room temperature (15-30 degree centigrade).

Mechanism of action:

  • Inhibition of ovulation
  • Cervical mucus thickening and thereby preventing sperm penetration
  • Endometrial atrophy preventing implantation.

The first dose can be taken: 

  • Anytime after regular menstruation, or 
  • After 6 weeks of delivery, or 
  • Immediately after abortion

This injectable contraceptive should not be given to a woman with:

  • Unexplained vaginal bleeding 
  • Stroke or severe diabetes
  • Breast cancer (past/present)
  • Active hepatitis or liver tumor
  • A desire for rapid return to fertility

Disadvantages

  • Menstrual irregularities: Light / heavy bleeding or amenorrhoea
  • Slight weight gain
  • No protection against HIV/STDs 
  • A slight loss in BMD during the first 2 years of use

Note:

Antara (Injectable contraceptive DMPA) and Chhaya (oral contraceptive Centchroman) were recently launched by the Government under its Mission Parivar Vikas.

Oral pills:

  • Combined oral contraceptive pills (COC)
    • Mala D - Levonorgestrel 0.15 mg + Ethinyl estradiol  0.03 mg + Ferrous fumarate
    • Mala N - Levonorgestrel 0.15 mg + Ethinyl estradiol  0.03 mg + Ferrous fumarate (Govt. supply, free of cost)
  • Progesterone only pills (POP) - suitable for lactating women
    • Norethisterone 350 μg
    • Norgestrel 75 μg
    • Levonorgestrel (LNG) 30 μg
  • Once a month or long-acting pills - highly disappointing results
    • Quinestrol (long-acting estrogen) + short-acting progesterone
  • Gossypol - male pill : Cottonseed derivative and causes azoospermia and severe oligospermia
  • Post-coital pills or interceptive
    • Levonorgestrel 0.75 mg, 2 doses, 12 hours apart
    • Mifepristone 10-600 mg
    • Ulipristal 30 mg, within 5 days of intercourse
    • Centchroman 60 mg, 2 tablets, within 24 hrs of intercourse

questions.text: A 50-year-old obese man was brought to casualty with complaints of chest pain for the last one hour. He has also had profuse sweating, pain in the left shoulder, nausea and one episode of vomiting. On examination, pulse rate is 50 bpm and BP - 90/60mm Hg. ECG confirms the diagnosis and cardiac troponin levels are elevated. Further evaluation shows that the involved artery runs through the sulcus marked with the red arrow below. Which of the following is true about this patient's ECG findings?

choices.text: ST-segment elevation in V5 and V6
ST-segment elevation in II, III and aVF
ST-segment elevation in V1 and V2
ST-segment elevation in I and aVL

questions.solution:
The given presentation of chest pain, the elevation of cardiac biomarkers, and involvement of the right coronary artery (the arrow in the image point to the coronary sulcus through which the right coronary artery runs) leads to a diagnosis of Inferior wall MI. Atherosclerosis/stenosis of the right coronary artery is causative in 80% of the cases.

The right coronary artery arises from the anterior aortic sinus (right coronary sinus) of the ascending aorta. It passes anteriorly and descends vertically in the coronary sulcus between the right atrium and the right ventricle. On reaching the inferior margin, it turns posteriorly and continues in the sulcus on to the diaphragmatic surface and the base of the heart.

The diameter of the right coronary artery is less than that of the left coronary artery. The right conal artery is, usually the first branch of the right coronary artery.

In the case of inferior wall MI, up to 50% of patients have symptoms of parasympathetic activation (hypotension and bradycardia). It is therefore advised that caution needs to be practiced before prescribing nitrates in these cases, as it may result in worsening of hypotension.

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman presented with a history of bony pain, abdominal cramps, and nausea. She has previously been treated twice for renal calculi. An X-ray revealed the findings shown below. Which of the following is not a characteristic association of this condition?

choices.text: Brown tumours due to excessive osteoclast activity
Cupping and splaying of the metaphysis
Salt and pepper appearance of the skull

questions.solution:
The arrow in the given image points to a brown tumor which is seen in primary hyperparathyroidism. The feature that is not seen in this condition is the cupping and splaying of the metaphysis.

Brown tumors (Osteitis Fibrosa Cystica)

Brown tumors are cystic bone lesions that occur due to excessive osteoclast activity (Option A). Histologically, a collection of osteoclasts and fibrous tissue with accompanying necrosis and hemorrhagic liquefaction is seen. Radiographically, they are seen as multiloculated cysts that may cause the expansion of bones.

Other radiological features of hyperparathyroidism:

  • The classical and pathognomonic feature of hyperparathyroidism is sub-periosteal cortical resorption (Option C) on the radial side of the middle phalanges, seen especially in the second and third fingers. This feature can also be visualized in the lateral end of the clavicle and symphysis pubis. 
  • Loss of lamina dura, the thin cortical bone of tooth socket surrounding teeth is seen as a thin white line
  • Salt and pepper appearance of the skull (Option D) with well-marked stippling of pin head size

The given X-ray of the skull shows multiple radiolucent lytic lesions which are typical of the salt and pepper appearance of the skull seen in hyperparathyroidism. 

  • Chondrocalcinosis on the hand (triangular ligament), the knees (articular cartilage and menisci), and the symphysis pubis.
  • Osteoporosis is seen as reduced radiodensity of the bone- especially in elderly and postmenopausal women.

Note- Cupping and splaying of the metaphysis is a classical feature of rickets that occurs due to deficiency of vitamin D. Some other findings include craniotabes, broadening of long bones, genu valgum, Rachitic rosary, and Harrison's sulcus.

Related Pearl: Radiological Signs of Hyperparathyroidism

Rugger jersey spine: It refers to the prominent hyperdensities at the endplates of successive vertebrae, which mimics the striped appearance of a rugby jersey.

Subperiosteal bone resorption: This is seen on the radial side of the proximal and middle phalanges of the index and middle fingers. It is the most consistent and specific finding of hyperparathyroidism and is virtually pathognomonic of the condition.

Brown tumors / Osteitis fribrosa cystica / Von Recklinghausen's disease of bone: These are composed of pseudotumors that are made up of macrophages, blood, and connective tissue. They are seen as radiolytic areas due to the reduction in the bone trabeculae.                        

Salt and pepper appearance of the skull:  Refers to multiple tiny well-defined lucencies in the calvaria of the skull ( top part of the skull) due to resorption of the trabecular bone. Alternate areas of mineralization (salt-white) and decalcification (pepper-black)

Acral osteolysis: This is also known as the tufting of phalanges

questions.text: A 54-year-old woman presented with painful swelling in the neck a few days after developing a fever, malaise, and generalized body aches.  She complains of tremors, palpitations, and heat intolerance for the past 2 weeks. She is not on any medications or nutritional supplements and has not undergone any imaging or surgical procedures in the past year. On examination, her pulse rate is 110 beats/min. Local examination revealed enlargement of both lobes of the thyroid gland which is extremely tender. TSH level is 0.05 mIU/L, free T4 level is 2.8 ng/dL, and radioiodine uptake was less than 1% at 24 hours. ESR is elevated while the leukocyte count is normal. Biopsy shows the following findings. Which of the following is correct regarding this condition?

choices.text: Hurthle cells are seen in this case

questions.solution:
This patient's symptoms and lab results, suggestive of thyrotoxicosis along with the biopsy findings are characteristic of subacute granulomatous thyroiditis. This condition is transient and resolves, in 2 to 6 weeks, even if the patient is not treated.

This condition is also known as painful subacute thyroiditis, de Quervain thyroiditis, and migratory thyroiditis (this is because the pain can shift to different locations in the thyroid). It is subacute granulomatous thyroiditis that occurs secondary to viral infections.

Many viruses such as mumps, influenza, coxsackie, adenoviruses, and echoviruses have been clinically implicated in this condition. Peak incidence is observed at 30-50 years and women are generally affected three times more often than men.

Histopathology image depends on the stage of the disease. The earlier picture shows the presence of granulomas in the thyroid gland. Aggregates of lymphocytes, activated macrophages, and plasma cells, and damaged thyroid follicles can be seen. Multinucleate giant cells encircle pools of colloid, hence the name granulomatous thyroiditis.

Clinically, it presents as a painfully enlarged thyroid and is sometimes accompanied by fever.

It has three distinct phases:

  • Thyrotoxic phase
  • Hypothyroid phase
  • Recovery phase

There may be raised inflammatory markers, absent thyroid antibodies, serum T4 may be high normal or slightly raised and I123 uptake of the gland is low.

The thyroid hormone levels are increased from the release of the preformed hormone and not from excessive production, and therefore antithyroid medications are not effective. The low iodine uptake and the tenderness of the thyroid confirm the diagnosis of subacute (painful) thyroiditis.

It is treated with large doses of aspirin, NSAIDs, steroids, and/or beta-blockers to relieve the observable clinical symptoms. Antithyroid drugs do not have any role. In case the hypothyroid phase is prolonged - levothyroxine can be used.

Other options: 

Subacute lymphocytic thyroiditis (postpartum thyroiditis) is typically painless. It often occurs after pregnancy and is characterized by lymphocytic inflammation in the thyroid.

Riedel thyroiditis is a rare disorder characterized by a nonpainful, rapidly growing thyroid mass with extensive fibrosis involving the thyroid and contiguous neck structures.

Hashimoto thyroiditis is an autoimmune disease that presents as painless enlargement of the thyroid associated with some degree of hypothyroidism in middle-aged women. Hurthle cells are seen in Hashimoto thyroiditis.

The slide shows the picture of Hashimoto thyroiditis, with

  • Follicular destruction
  • Reduced colloid with increased interstitial connective tissue
  • Small lymphocyte and plasma cell infiltration
  • A well-developed germinal center may be seen
  • Atrophied thyroid follicles, lined by epithelial cells, which contain eosinophilic granular cytoplasm. These epithelial cells are referred to as Hurthle cells.

The histopathological slide given below shows a Psammoma body. They are a product of dystrophic (not metastatic) calcification or of a biologically active process that aims at limiting the growth and spread of a tumor.

Psammoma bodies are associated with papillary histomorphology and are caused by

  1. Infarction and calcification of papillae tips
  2. Calcification of intralymphatic tumor thrombi

  1. Papillary thyroid carcinoma
  2. Papillary renal cell carcinoma
  3. Ovarian papillary serous cystadenocarcinoma
  4. Endometrial adenocarcinoma (Papillary Serous Carcinoma)
  5. Meningiomas
  6. Mesothelioma
  7. Somatostatinoma
  8. Prolactinoma

Psammoma bodies in Benign Conditions:

  1. Endosalpingiosis
  2. Psammomatous melanotic schwannoma
  3. Melanocytic nevus

questions.text: A 50-year-old postman complains of swelling of both his lower limbs. He has a feeling of heaviness in his legs and a burning sensation on the overlying skin. Physical examination reveals the findings seen in the image below. Veins in his lower limb show tortuous dilation. According to the new CEAP classification, which of the following is the correct diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given image is characteristic of atrophie blanche which is classified as C4B under CEAP guidelines.

Atrophie blanche is a localized white atrophic skin frequently surrounded by dilated capillaries and hyperpigmentation, usually seen around the ankle. This is a sign of severe chronic venous disease.

Corona phlebectatica(C4c) are fan-shaped patterns telangiectasia over ankle or foot. Considered an early sign of advanced disease.

Lipodermatosclerosis(C4b) is due to chronic inflammation and fibrosis leading to a tight, contracted, 'woody' leg. Can lead to contractures over the Achilles tendon and is a sign of severe chronic venous disease.

Healed ulcers(C5) are due to chronic venous insufficiency which leads to full-thickness loss of epithelium which may heal over time leading to scarring.

Varicose veins - are tortuous dilatation of veins due to venous insufficiency. It commonly presents as lower limb swelling with a sensation of heaviness, burning, and aching over the affected area or whole limb.

Diagnosis is majorly done using duplex ultrasound and very rarely involves MR venography or intravenous ultrasound(IVUS).

Treatment is achieved using modalities such as compression, laser ablation, endothermal ablation, radiofrequency ablation, endovenous glue, ultrasound-guided foam sclerotherapy, open surgery, etc.

questions.text: An HIV-positive male patient is found to be seropositive for both HBsAg and HBeAg. The consultant adds emtricitabine, a drug with dual antiviral activity, to his treatment card. This drug belongs to which of the following classes of antiviral agents?
questions.solution:
Emtricitabine is a nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitor. It has activity against HIV-1, HIV-2, and hepatitis B viruses (HBV).

Emtricitabine is an FDA-approved drug for treating HIV infection in adults, children, and infants, in combination with other antiretroviral agents. It is also approved for HIV pre-exposure prophylaxis (in combination with tenofovir) in adults with a high risk of acquiring the infection.

It has good oral absorption and can be taken without regard to meals. It is excreted unchanged in the urine and the dose should be reduced in patients with poor renal function.

Emtricitabine is one of the least toxic antiviral drugs. Prolonged exposure can cause hyperpigmentation of the skin, especially in sun-exposed areas. It should not be abruptly discontinued in HBV patients as it can lead to a rebound of HBV replication and exacerbation of hepatitis.

questions.text: A 4-year-old boy develops bloody diarrhea and abdominal cramps. The bacteria isolated from the stool specimen fermented lactose and produced colorless colonies on sorbitol MacConkey agar. The most likely etiological agent in this case is?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a boy with bloody diarrhea and abdominal cramps with the isolated bacteria fermenting lactose and forming colorless colonies on sorbitol MacConkey agar is suggestive of infection by Shiga toxin-producing E. coli (STEC) O157: H7, also known as Enterohemorrhagic E. coli (EHEC).

O157: H7 is the most common type of Shiga toxin-producing E. coli (STEC). Unlike most other E. coli serotypes, the STEC O157: H7 does not use sorbitol and produces clear colonies on the Sorbitol MacConkey agar. The non-STEC produces pink colonies. All species of E. coli are lactose fermenters and produce pink colonies.

They produce two antigenic forms of the cytotoxic toxin known as Shiga-like toxin 1 and Shiga-like toxin 2. Shiga-like toxin 1 is identical to the Shiga toxin of Shigella dysenteriae type 1. E. coli O157:H7 has a small infective dose (around 100 bacilli) and spreads easily from child to child by the feco-oral route.

It can cause mild non-bloody diarrhea to hemorrhagic colitis, or a severe form of diarrhea, with hemolytic uremic syndrome, a disease resulting in acute renal failure, microangiopathic hemolytic anemia, and thrombocytopenia. The most common cause of hemolytic uremic syndrome in the world is E.coli O157:H7. The most common cause of hemolytic uremic syndrome in India is Shigella dysenteriae type I.

Other options:

Option A: Campylobacter is a slender, spirally curved, gram-negative bacillus. They grow at a slower rate and thus require selective media containing antibiotics like Skirrow's media for culture.

Option B: Yersinia enterocolitica causes diarrhea with symptoms resembling appendicitis (pseudoappendicitis). The patients present with abdominal pain which can be localized to the right iliac fossa, thus mimicking appendicitis. Additionally, it is a non-lactose fermenter.

Option D: Shigella dysenteriae type 1 can produce the Shiga toxin and result in a clinical profile similar to EHEC. But Shigella is a non-lactose fermenting organism, unlike E. coli, and will form pale colonies on MacConkey agar. 

Enterobacteriaceae family is classified based on their action on lactose present in MacConkey's medium as,

Late lactose fermenters

Salmonella, Shigella, Proteus

questions.text: A 23-year-old farm worker from a remote village is brought to the hospital following a snake bite at 5 in the morning. The patient complained of headache, blurred vision, tingling sensation around the mouth, dizziness, and vertigo, and had multiple episodes of vomiting since the bite. The patient appears very apprehensive and the pulse rate is 98/min. The local wound showed mild swelling and blistering. There are no apparent bleeding manifestations. After an hour, the manifestation shown in the image was seen, The patient also developed respiratory failure for which mechanical ventilation was initiated. Which of the following snakes is most likely to be implicated in this scenario?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario given above with ptosis (drooping of the left eyelid), is suggestive of a common krait bite which is neurotoxic and can cause neurotoxicity with features described as above and muscle paralysis. The local reaction is generally mild.

Clinical features of Bites of Elapidae (Cobras, Kraits, Mambas, Coral Snakes) present in a similar pattern. The local bite reaction is generally mild with minimal swelling, blistering or superficial necrosis. However their neurotoxic effects are prominent and early symptoms usually include vomiting, hypersalivation, headache, the heaviness of the eyelids, blurred vision, tingling sensation around the mouth, hyperacusis, dizziness, vertigo, and ‘gooseflesh’.


Paralysis is first present as ptosis and external ophthalmoplegia, which may appear between a few minutes after the bite or after some hours. Later, the face, palate, jaws, tongue, neck muscles, and muscles involved in swallowing can become paralyzed. Respiratory failure can occur due to airway obstruction at this stage or later due to paralysis of intercostal muscles and diaphragm. Neurotoxicity effects are completely reversible in response to antivenom or anticholinesterase or they may wear off spontaneously in about a week.

 

Venom Ophthalmia

‘Spitting’ by Elapids can produce venom ophthalmia. It can present as intense pain in the eyes, blepharospasm, palpebral edema, and leucorrhea. Sometimes, venom is absorbed into the anterior chamber causing hypopyon and anterior uveitis.

Other options:

Bites by Viperidae like Saw scaled viper, Russell viper, or Pit Viper usually produce more severe local effects. Hemostatic abnormalities are characteristic. Persistent bleeding from the wound site where fangs have punctured, venipuncture, or injection sites suggest abnormality in blood coagulability. Spontaneous systemic hemorrhage, gingival bleeding, epistaxis, hematemesis, hemoptysis, subconjunctival, retroperitoneal, and intracranial hemorrhages can be seen.

Direct myocardial damage can also occur, seen as an abnormal ECG or cardiac arrhythmia. Renal failure is the major cause of death. Loin pain in a patient with Russell's viper bite suggests renal ischemia.

Marine or sea snake- bites can cause headache, tongue swelling, thirst, sweating, and vomiting. Generalized aches, stiffness, and tenderness of the muscles can occur along with trismus which is a common feature. Later, there is generalized flaccid paralysis as in elapid neurotoxicity. Myoglobinuria usually occurs after some hours of the bite. Myoglobin and potassium released from damaged skeletal muscles can cause renal failure, while hyperkalemia may lead to cardiac arrest.

questions.text: On examination of a dead body, the forensic medical officer-in-charge notices the following finding. What will be his inference in this case?
questions.solution:
The image shows postmortem hypostasis.

Postmortem hypostasis/ postmortem staining/ postmortem lividity/ livor mortis/ Suggillation refers to purple or reddish-purple discoloration of the skin due to the collection of blood in toneless capillaries in dependent parts of the body. The margins are clearly defined and there is no swelling or abrasion.

Fixation of hypostasis occurs 6-12 hours after death. It occurs earlier in summer and is delayed in asphyxial deaths and in intracranial lesions.  

The timeline for development of postmortem staining:

  • Mottled patches– 1-3 hours following the death
  • Uniform area of staining– 3-6 hours following the death
  • Fully developed and fixation of hypostasis– 6-12 hours following the death

Other options:

Option A: The image below shows postmortem lividity with bright cherry red discoloration seen in carbon monoxide poisoning.

Option C: Postmortem marbling occurs due to the hemolysis of the blood in the vessels, which stains the vessel walls and the adjacent tissues, giving rise to a marbled appearance. The marbling of the skin becomes prominent in about 36–48 hours after death in summer and is distinctly appreciable in the superficial veins of the abdomen, shoulders, chest, and inguinal region.

Option D: Adipocere, also called corpse wax, grave wax, or mortuary wax, is a wax-like organic substance formed by the anaerobic hydrolysis of fat in tissue by bacteria. It forms under warm and humid weather due to the hydrolysis of lipids. It has a whitish or yellowish appearance and has a distinctive offensive or sweetish smell.

questions.text: A 5-day old infant is being evaluated for an enlarged clitoris and a partially fused labia.  The infant was delivered by normal vaginal delivery and the mother had an uneventful antenatal course. Vitals show that the infant is markedly hypertensive.  Laboratory investigations show Na+ = 155mEq/L and K+ = 2mEq/L. The hormone responsible for these lab abnormalities and hypertension is released by which layer of the gland shown in the histopathological image?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette depicts a case of 11 hydroxylase deficiency. 11 hydroxylase deficiency leads to an excess of 11-deoxycorticosterone. The zona glomerulosa depicted by layer "A", secretes 11-deoxycorticosterone and other mineralocorticoids, responsible for electrolyte abnormalities and hypertension.

The deficiency in 11-hydroxylase leads to an excess of 11-deoxycorticosterone which is a mild mineralocorticoid and is an intermediate in aldosterone synthesis. Additionally, this leads to a decrease in glucocorticoids and an increase in testosterone. 11 hydroxylase deficiency presents as ambiguous genitalia in girls, fluid and salt retention, and hypertension. 

The zona glomerulosa is a thin layer of cells that lies just underneath the capsule of the adrenal gland. 

The adrenal cortex has three zones. From outer to inner, they are:

  • Zona glomerulosa: Secretes mineralocorticoids (Aldosterone) - increase leads to hypertension and salt retention with loss of potassium. Only these symptoms are tested in this question
  • Zona fasiculata: Secretes glucocorticoids (Cortisol) - decrease leads to hypoglycemia
  • Zona reticularis: Secreted sex steroids(dehydroepiandrosterone and androstenedione) - increased leads to an enlarged clitoris and ambiguous genitalia in females and precocious puberty in males.

The adrenal medulla secreted catecholamines. 

Angiotensin II regulates zona glomerulosa while ACTH regulates zona fasiculata and zona retucularis.

Labels:

A – Zona Glomerulosa (Just underneath the eosinophilic connective tissue) – Aldosterone synthesis is limited to this layer

B – Zona Fasciculata (in between zona glomerulosa and reticularis) – enzymatic mechanisms for both cortisol and sex hormones present

C – Zona Reticularis (Cells arranged in the form of irregular cords giving rise to the reticular pattern) – enzymatic mechanisms for both cortisol and sex hormones present

D – Adrenal Medulla – Produces Catecholamines: Norepinephrine, Epinephrine, and Dopamine

The outer Zona glomerulosa is identified by small, compact cells, the central zona fasciculata is characterized by larger lipid-rich cells arranged in radial columns and the inner zona reticularis by pigmented, compact cells.  

The adrenal medulla consists of a thin layer of large chromaffin cells, which synthesise, store and secrete catecholamines.
