questions.text: A patient came to the hospital in an agitated state and on examination, his BP was 98/66 mm Hg and respiratory rate was 28/min. He is a chronic asthma patient who has been on theophylline for a long time. His medical history shows the addition of a few new drugs 4 weeks ago for his other ailments like chronic gout, cough and peptic ulcer disease. Identify the drug which does not seem responsible for his present condition.
questions.solution:
Rifampicin is not responsible for this patient's agitation and low blood pressure as it increases theophylline's clearance by enzyme induction.

Theophylline is mainly metabolized by CYP1A2 in the liver and these drugs- erythromycin, cimetidine, and allopurinol inhibit CYP1A2, thereby decreasing the clearance of theophylline leading to agitation and hypotension. A dose reduction of theophylline may be necessary with these drugs.

Factors that decrease the clearance of theophylline are:

  • Drugs - erythromycin, cimetidine, ciprofloxacin, allopurinol, fluvoxamine, zileuton, zafirlukast
  • Congestive heart failure
  • Liver disease
  • Pneumonia
  • Viral infection and vaccination
  • High-carbohydrate diet
  • Old age

Factors that Increase the clearance of theophylline are:

  • Enzyme induction (mainly CYP1A2) by coadministered drugs (e.g. rifampicin, barbiturates, ethanol)
  • Smoking (tobacco, marijuana) via CYP1A2 induction
  • High-protein, low-carbohydrate diet
  • Barbecued meat.

Agitation and hypotension occur at concentrations > 25 micrograms/ml, while delirium occurs when levels rise to> 30 micrograms/ml. Arrhythmias and convulsions occur at concentrations of theophylline >35 microgram/ml.

questions.text: A 40-year-old diabetic woman is on an anti-arrhythmic drug after she had ventricular fibrillation 3 months back. During her routine diabetic workup, the ophthalmological examination shows corneal findings as in the image. Which of the following statements is incorrect regarding the drug implicated in this condition?

choices.text: It is contraindicated in a patient with interstitial lung disease
It belongs to the same class of drugs as propafenone
The most common cutaneous side effect is photosensitivity

questions.solution:
A bilateral whorl-like corneal pattern of golden-brown lines, as shown in the above image, is called vortex keratopathy (corneal verticillata). Corneal verticillata is observed with the use of amiodarone. Amiodarone is a Class III anti-arrhythmic drug whereas propafenone is a class IC antiarrhythmic.

Amiodarone is classified as a class III antiarrhythmic agent. It exerts its function through various mechanisms:

  • Blockade of the transient outward delayed rectifier and inward rectifier K+ currents mainly
  • Blockade of inactivated Na+ channels with a rapid rate of recovery
  • Decreases Ca2+ current
  • Inhibition of cell-to-cell coupling, thus decreasing conduction velocity

Ventricular tachycardia and recurrent ventricular fibrillation are the most important indications for amiodarone. It is also used to maintain sinus rhythm in atrial fibrillation when other drugs have failed.

Amiodarone is known to cause multiple side effects. Photosensitivity in the form of blue-grey discoloration occurs in body areas that are exposed to the sun, as shown in the image below. The most serious side effect is pulmonary fibrosis, which can progress rapidly and be fatal. Hypo- and hyperthyroidism can also occur during chronic amiodarone therapy. Amiodarone is a blocker of CYP3A4 and CYP2C9, and thus, dose modifications of concurrent drugs may be required.

 

Other causes of vortex keratopathy include:

  • Amiodarone
  • Chloroquine and hydroxychloroquine
  • Fabry disease

questions.text: A 53-year-old male patient presents to the ENT clinic with a history of chronic ear discharge in his right ear for the last 2 months. The discharge is persistent and purulent and he has also noticed some hardness of hearing in the right ear. On examination, there is whitish ear discharge filling the ear. There is no pain on manipulation of the ear canal and no erythema or edema is noted. There is a large marginal perforation of the tympanic membrane. There is a retraction pocket cholesteatoma that occupies the pars flaccida of the tympanic membrane. This patient is planned for surgical management of his condition. What kind of endaural incision should be placed to perform the procedure?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette describes a case of atticoantral CSOM. The given incision is Lempert's endaural incision. It is done for modified radical mastoidectomy when disease is limited to atticoantral part of mastoid.

Endaural approach is made through Lempert’s incision. It consists of two parts:

Lempert I: It is a semicircular incision, made from 12 o’clock to 6 o’clock position in the posterior meatal wall at the bony-cartilaginous junction.

Lempert II: Starts from the first incision at 12 o’clock and then passes upwards in a curvilinear fashion between tragus and the crus of helix. It passes through the incisura terminalis and thus does not cut the cartilage.

Both mastoid and external canal surgery can be done.

Atticoantral type of CSOM:

  • Also called the unsafe or dangerous type with high risk of complications (intra and extracranial)
  • Involves the posterosuperior part of the cleft (attic, antrum and mastoid)
  • Associated with an attic or marginal perforation
  • There may be a bone-eroding process such as a cholesteatoma, granulations or osteitis
  • Clinical features:
    • Patients usually present with chronic purulent ear discharge which may be persistent or intermittent
    • Hearing loss, which may be moderate to severe may be present in most patients
    • No ear pain, fever or dizziness 
    • Physical exam will reveal purulent ear discharge filling the ear canal and a perforation of the TM
    • Cholesteatoma may be visible
    • If the middle ear mucosa is visible, it could be edematous or polypoid

Other options:

Kocher incision (Option 1) is a subcostal incision on the right side of the abdomen for exposure of the gall bladder and the biliary tree.

Wilde's incision (Option 2) is a post-aural incision used for a variant mastoiditis drainage.

Chevron incision (Option 3) is also a subcostal incision that extends from mid to lateral costal ridge, across the midline to the contralateral side. This approach provide exposure for hepatic, pancreatic, upper gastrointestinal region, adrenal, or renal surgeries.

questions.text: A 76-year-old retired worker from a granite quarry presents with progressive dyspnea and a chronic cough. He has never smoked cigarettes. His chest X-ray is shown below. Which of the following patterns would you see on his pulmonary function tests?
questions.solution:
The chest X-ray shows calcification of the hilar lymph nodes called eggshell calcification. The clinical scenario along with the chest X-ray is suggestive of silicosis. It is a restrictive lung disease characterized by increased FEV1/FVC and decreased compliance.

It is an occupational interstitial lung disease.

questions.text:
A 30-year-old male comes to the clinic with a history of fatigue and one episode of syncope following strenuous exercise. Physical examination reveals a diffuse, forceful apical impulse, a fourth heart sound, and a high pitch crescendo-decrescendo, mid-systolic murmur at the lower left sternal border. ECHO shows significant LVOT obstruction. Which of the following statements is true about this condition?

1. The murmur decreases on sustained handgrip
2. Nifedipine may be used for treatment
3. The murmur decreases on standing up from squatting position
4. Metoprolol can be used in symptomatic patients
questions.solution:
This patient with a history of syncope after exercise has a characteristic murmur of hypertrophic cardiomyopathy. This patient's murmur will decrease with increased handgrip and metoprolol is the first-line of management for symptomatic patients. 

Symptoms:

  • Dyspnea on exertion
  • Fatigue
  • Atypical or anginal chest pain
  • Syncope or presyncope, during or after exertion
  • Palpitations

The physical findings seen in HCM are:

  • Normal first sound. The second heart sound may have a paradoxical split if there is a severe LVOT obstruction
  • A third or fourth heart sound may be heard in younger individuals
  • The carotid pulse will have a brisk upstroke
  • The JVP will have a prominent 'a' wave
  • Diffuse, forceful apical impulse
  • Harsh crescendo-decrescendo murmur that begins after S1 and is best heard at the apex or lower left sternal border
    • This murmur increases in intensity on assuming an upright posture from squatting, sitting or supine position, Valsalva maneuver and following the administration of nitroglycerin.
    • The murmur decreases in intensity when going to a sitting or squatting position from standing, with handgrip and passive elevation of the legs
  • A systolic thrill at the apex or the lower left sternal border
  • A parasternal lift in case of mitral regurgitation or pulmonary hypertension

Acute hemodynamic collapse in HCM is precipitated by events that increase the outflow obstruction:

  • Decreased preload due to dehydration, diuretics or an acute reduction in blood volume
  • Decreased afterload due to administration of vasodilators
  • SVT, AF, or sinus tachycardia
  • Acute MR due to flail leaflets or endocarditis

Diagnosis:

  • ECG findings: Prominent abnormal 'Q' waves in the inferior and lateral leads, 'P' wave abnormalities, left axis deviation and deeply inverted 'T' waves in V2-V4 (in patient with the apical variant)
  • ECHO findings: LV hypertrophy, systolic anterior motion of the mitral valve leaflet, LVOT obstruction

The management options in patients with HCM:

  • Beta-blockers
  • Non-dihydropyridine calcium channel blockers
  • Disopyramide

Drugs to be avoided in patients with significant LVOT obstruction: 

  • Dihydropyridine calcium channel blockers
  • Nitroglycerin
  • Angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors, ARBs
  • Diuretics

questions.text:
A 50-year-old man working in a nuclear power plant is brought to the emergency room with nausea, vomiting, severe abdominal cramps, and diarrhea. What dose of radiation is he likely to have been exposed to?
Lab Investigation Value
Na 127
K 2.5
HCO3 18
BUN/Cr Ratio 30
questions.solution:
This patient with nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, and abdominal cramps, has gastrointestinal manifestations of acute radiation toxicity. Gastrointestinal radiation syndrome occurs after exposure to more than 600 rads of radiation.

Acute radiation syndrome is characterized by three main presentations: hematopoietic, gastrointestinal, and neurological/vascular.

  • Hematopoietic: This syndrome is marked by aplastic anemia. This occurs at 0.7 Gy (70 rads) or higher. This may result in infections, bleeding, anemia due to few red blood cells in the circulation. Lymphopenia generally develops within 6-24 hours of exposure and worsens over the next 48 hours. Neutrophils reach their nadir about one week after exposure. Platelets are relatively radioresistant. 
  • Gastrointestinal: This syndrome often follows absorbed doses of 6-7 Gy (600–1000 rad). The signs and symptoms include nausea, vomiting, loss of appetite, and abdominal pain. This early phase is followed by a latent phase (5-7 days) during which symptoms are not apparent. The manifest illness stage is characterized by severe diarrhea leading to dehydration and electrolyte imbalances as seen in this patient. Other effects include malabsorption, ulceration, and necrosis of the bowel wall, infection, and sepsis. These effects are compounded by the hematopoietic syndrome which further compromises immunity.
  • Cardiovascular/Neurologic: This syndrome typically occurs at absorbed doses greater than 50 Gy (5000 rads), though it may occur at 10 Gy (1000 rad). It presents with neurological symptoms such as dizziness, headache, or decreased level of consciousness, occurring within minutes to a few hours, and with an absence of vomiting. Physical examination may show papilledema, ataxia, and loss of reflexes. It is invariably fatal.

questions.text: A 28-year-old severely agitated male is brought to the emergency with chest pain with a suspected drug overdose.  On examination, he is diaphoretic, tachycardic, and tachypneic. His BP is 170/96 mmHg and his temperature is 101F. His pupils are bilaterally dilated and he states that he has a feeling of ants crawling over him. What is the drug of choice to manage the chest pain and agitation in the suspected drug overdose?
questions.solution:
The probable drug overdose that should be suspected in this patient is cocaine. Benzodiazepines are the first-line for the management of cocaine intoxication.

The clinical features of agitation, diaphoresis, tachycardia, and tachypnea, raised BP, tactile hallucinations and fever are all in favor of the diagnosis of a cocaine overdose in this patient. 

Benzodiazepines(ex diazepam 5 - 10 mg IV every 3 - 5 minutes until symptoms are controlled) are used in the management of acute cocaine intoxication to treat chest pain, agitation, or seizures.

Rapid urine screening tests for benzoylecgonine is a highly specific test used for cocaine overdose screening.

 

Other options:

Option C. Beta-blockers are contraindicated in acute overdose until cocaine is eliminated from the body.

Option A  - Naloxone is drug of choice for opioid intoxication.

questions.text: A 50-year-old male patient is undergoing perioperative risk assessment for bariatric surgery. His BMI is 42 kg/m2. On physical examination, his pulse rate is 74/minute, blood pressure 150/90 mm Hg, and respiratory rate is 17/minute. He has a history of hypertension on medications, chronic hepatitis C, and a myocardial infarction (MI) 6 months ago. His ECG strip is shown below. What is his American Society of Anaesthesiologists (ASA) classification?
questions.solution:
The image shows an ECG strip taken from a patient with an implanted ventricular pacemaker.

The cardinal manifestation of pacing on a surface ECG is the stimulation artifact. In ventricular pacing, the vertical pacing spike will precede the QRS complex. Ventricular pacing also yields a wide QRS complex with an LBBB pattern.

This patient has a BMI >=40 kg/m2, hypertension on medications, chronic hepatitis C, a history of MI 6 months ago (> 3 months), and a pacemaker, which places him in the category of ASA III.
ASA grading is a physical status examination that strongly correlates with the perioperative risk.

questions.text: A 20-year-old man presents with muscle pain, early fatigue, painful cramps, and cola-colored urine after joining a gym. The muscle biopsy reveals the findings shown in the slide below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A clinical scenario of a 20-year-old presenting with muscle cramps, pain, fatigue, and likely myoglobinuria (causing cola-colored urine), and muscle biopsy specimen showing vacuolar myopathy is suggestive of McArdle's disease. It is caused by the deficiency of muscle glycogen phosphorylase. 

McArdle disease, also known as type V glycogen storage disorder, is an autosomal recessive condition. It typically presents during late childhood or in the second decade of life. The muscle glycogen phosphorylase enzyme deficiency interferes with ATP generation by glycogenolysis in the muscles. This causes muscle glycogen accumulation.

Symptoms are exercise intolerance associated with muscle cramps. Due to high-intensity exercise, sudden persistent muscle contraction occurs. This leads to severe muscle damage resulting in a massive release of muscle proteins and myoglobin in the blood. Myoglobinuria secondary to rhabdomyolysis leads to the passage of burgundy-colored urine in some patients. 

A unique feature associated with McArdle is the improvement in symptoms after a rest for a few minutes. This is termed as the second wind phenomenon. 

Standard diagnosis includes muscle biopsy, which shows periodic acid Schiff (PAS)-positive vacuoles of high glycogen content due to lack of myophosphorylase and genetic testing (PYGM gene sequencing). Avoiding strenuous exercise prevents symptoms. Glucose administration before exercise can improve tolerance. Vitamin B6 is also recommended.

Other options:

Option B: Cori's disease is due to the deficiency of glycogen debranching enzyme. Infants usually present with ketotic hypoglycemia, hepatomegaly, and hyperlipidemia. Muscle weaknesses are mostly seen in the third to the fourth decade of life. 

Option C: Hers disease is due to the deficiency of liver glycogen phosphorylase. Untreated children present with poor growth, ketotic hypoglycemia, and hepatomegaly.

Option D: Andersen disease is due to the deficiency of glycogen branching enzyme. Infants present with failure to thrive, hepatomegaly, progressive liver cirrhosis, and cardiomyopathy. Death occurs mostly by the age of 5 due to liver failure.

questions.text: A 20-year-old male patient diagnosed with treatment-resistant schizophrenia has been started on clozapine. Which of the following is the most serious side effect of this medication?
questions.solution:
The most serious side effect of clozapine is agranulocytosis. 

Clozapine is an atypical anti-psychotic drug that acts via D4 receptors and 5­HT2 as well as α adrenergic block. It is only used in treatment-resistant schizophrenia. 

Other side effects of clozapine include diabetes, weight gain, sedation, hypersalivation, fever, tachycardia, and postural hypotension. Seizures are more common with clozapine than with other antipsychotic drugs. 

Other options:

Option A - Corneal & lenticular deposits are seen with chlorpromazine which is a typical antipsychotic. 

Option B - Prolongation of QT is seen with ziprasidone which is an atypical antipsychotic. 

Option C - Extrapyramidal side effects are less common with clozapine, but more frequently seen with typical antipsychotics. They are acute dystonia, tardive dyskinesia, akathisia, neuroleptic malignant syndrome etc.

First-generation antipsychotics are generally not preferred due to the higher risk of extrapyramidal side effects/ tardive dyskinesia.

Second-generation antipsychotics are preferred drugs:

  • Risperidone
  • Olanzapine
  • Quetiapine
  • Aripiprazole
  • Ziprasidone
  • Paliperidone

Benzodiazepines can be added to treat associated agitation. It is the drug of choice for catatonia.

Special situations:

  • Emergency: Use a short-acting intramuscular agent such as haloperidol, fluphenazine, olanzapine, or ziprasidone.
  • Chronic compliance: Long-acting injectable is used.
  • Treatment resistance (2 failed trials): Consider Clozapine.
  • All meds ineffective: May consider ECT.

questions.text: A 25-year-old female and her 26-year-old husband present for infertility assessment. They have been unable to conceive despite >1 year of regular unprotected intercourse. As a first step male infertility is tested. The husband has normal vitals and his physical examination is unremarkable. A Miller–Kurzrok test for studying the sperm's penetration through normal cervical mucous is performed. It is considered abnormal if penetration is less than ____ cm at 30 minutes
questions.solution:
Penetration less than 3 cm at 30 min is considered abnormal.

  • Miller Kurzrok test is one of the special tests in semen analysis to diagnose the cause of infertility.
  • The Kurzrok–Miller test is an in vitro test of sperm–mucus interaction. It consists of establishing an interface between cervical mucosa and liquefied semen. It is one of the tests used for investigating infertility.

Procedure: It consists of placing ovulation mucus on a glass slide alongside the specimen of the husband’s semen and studying the penetration of sperms under the microscope. Normal cervical mucus permits invasion by motile sperms. Penetration less than 3 cm at 30 min is abnormal.

Other special tests in semen analysis:

  • Sperm penetration test: A normal sperm is capable of penetrating the zona-free hamster egg, showing its fertilizing capacity. The test is expensive and not reliable.
  • Semen–cervical mucus contact test: Equal quantity of semen and mucus is mixed so that there is no interface. In the presence of antibodies, more than 25% of sperms show jerky or shaky movements by 30 min. Later it is then cross-checked with the donor semen to know the source of antibodies i.e. whether it is cervical or seminal antibodies
  • Postcoital test (Sims’ or Huhner’s test, PCT):
    • Here the couple is advised to have intercourse close to the ovulation time, preferably in the early hours of the morning. The woman presents herself at the clinic within 2 h after the intercourse. The mucus is aspirated from the cervical canal and spread over a glass slide.
    • Another smear made from the posterior fornix serves as a control. Normally 10–50 motile sperms are seen per high-power field in cervical mucus.

questions.text: A 48-year-old male from a rural district presents to the clinic with severe pain during and after defecation. The pain has been present for the past 6 months but has increased in severity recently and reached maximal intensity 3 days back. Inspection of the rectum shows a bulging purple mass as shown below. Rectal examination was difficult to perform because of pain, but no other masses could be palpated. How will you manage this patient?
questions.solution:
The clinical features and the image are suggestive of thrombosed external hemorrhoids. If the patient presents to the hospital after 72 hours, then it is treated conservatively with analgesics and a Sitz bath. Once the symptoms come down, definitive surgery is performed. 

Patients who present within 72 hours of thrombosis are treated with excision(option D). This procedure involves the removal of the clot with an elliptical incision on the skin.

Four degrees of hemorrhoids:

First degree – bleed only, no prolapse

Second degree – prolapse but reduce spontaneously

Third-degree – prolapse and have to be manually reduced

Fourth degree – permanently prolapsed

Treatment of Hemorrhoids:

  • Grade1, grade 2, and some grade 3 hemorrhoids with only an internal component can be treated with simple procedures like rubber band ligation, sclerotherapy, infrared and laser coagulation, and cryotherapy.
  • Surgery is indicated in: 
    • Internal grade 3 or grade 4 hemorrhoids
    • Hemorrhoids with a significant external component
    • Early grade piles not responding to office procedures
  • Surgical procedures used in the removal of hemorrhoids are:
    • Open (Milligan–Morgan) hemorrhoidectomy: resection of hemorrhoidal tissue and wounds are left open and allowed to heal by secondary intention.
    • Closed (Ferguson) hemorrhoidectomy: involves resection of hemorrhoidal tissue and closure of the wounds with absorbable suture
    • Stapled hemorrhoidopexy
    • Doppler-guided hemorrhoidal artery ligation
    • Other options:

Sitz bath - involves sitting in a bath of water that contains salt or sodium bicarbonate. Image is shown below

Option A and C - Hemorrhoidectomy - it is indicated for hemorrhoids complicated by fissures, fistulae, ulceration and strangulation. Also for symptomatic external hemorrhoids.

Incision is not recommended as it may lead to complications such as rethrombosis.

Below is an image showing the two types of hemorrhoids.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man is brought by his family with complaints that he is seeing children run in the room who do not exist. He has also been reprimanded at work for not completing his assignments. He has a flat affect and utters several inappropriate words while talking. His family says that they had first noticed the change in his personality 7 months back. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination is unremarkable. Decreased activity in which of the following pathways is associated with his flat affect?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette describes a case of Schizophrenia. Decreased activity of the mesocortical pathway is responsible for the negative symptoms of schizophrenia.

Important dopaminergic pathways are:

  • Mesolimbic pathway - Increased activity responsible for positive symptoms of schizophrenia.
  • Mesocortical pathway - Decreased activity responsible for negative symptoms of schizophrenia.
  • Nigrostriatal pathway - Decreased activity causes extrapyramidal symptoms. Degeneration of this is responsible for Parkinson's disease.
  • Tuberoinfundibular pathway - Decreased activity causes an increase in prolactin.

Diagnostic criteria for schizophrenia (DSM V):

The DSM-5 criteria to diagnose schizophrenia require a total duration of 6 months. Within these 6 months, there must be at least 1 month of active-phase symptoms (overt psychotic symptoms) where 2 or more of the following have to be present : 

a.Delusion

b.Hallucination

c.Disorganized speech (or formal thought disorder)

d.Disorganized behavior

e.Affective flattening or other negative symptoms


At least one must be among the a, b, or c.

questions.text: A 23-year-old male from Andhra Pradesh presented with features of cervical stenosis and a strikingly noticeable genu-valgum. The radiograph of his forearms appears as given below. Personal history reveals his staple diet as jowar. How would this diet affect the fluoride levels in his body to cause this presentation?

choices.text: High fluoride levels by inhibiting urinary excretion
Low fluoride levels by promoting urinary excretion
High fluoride levels by increasing ingested fluoride retention
Low fluoride levels by decreasing ingested fluoride retention

questions.solution:
The given history of Genu valgum and the image showing interosseous membrane ossification is characteristic of fluorosis. It is seen in people consuming jawar(sorghum), as it promotes greater retention of ingested fluoride.

Fluorosis is seen with corresponding levels of fluoride intake:

  • Dental fluorosis: 1.5mg/L
  • Skeletal fluorosis: 3-6mg/L
  • Crippling fluorosis: >10mg/L

Fluorosis stimulates osteoblastic activity, fluorapatite crystals are laid down in bone and these are usually resistant to secondary osteoclastic resorption. This leads to calcium retention, osteosclerosis, and osteophytosis. Ossification of ligaments and fascial attachments is characteristic.

This leads to impaired mineralization and secondary hyperparathyroidism.

The characteristic pathology involves sub-periosteal new bone formation, osteosclerosis (most commonly seen in vertebrae, ribs, and pelvis), and hyperostosis at the bony attachments of ligaments, tendons, and fascia. 

Ossification of the posterior longitudinal ligament can also be seen, usually after the age of 50 years. It is associated with various bone-forming conditions such as diffuse idiopathic skeletal hyperostosis (DISH) and fluorosis. It is most commonly seen in the cervical spine.  It can result in spinal stenosis and cervical myelopathy causing pain and weakness in the limbs. X-ray shows dense ossification along the back of the vertebral bodies in the mid-cervical spine. 

Note: Nalgonda technique is used for defluoridation which involves the addition of lime and alum followed by flocculation, sedimentation, and filtration.

questions.text:
A 19-year-old girl is brought to the clinic for evaluation of fatigue. She is noted to have pallor. Hemoglobin electrophoresis shows HbA of 91%, HbA2 of 8%, and HbF of 1%. Peripheral smear shows findings as below. RDW is normal. Which of the following is likely to be true for this patient's condition?

RDW - Red cell distribution width
questions.solution:
This patient with pallor, microcytic hypochromic anemia with target cells on peripheral smear, haemoglobin electrophoresis revealing elevated HbA2 (normal: 2.2 to 2.8%), and a normal RDW is likely to have a beta-thalassemia minor. Thalassemia occurs due to disorders in globin synthesis. 

Thalassemia occurs due to mutations in globin gene expression. The mutations can affect the alpha and beta subunits, leading to variable presentation and severity depending on which gene is affected.

Patients with β thalassemia major present with severe anemia and hepatosplenomegaly due to extramedullary hematopoiesis. Marrow hyperplasia in the skill can lead to prominence of cheekbones and other bony prominences (chipmunk facies) and crewcut appearance, as shown below. 

These patients require regular blood transfusions and are at risk of developing secondary hemochromatosis. Iron chelators are given to prevent this. However, the prognosis is guarded, and the only curative treatment is hematopoietic stem cell transplantation. Patients with β thalassemia minor are mostly asymptomatic or may have mild anemia.

A complete blood count will show low hemoglobin and mean corpuscular volume (MCV), indicating microcytic hypochromic anemia. Mentzer index (MCV/red cell count) will be less than 13. The peripheral smear shows microcytic hypochromic cells, anisopoikilocytosis, increased reticulocyte count, and target cells. 

Iron studies are performed to differentiate between thalassemia and iron deficiency anemia. Thalassemia has normal or increased serum iron and transferrin saturation. Iron deficiency anemia has decreased serum iron and transferrin saturation. Red cell distribution width (RDW) is generally normal in thalassemia and increased in iron deficiency. 

Hemoglobin electrophoresis measures the type of hemoglobin present in cells. Normally, Hemoglobin A (HbA) is 95-98%, Hemoglobin A2 (HbA2) is 2-3%, and Hemoglobin F (HbF) is less than 2%. Patients with β thalassemia minor usually have HbA2 between 4-8%, HbA >90%, and a small amount of HbF. Patients with transfusion-dependent β thalassemia have <5% HbA1, while HbF is 90-100%. 

Other options:

Option A: A low transferrin saturation is seen in iron deficiency anemia.

Option C: Mentzer index of more than 13 is seen in iron deficiency anemia. 

Option D: Bite cells are seen in the peripheral smear of patients with glucose 6-phosphate dehydrogenase(G6PD) deficiency.

Related Pearl: Thalassemia syndromes

Normally each individual carries 4 functional alpha chain genes and 2 functional beta chain genes. Alpha and beta-thalassemia are inherited disorders in which there is reduced production of alpha-globin or beta-globin chains, respectively.

  • Alpha thalassemia: Gene deletion is the most common cause of reduced α-chain synthesis.
  • Beta +- thalassemia: The most common cause is splicing mutation.
  • Beta 0- thalassemia: Chain terminator mutations are the most common cause.

questions.text: A 40-year-old female came with a history of jerky movements involving limbs and trunk. She also complains that she is more irritable nowadays. Her MRI from a previous doctor's visit shows marked atrophy of the caudate nucleus. The pedigree chart is given below and investigations show trinucleotide repeat (CAG) sequences. Which of the following drugs can be used to manage the movement disorder in this condition?
questions.solution:
The given case scenario with trinucleotide repeat (CAG) sequences and the family pedigree showing the autosomal dominant mode of inheritance point towards a diagnosis of Huntington’s disease. VMAT2 (Vesicular monoamine transporter 2) inhibitor approved for the treatment of Huntington's chorea is deutetrabenazine.

Huntington's disease (HD) is a degenerative disease of the caudate and putamen (“striate neurons”) caused by an autosomal dominant inheritance of a trinucleotide repeat (CAG) in the Huntington gene (chromosome 4), which results in motor, behavioral, oculomotor, and cognitive dysfunction. HD is characterized by rapid, nonpatterned, semi-purposeful, involuntary choreiform movements of limb, face, or trunk. A phenomenon referred to as anticipation is seen particularly in males, with subsequent generations having larger numbers of repeats and earlier ages of disease onset.

Tetrabenazine and deutetrabenazine are inhibitors of VMAT2 and cause presynaptic depletion of catecholamines. Deutetrabenazine is a newer form of tetrabenazine approved for the treatment of chorea associated with Huntington's disease. Deutetrabenazine takes advantage of the stronger bonds that deuterium forms with carbon (deuterated tetrabenazine). They have a longer half-life than the corresponding products of tetrabenazine metabolism.

Tetrabenazine is extensively metabolized by CYP2D6. It may cause hypotension and depression with suicidal tendencies. It can also cause parkinsonism. Deutetrabenazine has adverse effects similar to those of tetrabenazine.

Other options:

Sodium valproate is used for moderate-severe Sydenham's chorea. It is characterized by involuntary, purposeless, jerky movements which mainly affect the head and upper limbs. In the tongue, it is visible as the characteristic darting movements.

Deflazacort: Corticosteroid approved for the treatment of Duchenne Muscular Dystrophy.

Edaravone: It is a free radical scavenger approved for the treatment of Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis.

questions.text: A woman came to the police station with complaints of domestic abuse and showed multiple bruises on her arms which were dark brown in color, with multiple vesicles, itching, and redness in the surrounding area. The shape of the bruise was irregular and the margins were well-defined. There was no typical change in the color of the bruise with the passage of time. Which of the following is the least likely to produce such lesions?
questions.solution:
The bruise located in an accessible area, associated with blisters, itching, and no color change is suggestive of an artificial bruise which is unlikely to be caused by  

Artificial bruises are caused by the application of certain irritant substances such as the juice of marking nut, Calotropis, or Plumbago rosea to simulate true bruises. However, the following features can be used to distinguish between the two categories.

Trait Artificial bruise True bruise
Site Accessible parts Anywhere
Color Dark brown Typical color progression over time
Shape Irregular Rounded
Margins Well-defined and regular Ill-defined and irregular
Vesicles Present Absent
Redness/ Inflammation Present in the surrounding skin Present over bruise
Itching Present Absent
Chemical tests Positive Negative

Semecarpus Anacardium commonly known as marking nut produces injuries that stimulate contusion. The active principles are semicarpol and bhilawanol.

The juice when applied locally to the skin produces irritation, painful blisters, itching, and eczematous eruption. Seeds are used to produce an artificial bruise. When taken orally, it can produce blisters in the mouth and throat, with gastroenteritis. It also produces dyspnoea, cyanosis, tachycardia, coma, and death.

The fatal period is 12 to 24 hours. The bruised nut is applied to the cervical os for criminal abortion. The juice can be used by malingerers to produce ophthalmia. Accidental poisoning may result from the administration of juice internally by quacks.

The image below shows marking nut:

The Calotropis plant is identified by the presence of purple or white flowers. The active principles of the plants are uscharin, calotoxin, calactin, and calotropin. The juice of the plant can be used to produce artificial bruises, introduced into the uterus on an abortion stick for criminal abortion, and occasionally used as an arrow poison.

The image given below shows Calotropis:

 

 

The root of Plumbago rosea contains an active principle plumbagin. Applied externally it causes blisters and irritation. While consumed it causes burning pain from mouth to stomach, vomiting, thirst, diarrhea, collapse, and death.

The active principles of Abrus precatorius are abrin, abrine, and abralin. It is a commonly used cattle poison in Indian villages by injecting the seed extract into the animal in the form of certain fine needle-shaped structures known as Sui (meaning needle in Hindi). These are prepared by mixing the seed extract with opium, datura, and spirit/water and then blended into a paste, shaped into fine needles, and used to kill cattle.

The image given below shows the seeds of Abrus precatorius:

questions.text: A dairy-farm owner presented to the OPD with the complaint of fever, headache and fatigue for the past 8 months and recent onset of night sweats, cough and shortness of breath. He gives a history of consumption of unpasteurized milk.  Faget's sign is positive. A new regurgitant murmur was found on CVS examination. The echocardiogram confirmed the presence of vegetation on the leaflet of mitral valve. Gram's staining does not show the causative organism but serology is positive for the specific antibodies. Which of the following statements is incorrect regarding the causative organism in this scenario?

choices.text: There is no vector involved in the transmission of this disease
It is a category A bioterrorism agent
Doxycycline and hydroxychloroquine are preferred for treatment
Indirect immunofluorescence is the best investigation for diagnosis

questions.solution:
The clinical scenario given above is suggestive of Q fever caused by Coxiella burnetti which is a Bioterrorism category B agent and should be cultivated in only biosafety level 3 laboratories.

It is a zoonotic disease and the most commonly identified sources of human infection are farm animals, such as cattle, goats, and sheep. Infected mammals shed C. burnetii in their urine, feces, milk, and placenta. Human exposure to C. burnetii may occur as a result of inhalation of contaminated aerosols arising from the placenta or parturient fluids of infected livestock or from contaminated secretions and consumption of unpasteurized contaminated milk. There is no vector involved in the transmission of the disease to man. Ticks can act as reservoirs.

Incubation period usually lasts for 2 to 3 weeks.

People working with farm animals and veterinarians are at a higher risk of infection.

Infection can be acute or chronic. Acute disease resembles influenza (fever, chills, headache), nonbacterial (atypical) pneumonia, and hepatitis. There is no skin lesion.

Chronic Q fever lasts more than 6 months. Infective endocarditis is the most common form of disease in this phase. Blood cultures for bacteria are negative, and there is a high titer of antibodies to C burnetii.

Diagnosis:

Serology is the diagnostic method of choice for Coxiella brunettii which shows a rise in the titer of specific antibodies to C. burnetii. But indirect immunofluorescence is considered the best method. PCR is useful in diagnosing culture-negative endocarditis.

A single positive blood culture for Coxiella burnetti is considered as one of the major criteria to establish the diagnosis of infective endocarditis.

Treatment:

Doxycycline is the drug of choice for the treatment of acute Q fever. Chronic Q fever requires treatment for at least 18 months with doxycycline and hydroxychloroquine.

Prevention:

Currently, “high-temperature, short-time” pasteurization at 71.5°C for 15 seconds is recommended to destroy viable Coxiella species in milk.

Pasteurization can be done by heating the Milk  at either 

  • 63°C for 30 minutes: the Holder method or
  • 72°C for 15–20 seconds: the flash process

Once heated appropriately, the milk is cooled quickly to 13°C or lower. 

All the non-sporing pathogens are killed except Coxiella burnetti, which may survive in the Holder method.

Relative bradycardia/Faget’s sign is seen when patients have a lower heart rate than might be expected for a given body temperature.

The body temperature is often considered an independent determinant of heart rate.

It is estimated that for every centigrade rise in temperature, the heart rate increases approximately by 10 bpm.

Infectious causes of relative bradycardia include: 

  • Salmonella typhi
  • Francisella tularensis
  • Brucella spp.
  • Coxiella burnetii (Q fever)
  • Leptospira interrogans
  • Legionella pneumophila
  • Rickettsia spp.
  • Orientia tsutsugamushi (scrub typhus)
  • Corynebacterium diphtheriae
  • Plasmodium spp. (malaria)

Viruses/viral infections:

  • Yellow fever virus
  • Dengue virus
  • Viral hemorrhagic fevers - Early in course of Marburg and Ebola
  • Viral myocarditis

questions.text: A 20-year-old man who is a victim of a road traffic accident presents to the emergency room.  Vital signs show BP of 130/87, heart rate - 80 bpm, and respiratory rate of 16 per minute. He has sustained several injuries and a physical exam shows contusions over his head. He opens his eyes to a painful stimulus and tries to make some sounds only. He is noted to have both his arms flexed with legs extended as shown below. What is his expected Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) score?
questions.solution:
The Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) score based on the given clinical scenario is 7.

It is calculated as follows

  • Opening of the eyes to a painful stimulus - 2
  • Sounds only - 2
  • Decorticate posturing/abnormal flexion  - 3

Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) is used in the assessment of patients with a head injury.

Decorticate posture:

  • It is caused due to damage to the upper midbrain
  • The upper limbs are flexed, lower limbs are extended with toes pointed slightly inward, and head is extended.
  • Decorticate posturing is given a score of 3 in best motor response in Glasgow Coma Scale.

Decerebrate posture:

  • It is caused due to damage to lower midbrain and upper pons
  • Here, lower extremities are extended with toes pointed inward and upper extremities extended with fingers flexed and forearms pronated. Neck and head are extended. 
  • Decerebrate posture has a score of 2 in best motor response in the Glasgow Coma Scale.

  • GCS, in particular, the motor score, is the best predictor of neurological outcome.
  • If an area cannot be assessed, no numerical score is given for that region, and it is considered “non-testable." (NT)
  • In case of endotracheal intubation or tracheostomy, the verbal component of the score is denoted as NT.
  • A score of  ‘1’ is not recorded in missing components, instead, NT is used
  • when a component is Not Testable, a total score is not recorded because the score will be low and this could be confusing to medical colleagues. This may also imply that the patient is more unwell than they actually are.

 

NOTE: 

A new parameter, "pupil reactivity score" has been added to GCS, and now, it is referred to as GCS-P.

P stands for "Pupils unreactive to light"

Pupils unreactive to light Score

One pupil 1

The pupillary score is subtracted from the GCS score to give the final value. Therefore, the range of GCS-P is 1–15.

Note: The minimum frequency of observations for patients with GCS equal to 15 should be as follows, starting after the initial assessment in the emergency department:

  • Half-hourly for 2 hours,
  • Then 1-hourly for 4 hours,
  • 2-hourly thereafter.

Should the patient with GCS equal to 15 deteriorate at any time after the initial 2-hour period, observations should revert to half-hourly and follow the original frequency schedule.

questions.text: An epidemiologist is calculating the incubation period for measles in children aged 2 to 14 years. He was assigned a rural area with a sizeable portion of unvaccinated children and adolescents. He takes the sample size as 100. The median incubation period is 10 days, and the standard deviation he obtains is 4. What will be the standard error in this scenario?
questions.solution:
The formula for standard error is SE = standard deviation/ square root of sample size.

In this scenario, the standard error = 4/10 = 0.4.

Related Pearl: The Standard Error and Related Aspects

  1. Sampling Errors: They refer to natural, expected, random variations in the data. They are not errors per se. Hence, the mean of the sample always differs from the mean of the total population. For example, consider a population with a mean weight of 75. If we take a sample of 500 people from this population, the mean weight of this sample will not be exactly 75.
  2. Random Sampling Distribution of Means (or Sampling Distribution):
    • This refers to the distribution formed when all possible sample means from a population are plotted in a frequency distribution.
    • Sampling distributions provide information into how different the samples are from each other and from the population mean.
    For example, the hemoglobin levels of 100 randomly selected women in a city are measured and their sample mean is calculated. This is done every day for a year with the same sample size but different women each time. If all the sample means of hemoglobin levels of all women are plotted on frequency distribution, the resulting distribution would be called the sampling distribution. It would resemble a normal distribution.
  3. Central Limit Theorem: According to this theorem, as the sample size increases:
    • The sampling distribution tends towards a normal distribution curve (bell curve)
      1. Regardless of the population's actual distribution shape
      2. Assuming all samples are identical in size
    • The sample mean and standard deviations become closer to the population mean and standard deviations 
  4. Standard Error of Mean (SE or σ x̄ ):
    • The standard error is a measure of the extent to which the sample means deviate from the true population mean. It is nothing but the standard deviation of the sampling distribution.
      1. Sample means closer to the population mean lead to a lower SE and a narrower and thinner distribution curve 
      2. More variation in sample means leads to a higher SE and a broader curve 
    SE = Standard deviation / √Sample size

          σ x̄ = σ/√n

Hence, SE is inversely related to √sample size.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man with a history of prosthetic valve surgery comes to the clinic for evaluation of fever. On examination, a new-onset systolic murmur is heard in the mitral region and dark-red petechiae are seen in the nail beds of his hand. The following finding is seen on fundoscopy. Which of the following can be most likely seen in this condition?

choices.text: Fish-mouth stenosis of the mitral valve
Multiple, large, friable vegetations on heart valves

questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of fever with a new-onset systolic murmur in the mitral region in a patient who underwent prosthetic valve surgery, along with the fundoscopy finding of Roth's spots (exudative hemorrhagic lesions), is strongly suggestive of infective endocarditis. 

Clinical features of left-sided endocarditis include fever with chills, anorexia, weight loss, malaise, headache, night sweats, abdominal pain, and arthralgias. Cardiac murmurs, valvular insufficiency, and heart failure may also be present.

Peripheral manifestations of infective endocarditis include the following:

  • Petechiae are common but nonspecific findings.
  • Purulent purpura
  • Osler nodes are tender subcutaneous nodules that are usually found on the distal pads of the digits.
  • Janeway lesions are non-tender maculae on the palms and soles.
  • Roth spots are relatively rare retinal hemorrhages with small, clear centers.
  • Splinter hemorrhages are seen in the nails of this patient. Subungual splinter hemorrhages are classically identified as dark-red, linear petechiae in the nail bed. 
  • Splenic and cerebral abscess

Diagnosis is made using modified Duke's criteria and treatment is done using long-term (6 weeks or more) antibiotic therapy and/or valve replacement

Other options:

Option A: Fish-mouth or “buttonhole” stenoses as seen in rheumatic mitral stenosis due to calcification and fibrous bridging across the valvular commissures.

The image below shows the fish-mouth appearance seen in mitral stenosis:

 

Option B: Brown atrophy can be seen in the liver and heart. It occurs due to the accumulation of a brown pigment called lipochrome or lipofuscin in large amounts due to normal aging process.

Option D: Calcified masses on the outflow surfaces of the cusps of aortic valves are seen in calcific aortic stenosis.

Diagnosis of Infective endocarditis is by Duke's Criteria, which requires either:

If clinical criteria are used, definitive endocarditis is defined by the presence of 2 major or 1 major + 3 minor or 5 minor criteria.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presents with nausea, abdominal pain, constipation, and altered mental status. Lab investigations reveal hypercalcemia. Her vitals show a BP of 135/90mm of Hg, PR of 80 bpm, and RR of 14/min. She has a history of resection of parathyroid glands 2 months back. Lab results show elevated calcium and PTH levels with normal Vit D levels. The surgeon suspects an ectopic parathyroid gland. What is the most common site for the ectopic gland which is responsible for this condition?
questions.solution:
The most common site of the ectopic parathyroid gland in persistent hyperparathyroidism(HPT) is Paraoesophageal (28%).

The common cause of hypercalcemia post parathyroid resection secondary to hyperparathyroidism is persistent HPT.

Hypercalcemia presents as - polyuria, nausea, vomiting, constipation, bone pain, muscle weakness, confusion, lethargy, fatigue, palpitations

Persistent HPT - HPT and hypercalcemia post parathyroid resection within a 6 month period.
Recurrent HPT - HPT and hypercalcemia occurring after alteast 6 months of documented normocalcemia. 

The most common sites of ectopic parathyroid glands in patients with persistent or recurrent hyperparathyroidism are as follows:

  • Paraesophageal (28%)
  • Mediastinal (26%)
  • Intrathymic(24%)
  • Intrathyroidal (11%)
  • Carotid sheath (9%)
  • High cervical or undescended (2%)

Signs and symptoms of hypercalcemia - constipation, anorexia, nausea, neuropsychiatric disturbances, nephrolithiasis, polyuria, shortened QT interval and muscle weakness.

questions.text:
A 3-day old male infant who has not yet passed meconium is referred to you. There is no history of fever or vomiting. The infant was born via normal vaginal delivery and had an APGAR score of 9. On examination, abdominal distension is noted and forceful expulsion of stool is observed after rectal examination. A barium enema is performed and the findings are shown in the image below. Which of the following statements are true regarding the rectal biopsy performed in this scenario?

1 - Absent ganglion cells in the myenteric and Meissner plexus.
2- Hypertrophied nerve trunks
3 - Positive immunostaining for acetylcholinesterase
4 - Calretinin immunostain­ing is considered superior to acetylcholinesterase staining to confirm the diagnosis.
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario along with the barium enema image showing a dilated right colon with a transition zone in the mid descending colon is suggestive of Hirschsprung's disease. All four statements given in the question are true about the rectal biopsy.

Hirschsprung disease:

More common in males. Risk factors include Down's syndrome and RET oncogene.

Hirschsprung’s disease is a developmental disorder characterized by the absence of ganglion cells in the myenteric (Auerbach) plexus and submucosal (Meissner) plexus. The area between the dilated and contracted segments is referred to as the transition zone.

Most infants present with abdominal distention and bilious emesis with failure to pass meconium within the first 24 hours of life.

The initial investigation is a contrast enema.

A rectal biopsy is a gold standard for the diagnosis of Hirschsprung’s disease. A rectal biopsy 2 cm above the dentate line is the ideal area for a biopsy. Biopsy specimen shows:

  • Absent ganglia
  • Hypertrophied nerve trunks
  • Positive immunostaining for acetylcholinesterase
  • Calretinin immunostain­ing has become more widely used and is considered superior to acetylcholinesterase staining to confirm the diagnosis.

Definitive surgeries for Hirschsprung disease are as follows:

  • Swenson procedure, where aganglionic bowel is removed and a coloanal anastomosis is performed.
  • Duhamel procedure, where aganglionic rectal stump is left in place and the ganglionated normal colon is pulled posterior.
  • Soave procedure: In this procedure, endorectal mucosal dissection is done within the aganglionic distal rectum and then the ganglionated normal colon is pulled through the remnant muscular cuff, and a coloanal anastomosis is performed.

Postoperative complications - constipation, soiling, incontinence and postoperative enterocolitis.

questions.text:
A 60-year-old female presented to the OPD with easy fatiguability, anorexia, weight loss, and pallor. She complains of irritability and poor concentration. There is no history of alcohol consumption or intake of any drugs. On examination, there is glossitis, angular cheilosis, and hyperpigmentation of the knuckles. Unconjugated bilirubin is slightly raised. The image of her peripheral blood smear is given below.

Her laboratory investigations show:

  • Hb-6.3gm%
  • TLC-1100cells/mm3
  • Platelet count-80,000/microL
  • MCV-102fl
  • MCH-40
  • MCHC-32g/dL

What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The peripheral blood smear showing Cabot's ring and macro-ovalocytes with typical clinical features and laboratory findings are seen in Cyanocobalamin Vitamin B12 deficiency which is a causative factor of megaloblastic anemia. Megaloblastic anemia that is caused by malabsorption of vitamin B12, due to deficiency of the intrinsic factor, is called pernicious anemia.

Cabot ring is considered as a remnant of microtubules during cell division. As such, it can be seen in megaloblastic anemia, post-splenectomy patients, lead poisoning, and in some cases of hemolytic anemias.

Pernicious anemia is an autoimmune disease characterized by the presence of autoantibodies which impairs the production or activity of the intrinsic factor (IF), which is required for the uptake of vitamin B12. There are three types of autoantibodies namely, type I, II, and III. The action of each of these include:

  • Autoantibody type I prevents the binding of vitamin B12 to the intrinsic factor (IF).
  • Autoantibody type II prevents the binding of the vitamin B12-IF complex to the ileal receptors.
  • Autoantibody type III acts against the α and β subunits of the gastric proton pump, which impairs the production of intrinsic factors.

These patients also develop chronic atrophic gastritis, characterized by loss of parietal cells, infiltration of lymphocytes and plasma cells, and megaloblastic changes in mucosal cells. Autoimmune gastritis refers to a chronic, diffuse inflammatory disease of the stomach that is restricted to the body and fundus. This disorder typically features diffuse atrophic gastritis, antibodies to parietal cells and the intrinsic factor, and increased serum gastrin due to G-cell hyperplasia. Due to the neutralization of the intrinsic factor, there is decreased absorption of vitamin B12. As a result, all lineages of bone marrow precursors show asynchronous maturation between the nucleus and cytoplasm (megaloblastic cells), and the peripheral blood displays megaloblastic anemia.

Clinical features of cyanocobalamin and folate deficiency (megaloblastic anemia) include:

  • Anorexia, weight loss, diarrhea, or constipation
  • Oral manifestations: glossitis, angular cheilosis
  • Mild fever in more severely anemic patients
  • Jaundice (unconjugated)
  • Reversible melanin skin hyperpigmentation
  • Bruising (thrombocytopenia) and infections (low leucocyte count)
  • Complications in pregnancy: recurrent fetal loss and neural tube defects
  • Cardiovascular disease: cerebrovascular, peripheral vascular, and coronary heart disease with deep vein thrombosis
  • Neurologic manifestations: Bilateral peripheral neuropathy or degeneration of the posterior and pyramidal tracts of the spinal cord (SACDSC). Seen in only B12 deficiency.
  • Psychiatric disturbances

 Vitamin B12 deficiency is a cause of megaloblastic anaemia.

Megablastic anaemia:  There is impairment of DNA synthesis that leads to ineffective hematopoiesis and distinctive morphologic changes, including abnormally large erythroid precursors and red cells.

Peripheral smear:

  • Macro-ovalocytes
  • Most macrocytes lack the central pallor of normal red cells and even appear hyperchromic, but the MCHC is not elevated.
  • The reticulocyte count is low.
  • Nucleated red cell progenitors occasionally appear in the circulating blood when anemia is severe.
  • Neutrophils are also larger than normal (macro polymorphonuclear) and show nuclear hypersegmentation, having five or more nuclear lobules.

Marrow:

  • Markedly hypercellular as a result of increased hematopoietic precursors.
  • Sieve like pattern of chromatin of immature precursors (Megaloblasts)
  • Granulocytic precursors also display dysmaturation in the form of giant metamyelocytes and band forms.
  • Megakaryocytes, too, can be abnormally large and have bizarre, multilobate nuclei.
  • The derangement in DNA synthesis causes most precursors to undergo apoptosis in the marrow (ineffective hematopoiesis) and leads to pancytopenia.

The haemogram findings, peripheral smear showing macroovalocytes and hypersegmented neutrophils are suggestive of Megaloblastic anemia.

Related Pearl: Causes of Megaloblastic Anemia

Vitamin B12 Deficiency causes:

  • Decreased Intake
    • Inadequate diet
    • Vegetarianism
  • Impaired Absorption
    • Intrinsic factor deficiency
    • Pernicious anemia
    • Gastrectomy
    • Malabsorption states
    • Diffuse intestinal disease (e.g., lymphoma, systemic sclerosis)
    • Ileal resection
    • Ileitis
  • Competitive parasitic uptake
    • Fish tapeworm infestation
    • Bacterial overgrowth in blind loops and diverticula of bowel

Folic Acid Deficiency causes:

  • Decreased Intake
    • Inadequate diet
    • Alcoholism
    • Infancy
  • Impaired Absorption
    • Malabsorption states
    • Intrinsic intestinal disease
    • Anticonvulsants
    • Oral contraceptives
  • Increased Loss
    • Hemodialysis
  • Increased Requirement
    • Pregnancy, infancy
    • Disseminated cancer
    • Markedly increased hematopoiesis
  • Impaired Utilization
    • Folic acid antagonists
    • Unresponsive to vitamin B12 or folic acid therapy
    • Metabolic inhibitors of DNA synthesis and/or folate metabolism

questions.text: A 27-year-old woman comes to the local police station with the complaint of sexual assault. She mentions that she was raped by her husband even though she is legally separated from him for the past two years. After registering the complaint, she is sent to the doctor for medical examination. Which among the following statements is false regarding this situation?

choices.text: Section 67 of the BNS (376B IPC) deals with such cases
This is a cognizable offence on complaint of victim

questions.solution:
Sexual assault by the husband upon his wife during separation is a bailable offense. 

Section 67 of the BNS (376B IPC) deals with sexual intercourse by the husband with his wife during separation. It is cognizable (only on a complaint of the victim) and bailable. Punishment is imprisonment for not less than 2 years but which may extend to 7 years and with a fine.

questions.text:
A 48-year-old woman presented with a 1-year history of worsening headaches and one episode of focal seizures recently. Imaging reveals a cortical calcified mass in the left cerebral hemisphere. The histopathological image is given below. What is the most probable diagnosis?

IDH- Isocitrate dehydrogenase
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario presence of cortical calcified mass in the left cerebral hemisphere with histopathology revealing a chicken-wire pattern and fried egg appearance is suggestive of oligodendroglioma.

In the given histopathological image there are regular sheets of tumor cells with spherical nuclei surrounded by a perinuclear halo termed fried egg appearance. The network of thin branched capillary-sized vessels shows a "chicken-wire" pattern in appearance. The cells that infiltrate the brain may collect around the neurons. This is called perineural satellitosis.

Oligodendroglioma is an infiltrating glioma composed of cells resembling oligodendrocytes. It is associated with mutations in IDH and deletion of chromosomes 1p and 19q.

Most commonly oligodendrogliomas are detected in the fourth and fifth decades of life. Patients may have had several years of antecedent neurologic complaints, often including seizures. The lesions are found mostly in the cerebral hemispheres, with a pre­dilection for white matter. The imaging may show the presence of cortical mass with calcifications.

Management includes a combination of surgery, chemotherapy, and radiotherapy.

Related Pearl: Most commons of Brain tumours

Most common tumor of the brain - Metastasis secondary to lungs > breast

Most common primary CNS tumor - glioma > meningioma

Most common primary CNS tumor in children - pilocytic astrocytoma

Most common primary CNS tumor in adults - astrocytoma

Most common primary malignant tumor of the brain in children - medulloblastoma

Most common primary malignant tumor of the brain in adults - glioblastoma

Related Pearl: Histological Features of CNS Tumors

Pilocytic Astrocytomas:

  • Biphasic architecture - loose microcystic component and dense fibrillary areas
  • Bipolar cells (tumor cells): thin, long hairlike processes that are GFAP - positive. 
  • Rosenthal fibers: eosinophilic corkscrew - shaped inclusions
  • Eosinophilic granular bodies: mulberry - like inclusions 

 

Medulloblastoma:

  • Very densely cellular, with sheets of small primitive appearing small blue cells
  • Individual tumor cells have scant cytoplasm and hyperchromatic nuclei that are frequently elongated or crescent-shaped
  • Tumor cells form Homer - Wright rosettes (pseudorosettes) with a central neuropil

 

Ependymoma:

  • Ependymal rosettes: gland - like round or elongated structures that resemble the embryologic ependymal canal, with long, delicate processes extending into the lumen 
  • Perivascular pseudorosettes: perivascular nuclear - free zone consisting of thin ependymal processes radiating toward the central blood vessel

 

Oligodendroglioma:

  • Fried - egg appearance: sheets of regular cells with spherical nuclei containing finely granular chromatin (similar to normal oligodendrocytes) surrounded by a clear halo of vacuolated cytoplasm. 
  • Chicken - wire capillaries: a delicate network of anastomosing capillaries

 

Retinoblastoma: 

  • Composed of collections of small, round cells with hyperchromatic nuclei
  • Flexner - Wintersteiner rosettes: arrangements of a single layer of tumor cells around an apparent lumen
  • Homer - Wright rosettes: a ring of cells with an eosinophilic fibrillary center
  • Fleurettes: retinoblastoma cells that have undergone greater photoreceptor differentiation and group together as a bouquet. Fleurettes lack mitosis or necrosis.

questions.text:
A 27-year-old woman with a history of moderate persistent asthma on treatment presents with progressive worsening of shortness of breath, wheezing, and cough over 3 days. Her husband gave a history suggestive of a recent upper respiratory tract infection. On examination, her respiratory rate is 34/minute. Auscultation reveals diffuse rhonchi in all lung fields. She is started on nebulized albuterol. Shortly thereafter, the patient's condition worsens, she is unable to speak and the chest is silent on auscultation.
ABG Component Value
pH 7.28
pCO2 45
HCO3 21
pO2 50

Which of the following is the next best step in management?
questions.solution:
This patient presented to the hospital with an acute exacerbation of asthma and then developed asthma with impending respiratory failure during the course of her stay. This patient requires immediate endotracheal intubation as the next step in management.

Asthma with impending respiratory failure will have a normal or rising PaCO2, in a mute/silent patient with relative bradycardia, a silent chest and respiratory acidosis. 
X-ray is usually normal but can show hyperinflated lungs in acute severe asthma. More importantly, it helps to rule out heart failure, pneumonia, pneumothorax or other complications.

Acute severe asthma has the following features:

  • Triggered by viral upper respiratory infection, exposure to allergens, cold or exercise.
  • Progressive chest tightness, loud wheezing not relieved by inhaler
  • Agitated with difficulty in speaking
  • Tachycardia and cyanosis
  • Increased respiratory rate
  • Hyperventilation leading to low or normal PaCO2
  • Respiratory alkalosis initially
  • Pulsus paradoxus may be seen

X-ray is usually normal but can show hyperinflated lungs in acute severe asthma. More importantly, it helps to rule out heart failure, pneumonia, pneumothorax, or other complications.

Intravenous corticosteroids (Option 1) and Ipratropium bromide which an anticholinergic agent (Option 2) and repeated doses of SABA (Option 3) may be used for management of acute severe asthma but not as the next step in this patient with impending failure. 

Other treatment options in acute severe asthma include a slow infusion of aminophylline and intravenous magnesium sulphate.

questions.text: A 17-year-old male patient comes to the clinic with complaints of pain in the groin and a limp while walking. He sustained an injury while performing a kick in karate class. On examination, there is no swelling or visible external signs of trauma. There is mild tenderness over the groin and the medial aspect of the upper thigh. Flexion of the hip is painful. X-ray of the hip confirms the diagnosis. You explain to the patient that a fracture of the structure marked "A" has occurred. Which of the following is attached to "A"?
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette describes an avulsion fracture of the lesser trochanter. The image shows the posterior surface of the right femur and the structure marked "A" is the lesser trochanter and the iliopsoas muscle is attached to it. 

The Iliopsoas comprises of Psoas major and Iliacus. They arise from the lumbar spine and the inner surface of the ilium bone respectively, and insert on the lesser trochanter. The iliopsoas cause flexion of the hip.

The femur can be divided into the proximal femur, shaft, and distal femur.

  • The proximal femur consists of the head, neck, greater and lesser trochanters. The intertrochanteric line is present on the anterior surface at the junction of the neck and shaft of the femur while the intertrochanteric crest is present on the posterior surface. The lesser trochanter is the posteromedial projection of the femur arising posteroinferiorly from the neck-shaft junction.
  • The shaft of the femur consists of linea aspera (bony crest present on the posterior surface), gluteal tuberosity, and pectineal line.
  • The distal femur consists of the medial condyle, lateral condyle, intercondylar fossa, and patellar surface.

questions.text: A young female patient presents with abdominal distension and a palpable pelvic mass. Ultrasonography indicates the mass to be ovarian. Staging laparotomy is done and the histopathological slide from this specimen is shown below. Which of the following can act as a reliable tumor marker in post-treatment surveillance?
questions.solution:
The given clinical features and the histopathological image showing Schiller Duval bodies are suggestive of a yolk sac tumor/ endodermal sinus tumor. Serum levels of alpha-fetoprotein can act as a reliable tumor marker in posttreatment surveillance. 

Yolk sac tumor originates from embryonal structures of the yolk sac by selective differentiation. Hence, they are rich in alpha-fetoprotein. Therefore, serum alpha-fetoprotein levels are a reliable tumor marker in surveillance after treatment.

A yolk sac tumor is an aggressive malignant germ cell tumor of the ovaries. It presents as abdominal distension and a palpable pelvic mass in children and young women. On appearance, these tumors are yellow, friable (hemorrhagic), and solid mass. 

Most of the yolk sac tumors have Schiller-Duval bodies and they are pathognomonic. This structure consists of a central capillary surrounded by tumor cells, present in a cystic space that is lined by flat to cuboidal tumor cells.

Other options:

Option B: Lactate dehydrogenase(LDH) is a tumor marker in dysgerminoma ovaries.

Option C: Placental alkaline phosphatase(PLAP) is a tumor marker in dysgerminoma ovaries

Option D: Human chorionic gonadotropin(hCG) is a tumor marker in embryonal carcinoma and dysgerminoma ovaries.

questions.text: An autopsy is being conducted on a person who was diagnosed with normal pressure hydrocephalus. An axial dissection of the brain reveals one of the ventricles that is enlarged in this disease. Enlargement of the anterior horn of this ventricle causes compression of which of the following structures laterally?
questions.solution:
The given image shows an axial section of the lateral ventricle seen from posterior to anterior. The lateral relation of the anterior horn is the caudate nucleus. Enlargement of the anterior horn of the lateral ventricle causes compression of the caudate nucleus laterally.

The clinical symptoms of normal-pressure hydrocephalus are characteristic of the classic triad of cognitive dysfunction, urinary symptoms, and a wide-based gait (wet, wacky, and wobbly). Additionally, depressed affect and UMN signs in lower limbs may be seen.
The diagnosis is established by a CT that shows a marked enlargement of ventricles and the Miller Fisher test that shows improvement in gait following a lumbar tap. Treatment generally involves ventriculoperitoneal shunting.

The lateral ventricle can be divided into the body and 3 horns—anterior, posterior, and inferior.

  • Body: Frontal and parietal lobe
  • Anterior horn: Frontal lobe
  • Posterior horn: Occipital lobe
  • Inferior horn: Temporal lobe

Extent: from the genu of the corpus callosum till the interventricular foramen

  • Anteriorly: Genu and rostrum of the corpus callosum
  • Roof: Anterior part of the body of the corpus callosum 
  • Floor and lateral wall: Caudate nucleus
  • Medial wall: Septum pellucidum and anterior column of fornix

  • Roof: Body of the corpus callosum

questions.text: A 53-year-old menopausal lady presents with bleeding per vagina. Ultrasound of her pelvis shows a thick endometrial stripe, which on biopsy showed grade 1 adenocarcinoma of the endometrium. Identify the true statements regarding this condition.

choices.text: Glandular pattern is maintained and cells do not show atypia
Glandular pattern is maintained but cells show atypia
Glandular pattern is lost but cells do not show atypia
Glandular pattern is lost and cells show atypia

questions.solution:
The given clinical presentation is indicative of endometrial cancer. Grade 1 endometrial carcinoma shows cellular atypia and the regular glandular pattern is maintained.

The grading of endometrial tumors is based on differentiation, glandular architecture, and anaplasia of the cells. It is as follows,

  • Grade 1: The glandular pattern is maintained, but cells show atypia.
  • Grade 2: Some glands show the papillary pattern and are solid.
  • Grade 3: The glands are solid with cellular proliferation, and glandular architecture is lost. The endometrium is packed with glands and little stroma.

The histopathology image below shows endometrioid endometrial adenocarcinoma with malignant endometrial glands and metaplasia at high magnification.

Histopathological image (a) and (b) of a well-differentiated endometrioid adenocarcinoma is shown below.

Histologically, adenocarcinoma is the most common type of endometrial carcinoma amounting to 75%. The rest are clear cells, squamous and serous variety. They are more malignant than adenocarcinoma.

Patients with endometrial cancer present with post-menopausal bleed or abnormal uterine bleeding in the perimenopausal period.

Aspiration cytology from the uterine cavity every 6 months is an effective method of screening in high-risk cases. Ultrasonography is a useful modality for the assessment of endometrial thickening and associated ovarian tumors.
