questions.text: Identify the cell marked in the histological image of the cerebellum shown below :
questions.solution:
The cells marked in the above histological image are Purkinje cells.

Characteristics of Purkinje cells:

  • Purkinje cells are the flask-shaped cells present in the Purkinje cell layer of the cerebellum.
  • The cells are evenly spaced and are arranged in a single layer.
  • A dendrite arises from the neck of each flask-shaped cell, which passes upward to enter the molecular layer, which then branches extensively to form a dendritic tree.
  • The axon of each cell passes downwards, crosses the granular cell layer to enter the white matter.
  • Axons of Purkinje cells are the only efferents of the cerebellar cortex.
  • The initial segment of the axon receives synaptic contacts from basket cell axons.
  • The main axon terminates in one of the cerebellar or vestibular nuclei.
  • Purkinje cells are inhibitory and use GABA as their neurotransmitter.

Pathological significance:

  • Negri bodies in rabies, are usually found as eosinophilic, cytoplasmic inclusions in the neurons of the hippocampus and Purkinje cells.
  • Loss of Purkinje cells and granule cells is seen in ataxia-telangiectasia.
  • In patients with subacute cerebellar degeneration, there is the destruction of Purkinje cells. Some patients show circulating PCA­1 antibody (anti­Yo) against Purkinje cells.
  • Purkinje cells and neurons in pyramidal cell layers of hippocampus and cerebral cortex are the most sensitive neurons to hypoxia, and are likely to be damaged in cases of global cerebral ischemia.

Related Pearl: Layers of the cerebellar cortex

The cerebellar cortex is divided into 3 layers. They are:

  • Molecular layer - It is the outermost layer. It contains stellate cells and basket cells. They receive excitatory input from the parallel fibers and form inhibitory synapses on the Purkinje cells. It contains many myelinated and unmyelinated nerve fibers giving it a pale appearance in H and E staining.
  • Purkinje layer - It is the middle layer. It contain flask-shaped cell bodies of Purkinje cells. Their dendrites pass into the molecular layer. The axons of the Purkinje cells passes through the granular layer into the white matter and synapses with the cerebellar nuclei.
  • Granular layer - It is the innermost layer. It contains the cell bodies of the granule cells as well as Golgi cells. It receives excitatory input from the mossy fibers. They end on the dendrites of the granule cells and these complexes are called glomeruli. The axon from the granule cells travels to the molecular layer and bifurcates in a T-shape. These branches form the T and are called parallel fibers. These parallel fibers form excitatory synapses with the Purkinje cells. The granule cells form the only excitatory neurons in the cerebellar cortex. Golgi cells receive input from parallel fibers and mossy fibers. They send inhibitory output to the granule cells.

Neurotransmitters released:

  • Stellate, basket, Golgi and Purkinje cells- GABA
  • Granule cells - Glutamate

The only output from the cerebellar cortex is inhibitory from the Purkinje cells to the deep cerebellar nuclei.

questions.text: A 50-year-old lady presented with a 1.5 cm pigmented lesion on the face which is growing rapidly and is associated with itching. Dermoscopy examination is shown below which revealed an atypical, pigmented network. The dermatologist performs an excisional biopsy. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a 1.5 cm pigmented lesion on the face which is asymmetrical, with an irregular border, made of black and brown pigments, and increasing rapidly in size, points towards a diagnosis of malignant melanoma. 

Dermoscopy is similar to a simple magnifying lens applied on the skin surface with an intervening oil layer. It is used for better visualization of surface lesions. It helps in differentiating malignant melanoma from other benign lesions in case of doubt. Other uses include examination of scabies burrows or trichoscopy and tungiasis.

Dermoscopic appearance patterns have been classified and specific scoring systems devised (ABCD dermoscopy score and seven-point checklist) to diagnose malignant melanoma. The following dermoscopic appearances point toward a diagnosis of malignant melanoma:      

  • Atypical network (seen as circled in question image - the spaces are placed at irregular intervals)
  • Atypical vascular structures
  • Atypical blotch
  • Atypical dots and globules
  • Regression structures
  • Crystalline structures
  • Negative network
  • Streaks
  • The blue-white veil over raised areas
  • Peripheral tan structureless areas.

If dermoscopic appearances point towards melanoma, a biopsy is done and accordingly treatment is initiated. If dermoscopic structures point towards a benign lesion, monitoring can be done.

Other options:

Option A: A dysplastic nevus is formed at the dermo-epidermal junction. They are usually smaller in size than melanoma, have a fuzzy border, and are more likely to show brown-tan pigmentation. Any blue-black pigmentation should raise suspicion of melanoma. The majority of dysplastic nevi regress on their own

Option B: Congenital melanocytic nevus may be small, medium, or large size (>20cm). A large-sized mole may show an atypical network and have a risk of melanoma growth. But a history of being present since birth or infancy needs to be present.

Option C: Acquired melanocytic nevus (common mole) is rarely more than 1cm in size. It also does not show an atypical network.

The image below demonstrates how a dermoscopy is performed:

Related Pearl: Clinical Findings suggestive of Melanoma

The ABCDE of melanoma consists of the rules for the examination of a nevus to assess its malignant potential:

A : Asymmetry

  • Melanoma lesions are irregular, or not symmetrical, in shape

B : Border irregular

  • Melanoma lesions usually have irregular borders that are ill-defined

C : Color variation

  • The presence of multiple colors (blue, black, brown, tan, etc.) or the uneven distribution of color

D : Diameter >6 mm

  • Melanoma lesions are often greater than 6 millimeters in diameter (approximately the size of a pencil eraser)

E : Evolution

  • There is a change in the size, shape, symptoms (such as itching or tenderness), surface (especially bleeding), or color of a mole

questions.text: A 20-day old baby is gasping for air and not feeding properly. The mother has no money to go to the nearby hospital. Which national programme has provisions to benefit this woman to take her baby to the health facility?
questions.solution:
The Janani Shishu Suraksha Karyakram (JSSK) has provisions for free transport of pregnant women and sick infants from:

  • home to the health facilities
  • between facilities in case of a referral
  • back home from the health facilities

The provisions of JSSK include:

  • Free transport
  • Free treatment
  • Free drugs and consumables
  • Free diagnostics and diet
  • Free and cashless delivery
  • Free C-Section
  • Free provision of blood

Note: Previously under JSSK, the free entitlements were provided only for sick newborns till 30 days after birth. Now it is expanded to cover infants also.

Assured 18 service guarantees are provided to all pregnant women under Surakshit Matritva Aashwasan (SUMAN). It is a new initiative to provide assured, dignified, respectful, and quality healthcare at no cost and zero tolerance for denial of services for every woman and newborn visiting the public health facility. It aims to end all preventable maternal and newborn deaths, morbidities and provide a positive birthing experience.

questions.text: A 17-year-old male student presented with diarrhea and acute onset cough with thick sticky sputum. There is a history of repeated lung infections since childhood. Chest Xray shows evidence of bilateral upper lobe bronchiectasis. A gram-negative, oxidase-positive bacteria  is isolated which exhibits the following color change on Mueller-Hinton agar. All of the following conditions are caused by this bacteria except?
questions.solution:
The image shows the production of blue-green-colored pyocyanin, a pigment produced by Pseudomonas aeruginosa which causes lung infection in the case of cystic fibrosis patients. Glanders disease is caused by Burkholderia Mallei, not pseudomonas.

Cystic fibrosis (CF) is an autosomal recessive exocrinopathy affecting multiple epithelial tissues. The gene product responsible for CF is the cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator (CFTR) which produces defective (CFTR) protein in the lungs, gastrointestinal tract, and pancreas.  

In the lungs, abnormal CFTR leads to thick, sticky mucus with abnormal mucociliary clearance. The patient will have recurrent respiratory infections with the development of bronchiectasis. Patients with cystic fibrosis also have fat malabsorption secondary to exocrine pancreatic insufficiency, hence the increased stool fat.

A complex bacterial flora that includes Staphylococcus aureus, Haemophilus influenzae, and Pseudomonas aeruginosa is routinely cultured from CF sputum. Infection with Pseudomonas aeruginosa is common in adults with CF and it exhibits a stereotypic mode of pathogenesis; a sentinel and early colonization event that poses risk of lifelong pulmonary infection by the same genetic strain.

Pseudomonas aeruginosa is a gram-negative, oxidase-positive bacteria. Pyocyanin is a bluish-green pigment, produced only by Pseudomonas aeruginosa and not produced by any other Pseudomonas species. Pigments produced by Pseudomonas aeruginosa and many other species include Pyoverdin (Greenish-yellow), Pyorubin (Red), Pyomelanin (Brown). Production of a combination of pyocyanin and pyoverdin can be visualised as a blue green color on Mueller Hinton agar plate.

Diseases caused by Pseudomonas aeruginosa:

  • Opportunistic infections and hospital acquired infections
  • Shanghai fever: It manifests as severe enteric disease and sepsis with invasive disease in previously healthy infants.
  • Malignant otitis externa in diabetics
  • Jacuzzi syndrome (Hot tub folliculitis/Pseudomonas aeruginosa folliculitis) is a common type of folliculitis, which causes inflammation of hair follicles.
  • Ecthyma gangrenosum - Hemorrhagic necrosis of skin occurs often in sepsis caused by P. aeruginosa. It usually occurs in patients who are critically ill and immunocompromised. The characteristic lesions of ecthyma gangrenosum are hemorrhagic pustules that evolve into a necrotic (black) ulcer.
  • Green-nail syndrome: It results from frequent submersion of the hands in water. Infection with Pseudomonas causes diffusion of pyocyanin into the nail bed.

Glander's disease is caused by Burkholderia mallei. It is a disease primarily of equine animals (horses and mules) but, capable of being transmitted to other animals and to human beings (among grooms and veterinarians).

Image: Ecthyma gangrenosum. Note the black central eschar surrounded by an erythematous edematous halo.

questions.text: A patient comes to the ENT OPD with complaints of ear pain associated with impaired hearing. She has occasionally experienced tinnitus as well. questions.text:
A 78-year-old female patient has ECG findings below and a history of diabetes mellitus and hypertension. Which medication would prevent future complications in this patient?



ECG - Electrocardiogram

BP -  Blood Pressure
questions.solution:
The medication that would prevent future thrombotic complications in this patient with the given ECG showing an irregularly irregular rhythm with absent 'p' waves, which is consistent with atrial fibrillation (AF) is rivaroxaban.

The CHA2DS2-VASc score is used to assess the risk of stroke in patients who have AF. Anticoagulation therapy is given when the score is ≥1. The CHA2DS2-VASc score in this patient is 5. This patient needs anticoagulation with rivaroxaban to prevent future thrombotic complications. 

  • Age ≥ 75 years = 2
  • Diabetes = 1
  • Hypertension = 1
  • Female gender = 1

Total score = 5

For patients with non-valvular AF, oral anticoagulation has been proven to reduce the risk of stroke and other thromboembolic events. The preferred agents are non-Vitamin K antagonist oral anticoagulants (NOACs) such as dabigatran, rivaroxaban, apixaban or edoxaban. 

The situations in which warfarin may be considered as an option include:

  • Patients already on warfarin who are comfortable with periodic INR monitoring and SC injections
  • Patients with mechanical heart valves or severe mitral stenosis
  • Patients who are unlikely to comply with the dosing of oral medications
  • Patients with eGFR < 30 mL/min
  • Patients who are on enzyme-inducing epileptic drugs like phenytoin or protease inhibitors for HIV

Other options :

Option A: Aspirin may be used in patients with a score < 2 in patients with AF.

Option B: Amiodarone may be used for rhythm control in patients with AF but is not used to prevent thrombotic complications.

Option D: Rosiglitazone is an anti diabetic drug but is associated with increased risk of cardiac complications like congestive hear failure, MI.

questions.text: A patient presents with abdominal pain and chronic diarrhea. Colonoscopy showed skip lesions in the terminal ileum and cecum, with cobblestone appearance and geographical ulcers. The obtained histopathology image is given below. Which of the following statements is incorrect regarding this condition?

choices.text: Uveitis and erythema nodosum are extraintestinal manifestations
TH1  cells play a crucial role in pathogenesis
p-ANCA positivity is seen in majority of such cases
Strictures and fistulas are common complications

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a patient presenting with abdominal pain, chronic diarrhea, colonoscopy revealing skip lesions in the terminal ileum and cecum, and histopathology image of non-caseating granulomas is suggestive of Crohn's disease. Perinuclear anti-neutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies (p-ANCA) are found in a majority of individuals with ulcerative colitis, and only in a minority of patients with Crohn's disease.

The histopathological image shows transmural inflammation, where inflammatory cells (neutrophils) extend from mucosa through submucosa, and to the muscularis thereby, infiltrating and damaging crypt epithelium. The normally straight and parallel crypts appear distorted.

Perinuclear anti-neutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies (p-ANCA) are found in 50% to 65% of individuals with ulcerative colitis but only 10% to 25% of those with Crohn's disease. In contrast, ulcerative colitis patients tend to lack antibodies to Saccharomyces cerevisiae, which are often present in those with Crohn's disease.

Extraintestinal manifestations of Crohn's disease include the following:

  • uveitis
  • migratory polyarthritis
  • sacroiliitis
  • ankylosing spondylitis
  • erythema nodosum
  • clubbing of the fingertips
  • primary sclerosing cholangitis (more frequent with ulcerative colitis)

Cutaneous granulomas form nodules that are referred to as metastatic Crohn disease (a misnomer since there is no cancer)

questions.text: A 30-year-old lady presents with complaints of inability to conceive despite regular intercourse for the past 2 years.  Physical examination and semen analysis are normal. Hysterosalpingography reveals the following picture. The anomaly in the image below falls under which category of the American Fertility Society classification of Mullerian duct anomalies?
questions.solution:
The image shows a hysterosalpingogram of a unicornuate uterus, which falls under Class II of Mullerian duct anomalies

In the unicornuate uterus, the formation of the uterus and fallopian tube occurs entirely from one Mullerian duct due to the developmental arrest of other Mullerian ducts. On Hysterosalpingography, the endometrial cavity usually appears fusiform shape tapering at the apex and draining into a single fallopian tube. The uterus generally appears shifted off the midline.

The AFS (American Fertility Society) classification of Mullerian duct anomalies is as follows:

  • Class I—Mullerian agenesis or hypoplasia.
  • Class II—Unicornuate uterus, with absent or defective development of one Mullerian duct.
  • Class III—Uterus didelphys
  • Class IV—Bicornuate uterus 
  • Class V—Septate uterus
  • Class VI—Arcuate uterus

Infertility is defined as lack of conception despite 12 months of regular unprotected intercourse in women aged < 35 years old and despite 6 months of regular unprotected intercourse in women aged > 35 years old.

  • Ectopic pregnancy

A common complication is an abortion in the second trimester.

Arcuate uterus: Some studies report no increase in adverse outcomes, whereas some studies have shown excessive second trimester loss, preterm labor and malpresentations.

questions.text: A 65-year-old male patient presented with shortness of breath, cough, and fatigue for the last two months. He is a chronic smoker. On examination, blood pressure is 90/60 mm Hg, JVP is elevated and muffled heart sounds are heard. Chest x-ray reveals hilar enlargement and a perihilar mass and ECHO findings are shown below.  Which of the following additional findings are likely to be seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette describes a case of pericardial effusion leading to cardiac tamponade. The features of Beck's triad (muffled heart sounds, hypotension, elevated JVP) and the echocardiography showing a swinging heart point towards the diagnosis. These patients show electrical alternans pattern on ECG.

Cardiac tamponade is characterized by the accumulation of fluid in the pericardial space leading to impairment of diastolic relaxation of the cardiac chambers. This leads to a decline in cardiac output.

The physical examination findings in a patient with cardiac tamponade are:

  • Tachycardia
  • Hypotension
  • Elevated JVP
  • Pulsus paradoxus: An inspiratory decline in systolic blood pressure by 10 mmHg. During inspiration, blood flows into the right ventricle. Because of the tamponade, the right ventricle is unable to accommodate the blood and this leads to bowing of the intraventricular septum towards the left ventricle. This, along with the underfilling of the left ventricle causes decreased stroke volume and blood pressure.
  • JVP will show a sharp 'x' descent and the absence of 'y' descent.

This patient is a chronic smoker, with a history of fatigue, cough, and a perihilar mass on chest x-ray likely has lung cancer. Malignancy is a common cause of large symptomatic pericardial effusions. The most common malignancy involving the pericardium is lung cancer. They may involve the pericardium by direct invasion or metastatic spread through the lymphatics or bloodstream. Chemotherapy and radiation may also cause effusions or worsen pre-existing effusions.

 

Pericardial effusion refers to the accumulation of excess fluid in the pericardial space. The accumulation of fluid in the pericardial space in quantities sufficient to cause significant obstruction to the filling of the ventricles results in cardiac tamponade.

Echocardiography is considered the primary imaging investigation for the evaluation of pericardial effusion.

  • The normal amount of pericardial fluid (15 to 35 mL), is not detectable on echocardiography.A quantity > 50mL is considered abnormal.
  • In the case of large effusions, the heart shows a characteristic ‘to-and-fro' motion on echocardiography, commonly known as the swinging heart sign. The appearance of a swinging heart is specific for pericardial effusion, and is responsible for the electrical alternans pattern on ECG, as shown below, which is an alternating QRS amplitude that is seen on any or all leads.

 

Other features that may be seen on echocardiography in patients with cardiac tamponade are:

  • Early diastolic collapse of the right ventricular free wall
  • Late diastolic collapse of the right atrium
  • Dilated inferior vena cava with minimal or absent collapse with inspiration
  • A greater than 60% relative inspiratory augmentation of blood flow across the tricuspid valve
  • A greater than 30% relative decrease in inspiratory flow across the mitral valve

 Other options:

Option A: Ejection systolic murmurs are characteristically heard in conditions involving the valves of the heart such as aortic stenosis or physiological high flow states like anemia. A pericardial friction rub may be heard in pericarditis.

Option C: Stratosphere sign is an ultrasound finding in pneumothorax that may be useful for bedside diagnosis.

Option D: Cardiac tamponade leads to a characteristic fall in BP on inspiration called pulsus paradoxus, not an increase in BP.

questions.text: A 3-month-old infant presented with abdominal distention and increased irritability for 10 days. Physical examination showed jaundice, hepatomegaly, and a boiled cabbage odor. Investigations were notable for elevated transaminases and succinylacetone. What is the likely enzyme deficiency in this case?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of type 1 tyrosinemia (tyrosinosis). It is caused by a deficiency of fumarylacetoacetate hydrolase enzyme.

Type 1 tyrosinemia usually present between 2-6 months of age with acute liver failure. They may also present with peripheral neuropathy resembling acute porphyria. Renal involvement is manifested as a Fanconi-like syndrome with hyperphosphaturia, hypophosphatemia, and vitamin D-resistant rickets.

An odor resembling boiled cabbage resulting from increased methionine metabolites can be noted. Elevated levels of succinylacetone in blood or urine are diagnostic of type 1 tyrosinemia.

It is treated by a combination of nitisinone and dietary restriction of phenylalanine and tyrosine.

There are three types of tyrosinemias:

  • Type 1 (Hepatorenal tyrosinemia): Fumaryl acetoacetate hydrolase deficiency
  • Type 2 (Oculocutaneous tyrosinemia/ Richner-Hanhart syndrome): Tyrosine transaminase deficiency
  • Type 3 (Neonatal tyrosinemia)

Other options:

Option A: Deficiency of ornithine transcarbamoylase causes hyperammonemia type 2.

Option B: Deficiency of tyrosine transaminase (also known as tyrosine aminotransferase) causes type 2 tyrosinemia.

Option C: Deficiency of carbamoyl phosphate synthetase I (CPS1) causes hyperammonemia type 1. 

Note: A boiled cabbage odor can also occur in hypermethioninemia.

questions.text: What is the most common cause of death in patients who undergo bariatric surgery?
questions.solution:
Pulmonary embolism is the most common cause of death in patients of bariatric surgery.

Pathogenesis:

Obesity
 ↓ 
Increased levels of plasminogen activator inhibitor-1
 ↓ 
Blocks conversion of plasminogen to plasmin
 ↓ 
Decreased fibrinolytic activity
 ↓ 
Hypercoagulable state
 ↓ 
Increased risk for VTE

Morbidly obese patients are physically inactive. Restricted mobility post-surgery potentiates this risk of developing deep vein thrombosis. 

Note: Most common cause of death in bariatric surgery is DVT/pulmonary embolism. Most common complication of bariatric surgery is an anastomotic leak

questions.text:
Which of the following women would need treatment for their fibroids?
  1. A 32-year-old nulliparous woman with recurrent abortions, which after a thorough workup, is revealed to be caused due to the presence of a submucous fibroid.
  2. A 50-year-old menopausal female with a rapidly enlarging fibromyoma
  3. A 28-year-old asymptomatic mother of 2, who is found to have a fibroid in a USG taken as part of her annual master health check-up
  4. A 36-year-old female with a history of recurrent UTI whose USG reveals a broad ligament fibroid and significant post-void residual urine in the bladder.
  5. A 26-year-old anxious to conceive woman who has undergone extensive infertility workup which reveals near-pristine reports except for the presence of cornual fibroids
questions.solution:
Small and asymptomatic uterine fibroids do not require surgical removal or medical treatment. They are usually observed. However, the following forms the indications for treatment in an asymptomatic fibroid,

  • Infertility caused by cornual fibroid (As it blocks the fallopian tube)
  • Habitual abortions due to a submucous fibroid.
  • A fibroid more than 12 weeks size and a pedunculated fibroid which can cause torsion.
  • A fibroid causing pressure on the ureter that is broad ligament fibroid and pressure on the bladder, leaving residual urine and causing urinary infection.
  • Rapidly growing fibromyoma in a menopausal woman implying impending malignancy and requires surgery.
  • When the nature of the tumor cannot be ascertained clinically (laparotomy is needed on this occasion).

questions.text:
A patient presented with painless cervical lymphadenopathy, fever, malaise, and weight loss. Identify the subtype of Hodgkin’s lymphoma based on the cell marked as 'A' in the image and choose the statements which are correct about this subtype?

A. The immunophenotype is CD20+ve, CD15−ve, C30−ve and BCL-2 +ve.

B. Not associated with EBV infection

C. The prognosis is poor.

D. Seen in older age group.
questions.solution:
The given image shows popcorn cell which is characteristic of lymphocyte-predominant Hodgkin lymphoma. It is not associated with EBV infection.

Popcorn cell is a lymphohistiocytic (L&H) variant of RS cells that has a delicate multilobed, puffy nucleus resembling popped corn. L&H variants usually are found within large nodules containing mainly small B cells along with variable numbers of macrophages.

The characteristics of Nodular Lymphocyte Predominant Hodgkin Lymphoma (NLPHL) are:

  • Uncommon (<5%)
  • Young males <35 years
  • Cervical and axillary lymphadenopathy
  • The involved nodes have a nodular infiltrate of mainly small lymphocytes and macrophages.
  • Eosinophils and plasma cells are scanty
  • Non-Classical type
  • Not associated with EBV
  • Popcorn cells - the nonclassical RS cell that is lymphocytic and histiocytic variants with a multilobed nucleus, hence resembling a popcorn
  • Immunophenotype : CD20 +ve, BCL6 +ve, CD15-ve, CD30-ve
  • Typical presentation in males younger than 35 years with an excellent prognosis

Related Pearl: Important Features of the Different Types of Hodgkin's Lymphoma (HL)

Classic subtypes

  • Nodular sclerosis 
  • Mixed cellularity 
  • Lymphocyte-rich
  • Lymphocyte depletion

Non-Classical subtype

  • Lymphocyte predominant

Note: Mixed cellularity is most commonly associated with HIV due to its high incidence.

questions.text: A 25-year-old patient presents with complaints of hair loss to your clinic. Her medical history is notable only for a femur fracture which was treated by using open repair 3 months ago. Physical exam shows diffuse thinning of hair. Trichogram reveals that the majority of shed hair look like image B shown below. What is incorrect regarding the diagnosis?

choices.text: Majority of hair lost are in telogen phase
Hair pull test is strongly positive in areas of vertex
If treatment is not done, it will result in total baldness
It does not shows inflammation and scarring of scalp

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of loss of telogen hair (marked as B) 3 months after an event of physiological stress points towards a diagnosis of telogen effluvium. It does not produce total baldness and usually resolves spontaneously.

Telogen effluvium describes an increase in the shedding of telogen club hairs due to premature termination of the anagen phase of the hair cycle following a period of stress. A hair pull test is positive and Histopathology shows an increase in the proportion of telogen hair.

  • Acute telogen effluvium is an acute-onset scalp hair loss that occurs 2–3 months after a triggering event such as high fever, surgical trauma, sudden starvation, or hemorrhage. In one-third of cases, no cause is identified.
  • Chronic diffuse telogen hair loss refers to telogen hair shedding persisting for longer than 6 months.
  • Accepted causes of chronic diffuse telogen hair loss are thyroid disorders, profound iron deficiency anemia, acroder­matitis enteropathica, and malnutrition.
  • Both hyper- and hypo­thyroidism (including drug-induced hypothyroidism) may cause a diffuse telogen hair loss.
  • Telogen gravidarum refers to telogen hair loss seen 2–3 months after childbirth.

Trichogram refers to the microscopic examination of hair plucked from the scalp. It gives clues regarding the hair type and the anomalies in hair diseases. Anagen hair roots (type A) are covered by a long sheath. Whereas telogen hair (type B) are club-shaped and lack a covering sheath

Other options

Hair loss is mainly in the telogen phase. They are identified on trichogram by their club shape and absence of sheath.

Hair pull test is strongly positive in vertex and scalp margins. Though negative test does not rule out the diagnosis. 

Telogen effluvium is a type of non-scarring alopecia. Hence it is not associated with inflammation and scarring of scalp.

 

The correct sequence of hair growth is Anagen, Catagen, Telogen, and Kenogen. Kenogen refers to the empty follicle in telogen after the club fiber has been shed.

Exogen though usually occurs following telogen, may occur in late anagen as well.

Related Pearl: Hair Cycle

Hair follicles undergo a repetitive sequence of growth and the rest is known as the hair cycle. Hair Cycle is usually described under three phases: Anagen, Catagen, and Telogen.

1. Anagen

  • The period of active hair growth is known as anagen and the duration of this phase is responsible for determining the final length of the hair.
  • The entry of a resting hair follicle into anagen is heralded by the onset of mitotic activity in epithelial cells overlying the dermal papilla at the base of the follicle (the secondary epithelial germ).
  • Under normal circumstances, 80–90% of hair follicles on the human scalp are in anagen at any one time.
  • Anagen can continue for several years.

Fig 1. Scalp hair follicle in the anagen II stage of development

Fig 2.  Anagen hair bulb. Co, hair cortex; Cu, hair cuticle; DP, dermal papilla; DS, dermal sheath; He, Henle layer; HM, hair matrix; Hu, Huxley layer; IRSCu, inner root sheath cuticle; Me, melanocyte; ORS, outer root sheath

2. Catagen

  • At the end of anagen, epithelial cell division declines and ceases, and the follicle enters an involutionary phase known as catagen.
  • During catagen, the proximal end of the hair shaft keratinizes to form a club-shaped structure and the lower part of the follicle involutes by apoptosis.
  • The basement membrane surrounding the follicle becomes thickened and corrugated to form the ‘glassy membrane’.
  • It lasts for about 10 days.

Fig 3.  Human hair follicle in mid-catagen. There is a prominent glassy membrane surrounding the regressing epithelial column. The dermal papilla is rounded and condensed. 

3. Telogen

  • It is the time period between catagen and the next anagen.
  • It lasts for about 3 months.
  • Club hair is eventually shed through an active process called exogen.
  • In the human scalp, hair follicles may remain in a state of latency, also known as kenogen, for a pro­longed period after the club hair is shed.

questions.text: A 42-year-old male, who is a known case of PVD, comes with complaints of rest pain. Which of the following values of ankle and brachial pressure correspond to the values that can be expected in this patient?
questions.solution:
An ABPI of <0.5 is associated with rest pain. The ABPI of 0.4, seen in case of option D, Ankle - 48/36mm Hg, Brachial - 120/80mm Hg, will be corresponding to that of rest pain.

ABPI = Systolic Pressure at Ankle/ Systolic Pressure in the arm(Brachial)

=48/120 = 0.4

 

Other options:

A - ABPI =1.25

B - ABPI = 1

C - ABPI = 0.75

Related Pearl: Ankle–brachial Pressure Index (ABPI)

The ankle-brachial Pressure Index (ABPI) is the ratio of systolic pressure at the ankle to that in the arm.

The numerator is the highest pressure in the dorsalis pedis, posterior tibial, or peroneal artery and the denominator is the highest brachial systolic pressure.

ABPI Reading Interpretation
>0.9 to <1.4 Normal
<0.9 Diagnostic of occlusive arterial disease in patients with symptoms of claudication or other signs of ischemia
0.5 to 0.9 Arterial obstruction often associated with claudication
<0.4 Critical limb ischemia (multilevel obstruction i.e any combination of iliac, femoral or tibial vessel disease and may be associated with non-healing ulcerations, ischemic rest pain, or pedal gangrene.
>1.4 Signifies poor compressibility of the arteries. Mostly due to calcification because of increased age, diabetes etc.

Note: A fall in the resting ABPI of more than 20% after exercise is indicative of arterial disease.

A 45-year-old businessman comes to the emergency room with fever, cough, and shortness of breath one week after he returned from a Mediterranean cruise where he dined on board and used the swimming pools and hot tubs for over 7 days. He also complains of abdominal pain and diarrhea. The patient has a 15 pack-year smoking history. Physical examination reveals bronchial breath sounds in the left lower lung fields. He gives a history of taking amoxicillin for 3 days with no improvement. Which of the following organisms should be tested for?

questions.solution:
This clinical vignette describes a case of Legionnaire's disease caused by Legionella pneumophila.

Risk factors for this condition:

  • Contamination of water supplies in large facilities such as hospitals, hotels, or apartment buildings
  • Contaminated water sources such as hot tubs, birthing pools, and fountains
  • Patient factors such as old age, smoking, chronic lung, cardiovascular or renal disease, impaired cell-mediated immunity
  • Failure to respond to beta-lactam antibiotics

Clinical presentations:

  • Pneumonia caused by Legionella is clinically similar to pneumonia caused by other organisms
  • Patients typically present with fever, cough and shortness of breath
  • Symptoms occur about 2-10 days after the exposure to contaminated water or soil (as in this patient on the cruise ship)
  • Patients may also have abdominal symptoms such as diarrhea and abdominal pain
  • Physical examination will show bronchial breath sounds, rales and other signs of consolidation
  • Labs will show hyponatremia and elevated hepatic transaminases
  • These patients may have elevated inflammatory markers such as CRP > 100 mg/L

Diagnosis:

  • PCR on any sample including sputum and urine
  • Urine antigen testing for Legionella pneumophila serotype 1
  • Culture on special media which is the gold standard for diagnosis
  • Direct fluorescent antibody testing

Treatment

Patients typically present with a history of failure to respond to beta-lactam antibiotics such as amoxicillin. Levofloxacin and azithromycin are the preferred agents for the treatment of Legionnaires' disease as these agents are bactericidal, achieve high intracellular concentrations, penetrate lung tissue, and are active against all Legionella species that cause human infection. Alternatives include other fluoroquinolones and tetracyclines.

questions.text: A 28-year-old female patient presents with an itchy rash along the extensor surface of her elbows, knees, and scalp. Examination reveals pink plaques with overlying silvery scales. She also has new lesions as shown in the image. The phenomenon that causes new lesions over scratched areas is known as?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette and image describe plaque psoriasis on the dorsum of the hand and isomorphic or Koebner phenomenon that causes new lesions over scratched areas.

Koebner or isomorphic phenomenon is the development of new lesions along the line of trauma in previously normal skin. The new lesions have 'iso' (same) and 'morphic' (morphology) as the existing lesions. The trauma may include mechanical trauma, thermal trauma, allergic or irritant reactants, or any treatment procedures. It is commonly associated with psoriasis, lichen planus, lichen sclerosus, pityriasis rubra pilaris, and vitiligo.

Other option:

Option B - Development of lesions seen as a result of the spread of an infective agent (like Molluscum contagiosum, viral warts), is called pseudo-Koebner’s phenomenon.

Option C - If a lesion disappears at the site of injury/trauma, then it is termed as the "reverse Koebner phenomenon". It has been documented in cases of psoriasis and vitiligo.

Option D - The isotopic phenomenon is the occurrence of a new skin disorder at the site of another healed skin condition. For example, the appearance of psoriasis at contact dermatitis or the appearance of granuloma annulare at the site of herpes zoster.

Related Pearl: Koebner phenomenon

Koebner or isomorphic Phenomenon is the development of new lesions along the line of trauma in a previously normal skin. The new lesions have 'iso' (same) and 'morphic' (morphology) as the existing lesions.

The trauma may include mechanical trauma, thermal trauma, allergic or irritant reactants or any treatment procedures.

Psoriasis

Vitiligo

Lichen planus
False Koebner's phenomenon In infectious diseases

Viral warts

Molluscum contagiosum

Spontaneous repigmentation of vitiligo patches distant from the autologous skin graft sites (trauma)

Generalized granuloma annulare

Vitiligo

Psoriasis

Some rare causes of True Koebner Phenomenon are : Darier's disease, Hailey-Hailey disease, Erythema multiforme, Kaposi's Sarcoma and Lichen sclerosus.

Image: Koebner phenomenon with linear psoriasis patch on the abdomen

questions.text:
A 4-year-old girl with a history of easy bruising was referred for further evaluation. Her previous lab reports showed that platelet count and morphology were normal. Platelet aggregations tests are given below. What is the likely diagnosis?
Agonist used Aggregation
ADP Absent
Epinephrine Absent
Collagen Absent
Ristocetin Normal
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Glanzmann thrombasthenia.

It is an abnormality of platelet GPIIb-IIIa (fibrinogen receptor). Platelets are unable to adhere to each other and to the underlying tissue of the damaged blood vessels. It is inherited in an autosomal recessive manner. The symptoms include mucocutaneous bleeding in the neonatal period, menorrhagia, ecchymoses, epistaxis, and gingival hemorrhage.

Types of Glanzmann thrombasthenia include:

  • Type 1: Absence of GPIIb-IIIa
  • Type 2: Reduced surface expression of GPIIb-IIIa/ Essentialis athrombia - clot retraction is normal
  • Type 3: Dysfunction of GPIIb-IIIa

Laboratory features of Glanzmann thrombasthenia:

  • Normal platelet count and morphology
  • Platelet aggregation occurs in response to ristocetin, but not to other agonists (such as ADP, thrombin, collagen or epinephrine)
  • Clot retraction is absent

questions.text: A 60-year-old hypertensive male presented with a throbbing headache to casualty. He complained of pain and blurry vision in the right eye. On examination, pulse rate - 90bpm, BP - 170/110 mm Hg. A CT-angiography was done to reveal a saccular outpouching, 5mm in size. The neurosurgeon performed clipping of the aneurysm arising from the artery marked "D" as shown in the image. What is the embryological origin of the artery giving rise to this aneurysm?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of the headache and visual field defects(due to compression of the optic nerve) point towards a diagnosis of a cerebral aneurysm. The image shows the Circle of Willis and the marked artery 'D' is the Anterior Cerebral Artery. The anterior cerebral arteries are derived from the internal carotid arteries and are linked by a small anterior communicating artery. These are derived from the 3rd aortic arch arteries.

Circle of Willis / Circulus Arteriosus: 

  • Large arterial anastomosis unites the internal carotid and vertebrobasilar systems
  • It lies in the subarachnoid space within the basal cisterns that surround the optic chiasma and infundibulum
  • The anterior cerebral arteries are derived from the internal carotid arteries and are linked by a small anterior communicating artery. These are derived from the 3rd aortic arch arteries.
  • The subclavian arteries derived from aortic arch 4 and 7th cervical intersegmental artery which gives rise to vertebral arteries. Posteriorly, the two vertebral arteries unite to form the basilar artery. It gives posterior cerebral arteries. They are joined to the ipsilateral internal carotid artery by a posterior communicating artery.

     

Derivatives of the aortic arch:
 
  • First aortic arch - Remnant forms a portion of the maxillary artery. This arch regresses early.
  • Second aortic arch - Remnant forms portions of the hyoid and stapedial arteries. This arch regresses early.
  • Third aortic arch - Contributes to the formation of the common carotid arteries and proximal internal carotid arteries bilaterally.
  • Fourth aortic arch -
    • The right arch contributes to the right proximal subclavian artery.
    • The left arch gives rise to the medial portion of the aortic arch.
  • Fifth aortic arch - never forms or incompletely forms and regresses.
  • Sixth aortic arch -
    • The right and left arches separate into ventral and dorsal segments.
    • The ventral segments are responsible for the formation of the pulmonary arteries bilaterally.
    • The left ventral arch also contributes to the formation of the pulmonary trunk.
    • The right dorsal arch regresses.
    • The left dorsal arch forms the ductus arteriosus, which later becomes the ligamentum arteriosum.

 

Related Pearl: Circle of Willis

questions.text: A young male presents to the STD clinic with painful lesions as shown in the image.  He also has painful lymphadenopathy and was prescribed Acyclovir for this condition. Which of the following statements is incorrect regarding his condition?

choices.text: Cowdry type A inclusions are seen in the vesicles
Tzanck smear show multinucleated giant cells
Smears are prepared from from the base of vesicles

questions.solution:
The scenario and the image given above are suggestive of herpes infection and they heal without scarring. 

In herpes, clusters of vesicles are seen on an erythematous base along with painful lymphadenopathy. The typical herpes lesions are thin-walled, umbilicated vesicles, which break down into superficial ulcers. The most common site of cutaneous lesions is the face - on the cheeks, chin, around the mouth or on the forehead.

Cowdry type A inclusions are seen in the vesicles of Herpes Simplex Virus infection. The classic Cowdry type A inclusion appears as a light purple, homogeneous intranuclear structure surrounded by a clear halo. The inclusions stain with antibodies to HSV, permitting a rapid, specific diagnosis of HSV infection.

The Tzanck smear is a rapid, sensitive, and inexpensive diagnostic method. Smears are prepared from the lesions, from the base of vesicles, and stained with 1 % aqueous solution of toluidine blue 'O ' for 15 seconds. Multinucleated giant cells with faceted nuclei and homogeneously stained 'ground glass' chromatin known as Tzanck cells are seen.

Large, multinucleate virus-infected cells with typical eosinophilic Cowdry Type A inclusions are present in a case of Herpes Simplex infection.

Related Pearl: Tzanck Smear in Dermatology

The Tzanck smear, introduced by the Frenchman Tzanck, is a simple to perform, inexpensive bed side cytological test that aids in the diagnosis of vesicular, pustular and bullous diseases, in particular herpes.

The sensitivity of the Tzanck smear exceeds 80%, and the specificity 90% when the investigators are experienced.

Preparation of Tzanck smear:

  • Viral infections and Blistering disorders - fresh vesicle or intact blister is de-roofed and base is scraped 
  • Suspected tumors - any crust should be removed from ulcerated tumors, and non-ulcerated tumors should be incised with a sharp, pointed scalpel and sample is then obtained with either a blunt scalpel or a small curette
  • The smear should preferably be fixed immediately using Formol-Zenker solution since significant artifacts can result from drying.
  • Tzanck smear can be stained by a variety of methods, most commonly by Giemsa stain. Other stains used are hematoxylin and eosin, Wright, methylene blue, Papanicolaou and toluidine blue. 

Results in Tzanck Smear:

A typical Tzanck cell is a large round keratinocyte with a hypertrophic nucleus, hazy or absent nucleoli, and abundant basophilic cytoplasm. The basophilic staining is deeper peripherally on the cell membrane ("mourning edged" cells) due to the cytoplasm's tendency to get condensed at the periphery, leading to a perinuclear halo.

questions.text: Low serum copper levels attributed to ATP7A gene is due to:
questions.solution:
Low serum copper level attributed to the ATP7A gene is due to Menke's disease (Option C).

Menke's disease or Menke-Kinky hair syndrome is an X-linked recessive condition occurring due to a mutation in the ATP7A gene on chromosome X. This causes impaired transport of dietary copper from the small intestine to the liver leading to low levels of copper-containing enzymes. It presents within 3 years of age and is characterized by:

  • Depigmented kinky hair
  • Failure to thrive
  • Neurodegenerative symptoms like loss of developmental milestones, truncal hypotonia, epilepsyLoose, wrinkled skin
  • Multiple fractures
  • Poor visual acuity
  • Recurrent infections.

Lab investigations show low serum copper (<65 μg/dL) and low ceruloplasmin(<20 mg/dl). The disease is fatal as it has no curative treatment. But, administration of L-histidine and copper chloride injections may be beneficial, if started early.

Aceruloplasminemia is an autosomal recessive disease characterized by tissue iron overload, mental deterioration, microcytic anemia, and low serum iron and copper concentrations.

Option B: Low serum copper and low ceruloplasmin is also seen in Wilson’s disease, but is associated with the gene defect ATP7B on chromosome 13. It is an autosomal recessive disorder of copper metabolism with features of hepatolenticular degeneration and Kayser Fleischer ring.   

Option A: Dubin Johnson Syndrome is an autosomal recessive disorder characterized by impaired canalicular excretion of bilirubin due to mutation in MRP-2 protein leading to conjugated hyperbilirubinemia. 

Option D: Gilbert’s Syndrome is characterized by decreased UDP glucuronyl transferase activity leading to unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia, which can be autosomal recessive or dominant.

Related Pearl: Menkes disease

questions.text: An 18-year-old boy with sickle cell disease presents with dull pain in the right lower limb with a fever, for 2 weeks. Physical examination shows tenderness, swelling, and erythema in the anterior aspect of the right lower limb with overlying skin ulceration and a draining sinus. Investigations reveal a WBC count of 25,000 and grossly elevated ESR and CRP. Which of the following imaging tests has the highest specificity for his likely condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette describes the signs and symptoms of osteomyelitis. MRI has the highest sensitivity and specificity for detecting osteomyelitis in children. Patients with sickle cell anemia are more prone to developing osteomyelitis and Salmonella is a common causative organism.

After a conventional radiographic evaluation, MRI is considered the imaging study of choice for further evaluation. It is useful to obtain information on the extent of cortical destruction and to evaluate for the presence of bone marrow abnormalities, soft tissue inflammation, and ischemia

Both T1 and T2-weighted images should be obtained. An abnormal osseous signal on all sequences in the region of concern in the correct clinical setting confirms the diagnosis of osteomyelitis. A characteristic penumbra sign may be seen in subacute infection. There will be a peripheral relatively high-signal ring of granulation tissue surrounding a low-signal central zone which is the abscess cavity

X-Ray (Option 1) may be done as the first step in the evaluation of a suspected case of osteomyelitis. But, it is not as sensitive or specific as MRI. CT scan (Option 2) is more sensitive than X-Ray and may be used for evaluating cortical and trabecular integrity, periosteal reaction, intraosseous gas, soft tissue gas, and the extent of sinus tracts. It is the most useful for evaluating involucrum and osseus debris. Nuclear imaging studies (Option 4) such as the triple-phase bone scan, tagged WBC scan, and Gallium scan may be used in the presence of metal hardware that precludes the use of CT or MRI. It is better at evaluating acute rather than chronic cases.

The leading symptoms are usually pain and low-grade fever. Infection may manifest as clinical sepsis and local signs of inflammation (erythema and swelling). Long-bone osteomyelitis may also present as septic arthritis of the surrounding joints.

Sub-acute osteomyelitis may present as a Brodie's abscess - this is a region of suppuration and necrosis encapsulated by granulation tissue within a rim of sclerotic bone. It usually occurs in patients <25 years of age. The most common sites are the distal tibia, femur, fibula, radius, and ulna. 

Complications of osteomyelitis include:

  • Sinus tract formation
  • Contiguous soft tissue infection
  • Abscess
  • Septic arthritis
  • Systemic infection
  • Bony deformity
  • Fracture 
  • Malignancy

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy is brought to the pediatrician with sudden-onset fever, decreased oral intake, abdominal pain, and one episode of vomiting. On examination, the child is tired, tachycardic, and has enlarged anterior cervical lymph nodes. Which of the following is the most common causative organism?
questions.solution:
Beta hemolytic streptococcus is the most common causative organism of acute tonsillitis, which the above clinical vignette along with the image points to. The image shows enlarged tonsils with purulent exudates.

Acute tonsillitis affects children of school-going age and is rare in infants and the elderly. It causes high-grade fever, sore throat, and dysphagia. The tonsils and tonsillar fossa are innervated by the glossopharyngeal nerve and any irritation can cause referred otalgia through its tympanic branch (Jacobson's nerve). An examination may show erythema of pillars, and enlarged tonsils with purulent exudates. The jugulodigastric lymph nodes can be enlarged and tender. 

Treatment involves bed rest, hydration, analgesics, and antibiotics (penicillin). In recurrent cases, tonsillectomy may be done.

Other options:

Option A: Corynebacterium diphtheriae causes diphtheria, a bacterial infection with much slower onset of symptoms. There is dirty gray membrane formation on the tonsils which extends into the pharynx and palate

Option B: Hemophilus influenzae B causes acute epiglottitis. It is usually seen in children of ages 2-7. There is rapid onset of symptoms such as dyspnea, stridor, fever, and sore throat. It can be fatal unless treated. 

Option D: Parainfluenza virus, type I and II, is responsible for acute laryngo-tracheo-bronchitis (Croup). Male children between 6 months and 3 years of age are commonly affected. Symptoms include hoarseness of voice, croupy cough, fever, and inspiratory stridor.

questions.text: A 34-year-old man has been bitten by a wild dog resulting in multiple, deep lacerated wounds on his leg left. He has a record of previous complete pre-exposure vaccination against rabies that he had taken 6 months back. He presents at the district hospital where you provide him with immediate wound care and prepare to administer the Rabies vaccine. While giving this vaccine intramuscularly, you would avoid administering it in _____.
questions.solution:
Rabies vaccination should never be given in the gluteal region as it results in lower neutralizing antibody titers.

The patient in the scenario above has been bitten by a wild dog resulting in a category III wound and has a record of previous complete pre-exposure vaccination against rabies that he had taken 6 months back. For such a rabies-exposed person who has documentation of previous complete rabies vaccination(>3 months old), a booster dose of IM/ID vaccination is sufficient on days 0 and 3.

Rabies immunoglobulin is not indicated in such cases. 

Proper wound care is essential in all dog bite cases. Washing with soap and water followed by application of antiseptic agent (Any virucidal agent like povidone-iodine, alcohol, etc) is to be done.

Zero by 30 : is the Global strategic plan to end human death from dog mediated rabies by 2030.

Related Pearl: Rabies vaccines and immunoglobulins schedules

According to the Ministry of Health and Family Welfare, Government of India:

WHO category II or III exposures should receive post-exposure prophylaxis (PEP) immediately.

One intradermal (ID) dose is 0.1 mL of vaccine and one intramuscular (IM) dose is an entire vial of vaccine, irrespective of the vial size.

Should a vaccine dose be delayed for any reason, the PEP schedule should be resumed (not restarted).

Rabies Immunoglobulin(RIG): 

  • Passive immunization
  • Single-dose; after initiation of PEP and not beyond 7 days after the first dose of vaccine
  • Max dose: hRIG - 20IU/kg , eRIG - 40IU/kg body weight
  • Vaccines should never be withheld regardless of the availability of RIG.
  • Alternatives for RIG- WHO recommends monoclonal antibodies (mAb) as a 'cocktail' containing at least two antibodies against the rabies virus.

Administration of RIG:

  • RIG should be administered into or around the wound site or sites.
  • The remaining RIG, if any, should be injected IM at a site distant from the site of vaccine administration.
  • RIG may be diluted to a volume sufficient for all wounds to be effectively and safely infiltrated.

Prioritization of RIG allocation (numbered according to priority order):

  1. Multiple bites
  2. Deep wounds
  3. Bites to head, neck, and hands
  4. Patients with severe immunodeficiency
  5. Confirmed/probable rabies in biting animal
  6. Bites, scratches, and exposure of mucous membranes caused by a bat

Pre-exposure prophylaxis (PrEP)

PrEP is considered in the following conditions:

  • High-risk groups- laboratory staff, wildlife wardens, veterinarians, animal handlers, and travelers to endemic regions.
  • Remote, rabies-endemic areas where access to PEP is difficult
  • Areas where dog bite incidence is >5% per year
  • Areas where vampire bat rabies is known to be present.

Pre-exposure rabies vaccination consists of 3 intramuscular (IM) or 3 intradermal (ID) doses. These are given on days 0, 7 and 21 or 28.

  • Adults - the vaccine should always be administered in the deltoid area of the arm
  • Young children (under 1 year of age)- Administration into the anterolateral area of the thigh is recommended.
  • Rabies vaccine should never be administered in the gluteal area. Administration in this manner will result in lower neutralizing antibody titers.

For exposed or re-exposed patients who can document previous completion of PEP or PrEP the following guidelines would be applicable:

  • Proper wound management should be done.
  • There is no need for the administration of RIG.
  • One site ID or IM vaccine administration on days 0 and 3.

Only adequate wound washing would be required in case of re-exposure where the animal bite victim has documented proof of complete PEP within the last three months.

The following cases are treated as fresh cases and given full PEP:

  • Those who have previously received full post-exposure treatment with neural tissue vaccines (NTV) or vaccines of unproven potency
  • Those who cannot document complete PEP or PrEP treatment

questions.text: A 3-month-old infant with an abnormally large head is brought to your clinic and appears as shown in the image below. A head circumference measurement indicates the head size to be well over the 98th percentile in age-matched charts. On examination, you notice the presence of a setting sun sign, Macewen sign, and increased spasticity of the lower limbs. Further investigations reveal the presence of Mickey mouse ventricles, indicating the ballooning of frontal horns of lateral ventricles and third ventricle. Which of the following conditions is likely to be the cause?
questions.solution:
The given case is clearly suggestive of obstructive hydrocephalus which makes toxoplasmosis the likely cause from above.

Hydrocephalus is not a specific disease; it represents a diverse group of conditions that result from impaired circulation or absorption of CSF. 

Causes of hydrocephalus

  • Communicating (increased production or reduced absorption)
    • Achondroplasia (raised ICP due to jugular foramen stenosis)
    • Choroid plexus papilloma
    • Meningeal malignancy
    • Meningitis
    • Posthemorrhagic
  • Noncommunicating (obstructive)
    • Aqueductal stenosis
    • Infectious (toxoplasmosis, mumps)
    • Inherited (X-linked, mitochondrial, autosomal recessive, autosomal dominant)
    • Chiari malformation
    • Dandy–Walker malformation
    • Klippel–Feil syndrome
    • Mass lesions
    • Hematoma
    • Tumors and neurocutaneous disorders
    • Vein of Galen malformation

Clinical features:

  • Headache, nausea, vomiting and lethargy
  • Behavioral changes and developmental delays
  • Macrocephaly, frontal bossing and prominent scalp veins. These children may present with a large tense anterior fontanelle or rapid increase in head size (increase in head circumference >1cm every fortnight, separation of sutures >0.5 cm after the first two weeks and persistent widening of the squamo-parietal sutures. 
    • Macewan's sign: crack pot sound on skull percussion suggesting sutural separation
    • Setting sun sign: upward gaze palsy due to pressure on the quadrigeminal plate leading to visible sclera above the iris
  • Extraocular muscle paralysis
  • Papilledema
  • Vital signs may show bradycardia, hypertension and altered respiratory rate (signs of increased intracranial pressure). This is usually seen in infants after sutural fusion.
  • Spasticity of the extremities
  • Acquired Chiari II malformation

Diagnosis:

  • Antenatal MRI
  • Ultrasound in newborns
  • CT/MRI in older children which may show ballooning of the frontal horns of the lateral ventricles and third ventricle (Mickey mouse ventricles) which indicate aqueductal obstruction
  • Lumbar puncture 
  • Measurement of ICP

Treatment:

  • Ventriculostomy
  • Diuretics
  • Serial lumbar punctures in certain patients
  • CSF diversion procedures

 

The other options are causes of communicating hydrocephalus.

questions.text:
A 62-year-old female presents with a chronic history of pain in the small joints of hands and morning stiffness that lasts for 2 hours after waking up. She has no fever. She has a history of hypertension that is well controlled with enalapril. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows swelling over the small joint of both her hands with ulnar deviation of her fingers. An X-ray of the hand is shown in the image below. She is started on the first-line drug to prevent the progression of the disease. Which of the following true about the management of this condition?

1- Glucocorticoids are indicated for flares
2- Leucovorin is used to manage myelosuppression due to methotrexate
3- Escalation with triple therapy involves - methotrexate + sulfasalazine + leflunomide
4 - Inhibits dihydrofolate reductase
5 - It is a pyrimidine analogue
questions.solution:
The history and image are typical of rheumatoid arthritis. Statements 1,2, and 4 are true regarding the management of rheumatoid arthritis.

1-Glucocorticoids are indicated for flares
2- Leucovorin is used to manage myelosuppression due to methotrexate
3- Escalation with triple therapy involves - methotrexate + sulfasalazine + hydroxychloroquine
4 - Inhibits dihydrofolate reductase
5 - It is a folic acid analog

Rheumatoid Arthritis - 

It is a chronic inflammatory disease. Its incidence increases between 25 and 55 years of age.

Signs and symptoms -

  • Swelling and pain of the small joints of the hands initially(spares DIP joint)
  • Morning stiffness
  • Swan-neck deformity(hyperextension of the PIP joint with flexion of the DIP joint), Boutonnière deformity(flexion of the PIP joint with hyperextension of the DIP joint), or Z-line deformity(subluxation of the first MCP joint with hyperextension of the first interphalangeal (IP) joint )
  • Ulnar deviation of fingers
  • Constitutional findings such as fever, weight loss, etc
  • Monoarthritis of large joints can occur later
  • Tenosynovitis of palm(trigger finger0
  • Atlantoaxial joint involvement

Joints commonly affected in Rheumatoid Arthritis: (bilateral and symmetrically involved) 

  • MCP joints
  • Wrists
  • PIP joints
  • MTP joints
  • Atlantoaxial joint

Diagnosis is made with clinical signs and symptoms with corroboration from lab and imaging findings.

Anti-CCP, RF, and synovial fluid analysis are important lab investigations.

X-ray findings show -
soft tissue swelling, joint space narrowing, periarticular osteopenia, and bony erosions

Treatment of rheumatoid arthritis (RA)

DMARDs (Disease-modifying antirheumatic drugs) are the mainstay of treatment.

Methotrexate is the drug of choice in patients with RA. It can be used alone (in low disease activity) or with a 3-drug combination (in high disease activity) with other DMARDs such as hydroxychloroquine, sulfasalazine, and leflunomide (reserve drug).

  • It is a folic acid analong
  • Inhibits dihydrofolate reductase
  • Causes reversible myelosuppression
  • Leucovorin is used to manage myelosuppression
  • Can cause pulmonary fibrosis
  • Escalation with triple therapy involves - methotrexate + sulfasalazine + hydroxychloroquine
  • Glucocorticoids 

Glucocorticoids: Mainly given in the active disease. May be administered in low to moderate doses to achieve rapid disease control before the onset of fully effective DMARD therapy, which often takes several weeks or even months. Second, a 1- to 2-week burst of glucocorticoids may be prescribed for the management of acute disease flares.

Biologicals: They are protein therapeutics designed mostly to target cytokines and cell-surface molecules.

They are indicated when the disease is not responding to two or more DMARDs. They include:

Anti-TNF alpha agents: Infliximab, etanercept, adalimumab, golimumab, certolizumab. Side effects include increased risk of infections, reactivation of latent TB, drug-induced SLE, malignancy, and hepatitis B flares.

Anakinra: IL-1 antagonist

Tocilizumab: IL-6 antagonist

Abatacept: Inhibits co-stimulation of T cells

Rituximab-Anti CD-20

Tofacitinib-JAK 3 inhibitor

Approach to the patient:

DMARDs, especially methotrexate are the first line to prevent the progression of joint damage.  Effective combinations are - methotrexate + sulfasalazine + hydroxychloroquine (oral triple therapy) or methotrexate + leflunomide or methotrexate plus a biological.  In 2015, the American College of Rheumatology recommended e use of a treat-to-target approach to switch or add therapies in cases of persistent moderate/high disease activity.  Unresponsive and patients with too many side effects to anti-TNF drugs may benefit from switching to another anti-TNF agent or an alternative biologic with a different mechanism of action. Oral triple therapy (hydroxychloroquine, methotrexate, and sulfasalazine) is effective for early RA especially if there is no response to methotrexate alone.

The image below shows extraarticular manifestations of rheumatoid arthritis -

Related Pearl: Important drugs for rheumatoid arthritis

1) NSAIDs - analgesic and anti-inflammatory, used as adjunctive for management of uncontrollable symptoms and in acute flares.

2) Glucocorticoids - used in acute flare for rapid control and as initial therapy before the onset of action of DMARDs. Chronic administration of low doses is needed in patients with inadequate response to DMARDs.

  • Prednisolone - oral

  • Triamcinolone - intraarticular
     

3) DMARDs - disease-modifying anti-rheumatoid drugs:

 

- Conventional DMARDs:

  • Methotrexate (MTX)- is an antifolate drug. The DMARD of choice and the anchor drug for combination therapy. Regular LFT monitoring is required.
  • Hydroxychloroquine- is used as monotherapy for early and mild disease and in combination with other DMARDs for severe cases.
  • Sulfasalazine- is a salicylate. It reduces the radiographic progression of the disease.
  • Leflunomide- is a pyrimidine synthase inhibitor used as an alternative to MTX.

- Biologicals:

  • TNF-α antagonists- used in combination with MTX. Has a risk of serious bacterial infections, opportunistic fungal infection & reactivation of latent TB. The TNF-α inhibitors are adalimumab, golimumab, etanercept, infliximab, and certolizumab.
  • Abatacept- a T-cell costimulation inhibitor, used in combination with MTX, leflunomide, etc.
  • Rituximab- an anti-CD20 antibody. Used in refractory disease in combination with MTX.
  • Anakinra- an IL-1 receptor antagonist. It should not be combined with anti-TNF alpha.
  • IL-6 receptor antagonists- tocilizumab and sarilumab are used as monotherapy or combination therapy in moderate to severe disease.  

- Small molecules: 

  • Janus kinase inhibitors: Tofacitinib, baricitinib, and upadacitinib are used as monotherapy or combination therapy.

questions.text:
A 60-year-old patient with poor dental hygiene presented with a complaint of pain in his right upper molars. Deep tenderness is present on palpation of the right cheek. Following radiograph is taken to look for involvement of maxillary sinus. What is the view called?

Water's view: The patient’s head is positioned such that the nose and the chin touch the film while the X-rays are projected from backward. The mouth is usually kept open, which allows visualising the sphenoid sinus.

questions.text: You notice the following while exploring your hospital's principal biomedical waste handling facility.  Which of the following statements is correct regarding the equipment used for sterilization in the image shown below?

choices.text: It sterilizes using steam under pressure
Used for destroying biomedical waste such as human anatomical waste
Holding time is at least 15 minutes at 121 °C
Coagulation of proteins occur by this method

questions.solution:
The given image shows an incinerator. Incineration is the terminal sterilization for destroying biomedical waste such as human anatomical waste.

The biomedical waste material is exposed to a very high temperature inside the incinerator converting the material into ash. Incineration is used for the disposal of human and animal anatomical waste, soiled waste (contaminated dressings, plaster casts, cotton swabs), expired or discarded medicines, chemical waste, etc. 

Other equipment used in sterilization include:

Hot air oven- A holding period of 160 C for two hours is necessary to sterilize glassware, forceps, scissors, scalpels, swabs, and some pharmaceutical products such as liquid paraffin, and dusting powder.

 

UV sterilization: Ultraviolet radiation is used for disinfecting enclosed areas such as biosafety cabinets in laboratories, operation theatres, and laboratories. The given image shows UV sterilization in a biosafety cabinet.

 

Autoclave - Autoclaving is a method of heat sterilization. Autoclave sterilizes using steam under pressure. It is used to sterilize linen, instruments, laboratory ware, media, pharmaceutical products, aqueous solutions, cardiac catheters, and implants.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man presents to you with a 6-month history of fatigue, non-productive cough, and shortness of breath for 3 months. He also complains of pain in his fingertips on exposure to the cold and has digital ulcers. Physical examination reveals crepitations in both lung fields. Pulmonary function testing shows a restrictive pattern. The diagram below shows the pressure-volume curves for 3 different lungs. If the compliance of the patient's lung is represented by curve C, what could curves A and B  most likely represent?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette describes a case of systemic sclerosis with pulmonary fibrosis. Curves B and A will represent emphysema and a normal lung respectively.

Systemic sclerosis present with the following findings - fatigue, joint pain, sclerodactyly, digital ulcers, calcinosis cutis, Raynaud phenomenon, dysphagia, pulmonary fibrosis, etc

Pulmonary fibrosis presents with a dry cough and dyspnea with physical exam findings of crepitations on auscultation. Fibrosis presents as a restrictive pattern on pulmonary function testing and a fibrosis lung is less compliant.

  • The pressure-volume relationship is the fundamental relation between the work of breathing and lung mechanics.
  • The diagram depicts the change in volume with a change in intrapleural pressure, which is nothing but compliance. Here, the change is more (steep curve) with B and least (flat curve) with C. 
  • The “stiffer” lung displays a more horizontal curve (C), meaning that it takes a greater pressure to achieve the same inflation volume compared with a normal lung (A). These lungs are called less compliant.
  • Curve (B) is more compliant as it takes lesser pressure to achieve the same inflation volume compared to normal (A).

Compliance is increased in emphysema. The mechanism is shown in the flow chart below.

Compliance is decreased in case of pulmonary edema or fibrosis.

Hysteresis:

The difference between the curve of inflation (inspiration) and deflation (expiration) in a pressure–volume curve of the lung is termed hysteresis.  

The alveolar environment and, specifically, the secreted factors that help reduce surface tension and keep alveoli from collapsing, contribute to hysteresis.

the mechanism behind inspiration and expiration curves are shown below.

Related Pearl: Lung Compliance

Compliance is the change in lung volume per unit change in the surrounding pressure.

It is represented by the formula:

Compliance = ΔV/ΔP

Factors Affecting Compliance

  • Lung volume: smaller the lungs, smaller is the compliance
  • For a given lung size, the compliance becomes less at extremes of lung volume
  • Compliance is slightly greater when measured during deflation than during inflation
  • If the surface tension is more, compliance is less
  • Compliance measured with saline is more than compliance measured with air.

Compliance is decreased in conditions such as:

  • Pulmonary fibrosis: Due to increased fibrous tissue in the lung, making it less elastic, and thus less expandable.
  • Alveolar edema, which prevents the expansion of some alveoli.
  • If lung remains unventilated for a long time, in a low volume lung, due to atelectasis (collapse) of lung units or increased surface tension.
  • Increased pulmonary venous pressure.

Compliance is increased in conditions such as:

  • Pulmonary emphysema
  • Normal aging lung

questions.text: A 40-year-old male patient suffered a diaphyseal tibial fracture sustained in a road traffic accident and he was managed conservatively with casts. The follow-up radiograph after a few months is as shown below. What could be the probable cause of this finding?

choices.text: Due to loss of a fragment of bone

questions.solution:
The given x-ray shows hypertrophic nonunion of the Tibia. It is mostly due to inadequate stabilization.

Based on increasing biologic potential for fracture healing, non-union can be of the following types:

  • Atrophic nonunion: Poor healing response with no callus formation due to little or no active bone-forming cells at the fracture site. The blood supply is typically poor. On radiography, there is an absence of bone reaction. 
  • Oligotrophic nonunion: There is minimal callus formation, often due to inadequate approximation of fracture surfaces. On radiography, there is minimal bone healing reaction.
  • Hypertrophic nonunion: These fractures have adequate healing response and good vascularity. There is a lack of adequate stability for the union to occur. On radiography, there is usually abundant callus formation with an intervening dark area of fibrocartilage-lacking mineral. It can occur after initial nonoperative management or in some cases after initial operative management where there was inadequate stabilization.

questions.text: A 65-year-old female comes to the clinic with complaints of sudden severe back pain. She recently moved into a new home and has spent the last day moving her belongings into the home. She has tried over-the-counter pain medications to no benefit. On examination, her pulse rate is 100/min. She appears to be in acute distress. Examination of the lower extremities reveals decreased sensation over the lateral foot and heel of the foot and weakness of foot eversion. The straight leg raising test is positive and the patient is unable to raise up on toes. MRI helps confirm the suspected diagnosis. Which of these findings will also be seen in this patient?

choices.text: Loss of sensation on the medial malleolus
Loss of sensation over the dorsum of the foot

questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette describes a case of intervertebral disc prolapse at the L5-S1 level. This will cause a loss of ankle jerk reflex in addition to the findings given above. 

Clinical features:

When there is an L5-S1 prolapse, the  

Important tests for diagnosis:

1. Straight Leg Raising Test (SLRT) or Lasegue sign

This is done to assess nerve root irritation in the lumbosacral area.  The patient is made to lie on the back with the head extended, with hips and legs in the neutral position. The affected leg is then passively and slowly raised by the ankle with the knee fully extended. The examiner stops further leg elevation when pain is elicited. Normally it should be possible to raise the limb to 80–90 degrees. The SLRT test is positive if the patient develops pain when the leg is between 30 and 60/70 degrees from horizontal. The pain should be radicular type and radiating to the back of the thigh or to the calf.

2. Bragard test (or Sciatic stretch test or Flip test)

Perform SLRT. At the point where the patient experiences discomfort, the leg is lowered a little. The stretching and pain become less. At this angle, the ankle is passively dorsiflexed. If the pain at the back of the thigh or in the calf is felt again, the test is positive. This is also called reinforcement positive or Bragard’s sign positive.

3. Crossed SLRT (or well-leg raising test or Fajersztajn sign)

When SLRT is performed on the unaffected side, the patient may feel pain on the affected side. This is termed a contralateral positive SLRT or crossed SLRT positive. It is a very specific sign of root compression. It becomes positive usually when there is severe compression due to a centrally located prolapse.

4. Bowstring sign (or popliteal compression test)

The ‘bowstring sign’ is even more specific for disc prolapse than SLRT. Perform SLRT until the patient experiences sciatic pain. Without reducing the amount of lift, bend the knee so as to relax the sciatic nerve (Buckling sign). Buttock pain is immediately relieved. The examiner then presses the popliteal fossa to stretch the lateral popliteal nerve behind the lateral tibial condyle. This will tighten the nerve like a bowstring and re-induce the pain. 

5. Femoral stretch (reverse Lasegue test or Mackiewicz sign)

The patient lies prone. The examiner flexes the knee to the thigh and the hip is passively extended. The test is positive if the patient experiences anterior thigh pain. This test is usually positive for L2-L3 and L3-L4 (high lumbar) protrusions. 

Treatment:

  • Continuous bed rest and traction for 2 weeks will reduce the herniation in over 90% of cases.
  • Operative removal of the disc by unilateral laminectomy is indicated in
    • Cauda equina compression syndrome that does not clear up within 6 hours of starting bed rest and traction
    • Neurological deterioration under conservative treatment
    • Persistent pain and signs of sciatic tension after 3 weeks
