questions.text: A 55-year-old female patient comes to the ophthalmology clinic for evaluation of blurred vision. She gives a history of polymyalgia rheumatica for which she is being treated with steroids. She complains of difficulty in night driving and coloured halos around light sources. Examination shows intact pupillary response. Visual testing shows 6/60 vision in her right eye and normal vision in her left eye. Ophthalmoscopy shows a dark shadow against a red glow. She undergoes the test depicted below. What is the name of this test?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignetter describes a case of cataract. The test depicted in the image is the Emsley-Fincham Test for coloured halos. The instrument that is used to perform this procedure is the stenopaeic slit.

Halos induced by corneal diseases and early cataractous changes in the lens may be differentiated by the Fincham Test.

A stenopaeic slit is a trial frame accessory with a narrow, slit-shaped aperture in the centre. It is passed before the eye across the line of vision. As it passes, a glaucomatous halo remains intact but a lenticular halo is broken up into segments that revolve as the slit is moved.

Uses of Stenopaeic Slit test:

  • Fincham’s test: to differentiate between the colored halos due to cataract and corneal edema due to glaucoma
  • To find out the optimal site for optical iridectomy in case of corneal opacities
  • To find out the axis in astigmatism

Cover Test (Option 1) is a simple test to detect heterophoria which is based on the concept of abolishing fusion so that the eyes assume their position at rest. A screen placed in front of the eye is used to abolish fusion in this test.

Duochrome test (Option 3) is a test used to refine the final sphere in refraction, which makes use of the longitudinal chromatic aberration of the eye. 

Maddox Wing Test (Option 4) is a test by which the amount of heterophoria for near vision can be measured.

Related Pearl: Fincham’s Test

Also called Emsley–Fincham Test

It used for differentiating between the colored halos due to cataract (lenticular) and those in corneal edema due to glaucoma. It is performed by passing a stenopaic slit across the pupil and observing the halos.

Halos are broken up into segments which revolve as the slit moves → Lenticular halo

Intact halos but the intensity and brightness are diminished → Glaucomatous halo

The image shows a stenopaeic slit.

It causes reduced size of blur circle in the meridian perpendicular to the slit and no change in the blur circle in the meridian coincident with it. So, it can be used to determine the axis of the cylinder in astigmatism.

In cases with corneal opacity, the optimal site for optical iridectomy is determined using a stenopaic slit.

questions.text:
A 30-year-old female presents with complaints of double vision. She has noticed that as the day progresses her diplopia increases and is maximum when she is reading her book at night. Additionally, she has had trouble swallowing chunks of meat for the past few days. Physical examination reveals normal deep tendon reflexes and mild bilateral ptosis. Placing an ice pack over her eyes significantly decreases the ptosis. Which of the following drugs must be avoided in this patient?

a - Aminoglycosides
b - Metformin
c - Ciprofloxacin
d - Propanolol
e - Magnesium hydroxide
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario describes a case of myasthenia gravis. Aminoglycosides, ciprofloxacin, beta-blockers, and magnesium hydroxide must be avoided in myasthenia gravis (a,c,d,e).

Drugs that may aggravate myasthenia gravis are

  • Antibiotics like aminoglycosides, quinolones, and macrolides
  • Beta-blockers
  • Botulinum toxin
  • Local anesthetics
  • Magnesium
  • Non–depolarising muscle relaxants
  • Penicillamine
  • Quinine derivatives

Aminoglycosides have to be avoided in a patient with myasthenia gravis. It blocks Ca2+ mediated exocytosis of acetylcholine from the presynaptic membrane in the neuromuscular junction. The decrease in ACh levels aggravates myasthenia gravis. Aminoglycosides can also have a direct inhibitory effect on post-synaptic acetylcholine receptors. 

The common antacid Digene contains Mg(OH)2 and must be avoided in myasthenia gravis.

Myasthenia Gravis-

It is an autoimmune disorder of the neuromuscular junction. Autoantibodies are directed against the nicotinic acetylcholine receptor (AChR)(more common) or muscle-specific receptor tyrosine kinase (MuSK).

Presentation-

  • Fluctuating muscle weakness
  • Weakness is worse with continued use
  • Ocular symptoms(most common presenting symptoms) - ptosis, diplopia
  • Bulbar symptoms -dysphagia, dysarthria, fatigable chewing
  • Proximal muscle weakness
  • Ice-pack test - ice pack improves ptosis(decreases activity of acetylcholinesterase this increases the amount of acetylcholine in the synaptic cleft_
  • Edrophonium chloride (Tensilon test) - edrophonium is an acetylcholinesterase inhibitor, this increases the amount of acetylcholine in the synaptic cleft.

Diagnosis-

AChR antibodies, MuSK antibodies, LRP4 antibodies, single-fiber electromyography, repetitive nerve stimulation.

Treatment -

Pyridostigmine, azathioprine, thymectomy

questions.text: A male patient with a history of panic disorder is brought to the emergency room. He complains of nausea, sweating, and palpitations. On examination, he appears anxious, and irritable. His pulse rate is 120/minute and respiratory rate is 30/minute. Upon inflating the BP cuff, the hand assumes the position shown below. Which of the following is the likely explanation for this patient's condition?

choices.text: Increased binding of calcium with inorganic salts
Decreased binding of albumin with calcium
Increased binding of albumin with calcium

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of panic attack and the image showing Trosseau's sign are suggestive of hypocalcemia in this patient. It occurs due to increased binding of calcium with albumin.

Panic attack leads to hyperventilation, which in turn, results in washout of carbon dioxide and acute respiratory alkalosis. An increase in extracellular pH increases the binding of calcium to albumin, lowering the ionized calcium concentration. Thus, respiratory alkalosis especially can precipitate tetany and laryngospasm in calcium-deficient patients.

Hypocalcemia can be associated with low albumin levels, hyperphosphatemia, tumor lysis syndrome and impaired parathyroid hormone secretion. 

The clinical features of hypocalcemia are:

  • Tetany: Increased peripheral neuromuscular irritability. May include perioral parasthesias, muscle spasms and cramps.
  • Trosseau's sign: Induction of carpal spasm when the BP cuff is inflated 20 mm Hg over the systolic BP for three minutes or more.
  • Chvostek's sign: Contraction of the ipsilateral circumoral facial muscles when the facial nerve is tapped just anterior to the ear.
  • Seizures
  • Papilledema
  • Psychiatric manifestations like emotional instability

 

Treatment for acute hypocalcemia:

Acute symptomatic hypocalcemia may be treated with calcium gluconate 10 mL 10% wt/vol (90 mg or 2.2 mmol) intravenously, diluted in 50 mL of 5% dextrose or 0.9% sodium chloride, given intravenously over 5 min.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman, in the first trimester of pregnancy from a tribal area, presented with fever and chills for the last 3 days. After examination of the peripheral smear given below, chloroquine was started but there was no improvement in the patient's condition. Which of the following is preferred for treating this patient?
questions.solution:
Quinine plus clindamycin is preferred for the treatment of chloroquine-resistant falciparum malaria in the 1st trimester of pregnancy.

The given clinical vignette is suggestive of a chloroquine-resistant malarial infection. The image given shows ring forms/ early trophozoites in erythrocytes, which are binucleate (double chromatin) and resemble stereo headphones in appearance, characteristic of malaria caused by P. falciparum. 

Worldwide most infections with P. falciparum malaria are resistant to chloroquine. In the 1st trimester, pregnant women diagnosed with uncomplicated malaria caused by chloroquine-resistant P. falciparum infection, the drug of choice is a combination of quinine and clindamycin. Artemisinin-based combination therapy can be used as an alternative for patients that are unable to tolerate oral quinine.

In the second and third trimesters, they can be treated with artemisinin combination therapy such as:

  • Artemether-lumefantrine
  • Artesunate-amodiaquine
  • Artesunate-mefloquine
  • Dihydroartemisinin-piperaquine
  • Artesunate + clindamycin

During pregnancy, P. vivax malaria is treated with chloroquine as it is safe in pregnancy and children. In chloroquine-resistant vivax cases, clindamycin, quinine, chloroquine, and proguanil can be used.

Other options:

Option B: Doxycycline is useful in the treatment of malaria but not used in pregnancy.

Options C: Artemether plus lumefantrine is not the drug of choice in the 1st trimester of pregnancy. ACT may be given in the first trimester only if oral quinine is not tolerated or not available.

Option D: ACT with sulfadoxine-pyrimethamine is avoided in the first trimester.

questions.text:
Which of the following does not increase the risk of breast carcinoma in women?
  1. Early age of first pregnancy
  2. Positive family history
  3. Breastfeeding
  4. Early menarche and late menopause
  5. Multiparity
questions.solution:
Early age of first pregnancy, breastfeeding, and multiparity are protective factors for carcinoma of the breast. This is due to a reduction in the overall number of ovulatory cycles thereby reducing the duration of estrogen's action on the breast tissues. 

Related Pearl: Risk Factors and Protective Factors for Breast Carcinoma

Risk factors:

  • Age: Incidence increases with increasing age.
  • Sex: more common in females.
  • Family history of breast cancer
  • Race, ethnicity (white women have increased risk compared to women of other races)
  • History of radiation exposure
  • Mammographically dense breast
  • Genetic factors:
  • Mutations in tumor suppressor genes:
    • BRCA 1
    • BRCA 2
    • TP53
    • CHEK2
  • Hereditary syndromes:
    • Li Fraumeni syndrome
    • Cowden’s syndrome
    • HNPCC syndrome
    • Peutz-Jegher’s syndrome
    • Ataxia telangiectasia
  • Hormonal factors (hyperestrogenemia is the risk factor):
    • Early menarche
    • Late menopause
    • First full-term pregnancy >30 years
    • Nulliparity
    • Obesity (postmenopausal)
  • Higher socioeconomic status, high fat diet, alcohol intake

Protective factors:

  • Early age at first pregnancy
  • Multiparity
  • Breastfeeding
  • Oophorectomy
  • Exercise
  • Tamoxifen and Aromatase inhibitors

questions.text: A 9-month-old child was brought to the PHC with complaints of fast breathing. On examination, the respiratory rate was 50 breaths/min, without chest indrawing. You diagnose the child with Pneumonia and prescribe an antibiotic. You advise the mother to give home care and to return with the child in 2 days for re-assessment. On review after 2 days, the child's condition was found to same as before. How would you proceed in this case?

choices.text: No intervention needed as the child hasn't worsened
Refer urgently to the nearest PICU center
Finish 5 days of antibiotic and reassess

questions.solution:
As the child's condition is the same after 2 days of antibiotic, it is advised to change the antibiotic.

Three key clinical signs are used to assess a sick child with cough or difficult breathing:

  • Respiratory rate
    • Which distinguishes children who have pneumonia from those who do not
    • > 50 for infants 2 months to 12 months
    • > 40 for children 12 months to 5 years of age
  • Lower chest wall indrawing
    • Which indicates pneumonia
  • Stridor
    • Which indicates those with severe pneumonia who require hospital admission.

The following table gives the classification for cough / difficult breathing from 2 months to 5 years of age:

Signs

Worse:

  • Not able to drink
  • Breathing slower
  • Has chest indrawing
  • Has other danger signs

  • Breathing slower
  • Less fever 
  • Eating better
Treatment Refer urgently to hospital Change antibiotic or Refer  Finish 5 days of antibiotic

The recent WHO guidelines state that chest indrawing and fast breathing is in the category of pneumonia.

Signs of severe pneumonia are:

  • Not able to drink
  • Persistent vomiting
  • Convulsions
  • Lethargic or unconscious
  • Stridor in a calm child
  • Severe malnutrition

questions.text:
Amidst a busy day in your clinic, you notice a toddler running towards you gleefully. The child has been brought to you for a well-baby checkup and the parents have no complaints. The child is quite playful. You notice the child has mild pallor on examination. She arranges the blocks kept on the table in a tower of 3 blocks. Which of the following additional tasks might the child be able to perform?
  1. Copy a circle on a sheet of paper
  2. Walk upstairs with alternate feet

The child can run, and can make a tower of 3, and therefore her age is likely to be 18 months. A child who can arrange a tower of 3 is likely to be 18 months of age and hence will also come when called, which is a social milestone achieved at 12 months of age.

questions.text: A patient presented to the ER with right wrist pain. He states that he was playing golf when he took a swing, missed the ball, and hit gravel. Vitals are within normal limits and physical examination shows tenderness to gentle palpation pain over hypothenar eminence and pain with right wrist range of motion testing. There is mild swelling over his right wrist.  X-ray shows a fracture of the hook of the hamate of the right wrist. Which of the following nerves could be most likely injured due to this fracture?

choices.text: Deep branch of the ulnar nerve
Superficial branch of the ulnar nerve

questions.solution:
The deep branch of the ulnar nerve is the likely nerve to be injured due to a fracture of the hook of Hamate.

The hook of Hamate fracture:

Most commonly due to direct blow to the hook of the hamate(ex: hitting the ground with a golf club)

Clinical features - 
- Pain and tenderness over hypothenar eminence, persistent pain over hypothenar eminence, and swelling may be mild or absent
- Clinical features include weakness/paralysis of the intrinsic muscles of the hand innervated by the ulnar nerve, which may present as a weakening of the handgrip and clawing of the fourth and fifth digits. Hypothenar atrophy may also be present.

questions.text: A third-year medical student is brought to the emergency room with a nose bleed after getting hit in the face during a rough football game. The bleeding is profuse and Trotter's method does not succeed in controlling the bleeding. As it not possible to identify the source of the bleed, the resident decides to perform anterior nasal packing on the patient. The student is not aware of any family history of bleeding disorders in the family. This can be done using:
questions.solution:
In the case of anterior epistaxis when the bleeding point is not located, anterior nasal packing with ribbon gauze soaked in paraffin can be done. Tilley's forceps marked as 'A' are used for anterior nasal packing. It can also be used for nasal packing, ear dressing removal, and removal of foreign bodies from the nose.The stepwise management of epistaxis:

  1. Pinching the nose 
  2. Hippocratic or Trotter’s method
  3. Cauterisation
  4. Anterior nasal packing
  5. Posterior nasal packing 
  6. Endoscopic Cauterisation 
  7. Ligation 
  8. Embolization

questions.text: A 28-year-old male patient comes to the ophthalmology clinic with complaints of floating spots in both eyes and blurring of vision for the last three weeks. On examination, there is some redness in both eyes. Corneal edema and a constricted pupil are seen. Fundus examination shows sheathing, superficial retinal hemorrhages, and cotton wool spots involving the small peripheral retinal capillaries, arterioles, and venules. Some branched retinal vein occlusion is also seen. Laboratory investigations done to rule out systemic conditions are negative. A diagnosis of Eales disease is made. Which of the following statements is incorrect regarding the management?

choices.text: Steroids are useful in the inflammatory stage
Antitubercular therapy is contraindicated in patients with this disease
Scatter photocoagulation of non perfused retina reduces neovascular stimulus
Vitrectomy is indicated for patients with persistent vitreous hemorrhage

questions.solution:
Antitubercular therapy is not contraindicated in patients with Eales disease. In fact, antitubercular treatment is strongly advocated by some authorities but is controversial. . It may be considered in selected patients in combination with steroids,  avoid reactivation of prior tubercular infection, or when severe ocular inflammatory signs are present.

Eales disease is an idiopathic occlusive peripheral periphlebitis. It commonly occurs in young males from the Indian subcontinent. 

Clinical presentation:

  • Most patients present with floaters
  • Mild visual blurring may occur early in the disease course
  • Sudden vision loss occurs in severe disease due to vitreous hemorrhage
  • Three overlapping clinical stages have been described: inflammatory, occlusive, and retinal neovascular
  • Examination:
    • Systemic neurological features have been reported in some patients
    • Mild anterior uveitis is seen 
    • Fundoscopy shows peripheral phlebitis (sheathing, superficial retinal hemorrhages, and cotton wool spots), branched retinal vein occlusion, peripheral capillary non-perfusion, microaneurysms, tortuosity, vascular shunts, and neovascularization. Recurrent vitreous hemorrhage may develop at the junction of the perfused and non-perfused retina. Macular edema may develop.
  • Complications
    • Tractional retinal detachment
    • Macular epiretinal membrane
    • Neovascular glaucoma
    • Cataract

Investigations:

Primarily to rule out systemic causes of vasculitis (sarcoidosis, TB), hemoglobinopathies, diabetes mellitus.

Treatment:

  • Periocular, systemic, topical, and intravitreal steroids are helpful in the inflammatory stage.
  • Antitubercular treatment is strongly advocated by some authorities but is controversial
  • Scatter photocoagulation or cryotherapy of the retina to reduce the neovascular stimulus
  • Intravitreal VEGF inhibitors
  • Vitrectomy for severe cases and complications

questions.text: A 37-year-old male from the Zaire region in Africa developed high-grade fever, sore throat, and pain in the muscles and joints. This was followed by severe vomiting, hemoptysis, and diarrhea. He develops a maculopapular rash after 5 days followed by severe bleeding and dies. There are many similar cases in his village. The likely infectious agent is shown in the given image.  The epidemiologist appointed by the WHO in this region is calculating the case fatality rate of this disease. By doing this, he is likely measuring the ______ of the disease/infection.
questions.solution:
The case fatality rate is one way of measuring the virulence of the disease or infection. Virulence is defined as the proportion of clinical cases resulting in severe clinical manifestations, including death.

The case fatality rate is calculated as (Total number of deaths due to a particular disease)/(Total number of cases due to the same disease)x 100.

The given clinical scenario and the electron micrograph image point towards an infection caused by the Ebola virus. Ebola virus is the cause of an emerging disease called Ebola virus disease and is widespread in Africa. It belongs to the Filoviridae family. Fruit bats act as reservoir hosts of the virus and it is transmitted to humans only accidentally. Human-to-human transmission is through direct contact with blood or body fluids of an infected symptomatic person. It can remain in semen for up to 3 months, although sexual transmission has not been reported yet.

The infection is common in Sudan and Zaire provinces in Africa. The incubation period of the disease is 2 to 21 days. Symptoms include fever, intense weakness, vomiting, diarrhea, rashes, and, in extreme cases, internal and external bleeding. The current treatment is mainly supportive. Ebola virus is highly virulent and requires maximum containment facilities (Biosafety Level 4) for laboratory work.

Ebola virus shows a bowl of spaghetti appearance. This virus has the highest mortality rate (25–90%) of all viral hemorrhagic fevers. Patients are susceptible to reinfection even after a complete cure.

 

Other options:

  • Infectivity is the ability of an infectious agent to invade and multiply in a host.
  • Incidence is the number of new cases occurring in a defined population during a period of time.
  • Prevalence is the proportion of all cases, old and new, of a particular disease at a given point in time or over a period of time in a given population.

Related Pearl: Case Fatality Rate

  • Case fatality rate =  (Total number of deaths due to a particular disease)/(Total number of cases due to the same disease)x 100
  • It is a good indicator of severity or killing power of a disease.
  • It is used mostly in acute and infectious diseases.
  • No time interval is used.
  • Case fatality rate is closely related to virulence.
  • Limitation of CFR is that its usefulness for chronic diseases is limited because the period from onset to death is variable.
  • It is expressed in percentage.
  • CFR is an incidence proportion and not a true rate.
  • CFR may vary for the same disease in different epidemics.

  • Case fatality of a few diseases:

    • Rabies - 100% especially after symptoms manifest
    • Ebola - 25 to 90%, average - 50% 
    • Yellow fever - 15 to 50%
    • Chicken pox - 0.001%
  • Diseases with a high case fatality rate: Tetanus, Rabies, Botulism, Ebola.
  • Diseases with a low case fatality rate: Leprosy, Trachoma, Lymphatic filariasis.

questions.text: A 50-year-old female presents with urinary incontinence for the past week. She states that laughing or sneezing causes her to urinate involuntarily. She is extremely embarrassed by this.  She does not have dribbling or urinary retention. Physical examination shows that the Valsalva maneuver causes expulsion of urine. During the surgical repair of this condition, the consultant performs anterior colporrhaphy along with plication of the bladder neck via a vaginal approach. Which of the following operations is being done on the above patient?
questions.solution:
Kelly’s repair done for stress urinary incontinence include anterior colporrhaphy with plication of the bladder neck via a vaginal approach.

Genuine stress incontinence (GSI) occurs when the bladder pressure exceeds urethral pressure during physical stress in the absence of detrusor contraction

Surgical Repair of Stress Urinary Incontinence includes,

Vaginal Operations: 

  • Kelly’s repair: Anterior colporrhaphy with plication of the bladder neck.
  • Pacey’s repair: Apposing medial fibres of puborectalis muscles in the midline under the bladder neck region to elevate it.

Abdominal Operations:

  • Marshall–Marchetti–Krantz operation: Here bladder neck and the vaginal vault is sutured to the periosteum of the back of the pubic symphysis. Osteitis may follow this operation.
  • Burch colposuspension: Here vaginal suspension is achieved using the iliopectineal ligaments.

Combined Abdominal and Vaginal Operations: Pereyra operation

questions.text: A female complains of pain in her right lower limb for 3 months. She has mild swelling below her right knee joint. She has no history of recent fever. Vital signs are within normal limits and physical examination is significant for tenderness over the right fibula proximally.  An X-ray of her right lower limb is shown in the image below. Which of the following represents the most common combination of age group and anatomic location for the occurrence of this disease?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario describes a case of an aneurysmal bone cyst. It commonly presents at an age <20 years old and occurs on the metaphysis of long bones.

Aneurysmal bone cyst - 

Aneurysmal bone cysts are benign, locally destructive multiloculated cysts filled with blood. They are eccentric, expansile, and lytic lesions. Most occur in patients younger than 20 years old. There is a slight female preponderance. The most common sites involved are the proximal humerus, distal femur, and proximal tibia. The spine is involved in 15-20% of cases. Presents with pain and swelling. Spinal lesions may cause neurologic deficits or radicular pain.

Clinical features of aneurysmal bone cyst -
Commonly presents in women age <20 years old. Presents as bone pain and swelling for a period of fewer than 6 months.

The below image has an extremely expansive, metaphyseal, lytic lesion, with a short transition zone and non-sclerotic rim, located in the proximal third of the left fibula suggestive of an Aneurysmal bone cyst.

Other Options:

The below X-ray shows expansile, eccentric, sub-articular soap bubble appearance lesion suggestive of Giant cell tumor (Osteoclastoma).

Differential: 

Simple bone cyst- 

  • Simple bone cyst presents most commonly in the first two decades.
  • It is due to the defect in the metaphyseal remodeling which blocks the drainage of interstitial fluid. This leads to increased pressure which leads to focal bone necrosis and accumulation of fluid.
  • Most common site is proximal humeral metaphysis.
  • On radiology, a centrally located, purely lytic lesion with a well-marginated outline is seen.
  • No periosteal reaction is seen unless there is a fracture.

questions.text:
A 34-year-old female patient presents with complaints of chronic cough, fatigue, joint pains, and swelling of both cheeks. She also complains of painful rashes on her knees which were diagnosed as erythema nodosum. On examination, the pulse rate is 90/min, respiratory rate is 19/min, and blood pressure is 120/80 mm Hg. Her chest X-Ray is shown below. Which of the following is likely to be seen in this condition?

ACTH: Adrenocorticotropic hormone
questions.solution:
The clinical features, X-ray showing bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy, together with the presence of erythema nodosum, suggests the diagnosis of sarcoidosis. Hypercalcemia is seen in patients with sarcoidosis. 

Sarcoidosis is a granulomatous disorder of unknown etiology that is characterized by the presence of non-caseating granulomas.

In acute cases, patients may typically present with Lofgren’s syndrome, consisting of arthritis, erythema nodosum, uveitis, bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy, lethargy, and occasional fever. Patients may also present with insidious onset of cough, breathlessness, and radiographic infiltrates.

An image of erythema nodosum is shown below:

 

Investigations:

  • Lymphopenia and deranged liver function tests are usually seen.
  • Hypercalcemia is seen that is due to the increased synthesis of calcitriol (1,25-dihydroxy vitamin D) by the granuloma. In some patients, there may be hypercalciuria, which can lead to nephrocalcinosis.
  • Pulmonary function test shows a restrictive lung disease, with impaired gas exchange.
  • Bronchoscopy shows the typical 'cobblestone' appearance of the mucosa. Bronchial and transbronchial biopsies reveal non-caseating granulomas. An increased CD4:CD8 T-cell ratio may be seen in bronchoalveolar lavage.
  • Chest X-ray is useful for staging sarcoidosis.
  • HRCT shows reticulonodular opacities and peribronchial thickening that are predominant in the subpleural areas.

Below is an image of the chest X-ray (a) and coronal (a’) high resolution computed tomography (HRCT) scans showing the typical symmetric reticulonodular opacities of sarcoidosis:

 

Note:

  • Hypercalcemia and/or hypercalciuria occurs in about 10% of sarcoidosis patients. It is more common in whites than African Americans and in men.
  • The mechanism of abnormal calcium metabolism is increased production of 1,25-dihydroxy vitamin D by the granuloma itself.
  • The 1,25-dihydroxy vitamin D causes increased intestinal absorption of calcium, leading to hypercalcemia with a suppressed parathyroid hormone (PTH) level.

 Treatment options:

  • Glucocorticoids remain the main drug of choice in the treatment of sarcoidosis.
  • In those patients who require persistent corticosteroids, the following steroid-sparing alternatives are considered 
    • Hydroxychloroquine 
    • Methotrexate
    • Azathioprine
    • Leflunomide
    • Mycophenolate
    • Cyclophosphamide
    • Thalidomide to some extent in a limited number of cases

Other options:

Option B- Although patients with chronic cough should be evaluated for tuberculosis, a tuberculin test is unlikely to be positive in this patient with typical features of sarcoidosis.

Option C- Stratosphere sign is seen on ultrasound in patients with pneumothorax. The below image shows the same.

 

Option D- Elevated ACTH is seen in patients with small cell carcinoma as a paraneoplastic syndrome leading to Cushingoid features.

choices.text: Deposition of calcium pyrophosphate crystals is associated
The crystals will be yellow when aligned parallel to the axis of polarised light
Genetic testing in this patient will reveal a HFE gene mutation
Calcifications involving the menisci are likely to be seen

questions.solution:
The clinical vignette describes a case of hemochromatosis with pseudogout. The crystals in pseudogout appear positively birefringent rhomboid-shaped crystals (blue when aligned parallel to the axis of polarized light) and it is due to the deposition of calcium pyrophosphate crystals.

This patient has been experiencing fatigue and has recently been diagnosed with diabetes mellitus. Patients with hemochromatosis have HFE gene mutations which leads to defective iron transport. It is an autosomal recessive condition with low penetrance. The resulting iron overload in these patients causes deposition of iron in the liver, pancreas, heart, pituitary gland and other organs. Iron deposition leads to characteristic clinical features such as fatigue, bronze discolouration of skin, diabetes mellitus, impotence.

In patients with hereditary hemochromatosis, the presence of ferric salts in the joints appears to enhance crystal deposition. This leads to deposition of calcium pyrophosphate thereby leading to pseudogout.

The given case is suggestive of pseudogout and in the study of synovial aspirate on polarized light, the 

Crystals on Polarised Microscopy
Gout Pseudogout
Negatively birefringent Positively birefringent
Needle shaped Rhomboid crystals
Na urate (Sodium urate) Calcium pyrophosphate

Clinically, CPP tends to have a slightly less acute onset, attacks lasting longer (7-10 days) and pain is less severe than gout. Larger joints are more affected in pseudogout, unlike gout.

Calcium pyrophosphate crystal deposition disease (CPPD), also known as pseudo-gout and chondrocalcinosis, usually occurs in individuals older than 50 years of age and becomes more common with increasing age.

  • CPPD is classified into the sporadic (idiopathic), hereditary, and secondary types.
  • The disease is caused by germline mutations in the pyrophosphate transport channel.
  • This is the most common cause of acute monoarthritis in the elderly, especially in hospital patients.
  • The secondary form is associated with previous joint damage, hyperparathyroidism, hemochromatosis, hypomagnesemia, hypothyroidism, ochronosis, and diabetes.
  • Individual crystals are rhomboid, 0.5 to 5 μm in the greatest dimension, and are positively birefringent. Inflammation, if present, is usually milder than in gout.
  • CPPD may produce acute, subacute, or chronic arthritis that can be confused with osteoarthritis or rheumatoid arthritis.
  • The joint involvement may be monoarticular or polyarticular; the knees, followed by the wrists, elbows, shoulders, and ankles, are most commonly affected.
  • Calcification of the cartilages (chondrocalcinosis) is a defining radiographic feature and commonly involves the menisci of the knee (usually bilaterally), the symphysis pubis, the triangular fibrocartilage of the wrist joints, and the glenoid and acetabular labra

Management: Rest, analgesia, aspiration, injection with steroid, NSAIDS, or Colchicine.

Gout: The image below shows characteristic long, slender, needle-shaped urate crystals found in Gout. They are negatively birefringent under polarized light.

Precipitation of monosodium urate crystals (MSU) is the hallmark of Gout. The lower temperature of the peripheral joints promotes their precipitation. MSU crystals are frequently found in the cytoplasm of the neutrophils and are arranged in small clusters in the synovium.

questions.text: A 32-year-old man presents with new-onset hematuria. He states that he has had abdominal pain for 1 week. There is no burning micturition or increased frequency/retention. His blood pressure is 158/105 mmHg, and there is flank tenderness. Ultrasound examination of the flanks is shown in the image below. Which of the following is false regarding the underlying disease?

choices.text: Cysts may also be present in the liver and pancreas.
Mutation of PKD 1 is responsible for 85% of the cases.
Cardiovascular complications are a major cause of mortality.
The most common type of kidney stone in this condition is the calcium oxalate stone.

questions.solution:
The clinical vignette describes a case of autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease (ADPKD). Uric acid stones are more common than calcium oxalate stones in ADPKD.

ADPKD is a genetic disorder characterized by multiple bilateral kidney cysts associated with cysts in other organs such as the liver, pancreas, and arachnoid membranes. It is caused by mutations in the PKD-1 (85% of cases) and PKD-2 genes which code for the transmembrane proteins polycystin-1 and polycystin-2. 

The presentation is variable and it may be asymptomatic until the fifth decade of life, when it is diagnosed incidentally. Abdominal mass, back or flank pain, and hypertension are common presentations among symptomatic patients. Gross hematuria may be present. 

Many patients develop renal stones. In patients with ADPKD, uric acid stones are more common than calcium oxalate stones. Renal cyst infections are very common in patients with ADPKD and are commonly caused by gram-negative bacteria.

Cysts may also be present in the liver and pancreas, and intracranial aneurysms may occur. Mitral valve prolapse and valvular insufficiency may be present. Cardiovascular complications are a major cause of mortality in ADPKD.  

The diagnosis is made based on positive family history and the presence of multiple bilateral renal cysts. Ultrasonography is used for presymptomatic screening of at-risk individuals.

Treatment involves blood pressure control, pain control with analgesics, and hydration. Surgical decompression of cysts is done occasionally. Most patients require dialysis eventually.

questions.text: A 35-year-old rice farmer presented with a high-grade fever, diarrhea, seizures, tremors, and vomiting. The physician suspects an illness transmitted by the mosquito shown below.  Which of the following statements is false?

choices.text: Wings are unspotted in adult stage
Siphon tube is present in larval stage
Rests parallel to the water surface in larval stage

questions.solution:
The image shown is of the Culex species of mosquito due to unspotted wings and hunched back. The false statement about the Culex mosquito is - rests parallel to the water surface in the larval stage.

The rice farmer presents with features of acute encephalitis and non-specific features like fever, cough, and diarrhea, the most likely diagnosis is Japanese encephalitis. 

The Culex mosquitoes are vectors or carriers for Bancroftian filariasis, Japanese encephalitis, West Nile fever, and viral arthritis. 

In the larval stage, they are suspended with head downwards at an angle, a siphon tube is present, and there is absence of palmate hairs. They lay the eggs in clusters, and adult mosquitoes have their wings unspotted with hunched back.

Various mosquito larvae are shown in the image below. Siphon tube is present in Aedes and Culex, whereas, it is absent in Anopheles.

 

Japanese encephalitis (JE) is the most prevalent cause of viral encephalitis in Asia. It is a mosquito-borne zoonotic disease caused by Flavivirus. It is transmitted mainly by the bite of Culex mosquitoes, specifically Culex tritaeniorhynchus and Culex vishnui (common in India) species.

JE is a zoonotic disease primarily affecting animals like pigs and ardeid birds. Pigs are considered the major vertebrate hosts and amplifiers for the JE virus. Humans are the dead-end hosts for this virus. When a mosquito bites an infected pig, the virus is transmitted to the mosquito. The virus, in turn, is transferred to other pigs or humans due to mosquito bites and this cycle continues. Horses are the only known domestic animals that present with signs of JE infection.

The control measures include mosquito control by areal or ground fogging with ultra-low-volume insecticides such as malathion and fenitrothion, locating piggeries away from the human dwellings, and vaccinating pigs. Ultra-low-volume fogging is a method of insecticide application where a small volume (<500 ml/hectare) of liquid insecticide is applied to provide maximum killing of disease vectors.

JE vaccine is given in two doses- at 9-12 months of age and at 16-24 months of age in areas that are endemic to the disease, according to the National Immunisation Schedule.

The transmission cycle of the Japanese encephalitis virus is shown below:

Related Pearl: The Mosquito

The mosquito as a vector:

  • Mosquitoes are global in distribution
  • The main species of mosquitoes include the Anopheles, Culex, Aedes, and Mansonia
  • Flight range varies up to 11 km, except Aedes for which it is 100 meters
  • The life span of mosquitoes is around 8 to 34 days
  • Their morphology consists of a head with a proboscis, a pair of palpi, and a pair of antennae; a thorax and an abdomen
  • The larval stage lasts for 5 to 7 days

questions.text: An 8-year-old boy with a history of fever,  colicky abdominal pain, the passage of blood per rectum 10 days ago, has now presented with swelling of knee joints and a non-blanching palpable erythematous rash, seen predominantly on the lower limbs and buttocks. Platelet levels are within normal ranges. Urine examination showed hematuria and proteinuria. A skin biopsy is done to reveal the following finding. What is the most likely type of hypersensitivity in this scenario?
questions.solution:
Clinical features along with the antibodies against vessel walls seen in the immunofluorescence study point towards a diagnosis of Henoch Schonlein purpura. It is also known as IgA vasculitis which is a type III hypersensitivity reaction. It is a small vessel vasculitis that occurs due to the IgA immune complex deposition within the wall of the blood vessels. It is commonly seen in children and is characterized by:

  • Palpable purpura without thrombocytopenia and coagulopathy
  • Arthralgia- commonly affecting hip, knee, or ankle joints
  • Abdominal pain
  • About half of the patients with HSP develop renal manifestations, which vary from asymptomatic microscopic hematuria to severe, progressive glomerulonephritis.

The skin biopsy will show small vessel vasculitis, with IgA and C3 deposition in the affected organs by immunofluorescence.

In type III hypersensitivity, immune complexes may deposit in tissues or blood vessels, and elicit an acute inflammatory reaction by activating the complement system. The inflammatory reaction causes tissue injury.

The pathogenesis of systemic immune complex disease can be divided into three phases:

  • Formation of immune complexes
  • Deposition of immune complexes
  • Inflammation and tissue injury.

questions.text:
A biochemistry resident plots a graph while studying the effect of an inhibitor on an enzymatic reaction. Which of the following statements is false, with respect to the following graph that he has plotted?

Km: The substrate concentration at which velocity is half the maximum.

Vmax: The maximum velocity of a reaction.

v0: Reaction velocity

[S]: Substrate concentration

choices.text: Reaction is with a non-competitive inhibitor
Inhibitor binds to the enzyme in location other than the active site
The degree of inhibition is based solely upon the concentration of inhibitor
Can be overcome by increasing the substrate concentration

questions.solution:
The given graph represents a reaction with a non-competitive inhibitor and it cannot be overcome by increasing the concentration of the substrate.

The above graph is called the 'Lineweaver-Burk plot' or 'double reciprocal' plot. 1/v0 is plotted versus 1/[S] and a straight line is obtained. This plot can be used to calculate Km and Vmax as well as to determine the mechanism of action of enzyme inhibitors.

In non-competitive inhibition, Vmax decreases (or 1/Vmax increases) but Km is unchanged. Hence the graphs of inhibited and uninhibited reactions have the same x-intercepts (converge at -1/Km) but different y-intercepts.

In contrast to competitive inhibitors, noncompetitive inhibitors bind to enzymes in locations away from the active site. For this reason, the degree of inhibition is based solely upon the concentration of the inhibitor, and increasing the substrate concentrations does not compete with or change the inhibition. Therefore, unlike the increase in Km seen with competitive inhibition, in noncompetitive inhibition, Vmax decreases while Km usually remains the same. While competitive inhibitors can be overcome at a sufficiently high substrate concentration, non-competitive inhibition is irreversible and cannot be overcome by increasing the concentration of the substrate.

questions.text:
A 45-year-old female comes in for an annual check-up. She states that she has been urinating more frequently than usual and also feels more hungry. Further lab results show elevated random blood sugar, fasting blood sugar, and HbA1c of 7.2%. A diagnosis of type II diabetes is made. Which of the following statements are true regarding the receptor responsible for insulin-mediated glucose uptake?

1 - Predominantly present on skeletal muscle, cardiac muscle, and adipose tissue
2 - Increases the number of GLUT-4 transporters in the cell membranes of liver
3 - Causes phosphorylation of glucose by inducing glucokinase
4 - A pool of GLUT-4 molecules is maintained in the Golgi apparatus of insulin-sensitive cells
5 - Insulin moves the vesicles to the cell membrane by activating a 5′-adenosine monophosphate (AMP)–activated kinase
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette is suggestive of diabetes mellitus and GLUT 4 is involved in insulin-mediated uptake of glucose. 

The following statements are true about GLUT 4
  • Predominantly present on skeletal muscle, cardiac muscle, and adipose tissue
  • Insulin increases the entry of glucose into the liver cells but it DOES NOT increase the number of GLUT-4 transporters in the cell membranes of the liver. Instead, it causes phosphorylation of glucose by inducing glucokinase.
  • A pool of GLUT-4 molecules is maintained within vesicles in the cytoplasm of insulin-sensitive cells. 
  • Activation of the insulin receptor moves these vesicles to the cell membrane by activating phosphatidylinositol 3-kinase.
  • A subset of GLUT-4 vesicles move to the cell membrane in response to exercise (independent of the action of the insulin) through a 5′-adenosine monophosphate (AMP)–activated kinase. This is why exercise lowers blood sugar.

questions.text: A 58-year-old man was treated with an intravenous diuretic for heart failure. Now he presents with  tinnitus,  vertigo, a sense of fullness in the ears and difficulty in hearing from the right ear. Examination shows Weber’s test localised to the left ear and Rinne’s test shows AC>BC in both ears.  The responsible offending agent acts most likely in which part of the nephron?

choices.text: Descending limb of the loop of Henle
Thick ascending limb of the loop of Henle

questions.solution:
The clinical scenario is suggestive of a drug-induced sensorineural type of hearing loss, and furosemide is likely to be associated with these side effects (ototoxicity). This is due to the adverse effect of IV furosemide used during his heart failure treatment. Furosemide acts on the thick ascending limb of the loop of Henle.

Interpretation of the given audiogram:

  • Red indicates right ear
  • O indicates AC and threshold is >15 dB. Hence AC is abnormal
  • < indicates BC and threshold is >25 dB. Hence BC is abnormal
  • Both AC and BC are abnormal. It indicates sensorineural hearing loss
  • There is no Air-Bone gap
  • Hence it is right side sensorineural hearing loss

Since Weber is lateralised towards left, it indicates left sided conductive deafness or right sided sensorineural deafness. Since Rinne is positive on both ears, conductive deafness is ruled out. Therefore, it is Right sided sensorineural hearing loss.

Other options:

Carbonic anhydrase acts on the PCT. It is used for glaucoma, pseudotumor cerebri, metabolic alkalosis and cystine stone prevention.Due to their structural homology to the sulfonamides, they may cause bone marrow depression, skin toxicity, and allergic reactions.

Thiazides act on the DCT. It is used for treatment of hypertension and chronic edema. Their adverse effects are as follows

  • Hypotension
  • Hyponatremia
  • Hypokalemia
  • Hypomagnesemia
  • Hypochloremia
  • Hyperuricemia
  • Hypercalcemia
  • Decrease glucose tolerance
  • May increase the lipid levels

ADH receptor antagonists like Tolvaptan act in medullary CT. Used for treating hyponatremia. They can cause hypokalemia, dehydration, liver damage (eps contraindicated in people with previous liver disease) as side effects.

Other common ototoxic drugs are:

  1. Antibiotics like Aminoglycosides ( gentamicin > tobramycin > amikacin > neomycin), erythromycin, tetracyclines.
  2. Chemotherapeutic agents like Cisplatin, Bleomycin and Nitrogen mustard.
  3. High dose aspirin, acetaminophen and NSAID’s
  4. Antimalarials like quinine and quinidine
  5. Phosphodiesterase 5 inhibitors like Sildenafil

questions.text: A 24-year-old man presented with a high fever, muscle aches, and easy fatigability. He gives history of diarrhoea and abdominal pain about 6 weeks ago. Dietary history reveals consumption of raw or undercooked pork. The blood investigations showed eosinophilia. His muscle biopsy shows the following finding. Which of the following statements is incorrect regarding the causative organism of this disease?

choices.text: Pig acts as an intermediate host

questions.solution:
The given image shows an encysted spiral larvae in the muscle which is characteristic of Trichinella spiralis. The clinical presentation and eosinophilia further support the diagnosis. Neurocysticercosis is caused by Taenia solium ( larval stage known as Cysticercosis cellulose).

Trichinella is viviparous i.e. produces larvae. The larvae enter the intestine and invade the epithelium developing into adult. Clinical features at this stage include nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, and abdominal pain. In the later phase of the infection, the larvae move from the intestines into the circulation and migrate into muscles where they are encysted. This causes symptoms like fever, myalgia, etc.

Detection of spiral larvae in muscle tissue is done by performing a muscle biopsy. Deltoid, biceps, gastrocnemius, or pectoralis muscles are usually selected for biopsy. About 1 g of muscle tissue preferably near the tendon insertion is biopsied. Safranin staining is done. 

It can be treated using albendazole along with steroids to control inflammation.

Note:

Neurocysticercosis is caused by the CNS infection with the pork "tapeworm", Taenia solium. It typically presents with seizures. Infection leads to extra-intestinal disease (including neurocysticercosis) usually occurs as a result of eating food or drinking water contaminated by human feces containing T. solium eggs.

questions.text: A pregnant woman is bitten by the following insect and develops a characteristic eschar at the site of the bite, with regional lymphadenopathy and a maculopapular rash. There is no history of contact with infected animal hide or skin. A positive Weil-Felix test with OX K agglutinins is observed. What will be the drug of choice in this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with a positive Weil-Felix test with OX K agglutinins, and the life cycle of a trombiculid mite (which acts as the vector) are suggestive of scrub typhus. Humans are seen to be infected when they are bitten by the mite larvae (chiggers). The drug of choice for a case of scrub typhus during pregnancy is azithromycin. For other patients the DOC is doxycycline.

Azithromycin or rifampin is administered as an alternative for patients allergic to doxycycline and in pregnancy. An alternative in pregnant women and patients allergic to doxycycline is chloramphenicol.

Scrub Typhus is also known as chigger-borne typhus which is caused by Rickettsia or Orientia tsutsugamushi. The vector is trombiculid mite. Humans are infected when they are bitten by the mite larvae known as chiggers. The incubation period is 1- 3 weeks. The patient typically develops a characteristic eschar at the site of the mite bite, with regional lymphadenopathy and maculopapular rash.

Cutaneous anthrax also presents with a characteristic black eschar, which is caused by Bacillus anthracis. It is commonly seen in tanners or hide porters who come in contact with infected animal hide and skins.

 

Doxycycline 100mg BD for 7-14 days is the drug of choice for treatment of Scrub Typhus in adults. Doxycycline is a tetracycline that acts by inhibiting protein synthesis.

Tetracyclines are active against MRSA and MSSA. Doxycycline and minocycline can be used in cutaneous MRSA infections. Ricketssia and chlamydia are highly susceptible to tetracyclines. Tetracyclines are considered fist line agents for chlamydial infections like non-specific urethritis/ endocervicitis and rickettsial infections like typhus, rocky mountain spotted fever, Q fever. They are also second-line drugs in syphilis patients who are allergic to penicillin.

Tetracyclines are bacteriostatic drug with more active against gram-positive  than gram-negative. They are  effective against spirochetes, Haemophilus ducreyi, Vibrio cholera, Mycoplasma pneumoniae.

Other uses of doxycycline:

  • Doxycycline as an alternative to penicillin for the treatment of leptospirosis.
  • Doxycycline treatment for 21 days is the first-line therapy for lymphogranuloma venerum. 
  • Doxycycline is indicated as one of the first-line treatment for borreliosis.

  • Doxycycline can be taken as prophylaxis before going to malaria-endemic places.

    Chemoprophylaxis in travelers:

    • If the duration of travel is less than 6 weeks then doxycycline 100mg once a day can be started 2 days before travel and continued atleast 4 weeks after travel.
    • If the duration of travel is more than 6 weeks then mefloquine 250mg once a week can be started 2 weeks before travel and continued atleast 4 weeks after travel.

Doxycycline does not require dose reduction in renal failure.

Doxycycline and tetracycline are not preferred in pregnant women/children due to their effect on teeth and bones especially in children < 8years.

Azithromycin is a macrolide antibiotic.

Azithromycin has a high volume of distribution. The tissue concentrations exceed serum concentrations by 10- to 100-fold. It is slowly released from tissue stores to produce an elimination half life approaching 3 days.

The unique property of azithromycin makes it appropriate for once daily dosing and shortening dosage period. A single 1 g azithromycin is as effective as 7 day course of doxycycline for chlamydial cervicitis and urethritis. Azithromycin is also safe for use in young children and pregnant women.

Other uses of Azithromycin:

  • Recommended therapy for severe babesiosis is azithromycin plus atovaquone.
  • Triple drug therapy for Mycobacterium avium complex regimen includes a Rifamycin, like rifampicin, Ethambutol and a Macrolide, like clarithromycin or azithromycin
  • Azithromycin 2g single dose is an alternative that can cover both Gonococcal and Non-gonococcal cervicitis . Three organisms needed to be covered when it comes to cervicitis in women
  • Gonorrhoea
    • Recommended regimen : Ceftriaxone 250mg IM + Azithromycin 1g oral single dose.
    • Alternative regimen: Cefixime 400 mg orally in a single dose + Azithromycin 1 g orally in a single dose
  • Chlamydia
    • Doxycycline 100mg BD for 7 days (or) Azithromycin 1g single dose
  • Mycoplasma
    • Azithromycin 1g single dose.

Azithromycin 2g single dose is an alternative that can cover all the given strains.

Note

  • Usually a combination of Ceftriaxone + Azithromycin is used as Azithromycin alone is lot inferior in treating gonococcus.

Scrub typhus gives positive Weil-Felix test with OX K agglutinins.

Weil-Felix reaction is a heterophile agglutination reaction wherein the sera are tested for agglutinins to the O antigens of certain Proteus strains OX 19, OX 2 and OX K. The basis of the test is sharing an alkali stable carbohydrate antigen by some Rickettsiae and by some strains of Proteus.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman comes for evaluation of recurrent fetal losses. She has had 4 spontaneous abortions all at <10 weeks of gestational age. She also has a history of recurrent deep venous thromboses. In the past year, she has had 5 events. Her physical exam is unremarkable. Diagnosis is made based on lab investigations and she is started on anticoagulation. Which of the following is not useful in diagnosing this patient's underlying condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette is suggestive of Antiphospholipid syndrome. All the above-mentioned antibodies are useful for the diagnosis of Antiphospholipid syndrome except Anti ds DNA antibodies.

The diagnostic criteria for antiphospholipid antibody syndrome are as follows:

Clinical criteria:

Obstetric

  • Three or more unexplained consecutive spontaneous abortions before 10 weeks
  • One or more deaths of a morphologically normal fetus at or beyond 10 weeks
  • At least one preterm birth before 34 weeks of gestation because of eclampsia, severe preeclampsia, or placental insufficiency

Vascular: One or more episodes of arterial, venous, or small vessel thrombosis in any tissue or organ.

Laboratory criteria:

  • Presence of lupus anticoagulant
  • Presence of IgG or IgM anti-cardiolipin antibodies
  • Presence of IgG or IgM anti-beta-2 glycoprotein I antibodies

At least one clinical and one laboratory criterion has to be present for a diagnosis to be made.

Management: Women are treated with low-dose aspirin (50 mg/day) and heparin (5,000 units SC twice daily) for up to 34 weeks. Unfractionated heparin and low molecular weight heparin (LMWH) are equally effective and safe.

Note: Fetal loss in APLA is due to fetal hypoxia.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman presents with a well-circumscribed, soft mass in the upper outer quadrant of the breast. On examination, the axillary lymph nodes are enlarged. Her paternal aunt and sister also had a history of breast carcinoma in the same age group. Molecular examination revealed the tumor to be triple-negative. Biopsy shows the following image. What is the most likely diagnosis in this scenario?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and histopathological findings are suggestive of medullary carcinoma of the breast which is associated with intense lymphocyte proliferation. The histopathology shows sheets of highly pleomorphic cells with mitotic figures, lymphoplasmacytic infiltrate, and pushing border.

Medullary carcinoma is a less common type of breast carcinoma and is a common type seen in BRCA1 mutation. The majority of the tumors are triple-negative. It is softer than other carcinomas due to minimal desmoplasia. The tumor can enlarge rapidly due to necrosis and hemorrhage.

ER-negative and HER2-negative (triple-negative or “basal-like”) carcinomas can be characterized by genomic instability (denoted by multiple chromosomal changes), a high proliferative rate, and expression of many proteins typical of myoepithelial cells (like basal keratins).

Histopathology consists of:

  • A dense lymphoreticular infiltration composed predominantly of lymphocytes and plasma cells
  • A sheet-like growth pattern of anaplastic cells with absent ductal or lobular differentiation
  • Solid, syncytium-like sheets of large cells with pleomorphic nuclei, and prominent nucleoli, which compose more than 75% of the tumor mass
  • Frequent mitotic figures
  • A pushing (non infiltrative) border

Therefore, the lymph node enlargement can be due to reactive hyperplasia rather than the spread of the cancer cells to the lymph nodes. 

It has a better survival rate than invasive ductal or invasive lobular carcinoma.

Other options:

Option B: Papillary carcinoma consists of true papillae with a leaf-like arrangement of fibrovascular tissue, lined by the tumor cells.

 

Option C: Lobular carcinoma of the breast : The histopathological image shows discohesive infiltrating tumor cells, signet-ring cells containing intracytoplasmic mucin droplets. Tubule formation is absent in this subtype. Single line of cells are seen lining the normal duct (bottom right of the image) which is the characteristic Indian file/ Single file appearance.

Lobular Carcinoma:

  • Usually bilateral
  • Multicentric and presents as hard irregular masses
  • It can have a diffuse infiltrative pattern with minimal desmoplasia
  • It is the most common type of breast carcinoma to present as an occult primary
  • Pathogenesis: Mutation in CDH-1 gene which encodes for cadherin. Loss of E-cadherin leads to small, monomorphic discohesive cells arranged one after another. This arrangement is called an Indian file/ Single file appearance.
  • Desmoplasia is minimal or absent
  • They are Luminal-A type
  • Excellent prognosis

Note: Mutation in CDH-1 also pose a high risk for gastric signet ring cell carcinoma. 

 

Option D: Colloidal carcinoma is an invasive breast carcinoma, which shows intra and extracellular mucin deposition. Extracellular type shows tumor cells with faint nuclei arranged in clusters floating in pools/lakes of mucin on histopathological examination. In intracellular type, nuclei are pushed to the peripherally to form signet ring appearance.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male patient with Type II Diabetes mellitus on insulin comes for a routine examination. Physical examination reveals an ulcer on the base of the great toe, pulse rate - 80/minute, blood pressure - 140/80 mm Hg. Laboratory investigations show HbA1c of 6.7% and findings consistent with renal tubular acidosis type IV. Which of the following is not associated with this condition?
questions.solution:
Type IV renal tubular acidosis (hyporeninemic hypoaldosteronism) may occur in Type 1 or 2 diabetes mellitus. Decreased urinary excretion of ammonium will be seen in these patients.

Causes for decreased renin activity that is commonly seen in patients with diabetes mellitus:

  • Injury to the juxtaglomerular apparatus (like afferent arteriolar hyalinization)
  • Defects in the stimulation factors and defective conversion of prorenin to renin
  • Autonomic dysfunction
  • Increase in renal salt retention with volume expansion, which suppresses renin synthesis paradoxically when compared to patients without DM
  • An increase in the secretion of atrial natriuretic peptide in these patients suppresses both renin and aldosterone.

The clinical features seen in Type IV RTA are:

  • Hyperkalemia: Aldosterone increases the number of open sodium channels which leads to reabsorption of sodium. This in turn creates an electrochemical gradient that favours the secretion of potassium. In the absence of this effect due to low aldosterone, there will be an increase in potassium concentration
  • Metabolic acidosis: Due to diminished ammonium production in the proximal tubule, decreased ammonium excretion, and impaired NH4 transport.
  • Urinary pH<5.5: The principal buffers in the urine are ammonia and phosphate. Hyperkalemia seen in RTA Type 4 causes impaired ammonia genesis in the proximal tubule and reduces the availability of NH3 to buffer H+ ions. This decreased ammonia leads to excess protons in the renal tubules decreasing the urinary pH.

Causes of Type IV RTA:

  • Diabetes and renal insufficiency
  • NSAIDs
  • Calcineurin inhibitors
  • Angiotensin inhibitors
  • Heparin and low-molecular-weight heparin
  • Primary adrenal insufficiency
  • Severe illness
  • Inherited conditions
    • Congenital isolated hypoaldosteronism
    • Pseudohypoaldosteronism Type 2 (Gordon's syndrome)
  • Aldosterone resistance
    • Potassium-sparing diuretics
    • Antibiotics: Trimethoprim and pentamidine
    • Pseudohypoaldosteronism Type 1

questions.text: A 53-year-old female presents with a hard, irregular mass in the right breast which has been progressively increasing in size for the past 3 months. Mammography reveals a mass in the right breast with findings suspicious for malignancy. Further evaluation with biopsy reveals invasive carcinoma of the breast and involvement of the axillary lymph nodes. A modified radical mastectomy is planned for the management of this patient. During surgery, the structure marked by the arrow is preserved. What is the action of this muscle at the shoulder joint?
questions.solution:
The marked muscle is the pectoralis major. It causes flexion, medial rotation, and adduction of the shoulder at the glenohumeral joint.

The pectoralis major has its origin from multiple sites as follows:

  • Sternal half of the clavicle
  • The anterior surface of the sternum
  • First to seventh costal cartilages
  • External oblique aponeurosis

It is attached to the lateral lip of the intertubercular sulcus.

  • Pectoral branch of the thoracoacromial axis
  • Internal thoracic artery
  • Superior and lateral thoracic artery

Innervation: Medial and lateral pectoral nerves

questions.text:
A 19-year-old male patient is brought to the emergency room with abdominal pain, nausea, and vomiting over the last three hours. On examination, he appears to be confused. Temperature is 98.8 def F, pulse rate 94/min, respiratory rate is 20/min. Skin turgor is increased and there is a fruity odour in his breath. Fingerstick glucose is found to be 400 mg/dL.
ABG Component Value
pH 7.30
pCO2 35
HCO3 12
Electrolyte Value
Na 134
K 3.8
Cl 96

 

The patient is started on treatment for his condition. A while later, ECG done at the bedside shows the findings below. Which of the following could have prevented this complication?
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette describes a case of diabetic ketoacidosis. In the ECG, there is depression of the ST segment, decrease in the amplitude of the T wave, and an increase in the amplitude of U waves which occur at the end of the T wave. These are the findings of hypokalemia which could have been prevented by appropriate potassium supplementation. 

Patients with DKA who are treated with insulin should be considered for K supplementation because of the intracellular movement of K with insulin. This causes a reduction in potassium levels. 

Hypokalemia can also cause premature atrial and ventricular beats, sinus bradycardia, paroxysmal atrial or junctional tachycardia, atrioventricular block, and ventricular tachycardia or fibrillation.

 In DKA, insulin to glucagon ratio is decreased which promotes gluconeogenesis, glycogenolysis, and ketone body formation in the liver. Ketone bodies exist as ketoacids at physiologic pH which are neutralized by bicarbonate. As bicarbonate stores are depleted, metabolic acidosis ensues. Increased lactic acid production also contributes to the acidosis

Diabetic ketoacidosis is an acute complication of type 1 diabetes mellitus. The symptoms include nausea, vomiting, and severe abdominal pain.

Signs:

  • Kussmaul breathing
  • Fruity odor on the patient’s breath
  • Tachycardia
  • Dehydration
  • Hypotension

Blood parameters:

  • Hyperglycemia – 250 – 600 mg%
  • Pseudohyponatremia- There is 1.6-mmol/L reduction in serum sodium level for each 5.6-mmol/L rise in the serum glucose level.
  • Overall total-body K+ deficit, however, the serum K+ at presentation may be mildly elevated, secondary to the acidosis
  • Osmolality– 300–320 mOsm/kg
  • Plasma ketones– Positive
  • Metabolic acidosis– Increased anion gap
  • Serum bicarbonate <15 meq/L– Best initial investigation
  • Hypertriglyceridemia
  • Hyperamylasemia

The chart shows the management algorithm for DKA.

 

 

ECG findings in other electrolyte abnormalities:

Hyperkalemia: causes tall peaked T waves with a shortened QT interval; progressive lengthening of the PR interval and QRS duration; disappearance of the P wave; and widening of the QRS complex to a sine wave pattern.

Hypocalcemia: Hypocalcemia causes prolongation of the QT interval. There is a lengthening of the ST segment, while the T wave (which correlates with the time for repolarization) remains unaltered.

Hypercalcemia: shortening of the QT interval, decrease in the ST segment duration

Related Pearl: Interpretation of Acid-Base Disorders

pH<7.35 is acidosis

pH>7.45 is alkalosis

A primary change in HCO3- is termed metabolic

If the change in HCO3- is in keeping with the pH (i.e. if there are acidosis and HCO3- is decreased) the problem is metabolic.

If the change in HCO3- is opposite with the pH (i.e. if there is acidosis and HCO3- is increased or normal) the problem is compensatory metabolic.

A primary change in CO2 is termed as respiratory

If the change in CO2 keeping in line with the pH (if in acidosis CO2 is raised) the problem is termed respiratory

If the change in CO2 is in the opposite direction of that of the pH (i.e. if there are acidosis and CO2 is decreased or normal ) the problem is termed compensatory respiratory

questions.text: A  chronic alcoholic presents to the emergency room with bloody vomitus.  Vital signs show a BP of 90/70 mm Hg, pulse - 110 bpm, and SpO2 - 97%. Physical examination shows scleral icterus and a distended abdomen with spider nevi. The bleeding is immediately controlled using the instrument shown in the image. Identify the instrument.
questions.solution:
The above image shows the Sengstaken Blakemore tube.

The given clinical scenario- a chronic alcoholic with hematemesis is suggestive of esophageal variceal bleeding, in which temporary hemostasis can be achieved with the help of balloon tamponades.

Sengstaken-Blakemore tube has 3 lumens. 1 suction tube and 2 inflation tubes. The 3 openings are the gastric balloon port, esophageal balloon port, and the gastric aspiration port

Only gastric contents can be aspirated.

Sengstaken–Blakemore tube should be decompressed every 12 hours to prevent necrosis.

A schematic representation of this tube can be seen below:

 

Other options:

Option (A): Minnesota tube: It has 4 openings – 2 suction tubes and 2 inflation tubes. Thus the four openings are the gastric aspiration port, esophageal aspiration port, gastric balloon port, and esophageal balloon port. This tube allows the aspiration of both gastric and esophageal contents.

Option (C): Linton-Nachlas tube has only two ports and a single gastric balloon.

 

Option (D): Ewalds tube is used in situations such as poisoning, relief of obstruction, and emptying of the stomach prior to gastroscopy. it has only one aspiration port for the stomach.

The Ewald tube is depicted in the image below:

  • Superior rectal veins to Middle and inferior rectal veins: Presents with rectal varices and lower GI tract bleeding

questions.text: A young patient comes to the emergency with pain in the right leg after falling from a height. The radiological image of his limb is shown below. What is the type of Salter-Harris physeal injury shown in this radiograph?
questions.solution:
The given radiograph(CT) shows a fracture line through the growth plate and the metaphysis of the lower end of tibia, sparing the epiphysis, this suggests Salter-Harris type II injury.

In a type II fracture, the fracture lies away from the joint. The fracture involves the physis and a triangle of metaphyseal bone (Thurston Holland sign). This type is the commonest type of epiphyseal injury in patients over 10 years of age.

Salter-Harris classified epiphyseal injuries into 5 types as mentioned below. Rang added the sixth type, where there is a peripheral physis lesion.

Related Pearl: Types of Salter–Harris fractures- Mnemonic

There are nine types of Salter-Harris fractures. Among these, types I to V are more common.

The mnemonic "SALTER" can be used to help remember the first five types.

TYPE  MNEMONIC DESCRIPTION
Type I S = Slip/straight across Transverse fracture through the growth plate
Type II A = Away The fracture lies away from the joint. A fracture through the growth plate and the metaphysis, sparing the epiphysis
Type III L = Lower The fracture is below the physis in the epiphysis.
Type IV TE = Through Everything  A fracture through all three elements of the bone, the growth plate, metaphysis, and epiphysis
Type V R = Rammed (crushed)  A compression fracture of the growth plate

Rarer types VI to IX have been added subsequently.

  • Type VI - Injury to the perichondral structures
  • Type VII - Isolated injury to the epiphyseal plate
  • Type VIII - Isolated injury to the metaphysis, with a potential injury related to endochondral ossification
  • Type IX - Injury to the periosteum that may interfere with membranous growth

questions.text: A 40-year-old man has left-sided CN III palsy and right-sided hemiplegia. Visual field testing reveals right homonymous hemianopia and Wernicke's hemianopic pupillary reaction. Which of the following represents the site of the lesion?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette describes Wernicke's hemianopic pupil reaction. The site of lesion in the Wernicke hemianopic pupil is the optic tract.

Wernicke's hemianopic pupil is an abnormal light reflex. Here, illumination of the blind half of the retina shows no pupillary reaction while illumination of the normal half of the retina shows a pupillary reaction. It is seen in lesions involving the optic tract.

Lesions of the optic tract cause blindness in half of the visual field, known as homonymous hemianopia. Homonymous hemianopia involves loss of vision on the same side of the visual field in both eyes. Optic tract lesions also present with contralateral CN III palsy and ipsilateral hemiplegia, due to the proximity of the crus cerebri and CN III. 

Common causes of optic tract lesions- 

  • More commonly due to secondary lesions of the optic tract such as chordomas, pituitary adenomas, tentorial meningiomas, aneurysms, etc. 
  • Primary lesions of the optic tract such as syphilitic meningitis or gumma, tuberculosis or tumor of optic thalamus or temporospenoidal lobe

 

Related Pearl: Lesions in the optic pathway

Transection of the pathways at the locations indicated by the letters causes the visual field defects shown in the diagram above.

  • The fibers from the nasal half of each retina decussate in the optic chiasm, so that the fibers in the optic tracts are those from the temporal half of one retina and the nasal half of the other.
  • A lesion that interrupts the optic nerve causes blindness in that eye.
  • Lesions affecting the optic chiasma destroy fibers from both nasal hemiretinas and produce a heteronymous (opposite sides of the visual fields) hemianopia.
  • A lesion in one optic tract causes blindness in half of the visual field and is called homonymous (same side of both visual fields) hemianopia (half-blindness).
  • Occipital lesions may spare the fibers from the macula because of the separation in the brain of these fibers from the other subserving vision.

questions.text: A 25-year-old primigravida presents to your hospital at 42 weeks of gestation. She does not complain of abdominal pain, contractions, or discharge per vaginum. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination shows an abdomen girth consistent with the reported gestation age. USG and Fetal NST are normal.  A decision is taken to induce labor and the device shown in the image is used. This device releases which of the following?
questions.solution:
The obstetric device shown in the above image is of Cervidil vaginal insert. This provides the release of 0.3 mg/hr of Prostaglandin E2.

Cervidil vaginal insert: It is a thin, flat, rectangular polymeric wafer held within a small, white mesh polyester sac. It contains 10 mg of Prostaglandin E2 (dinoprostone) released at a rate of 0.3mg/hour. The sac has a long attached tail to allow easy removal from the vagina.

Following insertion, the woman should remain recumbent for at least 2 hours. The insert is removed after 12 hours or with labor onset and at least 30 minutes before the administration of oxytocin.

Related Pearl: Indications & contraindications for induction of labor

Indications:
  • Uncontrolled maternal diabetes mellitus
  • Gestational hypertension
  • Pre-eclampsia
  • Post-term pregnancy
  • Abruption placentae
  • Premature rupture of membranes
  • Rh-isoimmunization
  • Intra-uterine growth restriction (IUGR)
  • Intra-uterine death (IUD)
  • Oligohydramnios
Contraindications:
  • Contracted/distorted pelvis and cephalopelvic disproportion
  • Placenta previa or vasa previa
  • Active genital herpes
  • Pelvic tumor & carcinoma cervix
  • Transverse lie or footling breech
  • Appreciable macrosomia
  • Severe hydrocephalus
  • Umbilical cord prolapse
  • High-risk pregnancy with fetal compromise
  • Previous classical cesarean or hysterotomy
  • Previous history of uterine rupture
  • Pelvic surgeries like vesicovaginal fistula/rectovaginal fistula/pelvic floor repair (third or fourth-degree perineal tears repair)
  • Previous 3 or more lower transverse cesarian sections.

questions.text: A person with a substance use disorder is brought to the emergency in a disoriented state. He was initially confused and agitated with profuse sweating. On examination, the temperature was 102 degrees F, heart rate 134/min, and BP 146/98 mm Hg. He shouts about nonexistent insects crawling on his hands and about snakes that aren't there. This was followed by two episodes of generalized tonic-clonic seizures and loss of consciousness. Considering the likely diagnosis, which of the following is unlikely to be seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario points towards delirium tremens likely due to acute alcohol withdrawal. Hypokalemia (not hyperkalemia) is commonly seen in this condition.

Delirium tremens refers to delirium (mental confusion with fluctuating levels of consciousness) along with a tremor, severe agitation, and autonomic overactivity, like a marked increase in pulse, blood pressure, and respiration. It occurs after 2-4 days of abstinence in a heavy or chronic drinker. It is characterized by autonomic hyperactivity, tremors, delusions, and hallucinations like seeing distorted objects, moving shadows, or auditory perceptions. It usually resolves spontaneously in 7 days but may cause the death of the patient due to cardiovascular collapse or infections or self-injury.

Severe alcohol withdrawal is often associated with fluid and electrolyte abnormalities. The majority of patients in acute withdrawal are hypovolemic due to diaphoresis, hyperthermia, vomiting, tachypnea, and decreased oral intake.

Hypokalemia is seen commonly due to renal and extrarenal potassium loss, alteration in aldosterone levels, and changes in potassium distribution across the cell membrane. Hypomagnesemia is also common in patients with Delirium Tremens and predisposes them to dysrhythmias and seizures. Hypophosphatemia can result from malnutrition, which can be symptomatic, and, if severe, can lead to cardiac failure and rhabdomyolysis.

Delirium tremens is treated using benzodiazepines starting with a higher dosage which is gradually tapered as withdrawal symptoms disappear. In cases of chronic alcohol use, vitamin deficiency (especially thiamine) may be co-existing and hence bolus doses of thiamine are given to prevent/treat Wernicke encephalopathy. Lorazepam + thiamine should be given to this patient.

Haloperidol is generally not the first-line drug in case of alcoholic withdrawal. It might be used as an add-on in agitated patients. It decreases the seizure threshold and its use would be appropriate in a case of co-existing psychotic disorder like schizophrenia.

questions.text: A 40-year-old chronic alcoholic presented with hematemesis. He had a similar episode in the past month and was found to have esophageal varices. He is a known case of alcoholic cirrhosis. Vital signs show a BP of 100/75 mm of Hg and a heart rate of 100 bpm. Physical examination is notable for a distended abdomen and spider angiomas over his abdomen. His platelet counts were low, Prothrombin time elevated, and AST: ALT ratio was 2:1. His MELD score is 25. The decision is made for liver transplantation. The surgeon decides to harvest the right-hemiliver from the donor. Which of the following structure forms the medial boundary, during dissection?
questions.solution:
Cholecysto-vena caval line (Cantlie line) separates the right and left parts of the liver. The surgeon wants to harvest the right half of the donor's liver, so he will remain lateral to Cantlie's line.

Cantlie line is an imaginary line that divides the liver into 2 planes. It extends from the midpoint of the gallbladder fossa at the inferior margin of the liver back to the midpoint of the IVC and contains the middle hepatic vein.

 Couinaud's classification divides the liver into 4 sectors based on supply by portal venous branches. These sectors are further divided into 2 segments based on vascular biliary sheath supplying it. It is but however, a functional or physiological classification. For surgery, based on the hepatic veins draining the liver part, it is divided by 3 major portal fissures not visible on the liver surface, but present within the liver parenchyma.

  • The main portal fissure called Cantlie's line divides the liver into right and left hemi-livers. It contains the middle hepatic vein.
  • The left portal fissure divides the left hemi-liver into medial (anterior) and lateral (posterior) segments. It contains the left hepatic vein.
  • The right portal fissure divides the right hemi-liver into medial( anterior) and lateral (posterior) segments. It contains the right hepatic vein.

 

This patient presented with classic complications of cirrhosis (recurrent hematemesis). In cases of decompensated alcoholic cirrhosis, if the patient is willing to stay abstinent from alcohol use, liver transplantation can be done. The priority for liver transplantation is decided based on the MELD score. More the MELD score, severe the condition and higher the priority for transplantation. However, in the early stages of alcoholic liver disease (fatty liver and steatohepatitis), the changes are reversible on abstinence from alcohol.
