The Couinaud classification is currently the most widely used system to describe functional liver anatomy.

  • Based on the distribution of hepatic portal venous branches in the parenchyma
  • Each segment has its own dual vascular inflow, biliary drainage and lymphatic drainage

Segment I corresponds to the gross anatomical caudate lobe and is considered as posterior segment.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man presented with weakness in the right side of the face for 24 hours. Thorough investigations were done which did not reveal any significant abnormality. The doctor as a diagnosis of exclusion prescribed him prednisolone for 5 days and 3 weeks later, he had recovered. Which of the following findings can be seen in his condition?

choices.text: The side of the face affected is the same side as the affected nerve
Flattening of the forehead and nasolabial fold on the contralateral side
Corner of the mouth is drawn to affected side
If the patient attempts to close the eye, the eyeball would turn down and inwards

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of acute onset facial paralysis recovering within 3 weeks is a classical case of Bell's palsy and the side of the face affected is the same side as the affected nerve is a finding that can be seen in this condition. 

Bell's palsy is a lower motor neuron lesion of the facial nerve and involves the ipsilateral side of the upper and lower halves of the face. Bell's palsy is idiopathic, peripheral facial paralysis, or paresis of acute onset. The onset of Bell's palsy is fairly abrupt. 

If the patient attempts to close the eye, the eyeball would turn up and out - this is known as the Bell's phenomenon. Decreased tearing, hyperacusis, taste disturbances, otalgia, weakness of the facial muscles, poor eyelid closure, etc can be seen. When the patient smiles, the face becomes distorted and lateralizes to the side opposite the palsy. Flattening of the forehead and nasolabial fold on the side affected by palsy. 

Treatment of Bell's palsy involves prednisone 60-80 mg daily during the first 5 days and then tapered over the next 5 days. The use of paper tape to depress the upper eyelid during sleep prevents corneal drying. For patients with permanent paralysis cosmetic surgical procedures have been used to restore a relatively symmetric appearance to the face.

Approximately 80% of patients recover within a few weeks or months. The presence of incomplete paralysis in the first week is the most favourable prognostic sign. Recurrences are seen in some cases (7%). Bell's palsy is a diagnosis of exclusion. All other possible causes of facial paralysis should be ruled out by investigation.

questions.text: "Vasopressin escape" in SIADH results due to:
questions.solution:
Vasopressin escape in SIADH (Syndrome of inappropriate ADH secretion) results due to downregulation of aquaporin 2 production.

Prolonged exposure to elevated levels of vasopressin (ADH) leads eventually to downregulation of aquaporin-2 receptors. This prevents excessive reabsorption of water, despite high serum ADH levels and hence maintains euvolemia. This is known as vasopressin escape. This helps prevent excessive dilutional hyponatremia in SIADH.

questions.text: A 40-year-old factory worker presented with the following lesion on the face. She gives a history of itchy, scaly lesions with central clearing and raised margins. She applied some topical ointment after which the itching subsided and she felt relief. However, these lesions appeared once she stopped applying that ointment. A microscopic examination revealed the presence of fungal mycelium. What is the likely ointment she had applied earlier?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with an image of an atypical clinical lesion of tinea, usually produced by incorrect treatment of fungal infection with a topical corticosteroid(beclomethasone here). It points towards a diagnosis of Tinea incognito. 

  • Steroids suppress inflammation without eliminating the fungus; so the typical raised margin is diminished, scaling is lost and inflammation reduces. Hence, diagnosis becomes difficult. Once steroid dosage is decreased or stopped, scaling reappears and shows fungal mycelium.
  • Treatment: Oral terbinafine or itraconazole

Tinea corporis/ ringworm infection is caused by the dermatophyte Trichophyton rubrum. It results from the invasion and proliferation of the causal fungi in the stratum corneum with lesions on the trunk and limbs. 

Characteristic lesions are circular, usually sharply marginated with a raised edge with central resolution. Scaling is a common but not a constant finding. The diagnosis is mostly clinical. In case of doubt, skin scrapings from site of lesion examined under a microscope may show fungal mycelium.

Pharmacological treatment of fungal Tinea infection is :

Localized disease, recent onset

  • Topical terbinafine twice daily for 2 weeks
  • Topical azole once or twice daily for 2–4 weeks

Widespread disease

  • First-line:
    Oral terbinafine 250 mg/day 2–3 weeks
    Oral Itraconazole 100 mg/day 2–4 weeks
  • Second line:
    Oral Griseofulvin 1 g/day for 4 weeks

questions.text: A 40-year-old man is brought to the casualty with severe abdominal pain radiating to the back for the past 1 day and has had 3 episodes of vomiting. There is no history of constipation. Vitals signs are remarkable for a BP of 100/78 mm of Hg. The physical exam showed findings as shown in the image below. The patient has no history of alcohol consumption. He has a history of seizure disorder managed with phenobarbital and valproic acid and has a history of hypertension managed with enalapril and losartan. The given clinical scenario describes a case of non-gallstone acute pancreatitis. White blood cell count, >16,000 cells/mm3(NOT >18,000 cells/mm3) is a parameter obtained under Ranson criteria at admission.

The patient seems to be suffering from leprosy, and a Split Skin Smear has been obtained. According to Ridley's logarithmic scale, 4+ would mean 10-100 bacilli, on average, in each oil-immersion field.

The Bacteria Index(BI) is calculated by adding the index from each site examined and dividing the total by the number of sites examined.

BI=20/4

therefore, BI=5+

questions.text: A 23-year-old survivor of a road traffic accident comes to the psychiatric OPD. The incident happened 4 months back. She reports frequent nightmares of the event. She also reported that these nightmares are now causing her to avoid driving her car as they induce flashbacks and panic attacks. Vitals are within normal limits and physical examination is unremarkable. Which of the following is the recommended psychotherapy modality to treat this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical features point to a diagnosis of Post-Traumatic Stress Disorder(PTSD). Exposure therapy is a recommended psychotherapy modality.

PTSD is the collective symptoms occurring after a life-threatening or potentially fatal event, (e.g., war, house fire, serious accident, rape, robbery) affecting the patient or the patient’s close friend or relative.

Diagnosis criteria:

  1. Exposure to mental trauma
  2. Reexperiencing one or more of the following intrusive symptoms
    a. Dissociative reactions(flashbacks)
    b. Nightmares
    c. Distress on seeing cues to traumatic event
    d. Distressing memories
  3. Avoidance (e.g., avoiding stimuli associated with the traumatic event)
  4. Negative cognition (e.g., negative beliefs, emotional numbing)
  5. Hyperarousal (e.g., anxiety, increased startle response, impaired sleep, hypervigilance)
  6. impairment of social and occupational functioning.

Symptoms must be present for 1 month

Psychotherapy is found to be effective for PTSD. It includes exposure therapy, trauma-focused cognitive-behavioral therapy, eye movement desensitization, and reprocessing.

Exposure therapy involves re-experiencing the trauma through images, in-vivo or virtual reality. Here exposure is provided safely until they no longer elicit such strong emotions in the patient.

 Other options:

Option A - Motivational interviewing is primarily used for drug abuse.

Option B - Biofeedback is used as a relaxation technique for tension headache, temporomandibular joint disorders, etc

Option C -  Dialectical behavioral therapy is used primarily for borderline personality traits.

questions.text: A 57-year-old male patient presented with anasarca, nephrotic range proteinuria and mild hepatomegaly. Suspecting amyloidosis, a renal biopsy was taken, which seen under polarised light shows the following appearance. What is the most likely stain used here?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of renal amyloidosis in which the biopsy specimen shows apple-green birefringence under polarized light with congo-red staining.

Amyloidosis is a condition caused due to the deposition of abnormal fibrillar proteins in extracellular spaces. Abnormal fibrils are produced by the aggregation of misfolded proteins. The fibrillar deposits bind a wide variety of proteoglycans and glycosaminoglycans, including heparan sulfate and dermatan sulfate, and plasma proteins, notably serum amyloid P component (SAP). Amyloid appears as an amorphous, eosinophilic, hyaline, extracellular substance.

Based on the involvement of organ systems it may be classified as systemic or localized. Hereditary amyloidosis is a separate group of heterogeneous disorders with many distinctive patterns of organ involvement. 

Microscopically, all types of amyloid deposits are made up of continuous, nonbranching fibrils. A characteristic cross-β-pleated sheet conformation is visualized on X-ray crystallography and infrared spectroscopy. 

On light microscopy (with hematoxylin and eosin stain): Amyloid appears as an amorphous, eosinophilic, hyaline substance in extracellular space.

Congo red stain, which is used to observe amyloid deposits is shown in the image below: 

  1. Under ordinary light, it imparts a pink or red color to amorphous extracellular material, as seen by the focal positive staining.
  2. Under the polarizing microscope, it imparts apple-green birefringence to amyloid deposits.
 The next best step is to determine the type of precursor protein by immunohistochemistry, immunoelectron microscopy, or extraction and biochemical analysis employing mass spectrometry.

Other options: 

Perl's Prussian blue stain is used in Hemochromatosis to stain liver tissue which shows hepatocellular iron, which is stained blue with this stain.


Amyloid deposits and Paget cells observed in Paget disease are stained by Alcian blue. 


The given slide shows the GI mucosa, which has been stained with Warthin-Starry silver stain, demonstrating the bacilli Helicobacter pylori.

Both the skull and pelvis appear to be of a male

questions.solution:
Both the skull and the pelvis belong to a female skeleton. 

The female pelvic brim is circular, the cavity is broad and round, the sub-pubic angle U-shaped, and the greater sciatic notches are large. The skull is smooth with round orbits, a small mandible, and the frontal and parietal eminences are larger in a female skull.

questions.text: A 30-year-old was brought into the ER after a car accident with a suspected neck injury. The radiological investigation of this patient is given below. Which of the following statements is true about the given condition?

choices.text: No neurological deficit would be seen
Fracture of pedicle of pars interarticularis of C3
Most fractures will require open reduction and stabilization
It is due to distraction flexion force

questions.solution:
The given fracture is Hangman's fracture, it is a fracture of pars interarticularis of axis (C2). These cases will have no neurological deficits.

It is also known as traumatic C2 spondylolisthesis. It usually occurs due to distraction extension force. In most cases, there is no neurological deficit as pars fractures expand the spinal canal. 

In the below X-ray of the cervical spine, a Hangman's fracture can be noted.  It can be observed that C2 (red outline) has moved forward with respect to C3 (blue outline).

The Levine and Edwards classification is used commonly for these fractures. 

Management: Most fractures can be managed conservatively

  • Minimally displaced fractures: Philadelphia collar.
  • Highly displaced and angulated fractures: Traction followed by Halo vest
  • Fractures with dislocation of the C2–C3 facet joint and neurological injuries: Open reduction and stabilization

Related Pearl: Named fractures of the vertebra

Motorcyclist's fracture - transverse fracture across base of the skull

Whiplash's injury - hyperextension followed by flexion

questions.text: A 28-year-old overweight female presents with complaints of infertility despite regular unprotected intercourse with her husband for the past 3 years. Her USG findings are shown in the image below. The medical treatments advised by her previous doctors haven't given any results, so she prefers surgical management. Identify the incorrect option regarding the surgical management of her condition.

choices.text: Not more than two cysts are to be drilled in each ovary laparoscopically
Surgery is indicated if overstimulation occurs
Chromotubation and tubal testing can be done at the same time
Other causes of infertility like endometriosis can be assessed

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the ultrasound showing multiple ovarian follicles arranged in a necklace pattern suggest polycystic ovarian disease (PCOD). Not more than four ovarian cysts are punctured/drilled in each ovary in polycystic ovary syndrome.

PCOS is a common endocrine disorder in a reproductive-age woman characterized by oligomenorrhoea, non-ovulation (infertility), obesity, and hirsutism. Rotterdam criteria are used to diagnose PCOS. The presence of any two of the three components of this criteria establishes the diagnosis of PCOS

  • Clinical/biochemical hyperandrogenism (alopecia, acne, hirsutism)
  • Irregular menstrual cycles (oligomenorrhoea/non-ovulation)
  • Polycystic ovaries

Surgery is indicated when medical treatment fails, overstimulation happens, infertile individuals, and loss of pregnancies in the past (Option B) 

Surgery comprises laparoscopic drilling or puncture of not more than four cysts in each ovary. It is done using a laser or by unipolar electrocautery. It restores the endocrinal balance and improves fertility for a year or so.

The advantages of surgery are as follows: 

  • Chromotubation and tubal testing can be done at the same time (Option C) 
  • One can search for additional infertility causes, such as endometriosis (Option D) 
  • There is no need for extensive or continuous side effect monitoring
  • Economical in contrast to IVF
  • Decreases the synthesis of LH and androgen
  • After surgery, medication is used to induce single ovulation to prevent hyperstimulation and multiple pregnancies 
  • 60%–70% of women experience pregnancy, and 80–90% ovulate

The disadvantages of surgery are as follows:

  • It involves giving anaesthesia and performing an invasive procedure like laparoscopy
  • Adhesions may form postoperatively. Thereafter, pelvic adhesions caused by surgery may again reduce the fertility rate. 
  • If cautery is used, premature ovarian failure due to destruction of ovarian tissue may be seen

Related Pearl: Management of PCOD

Complaint Management  
Irregular periods OCPs
Obesity Lifestyle modification
Insulin resistance Metformin
Hirsutism /acne OCPs with cyproterone acetate
Infertility Clomiphene

Note: Letrozole is as effective as Clomiphene in treating infertility in PCOD with fewer side effects. However, it's pending FDA approval and is used off-label.

Related Pearl: Endocrinological changes of PCOD

  1. Elevated Estrone/E1 levels.
  2. LH level is raised over 10 IU/mL. FSH level remains normal to low, but FSH/LH ratio falls.
  3. Testosterone and epi-androstenedione levels rise.
    • Testosterone elevated but < 200 ng/dL (normal range 20 -80 ng/dL)
    • Testosterone > 200 ng/dL suggests androgen-secreting ovarian tumor
    • DHEA-S values may be normal or slightly elevated
    • DHEA >700 ng/mL suggests adrenal tumour
  4. Serum SHBG is reduced.
  5. Triglyceride level >150 mg/dL-hyperlipidaemia HDL <50 mg/dL.
  6. Fasting blood glucose/fasting insulin <4.5 suggests insulin resistance
  7. Prolactin is mildly raised in 15% cases
  8. Fasting insulin is more than 10 mIU/L in PCOS in 50–70%cases
  9. Thyroid function tests may be abnormal (hypothyroidism)
  10. 17-a-hydroxyprogesterone in the follicular phase >300 ng/dL suggests adrenal hyperplasia due to 21-hydroxylase deficiency.
  11. Urinary cortisol <50 μg/24 h.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman presented with a history of chronic abdominal pain, diarrhea, low-grade fever, weight loss, and fatigue. She underwent a colonoscopy which revealed a cobble-stone appearance. Which of the following type of renal stones is most commonly seen in this condition?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario, cobblestone appearance on colonoscopy is suggestive of Crohn's disease. Calcium oxalate stones are more commonly associated with Crohn's disease. 

In Crohn's disease, fatty acids are not absorbed because of ileal dysfunction. These fatty acids in the gut lumen bind to calcium. Because of this, the dietary oxalates which normally bind to calcium are now left unbound. This leads to increased absorption of dietary oxalates causing hyperoxaluria and oxalate stones.

Clinical features of Crohn's disease:

Cardinal manifestations

  • Crampy abdominal pain may be limited to the right lower quadrant in patients with ileal disease.
  • Intermittent and persistent diarrhea: Fluid secretion/impaired absorption in the inflamed bowel, bile acid malabsorption, steatorrhea due to loss of bile salts, and enteroenteric fistulas.
  • Fatigue
  • Fistulae and abscesses
  • Malabsorption

Extraintestinal manifestations

  • Arthritis and arthropathy
  • Uveitis, iritis and episcleritis
  • Erythema nodosum and pyoderma gangrenosum
  • Primary sclerosing cholangitis
  • Secondary amyloidosis
  • Renal stones: Calcium oxalate stones
  • Bone loss
  • Pulmonary involvement: Bronchiectasis, chronic bronchitis, ILD, BOOP, sarcoidosis.

 Gross features of Crohn's disease include:

  • Aphthous ulcers
  • Longitudinal ulcers
  • Skip lesions
  • Creeping fat
  • Cobblestone appearance

Microscopically aphthoid ulcerations and focal crypt abscesses are the earliest lesions. There is transmural inflammation. Non-caseating granulomas can be found in all layers of affected organs Other histologic features of CD include submucosal or subserosal lymphoid aggregates, microscopic skip areas, and pseudo pyloric metaplasia

questions.text: A 20-year-old male patient presents with new-onset discomfort in his left eye for the last two weeks. He has been using contact lenses for the last three years and recalls two episodes recently when he had showered with his lenses on. He complains of tearing, photophobia, and foreign body sensation in the left eye.  Eye examination findings are given below. Which of the following agents is most useful in the treatment for this condition?
questions.solution:
The image depicts a ring lesion (stromal infiltrate) of acanthamoeba keratitis and among the above polyhexamethyl biguanide (PHMB) 0.02% is the is most useful in the treatment for this condition

Acanthamoeba is a free-living amoeba. It exists as a trophozoite form and resistant cystic form. Both these forms are infectious. The trophozoite is large and characterized by spine-like pseudopodia (acanthopodia). Human beings acquire by inhalation of cyst or trophozoite, ingestion of cysts, or through traumatized skin or eyes. It presents as two chronic conditions - acanthamoeba keratitis and granulomatous amoebic encephalitis.

Acanthamoeba keratitis

  • Rare protozoal infection of the cornea
  • Occurs in soft contact lens users who wash their lens with tap water
  • Pain is disproportionate to the degree of keratitis due to perineural invasion.
  • Presents as
    • Ring lesion (most common): Ring stromal infiltrates lead to ring stromal abscess
    • Pseudo-dendrites
    • Reticular pattern

Diagnosis:

  • Confocal Microscopy- may reveal bright trophozoites with pseudopodia in the basal epithelium and double-walled cyst forms
  • Staining: Calcofluor white, acridine orange, lactophenol blue
  • Histopathology- double-walled cysts are seen on H&E. Other stains for Acanthamoeba include calcofluor white, acridic orange, Giemsa-Wright, Wheatly trichrome or periodic acid-Schiff.
  • Culture: Acanthamoeba can be grown on a bed of E. Coli plated on a non-nutrient agar.

 Treatments for this condition include:

  • Polyhexamethyl biguanide (PHMB) 0.02%
  • Chlorhexidine 0.02%
  • Propamidine isothionate (0.1%)
  • Hexamidine
  • Neomycin
  • Paromomycin
  • Clotrimazole
  • Miconazole

All of these treatments are effective if administered by the topical route. Combination therapy can be administered, which includes PHMB with chlorhexidine, or either of these in combination with hexamidine or propamidine. Debridement may be warranted in certain conditions.

Chronic refractory cases may require corneal transplantation and unresponsive cases might need to be managed with enucleation. 

Fluorometholone 0.5% (Option-A) is a treatment option for marginal keratitis which is caused by a hypersensitivity reaction against staphylococcal exotoxins which causes subepithelial marginal infiltrates.

Topical cyclosporine 1% (Option-B) is a treatment option for Mooren's ulcer which is an autoimmune disease characterized by peripheral corneal stromal ulceration with subsequent central spread.

Doxycycline (Option-C) is a treatment option for ocular rosacea which may have corneal manifestations that include epithelial erosions, marginal keratitis, corneal thinning and perforation.

The first image shows double-walled cysts of acanthamoeba in normal H&E staining in a patient with advanced brain disease. The second image depicts the cysts of acanthamoeba in lactophenol cotton blue staining. The third image shows the corneal scrapings with multiple cysts wall of acanthamoeba on a plain mount.

questions.text: A female patient presented with the following lesions that are soft on palpation and asymptomatic otherwise. She gives a history of angina.  Her elder sister also has similar complaints. The lipid profile reveals hypercholesterolemia, hypertriglyceridemia, and increased levels of remnant chylomicron and intermediate-density lipoprotein (IDL). A genetic study shows a defective ApoE gene. What can be the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given image showing xanthelasma palpebrum, along with the history of angina, and an increase in remnant chylomicron and IDL levels with defective apoE suggests the diagnosis of familial type III hyperlipoproteinemia.

Xanthelasma palpebra or xanthelasmas are plain xanthomas that commonly develop on the upper eyelids and the area around the medial canthus. They appear pale yellow to yellow‐orange in color and are soft on palpation.

Type III hyperlipoproteinemia is also known as broad β-disease, remnant removal disease, or familial dysbetalipoproteinemia.

Type III hyperlipoproteinemia is caused by a defective ApoE that causes dysbetalipoproteinemia. ApoE mediates the removal of lipoprotein remnants. It typically has three isoforms- E2, E3, and E4. Patients with type III hyperlipoproteinemia lack isoforms E3 and E4 and have only E2. This leads to defective clearance of lipoprotein remnants by the liver.

Clinical features include hypercholesterolemia, xanthomas, and atherosclerosis. There is an increase in remnant chylomicrons, remnant VLDL (i.e.Intermediate-density lipoprotein), cholesterol, and triglyceride levels.

Fibrates are effective in treating patients with type III hyperlipoproteinemia. Fibrate therapy in these patients leads to lowering of the elevated triglyceride and cholesterol levels, regression of xanthomas, and improvement in angina and intermittent claudication.

Other options:

Option A- Type I hyperlipoproteinemia(Hyperchylomicronemia) patients with LPL(lipoprotein lipase) or apo C-II deficiency show increased levels of chylomicrons in the plasma, after a fatty meal. There is no increased risk of coronary disease in this condition.

Options B and D- Type II hyperlipoproteinemia also known as familial hypercholesterolemia, is due to a defective LDL receptor or mutation in the ligand region of apo B-100. Defective LDL receptors cause a decrease in the uptake of LDL and cholesterol. As a result, the blood levels of both LDL and total cholesterol rise. Clinical features include the presence of tendon xanthomas, atherosclerosis, and coronary heart disease.

questions.text: A study was done to assess the risk factors for breast cancer in 100 females from urban cities. A statistical group and analysis are shown below. The values indicate the odds ratio and the 95% confidence interval. How many risk factors may be ascertained from the statistical analysis of the research?
questions.solution:
Among the factors shown in the above statistical group, the odds ratio of early menarche, BRCA mutation, and obesity show positive association and are statistically significant. Hence these 3 factors can be ascertained as risk factors.
 
High socioeconomic status is not a risk factor. Even though there is a positive association, it is not statistically significant. Any association that has a 95% confidence interval range that includes the value of 1.0 is considered to be non-significant. The value of 1.0 in the range means that the two factors may co-exist together but one is not causing the other to happen.
 
Odds ratio (OR) is the key parameter in case-control studies to assess the strength of association between the exposure and outcome. The interpretation of the odds ratio can be done as below:
  • OR > 1 indicates a positive association. If both upper and lower limits of the 95% confidence limits are also >1, it suggests that the odds ratio is significant and the factor can be ascertained as a risk factor.
  • OR = 1indicates no association. Irrespective of the odds ratio, if the lower limit of 95% CI is <1 and the upper limit of 95% CI >1, the OR is non-significant and cannot be ascertained either as a protective or a risk factor.
  • OR < 1 indicates a negative association. If both upper and lower limits of the 95% confidence limits are also <1, it suggests that the odds ratio is significant and the factor can be ascertained as a protective factor.

questions.text: A 75-year-old male patient with a history of cough, fever, and fatigue for one week comes to the emergency room with worsening respiratory symptoms. The patient has a history of diabetes mellitus and hypertension and has previously not sought medical care for his condition. Physical examination reveals a patient in distress, with a pulse rate of 110/min, respiratory rate of 42/minute, and blood pressure 150/90 mm Hg. Oxygen saturation at room air is 80%. RT-PCR for COVID-19 is positive. The patient is placed on NIV but does not respond. Intubation and mechanical ventilation are planned. Chest X-ray reveals the findings below.  Which of the following is correct about the lung-protective ventilation strategy?

choices.text: Target plateau pressure should be < 30 cm H20
PEEP settings at 0-3 cm of H2O

questions.solution:
This patient has severe COVID-19 symptoms with acute respiratory distress syndrome based on the chest x-ray findings which show diffuse bilateral ground-glass opacities. In patients with ARDS, mechanical ventilation should be implemented using lower tidal volumes (4–8 ml/kg predicted body weight, PBW) and lower inspiratory pressures (plateau pressure <30 cmH2O).

The initial tidal volume is 6 ml/kg PBW but tidal volume up to 8 ml/kg PBW is allowed if undesirable side effects occur (e.g. pH <7.15).

In patients with moderate or severe ARDS, a higher PEEP is suggested. PEEP titration requires consideration of benefits (improving alveolar recruitment) vs. risks (end-inspiratory over distension leading to lung injury).

Lung protective ventilation strategy by ARDS net protocol recommends:

Tidal volume  6ml/kg
RR  15-35/min
PEEP  5-15cm H2O
Target plateau pressure < 30cm H2O
Target SpO2 88-95%
Target PaO2  55-80mmHg

 

Mild Moderate Severe
URTI and/or fever without shortness of breath or hypoxia

RR ≥ 24/min, breathlessness

OR

SpO2: 90% to ≤93% on room air

RR > 30/min, breathlessness

OR

SpO2 < 90% on room air

 
Home isolation and care Admit in ward Admit in ICU
Physical distancing, indoor mask use, strict hand hygiene, symptomatic management, monitor temperature and oxygen saturation. Seek immediate medical attention if:
  • Difficulty breathing
  • High grade fever/severe cough >5days
May consider
  • Tab Ivermectin (200 mcg/kg once a day for 3 days). Avoid in pregnant and lactating women.
OR
  • Tab HCQ (400 mg BD for 1 day f/b 400 mg OD for 4 days) unless contraindicated.
Inhalational Budesonide at a dose of 800mcg BD for 5 days to be given if fever and/or cough are persistent beyond 5 days of disease onset.

Oxygen support:

  • Target SpO2: 92-96% (88-92% for COPD patients)
  • Non-rebreathing face mask
  • Awake proning in all patients requiring supplemental O2 therapy

Anti-inflammatory or immunomodulatory therapy:

  • Inj. Methylprednisolone 0.5 to 1 mg/kg in 2 divided doses (or an equivalent dose of dexamethasone) for 5 to 10 days.
  • Switch to oral route if stable and/or improving

Anticoagulation:

  • Conventional dose prophylactic UH/LMWH (enoxaparin 0.5mg/kg per day SC)

Monitoring:

  • Clinical Monitoring - Work of breathing, Hemodynamic instability, Change in oxygen requirement.Serial CXR; HRCT chest to be done ONLY If there is worsening.
  • Lab monitoring: CRP and D-dimer 48 to 72 hourly; CBC, RFT, LFT 24 to 48 hourly. IL-6 to be done if deteriorating.

EUA use: Remdesivir

Respiratory support:

  • NIV in patients with increasing oxygen requirement, if work of breathing is low.
  • HFNC in patients with increasing oxygen requirement.
  • Intubation if high work of breathing/if NIV is not tolerated.
  • Conventional ARDS net protocol for ventilatory management.

Anti-inflammatory or immunomodulatory therapy:

  • Inj. Methylprednisolone 1 to 2 mg/kg in 2 divided doses (or an equivalent dose of dexamethasone) for 5 to 10 days.

Anticoagulation:

  • Conventional dose prophylactic UH/LMWH (enoxaparin 0.5mg/kg per day SC)

Supportive measures:

  • Maintain euvolemia
  • If sepsis/septic shock, then manage as per existing protocol.

Monitoring:

  • Serial CXR; HRCT chest to be done ONLY if there is worsening.
  • Lab monitoring: CRP and D-dimer 24-48 hourly; CBC, RFT, LFT daily; IL-6 to be done if deteriorating.

EUA/Off label use: 

  • Remdesivir
  • Tocilizumab.

EUA/Off label use:

Remdesivir (EUA): Considered only in patients with 

  • Moderate to severe disease (requiring supplemental O2)
  • No renal or hepatic dysfunction [eGFR <30 ml/min/m2; AST/ALT >5 times ULN (Not an absolute contraindication)]
  • Within 10 days of onset of symptoms
  • Not to be used in patients who are not on oxygen support or in home settings

Recommended dose: 200mg IV on day 1, 100 mg IV OD for next 4 days.

Tocilizumab (Off label):  Considered when all of the below criteria are met

  • Presence of severe disease (within 24 to 48 hrs of onset of severe disease)
  • Significantly raised inflammatory markers (CRP &/or IL-6).
  • Not improving despite use of steroids
  • No active bacterial/fungal/tubercular infection.

Recommended single dose: 4-6 mg/kg in 100ml NS over 1 hr.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male patient comes to the clinic with the chief complaint of gradually diminishing vision. He gives a history of difficulty adapting to dark rooms. His mother also describes instances around the home where he appears to be clumsy, tripping over objects. Fundoscopy reveals the findings below. Which of the following is also true about this disease?

choices.text: ERG shows decreased "a" and "b" waves in advanced disease
X-linked recessive inheritance generally has a milder course
Electro-oculogram (EOG) is the most critical diagnostic test for this condition
Night vision is preserved in all patients

questions.solution:
The fundus shows a pale waxy disc, attenuated arteries, and bony spicules, which implies Retinitis Pigmentosa (RP). Electroretinography (ERG) reveals a decreased amplitude of both "a" and "b" waves in RP. RP causes a reduction in amplitude and delay in the timing of the electrical signal produced by retinal stimulation.

Retinitis pigmentosa (RP) is a dystrophy of rods and cones, with rods being primarily affected. It is a genetic disease. The non-hereditary/sporadic type is most common, and among the hereditary type, it can occur in an autosomal dominant (AD), autosomal recessive (AR), or X-linked recessive (XLR) pattern. AD disease generally has the best prognosis.

Clinical features:

  • Night blindness
  • Progressive contraction of the visual field
  • Photopsia
  • Headache
  • Diminishing visual acuity due to cataracts, macular edema, or macular cysts

Investigations

  • Perimetry: Initial stage will have ring scotoma, which further develops into tunnel vision.
  • Electroretinography reveals a decreased amplitude of both "a" and "b" waves.

There is no effective treatment for RP.

Electroretinography (ERG) is the record of changes in the resting potential of the eye induced by a flash of light.

  • Waves of normal ERG
    • a-wave: negative wave possibly arising from the rods and cones
    • b-wave: large positive wave which is generated by Muller cells, but represents the activity of the bipolar cells
    • c-wave: positive wave representing the metabolic activity of pigment epithelium

X-linked recessive inheritance generally has the best prognosis (Option 2) is incorrect as XLR disease is generally more severe.

Electroretinogram (ERG) is the most critical diagnostic test for RP while Electro-oculogram (EOG) is not helpful in diagnosing RP.

Night blindness is not a symptom (Option 4) is incorrect as it is one of the earliest symptoms of RP

questions.text: A resident had a needle stick injury while dealing with a Hepatitis B positive patient. Serology was done and  HBsAg was negative and the Anti-HBs was >105 mIU/ml. What is the next step of management?

choices.text: No treatment required  as he already has Hep B antibody titres from vaccination

questions.solution: The given clinical scenario of needle-stick injury shows that HBsAg is negative and the anti-HBs is >105 mIU/ml. This suggests that the resident has had routine vaccination for Hep B infection. Since the antibody titers are more than 10 mIU/ml, no treatment is required.

questions.text: In an experiment, a researcher is using gene knockout technology and inducing cell death. The following pattern is visualized in an agarose gel by ethidium bromide staining of DNA fragments released from these cells. Which of the following statements is correct regarding this mechanism of cell death?

choices.text: BCL2, BCL-XL, MCL-1 promote cell death
Karyorrhexis and karyolysis are essential steps in the process
Annexin V is a marker for this process
Caspase-8 plays an important role in the intrinsic pathway

questions.solution:
Annexin V is a marker for this process.
 

The given image shows the characteristic DNA ladder pattern visualized in the agarose gel electrophoresis with an ethidium bromide stain which is indicative of apoptosis.

Apoptosis is defined as the programmed cell death characterized by activation of intrinsic enzymes that degrade the cells' genomic DNA, nuclear and cytoplasmic proteins.

Genes involved in the regulation of apoptosis:
  • BCL2, BCL-XL, MCL-1 are anti-apoptotic genes that keep the outer mitochondrial membrane-impermeable to death-inducing proteins. Thereby they prevent the leakage of cytochrome c and other death-inducing proteins into the cytosol.
  • BAX and BAK are pro-apoptotic factors that insert into the mitochondrial membrane and create channels that allow proteins from the inner mitochondrial membrane to leak out into the cytoplasm.
  • Initiators of apoptosis include BAD, BIM, BID, Puma, and Noxa. Their activity is upregulated and activated by sensors of cellular stress and damage.

Apoptosis has two pathways:

Mitochondrial or intrinsic pathway:

Cell injury results in the release of cytochrome c and other pro-apoptotic proteins from mitochondria. Cytochrome c binds to a protein called APAF-1 (apoptosis-activating factor-1), forming apoptosome. These then activate caspase 9 which cause nuclear fragmentation and the formation of apoptotic bodies

Death receptor or extrinsic pathway:

In this pathway, activation of death receptors causes apoptosis by activating caspase-8. Prototypic death receptors are the type I TNF receptor and Fas (CD95). Fas ligand (FasL) binds to Fas and forms a binding site to the FADD (Fas-associated death domain). This activates caspase 8 and initiates apoptosis.

Other Options:

Option A- BCL2, BCL-XL, MCL-1 are anti-apoptotic molecules.

Option B- Karyorrhexis and karyolysis are essential steps in necrosis.

Option D- Caspase-8 plays an important role in the extrinsic pathway.

questions.text: A 48-year-old diabetic male who recently returned from a trip to Europe is now found to be positive for the new variant of SARS-COV2 strain that has been detected in UK which is more virulent. This variant harbors a mutation in which of the following?
questions.solution:
The new UK variant (termed as V202012/01) is defined by multiple spike protein mutations. It includes the deletion of nucleotides causing loss of histidine and valine near the spike protein domain. This S-gene encoding it, is one amongst the many targets used to detect the virus via PCR.

This variant is believed to have more transmissibility.The new variant (H69/V70) that has been detected is due to deletion of histidine and valine at 69 and 70 positions. It has been detected by molecular typing.

A virus is classified into a species based on multiple different characteristics. Based on physicochemical characteristics, symmetry, type of genetic material, etc. But even within a species of virus, considerable changes may occur in its structure due to genetic mutations which may impact its clinical presentation, immunity against it, diagnostic test or treatment. For example different strains of the coronovirus species has earlier caused Severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS-CoV, China-2003) and Middle east respiratory syndrome(MERS-Cov, 2012-Gulf). This time we have SARS-CoV2 as a new strain. Each strain may have ongoing mutations which maybe silent (not affecting symptoms, spread or diagnosis) or maybe significant termed as variants.

Molecular typing thus involves genomic sequencing of the organism and based on how much related or different it is, classifying it to a particular species, strain and variant.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man has to undergo renal transplant surgery. You were asked to collect his blood samples for HLA matching in a yellow-colored vacutainer. Which of the following is present in the yellow-colored vacutainers?
questions.solution:
The most commonly used vacutainer for HLA typing is a yellow vacutainer containing acid-citrate dextrose.

Other uses of yellow vacutainers are DNA sampling and paternity testing. Other components that can be used in yellow vacutainers include Sodium polyanethol sulfonate (SPS) which is used to collect blood culture for microbiology specimens.

Other options:

  1. Ethylenediamine tetraacetic acid (EDTA) - It is used for routine hematology samples and is a part of violet vacutainers.
  2. Sodium fluoride - It is used for the determination of glucose and is a part of grey vacutainers
  3. Sodium citrate - It is used for coagulation studies and is a part of blue vacutainers.

Related Pearl: Anticoagulants in Vacutainers and their Uses

questions.text: A 52-year-old female complains of bleeding per vaginum for 1 week. Her last menstrual period was 2 years ago. She does not complain of fever or vaginal discharge. Physical examination shows a small amount of dry blood along her vaginal wall. USG examination performed shows increased endometrial thickness. Fractional curettage is planned for this patient. Which of the following statements is false regarding this procedure for this patient?

choices.text: Endocervical curettage is done after cervical dilatation
Following dilatation, the isthmic portion is curetted
Uterine cavity is curetted finally and usually sent separately
It is indicated due to suspected endometrial carcinoma

questions.solution:
The clinical vignette is suggestive of a post-menopausal bleed that is suspicious for malignancy. In fractional curettage, Endocervical curettage is done prior to cervical dilatation.

Fractional curettage:

  • It is indicated in suspected endometrial carcinoma.
  • In this procedure, endocervical curettage is done prior to cervical dilatation. Following dilatation, the isthmic portion is curetted and the tissue kept in a separate bottle.
  • Thereafter, the uterine cavity is curetted and sent separately.

Fractional curettage determines the extent of spread of malignancy down the uterine wall, so that staging can be done and appropriate treatment planned. Involvement of endocervical lining places the malignancy in stage II of the disease

Note : 

Procedure of Dilatation and curettage:

  • Dilatation and curettage is performed under either sedation, paracervical block or general anaesthesia. Local anaesthesia is adequate in a multiparous woman, but a nulliparous or an apprehensive woman may require general anaesthesia.
  • The woman is put in the lithotomy position.
  • Bimanual examination is done to ascertain the size of the uterus and its direction and to rule out adnexal mass.
  • With the help of Sim’s speculum and anterior vaginal wall retractor, the cervix is exposed and the anterior lip held with Vulsellum or Allis forceps.
  • The uterine sound confirms the size of the uterine cavity and its direction.
  • The cervix is dilated with a dilator and the curette is introduced into the uterine cavity and the uterine lining scraped from above downwards all round.
  • A gritty sensation indicates the end of curettage.
  • The tissue is preserved in 10% formalin. For culture and PCR, the tissue is sent in saline.

Normal endometrium appears pink and healthy. Profuse, pale-looking and friable tissue suggests malignancy. Fractional curettage determines the extent of spread of malignancy down the uterine wall so that staging can be done and appropriate treatment planned. Involvement of endocervical lining places the malignancy in stage II of the disease.

Note :

Endometrial biopsy is performed as an outpatient procedure without anaesthesia or under sedation. The cervix is not dilated and a biopsy curette is inserted and a strip or two of endometrial tissue is obtained for histological study.

questions.text: The method of asphyxia shown in the given image is ______
questions.solution:
The given image is characteristic of mugging where strangulation is caused by holding the neck of the victim in the bend of the elbow.

In this case, the pressure is put upon the neck by the arm held around the throat. The attack is usually made from behind, with the neck being trapped in the crook of the elbow and pressure exerted when the front and sides of the larynx. 

A diffuse abrasion is seen along the margin of the jaw due to the friction of the forearm. Death can occur due to asphyxia or reflex cardiac arrest

Other options:

Option A: Garrotting involves attacking the victim from behind using a ligature. The ligature is thrown around the unaware victim’s neck and then tightened with the help of two sticks tied at the free ends of the string. Earlier in Spain, garroting was also an official method of execution of criminals.

An image of the execution of a prisoner by garroting is shown below

Option B: Throttling or manual strangulation is defined as compression and strangulation with bare hands. 

Effects of pressure on the neck due to manual strangulation are:

  • Carotid artery blockage resulting in loss of consciousness
  • Carotid sinus pressure causing vagus nerve stimulation and cardiac arrest
  • Airway blockages causing hypoxemia 

The given autopsy images showing carotid intimal tear and muscle hematoma with nail marks on the neck and absence of ligature mark point towards a diagnosis of throttling.

Option D: Smothering is defined as a form of asphyxia where the external respiratory orifices are closed either by the hand or by other means or blocking up the cavities of the nose and mouth by the introduction of a foreign substance.

The image shows smothering, which involves the blockage of the external air passages, usually by a hand or soft fabric/pillow.

questions.text: A 6-month-old infant is brought to the emergency room with spasms of the neck and trunk. The episodes last about 15 seconds. This is usually followed by a period of decreased responses and motor activity lasting for a minute. The episodes occur most commonly in the mornings after the baby wakes up. On examination, neurodevelopmental delay is evident. An EEG obtained during one of these episodes is shown below. Which is the following is false about this condition?

choices.text: Hypsarrhythmia is the typical ictal EEG finding
Most cases present before one year of age

questions.solution:
The clinical vignette describes a case of infantile epileptic spasm. Hypsarrhythmia is the typical interictal EEG finding, seen between episodes, not during an episode. 

It is an age-specific seizure disorder that predominantly occurs before the age of one. Some cases may be diagnosed late as this condition may be mistaken to be hyperirritability, exaggerated startle responses, and/or colic. 

Clinical features

  • Spasms involve the muscles of the neck, trunk, and extremities.
  • They are symmetric and synchronous
  • There is an initial phasic contraction that lasts less than two seconds and involves sudden, brief, contractions of various muscle groups
  • The next phase is a tonic contraction phase that is less intense and lasts up to ten seconds
  • Motor arrest  or a period of attenuated responsiveness may occur following the contraction and lasts up to 90 seconds
  • Deviation of the eyes, nystagmus and change in respiratory pattern may be seen in some patients
  • Most patients develop neurodevelopmental delay
  • The triad of spasms, arrest of psychomotor development, and hypsarrhythmia is known as West syndrome

Diagnosis

  • EEG
    • Interictal: Hypsarrythmia is the defining feature of infantile spasms and is characterized by very high voltage, random, slow waves and spikes in all cortical areas. These spikes vary in duration and location. This finding may precede the onset of spasms.
    • Ictal: The ictal EEG generally shows a high-voltage slow-wave transient followed by a general attenuation of activity. Electrodecremental response which is generalized attenuation may occur with or without clinical evidence of a seizure
  • Neuroimaging with CT/MRI is recommended in all patients
  • Metabolic and genetic testing may be done to identify the etiology
  • EMG reveals a characteristic rhomboid pattern which may help to distinguish between brief tonic and myoclonic seizures

Treatment

The major options for treatment of IS include hormonal therapy, mainly corticotropin (ACTH), and antiseizure medication, mainly vigabatrin.

questions.text:
A 2-week-old neonate was brought to the pediatric OPD for evaluation of yellowing of the skin that has worsened in the last two days. The parents say that their baby is playful and feeds well. He is exclusively breastfed. He passes urine 9-10 times a day, and passes stools up to 5-6 times a day. He has a weight loss of 4% compared to his birth weight. This baby was born at 39 weeks gestation by normal vaginal delivery. On examination, the neonate appears jaundiced. Pulse rate is 120/min and respiratory rate is 40/minute. Laboratory investigations reveal the following:

 

Lab Investigation Value Normal Range

Total bilirubin (mg/dL)

 12 0.3-1.2
Direct bilirubin (mg/dL) 0.3 <0.3
Na (mmol/L) 138 135-145
K (mmol/L) 4.0 3.5-5.0
Cl (mmol/L) 100 95-105
Glucose (mg/dL) 96 65-110

Two days later, the total bilirubin is found to be 14 mg/dL and direct bilirubin is unchanged. Further workup reveals that an inhibitor present in breast milk is the cause for this presentation. The baby is started on formula feeds for 24 hours. Which of the following is appropriate advice to the mother during this time?

choices.text: Stop breastfeeding for one week and then resume
Continue to breast feed the baby along with formula feeds
Breastfeeding can be resumed when bilirubin normalises

questions.solution:
The clinical vignette describes a neonate with breast milk jaundice. Babies with persistenly elevated or increasing levels of bilirubin should be given formula feeds for 24-48 hours. During this time, breastfeeding should be continued.

Breast Milk Jaundice:

  • Human milk contains high levels of beta-glucuronidase, which catalyzes the hydrolysis of beta-D-glucuronic acid
  • There is enhanced absorption of bilirubin from the gut as the result of decreased beta-D-glucuronic acid
  • It appears later than breastfeeding jaundice and gradually declines by the 2nd or 3rd week of life
  • Persistently high or worsening indirect bilirubin levels require changing to formula feeds or phototherapy all while continuing breastfeeding

Breastfeeding failure jaundice:

Occurs due to inadequate breastfeeding and usually resolves once breastfeeding is adequate.

Indicators of inadequate breastfeeding in an infant:

  • Weight loss >7-10% of birth weight
  • Lethargy (sleeping longer than 2–3 hours)
  • Delayed stooling (Less than 4 times/day)
  • Decreased urine output (urinating less than 5–7 times/day)
  • Hypernatremic dehydration
  • Inconsolable crying and increased hunger

Insufficient milk intake could be due to insufficient milk production, failure of established breastfeeding, and health conditions in the infant that prevent proper breast stimulation.

Breastfed neonates usually feed 8–12 times a day, with a minimum of 8 times per day. However, the neonate should be breastfed on demand.

questions.text: A middle-aged man presents to the outpatient department with fever, epigastric discomfort, progressive weight loss, arthralgia, and foul-smelling diarrhea for the past 6 months. There is no relation between the abdominal pain and his bowel movements. He was started on a restrictive diet, which showed no improvement. His biopsy is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis is whipple disease which is caused by a gram-positive actinomycete, named Tropheryma whipplei.

Whipple's disease is a chronic multisystem disorder caused by a gram-positive bacteria Tropheryma whipplei. It presents as 

  • Diarrhea
  • Steatorrhea due to malabsorption caused by impaired lymphatic transport.
  • Weight loss
  • Arthralgia
  • Central nervous system problems
  • Cardiac problems

The morphologic hallmark of whipple disease is a dense accumulation of distended, foamy macrophages in the small intestinal lamina propria. Macrophages contain periodic acid–Schiff (PAS)-positive, diastase-resistant granules that represent lysosomes stuffed with partially digested bacteria.

Other options:

Option A: Irritable bowel syndrome presents with recurrent abdominal pain that may be - 

  • related to defecation
  • associated with a change in frequency 
  • associated with a change in appearance

Despite having these symptoms, the endoscopy and microscopic examination are normal in patients with irritable bowel syndrome.

Option C: Cystic fibrosis is a congenital disorder due to a mutation in the cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator (CFTR) gene located on chromosome 7. It leads to abnormal transport of chloride and bicarbonate ions in the lungs, gastrointestinal tract, pancreas and reproductive tract. It presents as

  • Lungs - recurrent respiratory infections. 
  • Pancreas - exocrine pancreatic insufficiency causing fat malabsorption and steatorrhoea. 
  • Reproductive tract - infertility due to absent vas deferens.

Option D: Celiac disease is an autoimmune gluten-induced enteropathy where there is an excessive inflammatory response to gluten and its breakdown product, gliadin. This leads to inflammatory infiltration of the lamina propria which subsequently impairs various nutrient absorption.

Clinically, it presents as a malabsorption syndrome with diarrhea, abdominal pain, and marked weight loss. Microscopic findings show

  • Villi atrophy
  • Villi flattening
  • Crypt hyperplasia
  • Increased intraepithelial T lymphocytes

Symptoms usually subside with a gluten restricted diet.

Image: Microscopic image of celiac disease

questions.text: A G2P1 lady at 32 weeks of gestation presents with irregularly occurring abdominal pain and discharge per vaginum. On examination, uterine contractions were noted and a nonstress test reveals a reassuring fetal heart rhythm. Preterm labor would be suspected, if this patient reveals

choices.text: Uterine contractions of 9 per hour with cervical length of 32 mm
Uterine contractions of 7 per hour with cervical length of 22 mm
Uterine contractions of 6 per hour with cervical length of 34 mm
Uterine contractions of 3 per hour with cervical length of 26 mm

questions.solution:
Among the given options, you would suspect preterm labor in a G2P1 patient at 32 weeks of gestation having uterine contractions of 7 per hour with a cervical length of 22 mm.

Irrespective of uterine contractions, preterm labor is very unlikely when the cervical length is > 30 mm (Option A, & C). 

Preterm labor is defined as the labor that starts before the 37th completed week(< 259 days), from the first day of the last menstrual period.

Predictors of preterm labor:

Clinical predictors:

  • History of prior preterm birth
  • Multiple pregnancies
  • Presence of genital tract infection
  • Symptoms of preterm labor

Biophysical predictors:

  • Uterine contractions ≥4/hr
  • Bishop score ≥ 4
  • Cervical length (TVS) ≤ 25 mm (Option D)

Biochemical predictors:

  • Fetal fibronectin (fFN) in cervicovaginal discharge 

Diagnosis of preterm labor:

  • Regular uterine contractions of at least one in every 10 minutes with or without pain 
  • ≥ 2 cm dilatation and 80 % effacement of the cervix
  • Transvaginal ultrasound shows ≤ 25 mm length of the cervix and funneling of the internal os
  • Presence of backache, vaginal discharge, or bleeding 

Note: Fibronectin is a glycoprotein that binds the fetal membranes to the decidua which is found in the cervicovaginal discharge before 22 weeks and again after 37 weeks of pregnancy.

The presence of fibronectin in the cervicovaginal discharge between 24 weeks and 34 weeks is a predictor of preterm labor. If the test is negative, it reassures that delivery will not occur in the next 7 days.

  • According to NICE guidelines, a score of 6-13 is favorable for induction of labour.

questions.text: A 33-year-old unvaccinated female physician has been working in a COVID-19 dedicated facility for the last two months. She now presents with worsening shortness of breath, cough, and myalgias for the last 4 days. She also reports a loss of smell and taste. On examination, temperature is 103 deg F, pulse rate is 110/min, respiratory rate is 33/minute and SpO2 is 89% on room air. CT scan of this patient is shown below. Which of the following is incorrect about this condition?

choices.text: Lymphopenia and elevated inflammatory markers are seen
APOL1 increases the risk of collapsing nephropathy in these patients
Remdesivir improves survival in hospitalised patients
Non-invasive ventilation and steroids are treatment modalities

questions.solution:
This physician, who has been working in a COVID-19 dedicated facility has a clinical presentation that points towards the diagnosis of severe COVID-19. In a recent update, WHO recommended against the use of remdesivir in hospitalized patients, regardless of disease severity, as there is no evidence of that it improves survival.

The CT scan in the given image shows bilateral, peripheral ground-glass opacity associated with smooth interlobular and intralobular septal thickening (crazy-paving pattern).

The following table classifies COVID-19 based on severity - 

Mild Moderate Severe
URTI and/or fever without shortness of breath or hypoxia

RR ≥ 24/min, breathlessness

OR

SpO2: 90% to ≤93% on room air

RR > 30/min, breathlessness

OR

SpO2 < 90% on room air

 
Home isolation and care Admit in ward Admit in ICU
Physical distancing, indoor mask use, strict hand hygiene, symptomatic management, monitor temperature and oxygen saturation. Seek immediate medical attention if:
  • Difficulty breathing
  • High grade fever/severe cough >5days
May consider
  • Tab Ivermectin (200 mcg/kg once a day for 3 days). Avoid in pregnant and lactating women.
OR
  • Tab HCQ (400 mg BD for 1 day f/b 400 mg OD for 4 days) unless contraindicated.
Inhalational Budesonide at a dose of 800mcg BD for 5 days to be given if fever and/or cough are persistent beyond 5 days of disease onset.

Oxygen support:

  • Target SpO2: 92-96% (88-92% for COPD patients)
  • Non-rebreathing face mask
  • Awake proning in all patients requiring supplemental O2 therapy

Anti-inflammatory or immunomodulatory therapy:

  • Inj. Methylprednisolone 0.5 to 1 mg/kg in 2 divided doses (or an equivalent dose of dexamethasone) for 5 to 10 days.
  • Switch to oral route if stable and/or improving

Anticoagulation:

  • Conventional dose prophylactic UH/LMWH (enoxaparin 0.5mg/kg per day SC)

Monitoring:

  • Clinical Monitoring - Work of breathing, Hemodynamic instability, Change in oxygen requirement.Serial CXR; HRCT chest to be done ONLY If there is worsening.
  • Lab monitoring: CRP and D-dimer 48 to 72 hourly; CBC, RFT, LFT 24 to 48 hourly. IL-6 to be done if deteriorating.

EUA use: Remdesivir

Respiratory support:

  • NIV in patients with increasing oxygen requirement, if work of breathing is low.
  • HFNC in patients with increasing oxygen requirement.
  • Intubation if high work of breathing/if NIV is not tolerated.
  • Conventional ARDS net protocol for ventilatory management.

Anti-inflammatory or immunomodulatory therapy:

  • Inj. Methylprednisolone 1 to 2 mg/kg in 2 divided doses (or an equivalent dose of dexamethasone) for 5 to 10 days.

Anticoagulation:

  • Conventional dose prophylactic UH/LMWH (enoxaparin 0.5mg/kg per day SC)

Supportive measures:

  • Maintain euvolemia
  • If sepsis/septic shock, then manage as per existing protocol.

Monitoring:

  • Serial CXR; HRCT chest to be done ONLY if there is worsening.
  • Lab monitoring: CRP and D-dimer 24-48 hourly; CBC, RFT, LFT daily; IL-6 to be done if deteriorating.

EUA/Off label use: 

  • Remdesivir
  • Tocilizumab.

EUA/Off label use:

Remdesivir (EUA): Considered only in patients with 

  • Moderate to severe disease (requiring supplemental O2)
  • No renal or hepatic dysfunction [eGFR <30 ml/min/m2; AST/ALT >5 times ULN (Not an absolute contraindication)]
  • Within 10 days of onset of symptoms
  • Not to be used in patients who are not on oxygen support or in home settings

Recommended dose: 200mg IV on day 1, 100 mg IV OD for next 4 days.

Tocilizumab (Off label):  Considered when all of the below criteria are met

  • Presence of severe disease (within 24 to 48 hrs of onset of severe disease)
  • Significantly raised inflammatory markers (CRP &/or IL-6).
  • Not improving despite use of steroids
  • No active bacterial/fungal/tubercular infection.

Recommended single dose: 4-6 mg/kg in 100ml NS over 1 hr.

Favipiravir (inhibits viral RNA polymerase) is the first oral drug approved in India for restricted emergency use for the treatment of mild to moderate COVID-19 patients. Studies show that the drug offers a rapid reduction in viral load and also provides a faster symptomatic and radiological improvement.

Common laboratory abnormalities seen in COVID-19 are:

  • Lymphopenia (reported in up to 90%)
  • Mild thrombocytopenia
  • Elevated aminotransaminase levels
  • Elevated lactate dehydrogenase levels
  • Elevated inflammatory markers - eg, ferritin, C-reactive protein, and erythrocyte sedimentation rate
  • Markers of a hypercoagulable state - high fibrinogen, high D-dimer levels, increased fibrin degradation products, prolonged prothrombin time (PT) and activated partial thromboplastin time (aPTT)

Due to hypercoagulable state, coagulation factors are consumed leading to prolonged prothrombin time (PT) and activated partial thromboplastin time (aPTT).

The degree of these abnormalities tends to correlate with disease severity.

Radiographic features:

Typical features for pulmonary involvement by COVID-19

  • Obligatory features:
    • Ground-glass opacities, with or without consolidation, in regions close to the visceral pleural lines, including the fissures
    • Multifocal bilateral distribution
  • Confirmatory patterns:
    • Ground glass regions
    • Unsharp, rounded shape
    • Sharp demarcation, outlining the shape of multiple adjacent pulmonary nodules
    • Crazy paving with visible intralobular lines
    • Patterns compatible with organizing pneumonia
    • Thickened vessels within parenchymal abnormalities

 Recent Update:

The Drugs Controller General of India (DCGI) in January 2021, has granted permission for restricted emergency use of the following vaccines against COVID-19:

  • Covaxin (Bharat biotech/NIV)
  • Covishield (Oxford University/ AstraZeneca/ Serum Institute of India)
  • Sputnik V (Gamaleya Research Institute/ Dr. Reddy's Laboratories)

The FDA has issued an emergency use authorization for the following vaccines against COVID-19: 

  • Pfizer/BioNtech
  • Moderna
  • Johnson and Johnson

 

Note:

APOL 1 gene increases the risk of collapsing nephropathy in patients infected with COVID-19. 

This type of COVID-19-​associated nephropathy (COVAN) specifically affects individuals of African ancestry who are carriers of this gene variant.

Histopathology is similar to those seen in other forms of collapsing glomerulopathy. But, tubulointerstitial lesions including microcystic tubular dilatation and tubular injury are typically associated with APOL1- related disease.

questions.text: A multiparous woman presents at 36 weeks of gestation. On examination, fundal height is less than the period of amenorrhea. In the fundal grip, the fetal pole is not palpable and in the pelvic grip, the lower pole of the uterus is empty. On the lateral grip, a soft, irregular breech is felt on one side of the midline. Identify the most common fetal position in the given presentation?
questions.solution:
The given examination findings are suggestive of a transverse lie. The most common fetal position in a transverse lie is dorso-anterior.

Transverse lie occurs when the long axis of the fetus lies perpendicularly to the maternal spine or centralized uterine axis.

The position of the fetus in a transverse lie is determined by the direction of the back, which is the denominator. The position may be:

  • Dorsoanterior, which is the most common. (60%)
  • Dorsoposterior, where the chance of fetal extension is common with increased risk of arm prolapse
  • Dorsosuperior 
  • Dorsoinferior

According to the position of the head, the fetal position is termed right or left, the left one being more common.

Abdominal examination findings:

On inspection, the uterus looks broader and is often asymmetrical. It does not maintain the pyriform shape.

Palpation:

  • Fundal height is less than the period of amenorrhea.
  • Fundal grip: Fetal pole (breech or head) is not palpable.
  • Lateral grip: A smooth, hard, and globular head is felt on one side. A soft, broad, and irregular breech is felt on the other side.
    • In dorso-anterior: The back is felt anteriorly across the long axis 
    • In dorso-posterior: Irregular small parts are felt anteriorly
  • Pelvic grip: The lower pole of the uterus is empty.

questions.text: A middle-aged woman was started on heparin postoperatively for thromboprophylaxis. A few days later, she presented with deep vein thrombosis. Her platelet count was found to be 60,000/microliter. Which of the following anticoagulants should be avoided in this condition?
questions.solution:
The patient in the above scenario has heparin-induced thrombocytopenia (HIT). Warfarin can decrease protein C levels and may precipitate venous limb gangrene or skin necrosis in patients with heparin-induced thrombocytopenia. Therefore, it should not be used until the platelet count returns to normal.

HIT is caused due to the development of IgG antibodies against complexes of heparin with platelet factor 4 (or other chemokines).

HIT usually starts 5-10 days after starting heparin. The patients will have platelet count <1,50,000/mL or reduced by 50% or more from the pre-treatment value. These are more common with unfractionated heparin than with low molecular weight (LMWH) and also more common in women.

Venous thrombosis (in the form of deep vein thrombosis or pulmonary embolism) is more common than arterial thrombosis. Arterial thrombosis can cause limb ischemia, myocardial infarction, or stroke. Bilateral adrenal hemorrhage and skin lesions at the site of subcutaneous heparin injection can also be seen.

The diagnosis of heparin-induced thrombocytopenia can be confirmed by enzyme-linked immunoassays to detect antibodies against heparin-PF4 complexes, platelet activation assays, and serotonin release assay.

Management of HIT includes:

  • Stop heparin/LMWH.
  • Give an alternative anticoagulant, such as lepirudin, argatroban, bivalirudin, fondaparinux or rivaroxaban. LMWH should be avoided because it cross-reacts with heparin antibodies.
  • Do not give warfarin until the platelet count returns to its baseline level. If warfarin was administered, give vitamin K to restore the INR to normal.

questions.text: A 58-year-old patient presented with weakness, fatigue, and abdominal discomfort. On examination, massive splenomegaly is present. Investigations reveal pancytopenia, and his peripheral blood smear is as shown below. Immunophenotype testing reveals  CD19, CD20, and CD22, CD11c, CD25, and CD103 positive. Which of the following is the mechanism of action of the drug used as first-line therapy for managing this patient?

choices.text: A purine analogue and an S phase specific drug producing DNA strand breaks
A platinum compound and a cell cycle independent anti cancer drug
An M phase specific anti cancer drug which prevents mitotic spindle formation
An S phase specific drug which inhibits topoisomerase 1 and prevents DNA unwinding and replication

questions.solution:
According to the clinical scenario given above and the presence of Hairy cells on the Wright-stained peripheral blood smear shown in the image, the most likely diagnosis is Hairy cell leukaemia. Cladribine is the first line therapy for hairy cell leukemia, which is a purine analogue and an S phase-specific anti-cancer drug. It is incorporated into DNA, where it produces DNA strand breaks and depletion of NAD and ATP, leading to apoptosis.

Hairy cell leukaemia is due to the clonal proliferation of B-cell lymphocytes. They appear as cells with oval nuclei, abundant cytoplasm, and distinctive membrane projections (hairy cells). Most patients present with symptoms of cytopenias or splenomegaly. The most common physical finding in hairy cell leukemia is splenomegaly. Patients are typically males in their 50s. A dry tap is obtained upon performing bone marrow aspiration due to HCL-induced marrow fibrosis and the interlocking cell borders of hairy cells.

CD11c, CD25, and CD103 are the characteristic immunophenotype diagnostic of Hairy cell leukaemia. Pan-B markers such as CD19, CD20, and CD22 can also test positive for Hairy cell leukemia.

Diagnosis: Annexin A1 on bone marrow specimens has been shown to have 100% sensitivity and specificity in differentiating hairy cell leukaemia from other B cell malignancies.

Tartrate-resistant acid phosphatase (TRAP) stain is an important tool in the clinical diagnosis of hairy cell leukaemia and yields positive results in ≈95% of the cases.

Hairy cells on Wright-stained peripheral blood smear is an important diagnostic finding. However, these can be seen in other B-cell disorders also.

Typical hairy cells (shown below) are mononuclear cells with abundant pale blue-grey agranular cytoplasm with elongated (hairy) projections.

Note: 

  • Splenic marginal zone lymphoma involves both white pulp and red pulp of the spleen (Hairy cell leukemia is limited to the red pulp)
  • All Non-Hodgkin's lymphomas involve the white pulp of the spleen except:
    • Hairy cell leukaemia
    • Hepatosplenic lymphoma

The pattern of bone marrow involvement on biopsy specimens is near to pathognomonic for hairy cell leukemia (>99%).

  • Diffuse infiltration of tumor cells with a honeycomb appearance.
  • Individual cells have a "fried egg" appearance such that the nucleus of each hairy cell is surrounded by a halo of cytoplasm.

Treatment: 

Cladribine is the first-line therapy for hairy cell leukemia.

It is a purine analogue and antineoplastic agent used primarily in the therapy of hairy cell leukemia. Cladribine is an S phase-specific anti-cancer drug. It is incorporated into DNA, where it produces DNA strand breaks and depletion of NAD and ATP, leading to apoptosis. Also, it is a potent inhibitor of ribonucleotide reductase. It does not require cell division to be cytotoxic.

Cladribine is administered daily for seven days by continuous intravenous infusion.

Cladribine and deoxycoformycin are highly active agents and cause durable remissions in patients. It is excreted by the kidneys, and doses should be adjusted
for renal dysfunction.

Cladribine is also used in CLL, low-grade lymphomas, Langerhans cell histiocytosis, Cutaneous T cell lymphomas (like mycosis fungoides and the Sézary syndrome), and Waldenström macroglobulinemia.

The major side effect is immunosuppression. Nausea, infections, thrombocytopenia, high fever, headache, fatigue, skin rashes, and tumor lysis syndrome can also occur.

Interferon-alpha is also used but not as effective as nucleoside analogues. 

Splenectomy is often associated with prolonged remissions.

Chemotherapy-refractory patients are treated with vemurafenib, a BRAF kinase inhibitor.

Other options:

Vinblastin is an M phase-specific anti-cancer drug. Vinca alkaloids bind β-tubulin and inhibit its polymerisation into microtubules →, preventing mitotic spindle formation.

Topotecan is S phase specific anticancer drug. It inhibits topoisomerase one and prevents DNA unwinding and replication.

Cisplatin is a cell cycle-independent anti-cancer drug. Its mode of action has been linked to its ability to crosslink with the purine bases on the DNA, interfering with DNA repair mechanisms, causing DNA damage, and subsequently inducing apoptosis in cancer cells.

It is used in the treatment of testicular, bladder, ovary, and lung carcinomas. However, because of drug resistance and numerous undesirable side effects, such as

  • Severe kidney injury,
  • Allergic reactions,
  • Decrease immunity to infections,
  • Gastrointestinal disorders,
  • Hemorrhage, and
  • Hearing loss, especially in younger patients,

Other platinum-containing anti-cancer drugs, such as carboplatin oxaliplatin, have been used.

Methotrexate is an antimetabolite. It is a folic acid analogue that inhibits the enzyme dihydrofolate reductase (DHFR). Methotrexate and its polyglutamate also inhibit the enzymes involved in the denovo purine and thymidylate synthesis.

questions.text: A woman presents postpartum with a history of depressive symptoms for 15 days. Since giving birth 3 weeks back she has had a low mood and decreased sleep. Recently she started hearing a voice instructing her to harm the baby. Treatment of choice for this patient would be:
questions.solution:
From the given clinical scenario the patient exhibits thoughts of wanting to harm the baby and is showing features of postpartum psychosis. Treatment of choice for this patient would be Antipsychotics + Lithium + Antidepressants

Postpartum psychosis can often begin within days of the delivery, although the mean time to onset is usually within 2 to 3 weeks of delivery. Characteristically, the patient begins to complain of fatigue, episodes of tearfulness, and emotional lability. Later, suspiciousness, confusion, irrational statements, and obsessive concerns about the baby's health and welfare may be present. They eventually develop delusions that involve the idea that the baby is dead or defective. Hallucinations if present may involve voices telling the patient to harm the baby or herself. 

if there is imminent harm to the mother or baby immediate hospitalization is recommended and the mother must be separated from the baby. Management involves antipsychotics and lithium with antidepressants as the treatment of choice. In refractory cases ECT may be used.

questions.text:
A young boy who is anticipating his board exams has been increasingly isolated with flat affect for the past 6 months. He has disorganized speech and says he hears a voice telling him that the government is tracking him. On mental status examination, you find that he is depressed. Considering the likely diagnosis, which of the following can be considered a good prognostic factor for him?
  1. Presence of depression
  2. Male sex
  3. Presence of a stressor
  4. Young age of onset
  5. Presence of negative symptoms
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario showing a flat affect, auditory hallucinations, and disorganized speech is highly suggestive of schizophrenia. The presence of a stressor and depression are good prognostic factors.

Schizophrenia is a psychosis, a type of mental illness characterized by distortions in thinking, perception, emotions, language, sense of self, and behavior.

The DSM-5 criteria to diagnose schizophrenia require a total duration of 6 months. Within this 6-month period, there must be at least 1 month of active-phase symptoms (overt psychotic symptoms) where 2 or more of the following have to be present, with at least one among the symptoms a, b, or c: 

  1. Delusion
  2. Hallucination
  3. Disorganized speech (or formal thought disorder)
  4. Disorganized behavior
  5. Affective flattening or other negative symptoms

Studies have pointed out that more than half of the patients generally have a poor prognosis. Poor prognostic factors are associated with repeated hospitalizations, exacerbation of symptoms, and suicide attempts. At least one-third of people with schizophrenia experiences complete remission of symptoms. Some people with schizophrenia experience worsening and remission of symptoms periodically throughout their lives, others a gradual worsening of symptoms over time.

The good and the poor prognostic factors are given below:

Late-onset Early-onset
Presence of a stressor Absence of a stressor
Presence of depression No depression
Positive symptoms Negative symptoms
Family history of mood disorder Family history of schizophrenia
Married, female sex Single, male sex

 

Based on the predominant clinical presentation, schizophrenia is divided into five subtypes: paranoid, disorganized, undifferentiated, catatonic, and residual. Antipsychotics form the mainstay of treatment, while psychotherapy is used as an adjunct.
