questions.text: A 28-year-old woman visited the local WHO camp with fever, headache, and joint pain for a month followed by trouble sleeping, and confusion. She gives a history of some insect bite, followed by the development of a painless chancre at the site. Examination revealed posterior cervical lymphadenopathy and hepatosplenomegaly. Blood examination shows the following findings. What is the causative organism?
questions.solution:
African trypanosomiasis, also known as sleeping sickness, is an arthropod-borne parasitic disease of humans and other animals. It is caused by protozoa of the species Trypanosoma brucei (shown in the image).

It is seen with an elongated body supporting a longitudinal lateral undulating membrane and a flagellum that borders the free edge of the membrane and emerges at the anterior end as a whiplike extension. The kinetoplast (circular DNA inside the single mitochondrion) is a darkly stained body lying next to the basal body from which the flagellum arises. T brucei rhodesiense and T brucei gambiense are indistinguishable morphologically.

The most reliable method for differentiating the trypomastigotes of T. brucei and T. cruzi is by the size of the kinetoplast. T. brucei has a relatively small kinetoplast, while T. cruzi has a larger kinetoplast.

Stages of African sleeping sickness:

Stage I – no CNS involvement

  • Painless chancre at the site of bite of Tsetse fly.
  • Initially, in the first stage of the disease, there are fevers, headaches, itchiness, and joint pains. This begins one to three weeks after the bite
  • Hepatosplenomegaly and lymphadenopathy, particularly in the posterior cervical region (Winterbottom’s sign)
  • Myocarditis
  • Hematological - anemia, moderate leucocytosis, and thrombocytopenia. High levels of immunoglobulins mainly immunoglobulin (IgM) are a constant feature.

Stage II – CNS invasion

  • Weeks to months later the second stage begins with confusion, poor coordination, numbness, and trouble sleeping.
  • Sleeping sickness, extrapyramidal symptoms, coma, and death

Other options:

Chagas disease (American trypanosomiasis) is caused by Trypanosoma cruzi. It is transmitted by the reduviid bug which is also called the kissing bug or triatomine.

Visceral leishmaniasis (kala-azar) is a slowly progressing indigenous disease caused by a protozoan parasite of the genus Leishmania. Leishmaniasis is a parasitic disorder transmitted by the bite of an infected female phlebotomus sandfly in developing countries. The disease is transmitted by sandflies, which inoculate the flagellated promastigotes into the skin of the host.

In human beings, the disease presents in four different forms with a broad range of clinical manifestation:

  • Visceral leishmaniasis, or kala-azar,
  • Cutaneous leishmaniasis,
  • Mucocutaneous leishmaniasis, and
  • Diffuse cutaneous leishmaniasis.
Disease Causative organism Vector
African trypanosomiasis (Sleeping sickness) Trypanosoma brucei (Gambiense and rhodesiense) Tsetse fly
South American trypanosomiasis (Chaga’s disease) Trypanosoma cruzi Reduvid bug
Visceral leishmaniasis/Kala-azar/ dum dum fever/ Black sickness Leishmania donovani Sandfly (Phlebotomus/ Lutzomia)

The vector seen in the image is tse tse fly (Glossina species) which is involved in the transmission of sleeping sickness (African trypanosomiasis) caused by Trypanosoma brucei.

DDT 25% and Dieldrin 18-20% are the insecticides used commonly for the control of tsetse fly. The female does not lay eggs. It gives birth to the larva.

Reduvid bug: Vector for Chagas disease (American trypanosomiasis) 

Metacyclic Trypomastigote is the infective form of Trypanosoma cruzi.

Identification of Trypomastigote forms:

  • Elongated, spindle shaped with a central nucleus.
  • The kinetoplast is posterior to the nucleus (postnuclear kinetoplast) and situated at the posterior end of the body.
  • The flagellum runs alongside the entire length of the cell to form a long undulating membrane before emerging as a free flagellum from the anterior end.
  • This is the infective stage of trypanosomes found in arthropod vector and in the blood of infected vertebrate.
  •  Note: This stage is lacking in Leishmania.

Sandfly 

They are also referred to as Phlebotomus. They transmit diseases such as kala-azar (visceral leishmaniasis), oriental sore, sandfly fever and oraya fever.They are generally smaller than mosquitoes and are hairy insects.

They like to dwell in cracks and crevices in walls during the daytime. They are active during night (nocturnal pests). They do not fly for more than 50 yards. They can be controlled by insecticides and also by proper sanitation.

questions.text: A 14-year-old boy presents with acute onset of pain in his scrotum. He previously had similar pain that would subside spontaneously but the pain this time is unbearable.  Physical examination shows a swollen erythematous scrotum. Cremasteric reflex is absent. What is the next best step in management?
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette is suggestive of testicular torsion. In cases of high clinical suspicion, the next best step is to explore surgically.

Clinical features of testicular torsion are painful scrotal swelling, erythema, nausea, and vomiting, testis seems high in the scrotum and the twisted cord can sometimes be palpated.

Signs seen on torsion of testis are:

  • Deming’s sign: Spasm of the cremaster muscle due to twisting of the spermatic cord causes the affected testis to be positioned higher than the normal testis.
  • Angell’s sign: The testis on the normal side lies horizontally because of the mesorchium between the testis and epididymis.
  • Cremastic reflex: Absent on the side of the affected testis

Management is determined primarily on clinical grounds. Doppler ultrasound scanning can confirm the absence of the blood supply to the affected testis, but the false positives are high and hence not routinely recommended.

Urgent scrotal exploration is indicated if there is doubt regarding the diagnosis. A transverse scrotal incision is taken and if the testis is viable twisting again is prevented by fixation with three non-absorbable sutures between the tunica albuginea of the testis and the scrotal raphe.

questions.text: An 11-year-old boy is brought to the emergency room after allegedly swallowing a coin while playing at home one hour ago. He appears to be in no apparent distress and is seated comfortably on the bed. Pulse rate is 100/min, respiratory rate is 19/minute and blood pressure is 110/60 mm Hg. The chest radiograph is shown below. Which of the following is the next best step in management for this patient?
questions.solution:
The coin is lodged in the oesophagus. In this asymptomatic patient who has swallowed a blunt object, it is appropriate to observe the patient for 24 hours.

When foreign bodies are lodged in the oesophagus, the flat surface of the object is seen in the anteroposterior view and the edge is seen in the lateral view as shown in the radiological image above. The reverse is true for objects in the trachea.

Commonly, oesophagal foreign bodies lodge at the level of the upper oesophagal sphincter(Cricopharyngeus), the aortic arch or the lower oesophagal sphincter(Gastro-esophageal junction).

Management:

  • Asymptomatic blunt objects (coins) can be observed for 24 hours for their passage from the oesophagus to the stomach
  • Only if the child is symptomatic (drooling/breathing difficulty), immediate endoscopic removal is recommended
  • Sharp objects in the oesophagus, disc button batteries, or foreign bodies associated with respiratory symptoms mandate urgent endoscopic removal
  • Dislodging the coin using the Ryle’s tube carries the risk of perforation and is not advised

questions.text: A 22-year-old female presents with complaints of bleeding after sexual intercourse. She also has watery mucoid discharge since the past week. Physical examination reveals an ulcerative cervical lesion. On biopsy study, the patient is diagnosed with cervical carcinoma stage IIIC2 according to the recent guidelines by FIGO for cancer cervix(2018). Which of the following represents findings in this patient?

choices.text: Invasive cervical carcinoma of <4cm with pelvic lymph node metastasis
Invasive cervical carcinoma of < 4cm with para-aortic lymph node metastasis
Invasive cervical carcinoma of >4cm with bladder metastasis
Invasive cervical carcinoma of >4cm with pelvic lymph node metastasis

questions.solution:
The clinical vignette describes cervical cancer. Patient showing invasive cervical carcinoma of < 4cm with para-aortic lymph node metastasis is classified under stage IIIC2.

Stage 3C of cervical carcinoma includes involvement of the pelvic and/or para-aortic lymph nodes, irrespective of the tumor size and extent.

  • 3C1: pelvic lymph node metastasis only.
  • 3C2: para-aortic lymph node metastasis.

Clinical Features of Cervical Cancer -

  • Irregular or heavy vaginal bleeding, postcoital bleeding, watery/mucoid/purulent, and malodorous vaginal discharge, a visible lesion on pelvic examination
  • Hematuria, hematochezia, or vaginal passage of urine or stool, are uncommon and suggest advanced disease

Diagnosis - 

  • Cervical cytology
  • Colposcopy and cervical biopsy

Other options:

Options A and D are classified as stage IIIC1 as only pelvic lymph node metastasis is seen.

Related Pearl: Staging of Carcinoma Cervix

Stage I - limited to the cervix

  • A: Microscopic lesion
    • A1 - stromal invasion <3mm depth
    • A2 - a stromal invasion of ≥3 and <5mm depth
  • B: Macroscopic lesion
    • B1 - stromal invasion ≥5mm depth & tumor size <2cm 
    • B2 - tumor size ≥2cm to <4cm 
    • B3 - tumor size ≥4cm 

Stage II - involves upper 2/3 of vagina

  • A: Extends to the upper two-thirds of the vagina without parametrial involvement
    • A1 - tumor size <4cm 
    • A2 - tumor size ≥4cm 
  • B: Extends to parametrium but not upto the pelvic wall.

Stage III - spreads to lower 1/3 of vagina

  • A: Extends to lower 1/3 of the vagina
  • B: Extends to the pelvic wall (hydronephrosis/non-functioning kidney)
  • C: Involvement of the pelvic and/or para-aortic lymph nodes, irrespective of the tumor size and extent
    • C1: pelvic lymph node involved
    • C2: para-aortic lymph node involved

Stage IV - metastasis

  • A: Bladder/bowel involvement (adjacent pelvic organs)
  • B: Distant metastasis

Note: The involvement of vascular/lymphatic spaces does not change the staging. The lateral extent of the lesion is no longer considered.

Stage IIIB is the most common stage of presentation.

questions.text: A 70-year-old woman presents with multiple tense bullae associated with pruritus. The lesions began first as erythema and urticaria. Physical examination shows tense bullae on the trunk and thigh region. Direct immunofluorescence done on skin biopsy tissue is as shown below. Which of the following statements is false regarding the diagnosis?

choices.text: Immunofluorescence shows linear deposits of IgG and C3
Antibodies are formed against hemidesmosome antigens
Acantholysis is uniformly seen on histology

questions.solution:
The given clinical picture along with a continuous linear immunofluorescence pattern shown in the image is highly suggestive of bullous pemphigoid.

Bullous pemphigoid is characterized by tense itchy bulla in the flexor areas and trunk that do not rupture easily. In bullous pemphigoid, the antibodies are formed against bullous pemphigoid antigens (BPAGs)- BP 180 and BP 230, which are components of hemidesmosomes. Since these antigens are not present in mucosa, mucosal involvement is not frequently seen as in pemphigus vulgaris. It is present in only 10% of cases.

The separation of bullous pemphigoid from pemphigus is based on the identification of subepidermal, non-acantholytic blisters. These blisters are tense and do not rupture easily and Eosinophils are present just below the basal cell layer. Immunofluorescence shows IgG and C3 deposits in a continuous linear pattern at the dermo-epidermal junction. 

Image: Direct immunofluorescence shows continuous linear pattern at the dermo-epidermal junction

Image (above) shows the fishnet pattern of immunofluorescence in pemphigus vulgaris

Related Pearl: Differences between pemphigus vulgaris and bullous pemphigoid

  Pemphigus vulgaris Bullous pemphigoid
Age 30-40 years 70-80 years
Antibody Anti-desmoglein Anti-hemidesmosome
Location of target antigens Intraepidermal Subepidermal
Immuno-fluorescence Fish-net pattern Linear, shoreline pattern
Bullae Thin and fragile Deep and tense
Mouth involved Yes No
Nikolsky’s sign Positive Negative
Symptom Painful Pruritic
Severity Life threatening Resolves

questions.text: A young lady complains of recurrent rhinitis, nasal discharge and bilateral nasal blockage for two years.  She has a history of allergic rhinitis. On rhinoscopy, multiple ethmoidal polyps with mucosal thickening and impacted secretions are seen in both the nasal cavities. A tissue biopsy is taken and sent for culture, which on microscopic examination shows the following appearance. What is the most probable organism implicated here?
questions.solution:
Recurrent rhinitis, chronic nasal discharge, bilateral nasal blockage, multiple ethmoidal polyps and the microscopic appearance of conical vesicles with conidia over two-thirds of the vesicle is suggestive of allergic fungal rhinosinusitis caused by Aspergillus fumigatus.

Aspergillus spp. can lead to the following types of sinusitis:

  1. Acute invasive sinusitis: It affects immunocompromised patients. They present with fever, nasal or facial discomfort, blocked nose and bloody nasal discharge. Pale, dusky or necrotic tissue will be present within the sinuses.
  2. Chronic aspergillus sinusitis:
    • Fungal ball of sinus: The maxillary sinus, most commonly, is filled with an aspergillus ball. No tissue invasion is present.
    • Chronic invasive sinusitis: There is slow destruction of the ethmoid and sphenoid sinuses with bone destruction and localised spread. Patients present with chronic nasal discharge and blockage, loss of the sense of smell and persistent headache. Involvement of the orbit results in proptosis and blindness.
    • Chronic granulomatous sinusitis: Patients present with facial swelling and unilateral proptosis. Biopsied tissue shows granulomatous (not necrotic) reaction.
  3. Allergic fungal rhinosinusitis: Patients present with chronic sinusitis and nasal polyps. On microscopy, eosinophilia and Charcot-Leyden crystals can be seen.

On microscopic examination of the sinus or polyp tissue, hyaline, septate, acute branching hyphae of Aspergillus spp. can be seen. The various species can be differentiated based on the appearance of the conidiophores. In Aspergillus fumigatus, the vesicle is conical. Phialides are arranged in a single row. Conidia arise from the upper two-thirds of the vesicle and are hyaline.

Option B: Aspergillus flavus has a globular vesicle. Phialides are arranged in one or two rows. Conidia arise from the entire vesicle and are hyaline.

Option C: Aspergillus niger has a globular-shaped vesicle. Phialides are in two rows. Conidia arise from the entire vesicle and are black.

Option D: Penicillium chrysogenum has septate hyphae with branched conidiophores bearing chains of spores (brush or broom appearance).
